Text

VOLUME I

CHAPTER I

[Emma Woodhouse]123-emma , handsome , clever , and rich , with a comfortable home and happy disposition , seemed to unite some of the best blessings of existence ; and had lived nearly twenty - one years in [the world]403-the world with very little to distress or vex [her]123-emma .

[She]123-emma was [the youngest of [the two daughters of [a most affectionate , indulgent father]406-a most affectionate , indulgent father]405-the two daughters of a most affectionate , indulgent father]404-the youngest of the two daughters of a most affectionate , indulgent father ; and had , in consequence of [[her]123-emma sister]407-her sister 's marriage , been [mistress of [[his]406-a most affectionate , indulgent father house]409-his house]408-mistress of his house from a very early period . [[Her]123-emma mother]410-her mother had died too long ago for [her]123-emma to have more than an indistinct remembrance of [her]410-her mother caresses ; and [her]123-emma place had been supplied by [an excellent woman]411-an excellent woman as [governess]412-governess , who had fallen little short of [a mother]413-a mother in affection .

Sixteen years had [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse been in [[Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's family]414-mr. woodhouse 's family , less as [a governess]415-a governess than [a friend]416-a friend , very fond of [both daughters]417-both daughters , but particularly of [Emma]123-emma . Between _ [them]417-both daughters _ it was more the intimacy of [sisters]418-sisters . Even before [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse had ceased to hold the nominal office of [governess]412-governess , the mildness of [her]84-miss woodhouse temper had hardly allowed [her]84-miss woodhouse to impose any restraint ; and the shadow of authority being now long passed away , [they]417-both daughters had been living together as [friend]420-friend and [friend]420-friend very mutually attached , and [Emma]123-emma doing just what [she]123-emma liked ; highly esteeming [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse 's judgment , but directed chiefly by [her]84-miss woodhouse own .

The real evils , indeed , of [Emma]123-emma 's situation were the power of having rather too much [her]123-emma own way , and a disposition to think a little too well of [herself]123-emma ; these were the disadvantages which threatened alloy to [her]123-emma many enjoyments . The danger , however , was at present so unperceived , that [they]422-they did not by any means rank as misfortunes with [her]123-emma .

Sorrow came -- a gentle sorrow -- but not at all in the shape of any disagreeable consciousness.--Miss [Taylor]84-miss woodhouse married . It was [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse 's loss which first brought grief . It was on the wedding - day of [this beloved friend]423-this beloved friend that [Emma]123-emma first sat in mournful thought of any continuance . The wedding over , and [the bride - people]424-the bride - people gone , [[her]123-emma father]425-her father and [herself]123-emma were left to dine together , with no prospect of a third to cheer a long evening . [[Her]123-emma father]425-her father composed [himself]425-her father to sleep after dinner , as usual , and [she]123-emma had then only to sit and think of what [she]123-emma had lost .

The event had every promise of happiness for [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston was [a man of unexceptionable character , easy fortune , suitable age , and pleasant manners]428-a man of unexceptionable character , easy fortune , suitable age , and pleasant manners ; and there was some satisfaction in considering with what self - denying , generous friendship [she]123-emma had always wished and promoted the match ; but it was a black morning 's work for [her]123-emma . The want of [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse would be felt every hour of every day . [She]123-emma recalled [her]123-emma past kindness -- the kindness , the affection of sixteen years -- how [she]123-emma had taught and how [she]123-emma had played with [her]123-emma from five years old -- how [she]123-emma had devoted all [her]123-emma powers to attach and amuse [her]123-emma in health -- and how nursed [her]123-emma through the various illnesses of childhood . A large debt of gratitude was owing here ; but the intercourse of the last seven years , the equal footing and perfect unreserve which had soon followed [Isabella]87-isabella 's marriage , on [their]429-their being left to [each other]430-each other , was yet a dearer , tenderer recollection . [She]123-emma had been [a friend]416-a friend and companion such as [few possessed]432-few possessed : intelligent , well - informed , useful , gentle , knowing all the ways of [the family]433-the family , interested in all its concerns , and peculiarly interested in [herself]123-emma , in every pleasure , every scheme of [hers]123-emma -- one to whom [she]123-emma could speak every thought as it arose , and who had such an affection for [her]123-emma as could never find fault .

How was [she]123-emma to bear the change?--It was true that [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend was going only half a mile from [them]429-their ; but [Emma]123-emma was aware that great must be the difference between [a Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , only half a mile from [them]429-their , and [a Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse in [the house]435-the house ; and with all [her]123-emma advantages , natural and domestic , [she]123-emma was now in great danger of suffering from intellectual solitude . [She]123-emma dearly loved [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , but [he]425-her father was [no companion for [her]123-emma]437-no companion for her . [He]425-her father could not meet [her]123-emma in conversation , rational or playful .

The evil of the actual disparity in [their]429-their ages ( and [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse had not married early ) was much increased by [his]425-her father constitution and habits ; for having been [a valetudinarian]438-a valetudinarian all [his]425-her father life , without activity of mind or body , [he]425-her father was [a much older man in ways than in years]439-a much older man in ways than in years ; and though everywhere beloved for the friendliness of [his]425-her father heart and [his]425-her father amiable temper , [his]425-her father talents could not have recommended [him]425-her father at any time .

[[Her]123-emma sister]407-her sister , though comparatively but little removed by matrimony , being settled in [London]1-london , only sixteen miles off , was much beyond [her]123-emma daily reach ; and many a long October and November evening must be struggled through at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , before Christmas brought the next visit from [Isabella]87-isabella and [[her]87-isabella husband]441-her husband , and [[their]442-their little children]443-their little children , to fill [the house]435-the house , and give [her]123-emma pleasant society again .

[Highbury]3-highbury , [the large and populous village]445-the large and populous village , almost amounting to [a town]446-a town , to which [Hartfield]2-hartfield , in spite of [its]2-hartfield separate lawn , and shrubberies , and name , did really belong , afforded [her]123-emma no equals . [The Woodhouses]447-the woodhouses were first in consequence [there]448-there . [All]449-all looked up to [them]447-the woodhouses . [She]123-emma had many acquaintance in [the place]450-the place , for [[her]123-emma father]425-her father was universally civil , but not one among [them]447-the woodhouses who could be accepted in lieu of [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse for even half a day . It was a melancholy change ; and [Emma]123-emma could not but sigh over it , and wish for impossible things , till [[her]123-emma father]425-her father awoke , and made it necessary to be cheerful . [His]425-her father spirits required support . [He]425-her father was [a nervous man]453-a nervous man , easily depressed ; fond of every body that [he]425-her father was used to , and hating to part with [them]454-them ; hating change of every kind . Matrimony , as the origin of change , was always disagreeable ; and [he]425-her father was by no means yet reconciled to [[his]425-her father own daughter]455-his own daughter 's marrying , nor could ever speak of [her]455-his own daughter but with compassion , though it had been entirely a match of affection , when [he]425-her father was now obliged to part with [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse too ; and from [his]425-her father habits of gentle selfishness , and of being never able to suppose that [other people]456-other people could feel differently from [himself]425-her father , [he]425-her father was very much disposed to think [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse had done as sad a thing for [herself]84-miss woodhouse as for [them]457-them , and would have been a great deal happier if [she]84-miss woodhouse had spent all the rest of [her]84-miss woodhouse life at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . [Emma]123-emma smiled and chatted as cheerfully as [she]123-emma could , to keep [him]425-her father from such thoughts ; but when tea came , it was impossible for [him]425-her father not to say exactly as [he]425-her father had said at dinner ,

“ [Poor Miss Taylor!--I]89-poor miss taylor!--i wish [she]84-miss woodhouse were [here]2707-here again . What a pity it is that [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston ever thought of [her]84-miss woodhouse ! ”[425-her father]

“ [I]425-her father can not agree with [you]425-her father , [papa]2708-papa ; [you]425-her father know [I]425-her father can not . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston is such [a good - humoured , pleasant , excellent man]2709-a good - humoured , pleasant , excellent man , that [he]86-mr. weston thoroughly deserves a good wife;--and [you]425-her father would not have had [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse live with [us]2710-we for ever , and bear all [my]425-her father odd humours , when [she]84-miss woodhouse might have [a house of [her]84-miss woodhouse own]2711-a house of her own ? ”[425-her father]

“ [A house of [her]84-miss woodhouse own!--But]2712-a house of her own!--but where is the advantage of [a house of [her]84-miss woodhouse own]2711-a house of her own ? This is three times as large.--And [you]425-her father have never any odd humours , [[my]425-her father dear]2714-my dear . ”[425-her father]

“ How often [we]2710-we shall be going to see [them]2715-they , and [they]2715-they coming to see us!--We shall be always meeting ! _ [We]2710-we _ must begin ; [we]2710-we must go and pay wedding visit very soon . ”[425-her father]

“ [[My]425-her father dear]2714-my dear , how am [I]425-her father to get so far ? [Randalls]101-randalls is such a distance . [I]425-her father could not walk half so far . ”[425-her father]

“ No , [papa]2708-papa , [nobody]2718-nobody thought of [your]2708-papa walking . [We]2710-we must go in [the carriage]2719-the carriage , to be sure . ”[425-her father]

“ [The carriage]2719-the carriage ! But [James]90-james will not like to put the horses to for such a little way;--and where are the poor horses to be while [we]2710-we are paying [our]2710-we visit ? ”[425-her father]

“ [They]2715-they are to be put into [[Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's stable]2721-mr. weston 's stable , [papa]2708-papa . [You]2708-papa know [we]2710-we have settled all that already . [We]2710-we talked it all over with [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston last night . And as for [James]90-james , [you]2708-papa may be very sure [he]86-mr. weston will always like going to [Randalls]101-randalls , because of [[his]86-mr. weston daughter]2723-his daughter 's being housemaid [there]448-there . [I]425-her father only doubt whether [he]86-mr. weston will ever take [us]2710-we anywhere else . That was [your]2708-papa doing , [papa]2708-papa . [You]2708-papa got [Hannah]91-hannah [that good place]2726-that good place . [Nobody]2718-nobody thought of [Hannah]91-hannah till [you]2708-papa mentioned [her]91-hannah -- [James]90-james is so obliged to [you]2708-papa ! ”[425-her father]

“ [I]425-her father am very glad [I]425-her father did think of [her]91-hannah . It was very lucky , for [I]425-her father would not have had poor [James]90-james think [himself]90-james slighted upon any account ; and [I]425-her father am sure [she]91-hannah will make [a very good servant]2728-a very good servant : [she]91-hannah is [a civil , pretty - spoken girl]2729-a civil , pretty - spoken girl ; [I]425-her father have a great opinion of [her]91-hannah . Whenever [I]425-her father see [her]91-hannah , [she]91-hannah always curtseys and asks [me]425-her father how [I]425-her father do , in a very pretty manner ; and when [you]2708-papa have had [her]91-hannah [here]2707-here to do needlework , [I]425-her father observe [she]91-hannah always turns the lock of the door the right way and never bangs it . [I]425-her father am sure [she]91-hannah will be [an excellent servant]2731-an excellent servant ; and it will be a great comfort to poor [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse to have somebody about [her]91-hannah that [she]91-hannah is used to see . Whenever [James]90-james goes over to see [[his]425-her father daughter]2723-his daughter , [you]2708-papa know , [she]91-hannah will be hearing of [us]2733-us . [He]425-her father will be able to tell [her]91-hannah how [we]2733-us all are . ”[425-her father]

[Emma]123-emma spared no exertions to maintain this happier flow of ideas , and hoped , by the help of backgammon , to get [[her]123-emma father]425-her father tolerably through the evening , and be attacked by no regrets but [her]123-emma own . The backgammon - table was placed ; but [a visitor]459-a visitor immediately afterwards walked in and made it unnecessary .

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , [a sensible man about seven or eight - and - thirty]460-a sensible man about seven or eight - and - thirty , was not only [a very old and intimate friend of [the family]433-the family]461-a very old and intimate friend of the family , but particularly connected with [it]433-the family , as [the elder brother of [[Isabella]87-isabella 's husband]464-isabella 's husband]463-the elder brother of isabella 's husband . [He]92-mr. knightley lived about a mile from [Highbury]3-highbury , was [a frequent visitor]465-a frequent visitor , and always welcome , and at this time more welcome than usual , as coming directly from [their]466-we mutual connexions in [London]1-london . [He]92-mr. knightley had returned to a late dinner , after some days ' absence , and now walked up to [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse to say that all were well in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . It was a happy circumstance , and animated [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse for some time . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley had a cheerful manner , which always did [him]92-mr. knightley good ; and [his]92-mr. knightley many inquiries after “ poor [Isabella]87-isabella ”[87-isabella] and [[her]87-isabella children]467-her children were answered most satisfactorily . When this was over , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse gratefully observed , “ It is very kind of [you]92-mr. knightley , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , to come out at this late hour to call upon [us]466-we . [I]85-mr. woodhouse am afraid [you]92-mr. knightley must have had a shocking walk . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Not at all , [sir]2734-sir . It is a beautiful moonlight night ; and so mild that [I]85-mr. woodhouse must draw back from [your]92-mr. knightley great fire . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ But [you]92-mr. knightley must have found it very damp and dirty . [I]85-mr. woodhouse wish [you]92-mr. knightley may not catch cold . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Dirty , [sir]2734-sir ! Look at [my]85-mr. woodhouse shoes . Not a speck on them . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Well ! that is quite surprising , for [we]466-we have had a vast deal of rain here . It rained dreadfully hard for half an hour while [we]466-we were at breakfast . [I]85-mr. woodhouse wanted [them]2736-them to put off the wedding . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ By the bye -- [I]85-mr. woodhouse have not wished [you]92-mr. knightley joy . Being pretty well aware of what sort of joy [you]92-mr. knightley must both be feeling , [I]85-mr. woodhouse have been in no hurry with [my]85-mr. woodhouse congratulations ; but [I]85-mr. woodhouse hope it all went off tolerably well . How did [you]92-mr. knightley all behave ? [Who cried most]2737-who cried most ? ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Ah ! [poor Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse ! ' Tis a sad business . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [Poor Mr.]2738-poor mr. and [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , if [you]92-mr. knightley please ; but [I]85-mr. woodhouse can not possibly say ' [poor Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse . ' [I]85-mr. woodhouse have a great regard for [you]92-mr. knightley and [Emma]123-emma ; but when it comes to the question of dependence or independence!--At any rate , it must be better to have only one to please than two . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Especially when _ one _ of those two is such [a fanciful , troublesome creature]2739-a fanciful , troublesome creature ! ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma playfully . “ That is what [you]92-mr. knightley have in [your]92-mr. knightley head , [I]123-emma know -- and what [you]92-mr. knightley would certainly say if [[my]123-emma father]2740-my father were not by . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]85-mr. woodhouse believe it is very true , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear , indeed , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , with a sigh . “ [I]85-mr. woodhouse am afraid [I]85-mr. woodhouse am sometimes very fanciful and troublesome . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [[My]92-mr. knightley dearest papa]2742-my dearest papa ! [You]2742-my dearest papa do not think [I]92-mr. knightley could mean _ [you]2742-my dearest papa _ , or suppose [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley to mean _ [you]2742-my dearest papa _ . What a horrible idea ! Oh no ! [I]92-mr. knightley meant only [myself]92-mr. knightley . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley loves to find fault with [me]92-mr. knightley , [you]2742-my dearest papa know -- in a joke -- it is all a joke . [We]2743-we always say what [we]2743-we like to [one another]2744-one another . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , in fact , was [one of [the few people who could see faults in [Emma Woodhouse]123-emma]469-the few people who could see faults in emma woodhouse , and [the only one who ever told [her]123-emma of [them]471-them]470-the only one who ever told her of them]468-one of the few people who could see faults in emma woodhouse , and the only one who ever told her of them : and though this was not particularly agreeable to [Emma]123-emma [herself]123-emma , [she]123-emma knew it would be so much less so to [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , that [she]123-emma would not have [him]425-her father really suspect such a circumstance as [her]123-emma not being thought perfect by every body .

“ [Emma]123-emma knows [I]92-mr. knightley never flatter [her]123-emma , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , “ but [I]92-mr. knightley meant no reflection on any body . [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse has been used to have [two persons to please]2745-two persons to please ; [she]84-miss woodhouse will now have but one . The chances are that [she]84-miss woodhouse must be [a gainer]2746-a gainer . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Well , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , willing to let it pass--“you want to hear about the wedding ; and [I]92-mr. knightley shall be happy to tell [you]2747-you , for [we]2748-we all behaved charmingly . [Every body]2749-every body was punctual , every body in [their]2749-every body best looks : not a tear , and hardly a long face to be seen . Oh no ; [we]2748-we all felt that [we]2748-we were going to be only half a mile apart , and were sure of meeting every day . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [Dear Emma]123-emma bears every thing so well , ”[425-her father] said [[her]123-emma father]425-her father . “ But , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , [she]84-miss woodhouse is really very sorry to lose poor [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse , and [I]425-her father am sure [she]84-miss woodhouse _ will _ miss [her]84-miss woodhouse more than [she]84-miss woodhouse thinks for . ”[425-her father]

[Emma]123-emma turned away [her]123-emma head , divided between tears and smiles . “ It is impossible that [Emma]123-emma should not miss such a companion , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . “ [We]2748-we should not like [her]84-miss woodhouse so well as [we]2748-we do , [sir]2734-sir , if [we]2748-we could suppose it ; but [she]84-miss woodhouse knows how much the marriage is to [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse 's advantage ; [she]84-miss woodhouse knows how very acceptable it must be , at [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse 's time of life , to be settled in [a home of [her]84-miss woodhouse own]2751-a home of her own , and how important to [her]84-miss woodhouse to be secure of a comfortable provision , and therefore can not allow [herself]84-miss woodhouse to feel so much pain as pleasure . [Every friend of [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse]2752-every friend of miss taylor must be glad to have [her]84-miss woodhouse so happily married . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ And [you]2734-sir have forgotten one matter of joy to [me]123-emma , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ and a very considerable one -- that [I]123-emma made the match [myself]123-emma . [I]123-emma made the match , [you]2734-sir know , four years ago ; and to have it take place , and be proved in the right , when [so many people]2753-so many people said [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston would never marry again , may comfort [me]123-emma for any thing . ”[123-emma]

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley shook [his]92-mr. knightley head at [her]123-emma . [[Her]123-emma father]425-her father fondly replied , “ Ah ! [[my]92-mr. knightley dear]2714-my dear , [I]92-mr. knightley wish [you]123-emma would not make matches and foretell things , for whatever [you]123-emma say always comes to pass . Pray do not make any more matches . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]425-her father promise [you]2734-sir to make none for [myself]425-her father , [papa]2708-papa ; but [I]425-her father must , indeed , for [other people]456-other people . It is the greatest amusement in [the world]403-the world ! And after such success , [you]2734-sir know!--Every body said that [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston would never marry again . Oh dear , no ! [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , who had been [a widower]2758-a widower so long , and who seemed so perfectly comfortable without [a wife]2759-a wife , so constantly occupied either in [his]86-mr. weston business in [town]2760-town or among [[his]86-mr. weston friends]2761-his friends here , always acceptable wherever [he]86-mr. weston went , always cheerful -- [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston need not spend a single evening in the year alone if [he]86-mr. weston did not like it . Oh no ! [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston certainly would never marry again . [Some people]2762-some people even talked of a promise to [[his]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife on [her]2763-his wife deathbed , and others of [the son]2764-the son and [the uncle]2765-the uncle not letting [him]86-mr. weston . All manner of solemn nonsense was talked on the subject , but [I]425-her father believed none of it .[425-her father]

“ Ever since the day -- about four years ago -- that [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse and [I]92-mr. knightley met with [him]86-mr. weston in [Broadway Lane]6-broadway lane , when , because it began to drizzle , [he]86-mr. weston darted away with so much gallantry , and borrowed two umbrellas for [us]2766-us from [Farmer Mitchell]94-farmer mitchell 's , [I]92-mr. knightley made up [my]92-mr. knightley mind on the subject . [I]92-mr. knightley planned the match from that hour ; and when such success has blessed [me]92-mr. knightley in this instance , [dear papa]2767-dear papa , [you]2767-dear papa can not think that [I]92-mr. knightley shall leave off match - making . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley do not understand what [you]2767-dear papa mean by ' success , ' ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . “ Success supposes endeavour . [Your]2767-dear papa time has been properly and delicately spent , if [you]2767-dear papa have been endeavouring for the last four years to bring about this marriage . A worthy employment for [a young lady]2768-a young lady 's mind ! But if , which [I]92-mr. knightley rather imagine , [your]2767-dear papa making the match , as [you]2767-dear papa call it , means only [your]2767-dear papa planning it , [your]2767-dear papa saying to [yourself]2767-dear papa one idle day , ' [I]92-mr. knightley think it would be a very good thing for [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse if [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston were to marry [her]84-miss woodhouse , ' and saying it again to [yourself]2767-dear papa every now and then afterwards , why do [you]2767-dear papa talk of success ? Where is [your]2767-dear papa merit ? What are [you]2767-dear papa proud of ? [You]2767-dear papa made a lucky guess ; and _ that _ is all that can be said . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ And have [you]2767-dear papa never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?--I pity you.--I thought [you]2767-dear papa cleverer -- for , depend upon it a lucky guess is never merely luck . There is always some talent in it . And as to [my]92-mr. knightley poor word ' success , ' which [you]2767-dear papa quarrel with , [I]92-mr. knightley do not know that [I]92-mr. knightley am so entirely without any claim to it . [You]2767-dear papa have drawn two pretty pictures ; but [I]92-mr. knightley think there may be a third -- a something between the do - nothing and the do - all . If [I]92-mr. knightley had not promoted [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's visits [here]2707-here , and given many little encouragements , and smoothed many little matters , it might not have come to any thing after all . [I]92-mr. knightley think [you]2767-dear papa must know [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse enough to comprehend that . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [A straightforward , open - hearted man like [Weston]86-mr. weston]2770-a straightforward , open - hearted man like weston , and [a rational , unaffected woman]2771-a rational , unaffected woman like [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse , may be safely left to manage [their]2772-their own concerns . [You]2767-dear papa are more likely to have done harm to [yourself]2767-dear papa , than good to [them]2772-their , by interference . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [Emma]123-emma never thinks of [herself]123-emma , if [she]123-emma can do good to [others]2773-others , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] rejoined [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , understanding but in part . “ But , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear , pray do not make any more matches ; they are silly things , and break up [one]2775-one 's family circle grievously . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Only one more , [papa]2708-papa ; only for [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton . [Poor Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton ! [You]2767-dear papa like [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , papa,--I must look about for [a wife for [him]95-mr. elton]2777-a wife for him . There is nobody in [Highbury]3-highbury who deserves [him]95-mr. elton -- and [he]95-mr. elton has been [here]2707-here a whole year , and has fitted up [[his]95-mr. elton house]409-his house so comfortably , that it would be a shame to have [him]95-mr. elton single any longer -- and [I]92-mr. knightley thought when [he]95-mr. elton was joining [their]2780-their hands to - day , [he]95-mr. elton looked so very much as if [he]95-mr. elton would like to have the same kind office done for [him]95-mr. elton ! [I]92-mr. knightley think very well of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , and this is the only way [I]92-mr. knightley have of doing [him]95-mr. elton a service . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton is [a very pretty young man]2781-a very pretty young man , to be sure , and [a very good young man]2782-a very good young man , and [I]85-mr. woodhouse have a great regard for [him]95-mr. elton . But if [you]2783-you want to shew [him]95-mr. elton any attention , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear , ask [him]95-mr. elton to come and dine with [us]2780-their some day . That will be a much better thing . [I]85-mr. woodhouse dare say [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley will be so kind as to meet [him]95-mr. elton . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ With a great deal of pleasure , [sir]2734-sir , at any time , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , laughing , “ and [I]92-mr. knightley agree with [you]2783-you entirely , that it will be a much better thing . Invite [him]95-mr. elton to dinner , [Emma]123-emma , and help [him]95-mr. elton to the best of the fish and the chicken , but leave [him]95-mr. elton to chuse [[his]95-mr. elton own wife]2786-his own wife . Depend upon it , [a man of six or seven - and - twenty]2787-a man of six or seven - and - twenty can take care of [himself]95-mr. elton . ”[92-mr. knightley]

CHAPTER II

[Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston was [a native of [Highbury]3-highbury]475-a native of highbury , and born of [a respectable family , which for the last two or three generations had been rising into gentility and property]476-a respectable family , which for the last two or three generations had been rising into gentility and property . [He]86-mr. weston had received a good education , but , on succeeding early in life to a small independence , had become indisposed for any of the more homely pursuits in which [[his]86-mr. weston brothers]477-his brothers were engaged , and had satisfied an active , cheerful mind and social temper by entering into the militia of [[his]86-mr. weston county]478-his county , then embodied .

[Captain Weston]96-captain weston was [a general favourite]479-a general favourite ; and when the chances of [his]96-captain weston military life had introduced [him]96-captain weston to [Miss Churchill]97-miss churchill , of [a great Yorkshire family]480-a great yorkshire family , and [Miss Churchill]97-miss churchill fell in love with [him]96-captain weston , [nobody]2718-nobody was surprized , except [[[her]97-miss churchill brother]482-her brother and [[his]482-her brother wife]2763-his wife , who had never seen [him]96-captain weston , and who were full of pride and importance , which the connexion would offend]483-her brother and his wife , who had never seen him , and who were full of pride and importance , which the connexion would offend .

[Miss Churchill]97-miss churchill , however , being of age , and with the full command of [her]97-miss churchill fortune -- though [her]97-miss churchill fortune bore no proportion to [the family]433-the family - estate -- was not to be dissuaded from the marriage , and it took place , to the infinite mortification of [Mr.]486-mr. and [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill , who threw [her]97-miss churchill off with due decorum . It was an unsuitable connexion , and did not produce much happiness . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ought to have found more in it , for [she]88-mrs. weston had [a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper]487-a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper made [him]487-a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper think every thing due to [her]88-mrs. weston in return for the great goodness of being in love with [him]487-a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper ; but though [she]88-mrs. weston had one sort of spirit , [she]88-mrs. weston had not the best . [She]88-mrs. weston had resolution enough to pursue [her]88-mrs. weston own will in spite of [[her]88-mrs. weston brother]482-her brother , but not enough to refrain from unreasonable regrets at [that brother]489-that brother 's unreasonable anger , nor from missing the luxuries of [[her]88-mrs. weston former home]490-her former home . [They]491-they lived beyond [their]491-they income , but still it was nothing in comparison of [Enscombe]7-enscombe : [she]88-mrs. weston did not cease to love [[her]88-mrs. weston husband]441-her husband , but [she]88-mrs. weston wanted at once to be [the wife of [Captain Weston]96-captain weston]493-the wife of captain weston , and [[Miss Churchill]97-miss churchill of [Enscombe]7-enscombe]494-miss churchill of enscombe .

[Captain Weston]96-captain weston , who had been considered , especially by [the Churchills]100-the churchills , as making such an amazing match , was proved to have much the worst of the bargain ; for when [[his]96-captain weston wife]2763-his wife died , after a three years ' marriage , [he]96-captain weston was rather [a poorer man]496-a poorer man than at first , and with [a child]497-a child to maintain . From the expense of [the child]498-the child , however , [he]96-captain weston was soon relieved . [The boy]499-the boy had , with the additional softening claim of a lingering illness of [[his]499-the boy mother]500-his mother 's , been the means of a sort of reconciliation ; and [Mr.]501-mr. and [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill , having [no children of [their]503-their own]502-no children of their own , nor [any other young creature of equal kindred to care for]504-any other young creature of equal kindred to care for , offered to take the whole charge of [the little Frank]505-the little frank soon after [her]98-mrs. churchill decease . Some scruples and some reluctance [the widower - father]506-the widower - father may be supposed to have felt ; but as [they]503-their were overcome by other considerations , [the child]498-the child was given up to the care and the wealth of [the Churchills]100-the churchills , and [he]498-the child had only [his]498-the child own comfort to seek , and [his]498-the child own situation to improve as [he]498-the child could .

A complete change of life became desirable . [He]498-the child quitted [the militia]508-the militia and engaged in trade , having [brothers]509-brothers already established in a good way in [London]1-london , which afforded [him]498-the child a favourable opening . It was a concern which brought just employment enough . [He]498-the child had still [a small house in [Highbury]3-highbury]510-a small house in highbury , where most of [his]498-the child leisure days were spent ; and between useful occupation and the pleasures of society , the next eighteen or twenty years of [his]498-the child life passed cheerfully away . [He]498-the child had , by that time , realised an easy competence -- enough to secure the purchase of [a little estate adjoining [Highbury]3-highbury , which [he]498-the child had always longed for]511-a little estate adjoining highbury , which he had always longed for -- enough to marry [a woman as portionless even as [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse , and to live according to the wishes of [his]498-the child own friendly and social disposition]512-a woman as portionless even as miss taylor , and to live according to the wishes of his own friendly and social disposition .

It was now some time since [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse had begun to influence [his]498-the child schemes ; but as it was not the tyrannic influence of youth on youth , it had not shaken [his]498-the child determination of never settling till [he]498-the child could purchase [Randalls]101-randalls , and the sale of [Randalls]101-randalls was long looked forward to ; but [he]498-the child had gone steadily on , with these objects in view , till they were accomplished . [He]498-the child had made [his]498-the child fortune , bought [[his]498-the child house]409-his house , and obtained [[his]498-the child wife]2763-his wife ; and was beginning a new period of existence , with every probability of greater happiness than in any yet passed through . [He]498-the child had never been [an unhappy man]515-an unhappy man ; [his]498-the child own temper had secured [him]498-the child from that , even in [his]498-the child first marriage ; but [his]498-the child second must shew [him]498-the child how delightful [a well - judging and truly amiable woman]516-a well - judging and truly amiable woman could be , and must give [him]498-the child the pleasantest proof of its being a great deal better to choose than to be chosen , to excite gratitude than to feel it .

[He]498-the child had only [himself]498-the child to please in [his]498-the child choice : [his]498-the child fortune was [his]498-the child own ; for as to [Frank]102-frank churchill , it was more than being tacitly brought up as [[his]102-frank churchill uncle]517-his uncle 's heir , it had become so avowed an adoption as to have [him]102-frank churchill assume the name of [Churchill]102-frank churchill on coming of age . It was most unlikely , therefore , that [he]498-the child should ever want [[his]498-the child father]518-his father 's assistance . [[His]498-the child father]518-his father had no apprehension of it . [The aunt]520-the aunt was [a capricious woman]521-a capricious woman , and governed [[her]520-the aunt husband]441-her husband entirely ; but it was not in [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's nature to imagine that any caprice could be strong enough to affect one so dear , and , as [he]86-mr. weston believed , so deservedly dear . [He]86-mr. weston saw [[his]86-mr. weston son]523-his son every year in [London]1-london , and was proud of [him]523-his son ; and [his]86-mr. weston fond report of [him]523-his son as [a very fine young man]524-a very fine young man had made [Highbury]3-highbury feel a sort of pride in [him]523-his son too . [He]523-his son was looked on as sufficiently belonging to [the place]450-the place to make [his]523-his son merits and prospects a kind of common concern .

[Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill was one of the boasts of [Highbury]3-highbury , and a lively curiosity to see [him]102-frank churchill prevailed , though the compliment was so little returned that [he]102-frank churchill had never been there in [his]102-frank churchill life . [His]102-frank churchill coming to visit [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father had been often talked of but never achieved .

Now , upon [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father 's marriage , it was very generally proposed , as a most proper attention , that the visit should take place . There was not a dissentient voice on the subject , either when [Mrs. Perry]104-mrs. perry drank tea with [Mrs.]528-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , or when [Mrs.]529-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates returned the visit . Now was the time for [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill to come among [them]530-them ; and the hope strengthened when it was understood that [he]102-frank churchill had written to [[his]102-frank churchill new mother]531-his new mother on the occasion . For a few days , every morning visit in [Highbury]3-highbury included some mention of the handsome letter [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston had received . “ [I]88-mrs. weston suppose [you]88-mrs. weston have heard of the handsome letter [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill has written to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ? [I]88-mrs. weston understand it was a very handsome letter , indeed . [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse told [me]88-mrs. weston of it . [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse saw the letter , and [he]85-mr. woodhouse says [he]85-mr. woodhouse never saw such a handsome letter in [his]85-mr. woodhouse life . ”[88-mrs. weston]

It was , indeed , a highly prized letter . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston had , of course , formed a very favourable idea of [the young man]532-the young man ; and such a pleasing attention was an irresistible proof of [his]532-the young man great good sense , and a most welcome addition to every source and every expression of congratulation which [her]88-mrs. weston marriage had already secured . [She]88-mrs. weston felt [herself]88-mrs. weston [a most fortunate woman]533-a most fortunate woman ; and [she]88-mrs. weston had lived long enough to know how fortunate [she]88-mrs. weston might well be thought , where the only regret was for a partial separation from friends whose friendship for [her]88-mrs. weston had never cooled , and who could ill bear to part with [her]88-mrs. weston .

[She]88-mrs. weston knew that at times [she]88-mrs. weston must be missed ; and could not think , without pain , of [Emma]123-emma 's losing a single pleasure , or suffering an hour 's ennui , from the want of [her]123-emma companionableness : but [dear Emma]123-emma was of no feeble character ; [she]123-emma was more equal to [her]123-emma situation than [most girls]534-most girls would have been , and had sense , and energy , and spirits that might be hoped would bear [her]123-emma well and happily through its little difficulties and privations . And then there was such comfort in the very easy distance of [Randalls]101-randalls from [Hartfield]2-hartfield , so convenient for even [solitary female]535-solitary female walking , and in [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's disposition and circumstances , which would make the approaching season no hindrance to [their]536-their spending half the evenings in the week together .

[Her]123-emma situation was altogether the subject of hours of gratitude to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , and of moments only of regret ; and [her]123-emma satisfaction -- [her]123-emma more than satisfaction -- [her]123-emma cheerful enjoyment , was so just and so apparent , that [Emma]123-emma , well as [she]123-emma knew [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , was sometimes taken by surprize at [his]425-her father being still able to pity ' [poor Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse , ' when [they]538-they left [her]123-emma at [Randalls]101-randalls in the centre of every domestic comfort , or saw [her]123-emma go away in the evening attended by [[her]123-emma pleasant husband]539-her pleasant husband to [a carriage]540-a carriage of [her]123-emma own . But never did [she]123-emma go without [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's giving a gentle sigh , and saying , “ Ah , poor [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse ! [She]84-miss woodhouse would be very glad to stay . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

There was no recovering [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse -- nor much likelihood of ceasing to pity [her]84-miss woodhouse ; but a few weeks brought some alleviation to [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse . The compliments of [[his]85-mr. woodhouse neighbours]541-his neighbours were over ; [he]85-mr. woodhouse was no longer teased by being wished joy of so sorrowful an event ; and the wedding - cake , which had been a great distress to [him]85-mr. woodhouse , was all eat up . [His]85-mr. woodhouse own stomach could bear nothing rich , and [he]85-mr. woodhouse could never believe [other people]456-other people to be different from [himself]85-mr. woodhouse . What was unwholesome to [him]85-mr. woodhouse [he]85-mr. woodhouse regarded as unfit for any body ; and [he]85-mr. woodhouse had , therefore , earnestly tried to dissuade [them]541-his neighbours from having any wedding - cake at all , and when that proved vain , as earnestly tried to prevent any body 's eating it . [He]85-mr. woodhouse had been at the pains of consulting [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry , [the apothecary]543-the apothecary , on the subject . [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry was [an intelligent , gentlemanlike man , whose frequent visits were one of the comforts of]544-an intelligent , gentlemanlike man , whose frequent visits were one of the comforts of [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's life ; and upon being applied to , [he]85-mr. woodhouse could not but acknowledge ( though it seemed rather against the bias of inclination ) that wedding - cake might certainly disagree with [many]545-many -- perhaps with [most people]546-most people , unless taken moderately . With such an opinion , in confirmation of [his]85-mr. woodhouse own , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse hoped to influence [every visitor of the newly married pair]547-every visitor of the newly married pair ; but still the cake was eaten ; and there was no rest for [his]85-mr. woodhouse benevolent nerves till it was all gone .

There was a strange rumour in [Highbury]3-highbury of all [the little Perrys]107-the little perrys being seen with a slice of [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's wedding - cake in [their]107-the little perrys hands : but [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse would never believe it .

CHAPTER III

[Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse was fond of society in [his]85-mr. woodhouse own way . [He]85-mr. woodhouse liked very much to have [[his]85-mr. woodhouse friends]2761-his friends come and see [him]85-mr. woodhouse ; and from various united causes , from [his]85-mr. woodhouse long residence at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , and [his]85-mr. woodhouse good nature , from [his]85-mr. woodhouse fortune , [[his]85-mr. woodhouse house]409-his house , and [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter , [he]85-mr. woodhouse could command the visits of [[his]85-mr. woodhouse own little circle]551-his own little circle , in a great measure , as [he]85-mr. woodhouse liked . [He]85-mr. woodhouse had not much intercourse with [any families beyond that circle]552-any families beyond that circle ; [his]85-mr. woodhouse horror of late hours , and large dinner - parties , made [him]85-mr. woodhouse unfit for any acquaintance but such as would visit [him]85-mr. woodhouse on [his]85-mr. woodhouse own terms . Fortunately for [him]85-mr. woodhouse , [Highbury]3-highbury , including Randalls in [the same parish]553-the same parish , and [Donwell Abbey]8-donwell abbey in [the parish]554-the parish adjoining , [the seat of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley]555-the seat of mr. knightley , comprehended many such . Not unfrequently , through [Emma]123-emma 's persuasion , [he]85-mr. woodhouse had some of the chosen and the best to dine with [him]85-mr. woodhouse : but evening parties were what [he]85-mr. woodhouse preferred ; and , unless [he]85-mr. woodhouse fancied [himself]85-mr. woodhouse at any time unequal to company , there was scarcely an evening in the week in which [Emma]123-emma could not make up a card - table for [him]85-mr. woodhouse .

Real , long - standing regard brought [the Westons]108-the westons and [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; and by [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , [a young man living alone without liking it]556-a young man living alone without liking it , the privilege of exchanging any vacant evening of [his]95-mr. elton own blank solitude for the elegancies and society of [[Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's drawing - room]557-mr. woodhouse 's drawing - room , and the smiles of [[his]95-mr. elton lovely daughter]558-his lovely daughter , was in no danger of being thrown away .

After these came a second set ; among [the most come - at - able of whom]559-the most come - at - able of whom were [Mrs.]560-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , and [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard , [three ladies almost always at the service of an invitation from [Hartfield]2-hartfield , and who were fetched and carried [home]562-home]561-three ladies almost always at the service of an invitation from hartfield , and who were fetched and carried home so often , that [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse thought it no hardship for either [James]90-james or the horses . Had it taken place only once a year , it would have been a grievance .

[Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates , [the widow of [a former vicar of [Highbury]3-highbury]564-a former vicar of highbury]563-the widow of a former vicar of highbury , was [a very old lady , almost past every thing but tea and quadrille]565-a very old lady , almost past every thing but tea and quadrille . [She]110-mrs. bates lived with [[her]110-mrs. bates single daughter]566-her single daughter in a very small way , and was considered with all the regard and respect which [a harmless old lady]567-a harmless old lady , under such untoward circumstances , can excite . [[Her]110-mrs. bates daughter]568-her daughter enjoyed a most uncommon degree of popularity for [a woman neither young , handsome , rich , nor married]569-a woman neither young , handsome , rich , nor married . [Miss Bates]105-miss bates stood in the very worst predicament in [the world]403-the world for having much of the public favour ; and [she]105-miss bates had no intellectual superiority to make atonement to [herself]105-miss bates , or frighten those who might hate [her]105-miss bates into outward respect . [She]105-miss bates had never boasted either beauty or cleverness . [Her]105-miss bates youth had passed without distinction , and [her]105-miss bates middle of life was devoted to the care of [a failing mother]571-a failing mother , and the endeavour to make a small income go as far as possible . And yet [she]105-miss bates was [a happy woman]572-a happy woman , and [a woman whom [no one named without good - will]574-no one named without good - will . It was [her]105-miss bates own universal good - will and contented temper which worked such wonders . [She]105-miss bates loved every body , was interested in every body 's happiness , quicksighted to [every body]2749-every body 's merits ; thought [herself]105-miss bates [a most fortunate creature]576-a most fortunate creature , and surrounded with blessings in such [an excellent mother]577-an excellent mother , and so many [good neighbours]578-good neighbours and [friends]579-friends , and [a home that wanted for nothing]580-a home that wanted for nothing]573-a woman whom no one named without good - will . it was her own universal good - will and contented temper which worked such wonders . she loved every body , was interested in every body 's happiness , quicksighted to every body 's merits ; thought herself a most fortunate creature , and surrounded with blessings in such an excellent mother , and so many good neighbours and friends , and a home that wanted for nothing . The simplicity and cheerfulness of [her]105-miss bates nature , [her]105-miss bates contented and grateful spirit , were a recommendation to every body , and a mine of felicity to [herself]105-miss bates . [She]105-miss bates was a great talker upon little matters , which exactly suited [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , full of trivial communications and harmless gossip .

[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard was [the mistress of [a School]582-a school]581-the mistress of a school -- not of [a seminary]583-a seminary , or [an establishment]584-an establishment , or any thing which professed , in long sentences of refined nonsense , to combine liberal acquirements with elegant morality , upon new principles and new systems -- and where [young ladies for enormous pay]585-young ladies for enormous pay might be screwed out of health and into vanity -- but [a real , honest , old - fashioned Boarding - school]586-a real , honest , old - fashioned boarding - school , where a reasonable quantity of accomplishments were sold at a reasonable price , and where [girls]587-girls might be sent to be out of the way , and scramble [themselves]587-girls into a little education , without any danger of coming back prodigies . [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's school]588-mrs. goddard 's school was in high repute -- and very deservedly ; for [Highbury]3-highbury was reckoned [a particularly healthy spot]589-a particularly healthy spot : [she]105-miss bates had [an ample house and garden]590-an ample house and garden , gave [the children]591-the children plenty of wholesome food , let [them]591-the children run about a great deal in the summer , and in winter dressed [their]591-the children chilblains with [her]105-miss bates own hands . It was no wonder that [a train of twenty young couple]592-a train of twenty young couple now walked after [her]105-miss bates to [church]593-church . [She]105-miss bates was [a plain , motherly kind of woman , who had worked hard in [her]105-miss bates youth , and now thought [herself]105-miss bates entitled to the occasional holiday of a tea - visit]594-a plain , motherly kind of woman , who had worked hard in her youth , and now thought herself entitled to the occasional holiday of a tea - visit ; and having formerly owed much to [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's kindness , felt [his]85-mr. woodhouse particular claim on [her]105-miss bates to leave [[her]105-miss bates neat parlour]595-her neat parlour , hung round with fancy - work , whenever [she]105-miss bates could , and win or lose a few sixpences by [his]85-mr. woodhouse fireside .

These were [the ladies whom [Emma]123-emma found [herself]123-emma very frequently able to collect]596-the ladies whom emma found herself very frequently able to collect ; and happy was [she]123-emma , for [[her]123-emma father]425-her father 's sake , in the power ; though , as far as [she]123-emma was [herself]123-emma concerned , it was no remedy for the absence of [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . [She]123-emma was delighted to see [[her]123-emma father]425-her father look comfortable , and very much pleased with [herself]123-emma for contriving things so well ; but the quiet prosings of [three such women]599-three such women made [her]123-emma feel that every evening so spent was indeed one of the long evenings [she]123-emma had fearfully anticipated .

As [she]123-emma sat one morning , looking forward to exactly such a close of the present day , a note was brought from [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard , requesting , in most respectful terms , to be allowed to bring [Miss Smith]111-harriet with [her]123-emma ; a most welcome request : for [Miss Smith]111-harriet was [a girl of seventeen]600-a girl of seventeen , whom [Emma]123-emma knew very well by sight , and had long felt an interest in , on account of [her]111-harriet beauty . A very gracious invitation was returned , and the evening no longer dreaded by [the fair mistress of [the mansion]602-the mansion]601-the fair mistress of the mansion .

[Harriet Smith]111-harriet was [the natural daughter of [somebody]604-somebody]603-the natural daughter of somebody . [Somebody]604-somebody had placed [her]111-harriet , several years back , at [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's school]588-mrs. goddard 's school , and [somebody]604-somebody had lately raised [her]111-harriet from the condition of [scholar]608-scholar to that of [parlour - boarder]609-parlour - boarder . This was all that was generally known of [her]111-harriet history . [She]111-harriet had [no visible friends]610-no visible friends but what had been acquired at [Highbury]3-highbury , and was now just returned from a long visit in [the country]611-the country to [some young ladies who had been at [school]613-school [there]448-there with [her]111-harriet]612-some young ladies who had been at school there with her .

[She]111-harriet was [a very pretty girl]615-a very pretty girl , and [her]111-harriet beauty happened to be of a sort which [Emma]123-emma particularly admired . [She]111-harriet was short , plump , and fair , with a fine bloom , blue eyes , light hair , regular features , and a look of great sweetness , and , before the end of the evening , [Emma]123-emma was as much pleased with [her]123-emma manners as [[her]123-emma person]616-her person , and quite determined to continue the acquaintance .

[She]123-emma was not struck by any thing remarkably clever in [Miss Smith]111-harriet 's conversation , but [she]123-emma found [her]111-harriet altogether very engaging -- not inconveniently shy , not unwilling to talk -- and yet so far from pushing , [shewing]617-shewing so proper and becoming a deference , seeming so pleasantly grateful for being admitted to [Hartfield]2-hartfield , and so artlessly impressed by the appearance of every thing in so superior a style to what [she]111-harriet had been used to , that [she]111-harriet must have good sense , and deserve encouragement . Encouragement should be given . Those soft blue eyes , and all those natural graces , should not be wasted on [the inferior society of [Highbury]3-highbury and [its]3-highbury connexions]618-the inferior society of highbury and its connexions . The acquaintance [she]111-harriet had already formed were unworthy of [her]111-harriet . [The friends from whom [she]111-harriet had just parted , though [very good sort of people]620-very good sort of people]619-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people , must be doing [her]111-harriet harm . [They]619-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people were [a family of the name of Martin]621-a family of the name of martin , whom [Emma]123-emma well knew by character , as renting [a large farm of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley]622-a large farm of mr. knightley , and residing in [the parish of Donwell]623-the parish of donwell -- very creditably , [she]123-emma believed -- [she]123-emma knew [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley thought highly of [them]619-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people -- but [they]619-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people must be coarse and unpolished , and very unfit to be the intimates of [a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and elegance to be quite perfect]624-a girl who wanted only a little more knowledge and elegance to be quite perfect . _ [She]111-harriet _ would notice [her]111-harriet ; [she]111-harriet would improve [her]111-harriet ; [she]111-harriet would detach [her]111-harriet from [her]111-harriet bad acquaintance , and introduce [her]111-harriet into good society ; [she]111-harriet would form [her]111-harriet opinions and [her]111-harriet manners . It would be an interesting , and certainly a very kind undertaking ; highly becoming [her]111-harriet own situation in life , [her]111-harriet leisure , and powers .

[She]111-harriet was so busy in admiring those soft blue eyes , in talking and listening , and forming all these schemes in the in - betweens , that the evening flew away at a very unusual rate ; and the supper - table , which always closed such parties , and for which [she]111-harriet had been used to sit and watch the due time , was all set out and ready , and moved forwards to the fire , before [she]111-harriet was aware . With an alacrity beyond the common impulse of a spirit which yet was never indifferent to the credit of doing every thing well and attentively , with the real good - will of a mind delighted with its own ideas , did [she]111-harriet then do all the honours of the meal , and help and recommend the minced chicken and scalloped oysters , with an urgency which [she]111-harriet knew would be acceptable to the early hours and civil scruples of [[their]619-the friends from whom she had just parted , though very good sort of people guests]625-their guests .

Upon such occasions [poor Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's feelings were in sad warfare . [He]85-mr. woodhouse loved to have the cloth laid , because it had been the fashion of [his]85-mr. woodhouse youth , but [his]85-mr. woodhouse conviction of suppers being very unwholesome made [him]85-mr. woodhouse rather sorry to see any thing put on it ; and while [his]85-mr. woodhouse hospitality would have welcomed [[his]85-mr. woodhouse visitors]626-his visitors to every thing , [his]85-mr. woodhouse care for [their]626-his visitors health made [him]85-mr. woodhouse grieve that [they]626-his visitors would eat .

Such another small basin of thin gruel as [his]85-mr. woodhouse own was all that [he]85-mr. woodhouse could , with thorough self - approbation , recommend ; though [he]85-mr. woodhouse might constrain [himself]85-mr. woodhouse , while [the ladies]627-the ladies were comfortably clearing the nicer things , to say :

“ [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates , let [me]627-the ladies propose [your]110-mrs. bates venturing on one of these eggs . An egg boiled very soft is not unwholesome . [Serle]112-serle understands boiling an egg better than any body . [I]627-the ladies would not recommend an egg boiled by any body else ; but [you]110-mrs. bates need not be afraid , they are very small , [you]110-mrs. bates see -- one of [our]2788-our small eggs will not hurt [you]110-mrs. bates . [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , let [Emma]123-emma help [you]110-mrs. bates to a _ little _ bit of tart -- a _ very _ little bit . [Ours]2788-our are all apple - tarts . [You]110-mrs. bates need not be afraid of unwholesome preserves here . [I]627-the ladies do not advise the custard . [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard , what say [you]110-mrs. bates to _ half _ a glass of wine ? A _ small _ half - glass , put into a tumbler of water ? [I]627-the ladies do not think it could disagree with [you]110-mrs. bates . ”[627-the ladies]

[Emma]123-emma allowed [[her]123-emma father]425-her father to talk -- but supplied [[her]123-emma visitors]629-her visitors in a much more satisfactory style , and on the present evening had particular pleasure in sending [them]629-her visitors away happy . The happiness of [Miss Smith]111-harriet was quite equal to [her]111-harriet intentions . [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse was so great [a personage in [Highbury]3-highbury]630-a personage in highbury , that the prospect of the introduction had given as much panic as pleasure ; but [the humble , grateful little girl]631-the humble , grateful little girl went off with highly gratified feelings , delighted with the affability with which [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse had treated [her]631-the humble , grateful little girl all the evening , and actually shaken hands with [her]631-the humble , grateful little girl at last !

CHAPTER IV

[Harriet Smith]111-harriet 's intimacy at [Hartfield]2-hartfield was soon a settled thing . Quick and decided in [her]123-emma ways , [Emma]123-emma lost no time in inviting , encouraging , and telling [her]111-harriet to come very often ; and as [their]632-their acquaintance increased , so did [their]632-their satisfaction in [each other]430-each other . As [a walking companion]634-a walking companion , [Emma]123-emma had very early foreseen how useful [she]123-emma might find [her]111-harriet . In that respect [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's loss had been important . [[Her]123-emma father]425-her father never went beyond the shrubbery , where two divisions of the ground sufficed [him]425-her father for [his]425-her father long walk , or [his]425-her father short , as the year varied ; and since [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's marriage [her]123-emma exercise had been too much confined . [She]123-emma had ventured once alone to [Randalls]101-randalls , but it was not pleasant ; and [a Harriet Smith]111-harriet , therefore , one whom [she]123-emma could summon at any time to a walk , would be a valuable addition to [her]123-emma privileges . But in every respect , as [she]123-emma saw more of [her]111-harriet , [she]123-emma approved [her]111-harriet , and was confirmed in all [her]111-harriet kind designs .

[Harriet]111-harriet certainly was not clever , but [she]111-harriet had a sweet , docile , grateful disposition , was totally free from conceit , and only desiring to be guided by any one [she]111-harriet looked up to . [Her]111-harriet early attachment to [herself]111-harriet was very amiable ; and [her]111-harriet inclination for good company , and power of appreciating what was elegant and clever , [shewed]636-shewed that there was no want of taste , though strength of understanding must not be expected . Altogether [she]123-emma was quite convinced of [Harriet Smith]111-harriet 's being exactly [the young friend [she]123-emma wanted]637-the young friend she wanted -- exactly the something which [[her]123-emma home]638-her home required . [Such a friend as [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston]639-such a friend as mrs. weston was out of the question . Two such could never be granted . Two such [she]123-emma did not want . It was quite a different sort of thing , a sentiment distinct and independent . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was the object of a regard which had its basis in gratitude and esteem . [Harriet]111-harriet would be loved as one to whom [she]111-harriet could be useful . For [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston there was nothing to be done ; for [Harriet]111-harriet every thing .

[Her]111-harriet first attempts at usefulness were in an endeavour to find out who were [the parents]640-the parents , but [Harriet]111-harriet could not tell . [She]111-harriet was ready to tell every thing in [her]111-harriet power , but on this subject questions were vain . [Emma]123-emma was obliged to fancy what [she]123-emma liked -- but [she]123-emma could never believe that in the same situation _ [she]123-emma _ should not have discovered the truth . [Harriet]111-harriet had no penetration . [She]111-harriet had been satisfied to hear and believe just what [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard chose to tell [her]111-harriet ; and looked no farther .

[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard , and [the teachers]641-the teachers , and [the girls]642-the girls and the affairs of [the school]643-the school in general , formed naturally a great part of the conversation -- and but for [her]111-harriet acquaintance with [the Martins of [Abbey - Mill Farm]10-abbey - mill farm]644-the martins of abbey - mill farm , it must have been the whole . But [the Martins]113-the martins occupied [her]111-harriet thoughts a good deal ; [she]111-harriet had spent two very happy months with [them]113-the martins , and now loved to talk of the pleasures of [her]111-harriet visit , and describe the many comforts and wonders of [the place]450-the place . [Emma]123-emma encouraged [her]111-harriet talkativeness -- amused by such a picture of [another set of beings]646-another set of beings , and enjoying the youthful simplicity which could speak with so much exultation of [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin 's having “ _ [two _ parlours]2789-two _ parlours , [two very good parlours]2790-two very good parlours , indeed ; one of them quite as large as [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's drawing - room]2791-mrs. goddard 's drawing - room ; and of [her]114-mrs. martin having [an upper maid who had lived five - and - twenty years with [her]114-mrs. martin]2792-an upper maid who had lived five - and - twenty years with her ; and of [their]113-the martins having eight cows , two of [them]2793-them [Alderneys]115-alderneys , and one a little Welch cow , a very pretty little Welch cow indeed ; and of [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin 's saying as [she]114-mrs. martin was so fond of it , it should be called _ [her]114-mrs. martin _ cow ; and of [their]113-the martins having [a very handsome summer - house in [their]113-the martins garden]2794-a very handsome summer - house in their garden , where some day next year [they]113-the martins were all to drink [tea:--a very handsome summer - house]2795-tea:--a very handsome summer - house , large enough to hold [a dozen people]2796-a dozen people . ”[114-mrs. martin]

For some time [she]114-mrs. martin was amused , without thinking beyond the immediate cause ; but as [she]114-mrs. martin came to understand [the family]433-the family better , other feelings arose . [She]114-mrs. martin had taken up a wrong idea , fancying it was [a mother]413-a mother and [daughter]649-daughter , [a son]650-a son and [[son]651-son 's wife]652-son 's wife , who all lived together ; but when it appeared that [the Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin , who bore a part in the narrative , and was always mentioned with approbation for [his]116-mr. martin great good - nature in doing something or other , was [a single man]653-a single man ; that there was [no young [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin]654-no young mrs. martin , [no wife in the case]655-no wife in the case ; [she]114-mrs. martin did suspect danger to [[her]114-mrs. martin poor little friend]656-her poor little friend from all this hospitality and kindness , and that , if [she]114-mrs. martin were not taken care of , [she]114-mrs. martin might be required to sink [herself]114-mrs. martin forever .

With this inspiriting notion , [her]114-mrs. martin questions increased in number and meaning ; and [she]114-mrs. martin particularly led [Harriet]111-harriet to talk more of [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin , and there was evidently no dislike to it . [Harriet]111-harriet was very ready to speak of the share [he]116-mr. martin had had in [their]657-their moonlight walks and merry evening games ; and dwelt a good deal upon [his]116-mr. martin being so very good - humoured and obliging . [He]116-mr. martin had gone three miles round one day in order to bring [her]111-harriet some walnuts , because [she]111-harriet had said how fond [she]111-harriet was of them , and in every thing else [he]116-mr. martin was so very obliging . [He]116-mr. martin had [[his]116-mr. martin shepherd 's son]658-his shepherd 's son into [the parlour]659-the parlour one night on purpose to sing to [her]111-harriet . [She]111-harriet was very fond of singing . [He]116-mr. martin could sing a little [himself]116-mr. martin . [She]111-harriet believed [he]116-mr. martin was very clever , and understood every thing . [He]116-mr. martin had [a very fine flock]660-a very fine flock , and , while [she]111-harriet was with [them]660-a very fine flock , [he]116-mr. martin had been bid more for [his]116-mr. martin wool than any body in [the country]611-the country . [She]111-harriet believed [every body]2749-every body spoke well of [him]116-mr. martin . [[His]116-mr. martin mother]500-his mother and [sisters]418-sisters were very fond of [him]116-mr. martin . [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin had told [her]111-harriet one day ( and there was a blush as [she]114-mrs. martin said it , ) that it was impossible for [any body]665-any body to be [a better son]666-a better son , and therefore [she]111-harriet was sure , whenever [he]116-mr. martin married , [he]116-mr. martin would make [a good husband]667-a good husband . Not that [she]111-harriet _ wanted _ [him]116-mr. martin to marry . [She]111-harriet was in no hurry at all .

“ Well done , [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin ! ”[123-emma] thought [Emma]123-emma . “ [You]114-mrs. martin know what [you]114-mrs. martin are about . ”[123-emma]

“ And when [she]114-mrs. martin had come away , [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin was so very kind as to send [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard a beautiful goose -- the finest goose [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard had ever seen . [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard had dressed it on a Sunday , and asked [all the three teachers]2797-all the three teachers , [Miss Nash]117-miss nash , and [Miss Prince]118-miss prince , and [Miss Richardson]119-miss richardson , to sup with [her]114-mrs. martin . ”[111-harriet]

“ [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin , [I]123-emma suppose , is not [a man of information beyond the line of [his]116-mr. martin own business]2798-a man of information beyond the line of his own business ? [He]116-mr. martin does not read ? ”[123-emma]

“ Oh yes!--that is , no -- [I]111-harriet do not know -- but [I]111-harriet believe [he]116-mr. martin has read a good deal -- but not what [you]114-mrs. martin would think any thing of . [He]116-mr. martin reads the Agricultural Reports , and some other books that lay in one of the window seats -- but [he]116-mr. martin reads all _ them _ to [himself]116-mr. martin . But sometimes of an evening , before [we]2799-we went to cards , [he]116-mr. martin would read something aloud out of the Elegant Extracts , very entertaining . And [I]111-harriet know [he]116-mr. martin has read [the Vicar of [Wakefield]11-wakefield]2800-the vicar of wakefield . [He]116-mr. martin never read the Romance of [the Forest]12-the forest , nor [The Children of [the Abbey]2802-the abbey]2801-the children of the abbey . [He]116-mr. martin had never heard of such books before [I]111-harriet mentioned them , but [he]116-mr. martin is determined to get them now as soon as ever [he]116-mr. martin can . ”[111-harriet]

The next question was--

“ What [sort of looking man]2803-sort of looking man is [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin ? ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! not handsome -- not at all handsome . [I]123-emma thought [him]116-mr. martin very plain at first , but [I]123-emma do not think [him]116-mr. martin so plain now . [One]2775-one does not , [you]111-harriet know , after a time . But did [you]111-harriet never see [him]116-mr. martin ? [He]116-mr. martin is in [Highbury]3-highbury every now and then , and [he]116-mr. martin is sure to ride through every week in [his]116-mr. martin way to [Kingston]13-kingston . [He]116-mr. martin has passed [you]111-harriet very often . ”[123-emma]

“ That may be , and [I]123-emma may have seen [him]116-mr. martin fifty times , but without having any idea of [his]116-mr. martin name . [A young farmer , whether on horseback or on foot]2805-a young farmer , whether on horseback or on foot , is the very last sort of person to raise [my]123-emma curiosity . The yeomanry are precisely the order of people with whom [I]123-emma feel [I]123-emma can have nothing to do . A degree or two lower , and a creditable appearance might interest [me]123-emma ; [I]123-emma might hope to be useful to [[their]2805-a young farmer , whether on horseback or on foot families]2806-their families in some way or other . But [a farmer]2807-a farmer can need none of [my]123-emma help , and is , therefore , in one sense , as much above [my]123-emma notice as in every other [he]2807-a farmer is below it . ”[123-emma]

“ To be sure . Oh yes ! It is not likely [you]111-harriet should ever have observed [him]116-mr. martin ; but [he]116-mr. martin knows [you]111-harriet very well indeed -- [I]123-emma mean by sight . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]123-emma have no doubt of [his]116-mr. martin being [a very respectable young man]2808-a very respectable young man . [I]123-emma know , indeed , that [he]116-mr. martin is so , and , as such , wish [him]116-mr. martin well . What do [you]111-harriet imagine [his]116-mr. martin age to be ? ”[123-emma]

“ [He]116-mr. martin was four - and - twenty the 8th of last June , and [my]123-emma birthday is the 23rd just a fortnight and a day 's difference -- which is very odd . ”[123-emma]

“ Only four - and - twenty . That is too young to settle . [[His]116-mr. martin mother]500-his mother is perfectly right not to be in a hurry . [They]2810-they seem very comfortable as [they]2810-they are , and if [she]500-his mother were to take any pains to marry [him]116-mr. martin , [she]500-his mother would probably repent it . Six years hence , if [he]116-mr. martin could meet with [a good sort of young woman in the same rank as [his]116-mr. martin own]2811-a good sort of young woman in the same rank as his own , with a little money , it might be very desirable . ”[123-emma]

“ Six years hence ! [Dear Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , [he]116-mr. martin would be thirty years old ! ”[123-emma]

“ Well , and that is as early as [most men]2812-most men can afford to marry , who are [not born to an independence]2813-not born to an independence . [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin , [I]123-emma imagine , has [his]116-mr. martin fortune entirely to make -- cannot be at all beforehand with [the world]403-the world . Whatever money [he]116-mr. martin might come into when [[his]116-mr. martin father]518-his father died , whatever [his]116-mr. martin share of the family property , it is , [I]123-emma dare say , all afloat , all employed in [his]116-mr. martin stock , and so forth ; and though , with diligence and good luck , [he]116-mr. martin may be rich in time , it is next to impossible that [he]116-mr. martin should have realised any thing yet . ”[123-emma]

“ To be sure , so it is . But [they]2816-they live very comfortably . [They]2816-they have [no indoors man]2817-no indoors man , else [they]2816-they do not want for any thing ; and [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin talks of taking [a boy]2818-a boy another year . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]123-emma wish [you]123-emma may not get into a scrape , [Harriet]111-harriet , whenever [he]116-mr. martin does marry;--I mean , as to being acquainted with [[his]116-mr. martin wife]2763-his wife -- for though [[his]116-mr. martin sisters]2820-his sisters , from a superior education , are not to be altogether objected to , it does not follow that [he]116-mr. martin might marry any body at all fit for [you]123-emma to notice . The misfortune of [your]123-emma birth ought to make [you]123-emma particularly careful as to [[your]123-emma associates]2821-your associates . There can be no doubt of [your]123-emma being [[a gentleman]2822-a gentleman 's daughter]2823-a gentleman 's daughter , and [you]123-emma must support [your]123-emma claim to [that station]2824-that station by every thing within [your]123-emma own power , or there will be plenty of people who would take pleasure in degrading [you]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

“ Yes , to be sure , [I]123-emma suppose there are . But while [I]123-emma visit at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , and [you]123-emma are so kind to [me]123-emma , [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , [I]123-emma am not afraid of what [any body]665-any body can do . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]123-emma understand the force of influence pretty well , [Harriet]111-harriet ; but [I]123-emma would have [you]123-emma so firmly established in good society , as to be independent even of [Hartfield]2-hartfield and [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse . [I]123-emma want to see [you]123-emma permanently well connected , and to that end it will be advisable to have as [few odd acquaintance]2826-few odd acquaintance as may be ; and , therefore , [I]123-emma say that if [you]123-emma should still be in [this country]2827-this country when [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin marries , [I]123-emma wish [you]123-emma may not be drawn in by [your]123-emma intimacy with [the sisters]2828-the sisters , to be acquainted with [the wife]2829-the wife , who will probably be [[some mere farmer]2830-some mere farmer 's daughter]2831-some mere farmer 's daughter , without education . ”[123-emma]

“ To be sure . Yes . Not that [I]123-emma think [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin would ever marry any body but what had had some education -- and been very well brought up . However , [I]123-emma do not mean to set up [my]123-emma opinion against [yours]123-emma -- and [I]123-emma am sure [I]123-emma shall not wish for the acquaintance of [[his]116-mr. martin wife]2763-his wife . [I]123-emma shall always have a great regard for [the Miss Martins]113-the martins , especially [Elizabeth]120-elizabeth , and should be very sorry to give [them]113-the martins up , for [they]113-the martins are quite as well educated as [me]123-emma . But if [he]116-mr. martin marries [a very ignorant , vulgar woman]2833-a very ignorant , vulgar woman , certainly [I]123-emma had better not visit [her]2833-a very ignorant , vulgar woman , if [I]123-emma can help it . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma watched [her]123-emma through the fluctuations of this speech , and saw no alarming symptoms of love . [The young man]532-the young man had been [the first admirer]669-the first admirer , but [she]123-emma trusted there was no other hold , and that there would be no serious difficulty , on [Harriet]111-harriet 's side , to oppose any friendly arrangement of [her]123-emma own .

[They]670-they met [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin the very next day , as [they]670-they were walking on [the Donwell road]671-the donwell road . [He]116-mr. martin was on foot , and after looking very respectfully at [her]123-emma , looked with most unfeigned satisfaction at [[her]123-emma companion]672-her companion . [Emma]123-emma was not sorry to have such an opportunity of survey ; and walking a few yards forward , while [they]670-they talked together , soon made [her]123-emma quick eye sufficiently acquainted with [Mr. Robert Martin]116-mr. martin .
