“ [I]2714-my dear do not know , [[my]2714-my dear dear]2714-my dear -- but it is so long since [she]87-isabella was here!--not since last Easter , and then only for a few days.--Mr . [John Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's being [a lawyer]3198-a lawyer is very inconvenient.--Poor [Isabella!--she]148-isabella!--she is sadly taken away from [us]3199-us all!--and how sorry [she]87-isabella will be when [she]87-isabella comes , not to see [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse [here]2707-here ! ”[2714-my dear]

“ [She]87-isabella will not be surprized , [papa]2708-papa , at least . ”[2714-my dear]

“ [I]2714-my dear do not know , [[my]2714-my dear dear]2714-my dear . [I]2714-my dear am sure [I]2714-my dear was very much surprized when [I]2714-my dear first heard [she]87-isabella was going to be married . ”[2714-my dear]

“ [We]3199-us must ask [Mr.]3203-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston to dine with [us]3199-us , while [Isabella]87-isabella is [here]2707-here . ”[2714-my dear]

“ Yes , [[my]2714-my dear dear]2714-my dear , if there is [time.--But--(in a very depressed tone)--she]3206-time.--but--(in a very depressed tone)--she is coming for only one week . There will not be time for any thing . ”[2714-my dear]

“ It is unfortunate that [they]3207-they can not stay longer -- but it seems a case of necessity . [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley must be in [town]2760-town again on the 28th , and [we]3199-us ought to be thankful , [papa]2708-papa , that [we]3199-us are to have the whole of the time [they]3207-they can give to [the country]611-the country , that two or three days are not to be taken out for [the Abbey]8-donwell abbey . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley promises to give up [his]92-mr. knightley claim this Christmas -- though [you]2708-papa know it is longer since [they]3207-they were with [him]92-mr. knightley , than with [us]3199-us . ”[2714-my dear]

“ It would be very hard , indeed , [[my]2714-my dear dear]2714-my dear , if [poor Isabella]87-isabella were to be anywhere but at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . ”[2714-my dear]

[Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse could never allow for [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's claims on [[his]92-mr. knightley brother]824-his brother , or any body 's claims on [Isabella]87-isabella , except [his]92-mr. knightley own . [He]85-mr. woodhouse sat musing a little while , and then said ,

“ But [I]85-mr. woodhouse do not see why poor [Isabella]87-isabella should be obliged to go back so soon , though [he]92-mr. knightley does . [I]85-mr. woodhouse think , [Emma]123-emma , [I]85-mr. woodhouse shall try and persuade [her]87-isabella to stay longer with [us]3199-us . [She]87-isabella and [the children]591-the children might stay very well . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Ah ! [papa]2708-papa -- that is what [you]2708-papa never have been able to accomplish , and [I]85-mr. woodhouse do not think [you]2708-papa ever will . [Isabella]87-isabella can not bear to stay behind [[her]87-isabella husband]441-her husband . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

This was too true for contradiction . Unwelcome as it was , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse could only give a submissive sigh ; and as [Emma]123-emma saw [his]85-mr. woodhouse spirits affected by the idea of [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter 's attachment to [[her]2723-his daughter husband]441-her husband , [she]123-emma immediately led to such a branch of the subject as must raise [them]827-them .

“ [Harriet]111-harriet must give [us]3199-us as much of [her]111-harriet company as [she]111-harriet can while [[my]123-emma brother]2939-my brother and [sister]3216-sister are [here]2707-here . [I]123-emma am sure [she]111-harriet will be pleased with [the children]591-the children . [We]3199-us are very proud of [the children]591-the children , are not [we]3199-us , [papa]2708-papa ? [I]123-emma wonder which [she]111-harriet will think the handsomest , [Henry]125-henry or [John]92-mr. knightley ? ”[123-emma]

“ Aye , [I]123-emma wonder which [she]111-harriet will . [Poor little dears]3221-poor little dears , how glad [they]3221-poor little dears will be to come . [They]3221-poor little dears are very fond of being at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , [Harriet]111-harriet . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]123-emma dare say [they]3221-poor little dears are , [sir]2734-sir . [I]123-emma am sure [I]123-emma do not know who is not . ”[123-emma]

“ [Henry]125-henry is [a fine boy]3223-a fine boy , but [John]92-mr. knightley is very like [[his]92-mr. knightley mama]3224-his mama . [Henry]125-henry is [the eldest]3225-the eldest , [he]125-henry was named after [me]123-emma , not after [[his]125-henry father]518-his father . [John]92-mr. knightley , [the second]3227-the second , is named after [[his]92-mr. knightley father]518-his father . [Some people]2762-some people are surprized , [I]123-emma believe , that [the eldest]3225-the eldest was not , but [Isabella]87-isabella would have [him]3225-the eldest called [Henry]125-henry , which [I]123-emma thought very pretty of [her]87-isabella . And [he]3225-the eldest is [a very clever boy]3231-a very clever boy , indeed . [They]2762-some people are all remarkably clever ; and [they]2762-some people have so many pretty ways . [They]2762-some people will come and stand by [my]123-emma chair , and say , ' [Grandpapa]149-grandpapa , can [you]149-grandpapa give [me]123-emma a bit of string ? ' and once [Henry]125-henry asked [me]123-emma for a knife , but [I]123-emma told [him]125-henry knives were only made for [grandpapas]3232-grandpapas . [I]123-emma think [[their]2762-some people father]3233-their father is too rough with them very often . ”[123-emma]

“ [He]125-henry appears rough to [you]149-grandpapa , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ because [you]149-grandpapa are so very gentle [yourself]149-grandpapa ; but if [you]149-grandpapa could compare [him]125-henry with [other papas]3234-other papas , [you]149-grandpapa would not think [him]125-henry rough . [He]125-henry wishes [[his]125-henry boys]3235-his boys to be active and hardy ; and if [they]3235-his boys misbehave , can give [them]3235-his boys a sharp word now and then ; but [he]125-henry is [an affectionate father]3236-an affectionate father -- certainly [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley is [an affectionate father]3236-an affectionate father . [The children]591-the children are all fond of [him]125-henry . ”[123-emma]

“ And then [[their]591-the children uncle]3239-their uncle comes in , and tosses [them]591-the children up to the ceiling in a very frightful way ! ”[123-emma]

“ But [they]591-the children like it , [papa]2708-papa ; there is nothing [they]591-the children like so much . It is such enjoyment to [them]591-the children , that if [[their]591-the children uncle]3239-their uncle did not lay down the rule of [their]591-the children taking turns , whichever began would never give way to the other . ”[123-emma]

“ Well , [I]123-emma can not understand it . ”[123-emma]

“ That is the case with [us]3242-us all , [papa]2708-papa . [One half of [the world]403-the world]3244-one half of the world can not understand the pleasures of the other . ”[123-emma]

Later in the morning , and just as [the girls]642-the girls were going to separate in preparation for the regular four o'clock dinner , [the hero of this inimitable charade]829-the hero of this inimitable charade walked in again . [Harriet]111-harriet turned away ; but [Emma]123-emma could receive [him]829-the hero of this inimitable charade with the usual smile , and [her]123-emma quick eye soon discerned in [his]829-the hero of this inimitable charade the consciousness of having made a push -- of having thrown a die ; and [she]123-emma imagined [he]829-the hero of this inimitable charade was come to see how it might turn up . [His]829-the hero of this inimitable charade ostensible reason , however , was to ask whether [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's party could be made up in the evening without [him]829-the hero of this inimitable charade , or whether [he]829-the hero of this inimitable charade should be in the smallest degree necessary at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . If [he]829-the hero of this inimitable charade were , every thing else must give way ; but otherwise [[his]829-the hero of this inimitable charade friend]830-his friend [Cole]145-mr. cole had been saying so much about [his]829-the hero of this inimitable charade dining with [him]829-the hero of this inimitable charade -- had made such a point of it , that [he]829-the hero of this inimitable charade had promised [him]829-the hero of this inimitable charade conditionally to come .

[Emma]123-emma thanked [him]829-the hero of this inimitable charade , but could not allow of [his]829-the hero of this inimitable charade disappointing [[his]829-the hero of this inimitable charade friend]830-his friend on [their]832-their account ; [[her]123-emma father]425-her father was sure of [his]425-her father rubber . [He]829-the hero of this inimitable charade re - urged -- [she]123-emma re - declined ; and [he]829-the hero of this inimitable charade seemed then about to make [his]829-the hero of this inimitable charade bow , when taking the paper from the table , [she]123-emma returned it--

“ Oh ! here is the charade [you]123-emma were so obliging as to leave with [us]832-their ; thank [you]123-emma for the sight of it . [We]832-their admired it so much , that [I]123-emma have ventured to write it into [Miss Smith]111-harriet 's collection . [[Your]123-emma friend]2922-your friend will not take it amiss [I]123-emma hope . Of course [I]123-emma have not transcribed beyond the first eight lines . ”[123-emma]

[Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton certainly did not very well know what to say . [He]95-mr. elton looked rather doubtingly -- rather confused ; said something about “ honour,”--glanced[95-mr. elton] at [Emma]123-emma and at [Harriet]111-harriet , and then seeing the book open on the table , took it up , and examined it very attentively . With the view of passing off an awkward moment , [Emma]123-emma smilingly said ,

“ [You]123-emma must make [my]123-emma apologies to [[your]123-emma friend]2922-your friend ; but so good a charade must not be confined to one or two . [He]2922-your friend may be sure of [every woman]3248-every woman 's approbation while [he]2922-your friend writes with such gallantry . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]95-mr. elton have no hesitation in saying , ”[95-mr. elton] replied [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , though hesitating a good deal while [he]95-mr. elton spoke ; “ [I]95-mr. elton have no hesitation in saying -- at least if [[my]95-mr. elton friend]3149-my friend feels at all as _ [I]95-mr. elton _ do -- [I]95-mr. elton have not the smallest doubt that , could [he]3149-my friend see [his]3149-my friend little effusion honoured as _ [I]95-mr. elton _ see it , ( looking at the book again , and replacing it on the table ) , [he]3149-my friend would consider it as the proudest moment of [his]3149-my friend life . ”[95-mr. elton]

After this speech [he]95-mr. elton was gone as soon as possible . [Emma]123-emma could not think it too soon ; for with all [his]95-mr. elton good and agreeable qualities , there was a sort of parade in [his]95-mr. elton speeches which was very apt to incline [her]123-emma to laugh . [She]123-emma ran away to indulge the inclination , leaving the tender and the sublime of pleasure to [Harriet]111-harriet 's share .

CHAPTER X

Though now the middle of December , there had yet been no weather to prevent [the young ladies]834-the young ladies from tolerably regular exercise ; and on the morrow , [Emma]123-emma had a charitable visit to pay to [a poor sick family]835-a poor sick family , who lived a little way out of [Highbury]3-highbury .

[[Their]835-a poor sick family road to [this detached cottage]837-this detached cottage]836-their road to this detached cottage was down [Vicarage Lane]21-vicarage lane , [a lane leading at right angles]838-a lane leading at right angles from [the broad , though irregular , main street of [the place]450-the place]839-the broad , though irregular , main street of the place ; and , as may be inferred , containing [the blessed abode of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton]841-the blessed abode of mr. elton . [A few inferior dwellings]842-a few inferior dwellings were first to be passed , and then , about a quarter of a mile down [the lane]843-the lane rose [the Vicarage]844-the vicarage , [an old and not very good house]845-an old and not very good house , almost as close to [the road]846-the road as [it]844-the vicarage could be . It had no advantage of situation ; but had been very much smartened up by [the present proprietor]847-the present proprietor ; and , such as it was , there could be no possibility of [the two friends]848-the two friends passing it without a slackened pace and observing eyes.--Emma 's remark was--

“ There it is . There go [you]111-harriet and [your]111-harriet riddle - book one of these days . ”--Harriet[847-the present proprietor] 's was--

“ Oh , what a sweet house!--How very beautiful!--There are the yellow curtains that [Miss Nash]117-miss nash admires so much . ”[847-the present proprietor]

“ [I]123-emma do not often walk this way _ now _ , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , as [they]849-they proceeded , “ but _ then _ there will be an inducement , and [I]123-emma shall gradually get intimately acquainted with all the hedges , gates , pools and pollards of [this part of [Highbury]3-highbury]3250-this part of highbury . ”[123-emma]

[Harriet]111-harriet , [she]123-emma found , had never in [her]111-harriet life been inside [the Vicarage]844-the vicarage , and [her]111-harriet curiosity to see it was so extreme , that , considering exteriors and probabilities , [Emma]123-emma could only class it , as a proof of love , with [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's seeing ready wit in [her]111-harriet .

“ [I]111-harriet wish [we]849-they could contrive it , ”[111-harriet] said [she]111-harriet ; “ but [I]111-harriet can not think of any tolerable pretence for going [in;--no servant that [I]111-harriet want to inquire about of [[his]95-mr. elton housekeeper]3252-his housekeeper]3251-in;--no servant that i want to inquire about of his housekeeper -- no message from [[my]111-harriet father]2740-my father . ”[111-harriet]

[She]111-harriet pondered , but could think of nothing . After a mutual silence of some minutes , [Harriet]111-harriet thus began again--

“ [I]111-harriet do so wonder , [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , that [you]84-miss woodhouse should not be married , or going to be married ! so charming as [you]84-miss woodhouse are!”--[111-harriet]

[Emma]123-emma laughed , and replied ,

“ [My]123-emma being charming , [Harriet]111-harriet , is not quite enough to induce [me]123-emma to marry ; [I]123-emma must find [other people]456-other people charming -- [one other person]3255-one other person at least . And [I]123-emma am not only , not going to be married , at present , but have very little intention of ever marrying at all . ”[123-emma]

“ Ah!--so [you]84-miss woodhouse say ; but [I]111-harriet can not believe it . ”[111-harriet]

“ [I]123-emma must see somebody very superior to [any one [I]123-emma have seen yet]3256-any one i have seen yet , to be tempted ; [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , [you]84-miss woodhouse know , ( recollecting [herself]95-mr. elton , ) is out of the question : and [I]123-emma do _ not _ wish to see [any such person]3257-any such person . [I]123-emma would rather not be tempted . [I]123-emma can not really change for the better . If [I]123-emma were to marry , [I]123-emma must expect to repent it . ”[123-emma]

“ Dear me!--it is so odd to hear [a woman]2864-a woman talk so!”--[111-harriet]

“ [I]123-emma have none of the usual inducements of [women]3259-women to marry . Were [I]123-emma to fall in love , indeed , it would be a different thing ! but [I]123-emma never have been in love ; it is not [my]123-emma way , or [my]123-emma nature ; and [I]123-emma do not think [I]123-emma ever shall . And , without love , [I]123-emma am sure [I]123-emma should be a fool to change such a situation as [mine]123-emma . Fortune [I]123-emma do not want ; employment [I]123-emma do not want ; consequence [I]123-emma do not want : [I]123-emma believe [few married women]3260-few married women are half as much mistress of [[[their]3260-few married women husband]3261-their husband 's house]3262-their husband 's house as [I]123-emma am of [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; and never , never could [I]123-emma expect to be so truly beloved and important ; so always first and always right in [any man]3263-any man 's eyes as [I]123-emma am in [[my]123-emma father]2740-my father 's . ”[123-emma]

“ But then , to be [an old maid]3265-an old maid at last , like [Miss Bates]105-miss bates ! ”[111-harriet]

“ That is as formidable an image as [you]3266-you could present , [Harriet]111-harriet ; and if [I]123-emma thought [I]123-emma should ever be like [Miss Bates]105-miss bates ! so silly -- so satisfied -- so smiling -- so prosing -- so undistinguishing and unfastidious -- and so apt to tell every thing relative to every body about [me]123-emma , [I]123-emma would marry to - morrow . But between _ [us]3267-us _ , [I]123-emma am convinced there never can be any likeness , except in being unmarried . ”[123-emma]

“ But still , [you]3266-you will be [an old maid]3265-an old maid ! and that 's so dreadful ! ”[111-harriet]

“ Never mind , [Harriet]111-harriet , [I]123-emma shall not be [a poor old maid]3269-a poor old maid ; and it is poverty only which makes celibacy contemptible to [a generous public]3270-a generous public ! [A single woman]3271-a single woman , with a very narrow income , must be [a ridiculous , disagreeable old maid]3272-a ridiculous , disagreeable old maid ! the proper sport of [boys]3273-boys and [girls]587-girls , but [a single woman , of good fortune]3275-a single woman , of good fortune , is always respectable , and may be as sensible and pleasant as any body else . And the distinction is not quite so much against the candour and common sense of [the world]403-the world as appears at first ; for a very narrow income has a tendency to contract the mind , and sour the temper . [Those who can barely live , and who live perforce in a very small , and generally very inferior , society]3277-those who can barely live , and who live perforce in a very small , and generally very inferior , society , may well be illiberal and cross . This does not apply , however , to [Miss Bates]105-miss bates ; [she]105-miss bates is only too good natured and too silly to suit [me]123-emma ; but , in general , [she]105-miss bates is very much to the taste of every body , though single and though poor . [Poverty]150-poverty certainly has not contracted [her]105-miss bates mind : [I]123-emma really believe , if [she]105-miss bates had only a shilling in [the world]403-the world , [she]105-miss bates would be very likely to give away sixpence of it ; and [nobody]2718-nobody is afraid of [her]105-miss bates : that is a great charm . ”[123-emma]

“ Dear [me]111-harriet ! but what shall [you]111-harriet do ? how shall [you]111-harriet employ [yourself]111-harriet when [you]111-harriet grow old ? ”[111-harriet]

“ If [I]123-emma know [myself]123-emma , [Harriet]111-harriet , [mine]123-emma is an active , busy mind , with a great many independent resources ; and [I]123-emma do not perceive why [I]123-emma should be more in want of employment at forty or fifty than one - and - twenty . [Woman]749-woman 's usual occupations of hand and mind will be as open to [me]123-emma then as [they]3281-they are now ; or with no important variation . If [I]123-emma draw less , [I]123-emma shall read more ; if [I]123-emma give up music , [I]123-emma shall take to carpet - work . And as for objects of interest , objects for the affections , which is in truth the great point of inferiority , the want of which is really the great evil to be avoided in _ not _ marrying , [I]123-emma shall be very well off , with [all the children of [a sister]3283-a sister [I]123-emma love so much , to care about]3282-all the children of a sister i love so much , to care about . There will be enough of [them]3282-all the children of a sister i love so much , to care about , in all probability , to supply every sort of sensation that declining life can need . There will be enough for every hope and every fear ; and though [my]123-emma attachment to none can equal that of [a parent]3284-a parent , it suits [my]123-emma ideas of comfort better than what is warmer and blinder . [[My]123-emma nephews]3285-my nephews and nieces!--I shall often have [a niece]3286-a niece with [me]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

“ Do [you]123-emma know [[Miss Bates]105-miss bates 's niece]3287-miss bates 's niece ? That is , [I]111-harriet know [you]123-emma must have seen [her]3287-miss bates 's niece a hundred times -- but are [you]123-emma acquainted ? ”[111-harriet]

“ Oh ! yes ; [we]3288-we are always forced to be acquainted whenever [she]3287-miss bates 's niece comes to [Highbury]3-highbury . By the bye , _ that _ is almost enough to put one out of conceit with [a niece]3286-a niece . Heaven forbid ! at least , that [I]123-emma should ever bore [people]2986-people half so much about all [the Knightleys]151-the mr. knightleys together , as [she]3287-miss bates 's niece does about [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . [One]2775-one is sick of the very name of [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . Every letter from [her]152-miss fairfax is read forty times over ; [her]152-miss fairfax compliments to [all friends]3292-all friends go round and round again ; and if [she]152-miss fairfax does but send [[her]152-miss fairfax aunt]3293-her aunt the pattern of a stomacher , or knit a pair of garters for [[her]152-miss fairfax grandmother]3294-her grandmother , [one]2775-one hears of nothing else for a month . [I]123-emma wish [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax very well ; but [she]152-miss fairfax tires [me]123-emma to death . ”[123-emma]

[They]851-them were now approaching [the cottage]852-the cottage , and all idle topics were superseded . [Emma]123-emma was very compassionate ; and the distresses of [the poor]853-the poor were as sure of relief from [her]123-emma personal attention and kindness , [her]123-emma counsel and [her]123-emma patience , as from [her]123-emma purse . [She]123-emma understood [their]853-the poor ways , could allow for [their]853-the poor ignorance and [their]853-the poor temptations , had no romantic expectations of extraordinary virtue from those for whom education had done so little ; entered into [their]853-the poor troubles with ready sympathy , and always gave [her]123-emma assistance with as much intelligence as good - will . In the present instance , it was sickness and poverty together which [she]123-emma came to visit ; and after remaining there as long as [she]123-emma could give comfort or advice , [she]123-emma quitted [the cottage]852-the cottage with such an impression of the scene as made [her]123-emma say to [Harriet]111-harriet , as [they]851-them walked away ,

“ These are the sights , [Harriet]111-harriet , to do one good . How trifling [they]853-the poor make every thing else [appear!--I]3296-appear!--i feel now as if [I]123-emma could think of nothing but [these poor creatures]3297-these poor creatures all the rest of the day ; and yet , who can say how soon it may all vanish from [my]123-emma mind ? ”[123-emma]

“ Very true , ”[111-harriet] said [Harriet]111-harriet . “ [Poor creatures]3298-poor creatures ! [one]2775-one can think of nothing else . ”[111-harriet]

“ And really , [I]123-emma do not think the impression will soon be over , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , as [she]123-emma crossed the low hedge , and tottering footstep which ended the narrow , slippery path through [the cottage garden]855-the cottage garden , and brought [them]851-them into [the lane]843-the lane again . “ [I]123-emma do not think it will , ”[123-emma] stopping to look once more at all the outward wretchedness of [the place]450-the place , and recall the still greater within .

“ Oh ! dear , no , ”[672-her companion] said [[her]123-emma companion]672-her companion .

[They]851-them walked on . [The lane]843-the lane made a slight bend ; and when that bend was passed , [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton was immediately in sight ; and so near as to give [Emma]123-emma time only to say farther ,

“ Ah ! [Harriet]111-harriet , here comes a very sudden trial of [our]851-them stability in good thoughts . Well , ( smiling , ) [I]95-mr. elton hope it may be allowed that if compassion has produced exertion and relief to [the sufferers]3300-the sufferers , it has done all that is truly important . If [we]851-them feel for [the wretched]3301-the wretched , enough to do all [we]851-them can for [them]3301-the wretched , the rest is empty sympathy , only distressing to [ourselves]851-them . ”[95-mr. elton]

[Harriet]111-harriet could just answer , “ Oh ! dear , yes , ”[680-the gentleman] before [the gentleman]680-the gentleman joined [them]851-them . The wants and sufferings of [the poor family]861-the poor family , however , were the first subject on meeting . [He]95-mr. elton had been going to call on [them]851-them . [His]95-mr. elton visit [he]95-mr. elton would now defer ; but [they]851-them had a very interesting parley about what could be done and should be done . [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton then turned back to accompany [them]851-them .

“ To fall in with each other on such an errand as this , ”[123-emma] thought [Emma]123-emma ; “ to meet in a charitable scheme ; this will bring a great increase of love on each side . [I]123-emma should not wonder if it were to bring on the declaration . It must , if [I]123-emma were not [here]2707-here . [I]123-emma wish [I]123-emma were anywhere else . ”[123-emma]

Anxious to separate [herself]123-emma from [them]851-them as far as [she]123-emma could , [she]123-emma soon afterwards took possession of [a narrow footpath]862-a narrow footpath , a little raised on one side of [the lane]843-the lane , leaving [them]851-them together in [the main road]864-the main road . But [she]123-emma had not been there two minutes when [she]123-emma found that [Harriet]111-harriet 's habits of dependence and imitation were bringing [her]123-emma up too , and that , in short , [they]851-them would both be soon after [her]123-emma . This would not do ; [she]123-emma immediately stopped , under pretence of having some alteration to make in the lacing of [her]123-emma half - boot , and stooping down in complete occupation of [the footpath]865-the footpath , begged [them]851-them to have the goodness to walk on , and [she]123-emma would follow in half a minute . [They]851-them did as they were desired ; and by the time [she]123-emma judged it reasonable to have done with [her]123-emma boot , [she]123-emma had the comfort of farther delay in [her]123-emma power , being overtaken by [a child from [the cottage]852-the cottage]866-a child from the cottage , setting out , according to orders , with [her]123-emma pitcher , to fetch broth from [Hartfield]2-hartfield . To walk by the side of [this child]868-this child , and talk to and question [her]868-this child , was the most natural thing in [the world]403-the world , or would have been the most natural , had [she]868-this child been acting just then without design ; and by this means [the others]870-the others were still able to keep ahead , without any obligation of waiting for [her]123-emma . [She]123-emma gained on [them]851-them , however , involuntarily : [the child]498-the child 's pace was quick , and theirs rather slow ; and [she]123-emma was the more concerned at it , from [their]851-them being evidently in a conversation which interested [them]851-them . [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton was speaking with animation , [Harriet]111-harriet listening with a very pleased attention ; and [Emma]123-emma , having sent [the child]498-the child on , was beginning to think how [she]123-emma might draw back a little more , when [they]851-them both looked around , and [she]123-emma was obliged to join [them]851-them .

[Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton was still talking , still engaged in some interesting detail ; and [Emma]123-emma experienced some disappointment when [she]123-emma found that [he]95-mr. elton was only giving [[his]95-mr. elton fair companion]873-his fair companion an account of the yesterday 's party at [[his]95-mr. elton friend]830-his friend [Cole]145-mr. cole 's , and that [she]123-emma was come in [herself]123-emma for the Stilton cheese , [the north Wiltshire]875-the north wiltshire , the butter , the celery , the beet - root , and all the dessert .

“ This would soon have led to something better , of course , ”[123-emma] was [her]123-emma consoling reflection ; “ any thing interests between [those who love]3303-those who love ; and any thing will serve as introduction to what is near the heart . If [I]123-emma could but have kept longer away ! ”[123-emma]

[They]851-them now walked on together quietly , till within view of [the vicarage pales]876-the vicarage pales , when a sudden resolution , of at least getting [Harriet]111-harriet into [the house]435-the house , made [her]111-harriet again find something very much amiss about [her]111-harriet boot , and fall behind to arrange it once more . [She]111-harriet then broke the lace off short , and dexterously throwing it into a ditch , was presently obliged to entreat [them]851-them to stop , and acknowledged [her]111-harriet inability to put [herself]111-harriet to rights so as to be able to walk [home]562-home in tolerable comfort .

“ Part of [my]111-harriet lace is gone , ”[111-harriet] said [she]111-harriet , “ and [I]111-harriet do not know how [I]111-harriet am to contrive . [I]111-harriet really am [a most troublesome companion to [you]95-mr. elton both]3304-a most troublesome companion to you both , but [I]111-harriet hope [I]111-harriet am not often so ill - equipped . [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , [I]111-harriet must beg leave to stop at [[your]95-mr. elton house]3305-your house , and ask [[your]95-mr. elton housekeeper]3306-your housekeeper for a bit of ribband or string , or any thing just to keep [my]111-harriet boot on . ”[111-harriet]

[Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton looked all happiness at this proposition ; and nothing could exceed [his]95-mr. elton alertness and attention in conducting [them]879-them into [[his]95-mr. elton house]409-his house and endeavouring to make every thing appear to advantage . [The room [they]879-them were taken into]881-the room they were taken into was [the one [he]95-mr. elton chiefly occupied]882-the one he chiefly occupied , and looking forwards ; behind [it]881-the room they were taken into was another with which [it]881-the room they were taken into immediately communicated ; the door between [them]879-them was open , and [Emma]123-emma passed into [it]881-the room they were taken into with [the housekeeper]883-the housekeeper to receive [her]883-the housekeeper assistance in the most comfortable manner . [She]123-emma was obliged to leave the door ajar as [she]123-emma found it ; but [she]123-emma fully intended that [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton should close [it]881-the room they were taken into . It was not closed , however , [it]881-the room they were taken into still remained ajar ; but by engaging [the housekeeper]883-the housekeeper in incessant conversation , [she]123-emma hoped to make it practicable for [him]95-mr. elton to chuse [his]95-mr. elton own subject in [the adjoining room]885-the adjoining room . For ten minutes [she]123-emma could hear nothing but [herself]123-emma . It could be protracted no longer . [She]123-emma was then obliged to be finished , and make [her]123-emma appearance .

[The lovers]886-the lovers were standing together at one of the windows . It had a most favourable aspect ; and , for half a minute , [Emma]123-emma felt the glory of having schemed successfully . But it would not do ; [he]95-mr. elton had not come to the point . [He]95-mr. elton had been most agreeable , most delightful ; [he]95-mr. elton had told [Harriet]111-harriet that [he]95-mr. elton had seen [them]886-the lovers go by , and had purposely followed [them]886-the lovers ; other little gallantries and allusions had been dropt , but nothing serious .

“ Cautious , very cautious , ”[123-emma] thought [Emma]123-emma ; “ [he]95-mr. elton advances inch by inch , and will hazard nothing till [he]95-mr. elton believes [himself]95-mr. elton secure . ”[123-emma]

Still , however , though every thing had not been accomplished by [her]123-emma ingenious device , [she]123-emma could not but flatter [herself]123-emma that it had been the occasion of much present enjoyment to [both]887-both , and must be leading [them]887-both forward to the great event .

[CHAPTER XI

Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton must now be left to [himself]95-mr. elton . It was no longer in [Emma]123-emma 's power to superintend [his]95-mr. elton happiness or quicken [his]95-mr. elton measures . The coming of [[[her]123-emma sister]407-her sister 's family]889-her sister 's family was so very near at hand , that first in anticipation , and then in reality , it became henceforth [her]123-emma prime object of interest ; and during the ten days of [their]886-the lovers stay at [Hartfield]2-hartfield it was not to be expected -- [she]123-emma did not [herself]123-emma expect -- that any thing beyond occasional , fortuitous assistance could be afforded by [her]123-emma to [the lovers]886-the lovers . [They]887-both might advance rapidly if [they]887-both would , however ; [they]887-both must advance somehow or other whether [they]887-both would or no . [She]123-emma hardly wished to have more leisure for [them]887-both . There are [people]2986-people , who the more [you]892-you do for [them]2986-people , the less [they]2986-people will do for [themselves]2986-people .

[Mr.]893-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley , from having been longer than usual absent from [Surry]31-surry , were exciting of course rather more than the usual interest . Till this year , every long vacation since [their]886-the lovers marriage had been divided between [Hartfield]2-hartfield and [Donwell Abbey]8-donwell abbey ; but all the holidays of this autumn had been given to sea - bathing for [the children]591-the children , and it was therefore many months since [they]591-the children had been seen in a regular way by [[their]591-the children Surry connexions]895-their surry connexions , or seen at all by [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , who could not be induced to get so far as [London]1-london , even for poor [Isabella]87-isabella 's sake ; and who consequently was now most nervously and apprehensively happy in forestalling this too short visit .

[He]893-mr. thought much of the evils of the journey for [her]87-isabella , and not a little of the fatigues of [his]893-mr. own horses and coachman who were to bring some of [the party the last half of the way]896-the party the last half of the way ; but [his]893-mr. alarms were needless ; the sixteen miles being happily accomplished , and [Mr.]897-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley , [[their]886-the lovers five children]898-their five children , and [a competent number of nursery - maids]899-a competent number of nursery - maids , all reaching [Hartfield]2-hartfield in safety . The bustle and joy of such an arrival , [the many to be talked to]900-the many to be talked to , welcomed , encouraged , and variously dispersed and disposed of , produced a noise and confusion which [his]893-mr. nerves could not have borne under any other cause , nor have endured much longer even for this ; but the ways of [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse and the feelings of [[her]87-isabella father]425-her father were so respected by [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley , that in spite of maternal solicitude for the immediate enjoyment of [[her]87-isabella little ones]902-her little ones , and for [their]898-their five children having instantly all the liberty and attendance , all the eating and drinking , and sleeping and playing , which [they]898-their five children could possibly wish for , without the smallest delay , [the children]591-the children were never allowed to be long a disturbance to [him]893-mr. , either in [themselves]591-the children or in any restless attendance on [them]591-the children .

[Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley was [a pretty , elegant little woman , of gentle , quiet manners , and a disposition]904-a pretty , elegant little woman , of gentle , quiet manners , and a disposition remarkably amiable and affectionate ; wrapt up in [[her]122-mrs. john knightley family]2871-her family ; [a devoted wife]906-a devoted wife , [a doating mother]907-a doating mother , and so tenderly attached to [[her]122-mrs. john knightley father]425-her father and sister that , but for these higher ties , a warmer love might have seemed impossible . [She]122-mrs. john knightley could never see a fault in any of [them]909-them . [She]122-mrs. john knightley was not [a woman of strong understanding or any quickness]910-a woman of strong understanding or any quickness ; and with this resemblance of [[her]122-mrs. john knightley father]425-her father , [she]122-mrs. john knightley inherited also much of [his]425-her father constitution ; was delicate in [her]122-mrs. john knightley own health , over - careful of that of [[her]122-mrs. john knightley children]467-her children , had many fears and many nerves , and was as fond of [her]122-mrs. john knightley own Mr. Wingfield in [town]2760-town as [[her]122-mrs. john knightley father]425-her father could be of [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry . [They]915-they were alike too , in a general benevolence of temper , and a strong habit of regard for [every old acquaintance]916-every old acquaintance .

[Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley was [a tall , gentleman - like , and very clever man]917-a tall , gentleman - like , and very clever man ; rising in [his]92-mr. knightley profession , domestic , and respectable in [his]92-mr. knightley private character ; but with reserved manners which prevented [his]92-mr. knightley being generally pleasing ; and capable of being sometimes out of humour . [He]92-mr. knightley was not [an ill - tempered man]918-an ill - tempered man , not so often unreasonably cross as to deserve such a reproach ; but [his]92-mr. knightley temper was not [his]92-mr. knightley great perfection ; and , indeed , with such [a worshipping wife]919-a worshipping wife , it was hardly possible that any natural defects in it should not be increased . The extreme sweetness of [her]919-a worshipping wife temper must hurt [his]92-mr. knightley . [He]92-mr. knightley had all the clearness and quickness of mind which [she]919-a worshipping wife wanted , and [he]92-mr. knightley could sometimes act an ungracious , or say a severe thing .

[He]92-mr. knightley was [not a great favourite with [[his]92-mr. knightley fair sister - in - law]921-his fair sister - in - law]920-not a great favourite with his fair sister - in - law . Nothing wrong in [him]92-mr. knightley escaped [her]919-a worshipping wife . [She]919-a worshipping wife was quick in feeling the little injuries to [Isabella]87-isabella , which [Isabella]87-isabella never felt [herself]87-isabella . Perhaps [she]919-a worshipping wife might have passed over more had [his]92-mr. knightley manners been flattering to [[Isabella]87-isabella 's sister]922-isabella 's sister , but they were only those of [a calmly kind brother and friend , without praise and without blindness]923-a calmly kind brother and friend , without praise and without blindness ; but hardly any degree of personal compliment could have made [her]919-a worshipping wife regardless of that greatest fault of all in [her]919-a worshipping wife eyes which [he]92-mr. knightley sometimes fell into , the want of respectful forbearance towards [[her]919-a worshipping wife father]425-her father . There [he]92-mr. knightley had not always the patience that could have been wished . [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's peculiarities and fidgetiness were sometimes provoking [him]92-mr. knightley to a rational remonstrance or sharp retort equally ill - bestowed . It did not often happen ; for [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley had really a great regard for [[his]92-mr. knightley father - in - law]925-his father - in - law , and generally a strong sense of what was due to [him]92-mr. knightley ; but it was too often for [Emma]123-emma 's charity , especially as there was all the pain of apprehension frequently to be endured , though the offence came not . The beginning , however , of every visit displayed none but the properest feelings , and this being of necessity so short might be hoped to pass away in unsullied cordiality . [They]926-they had not been long seated and composed when [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , with a melancholy shake of the head and a sigh , called [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter 's attention to the sad change at [Hartfield]2-hartfield since [she]919-a worshipping wife had been [there]448-there last .

“ Ah , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [he]85-mr. woodhouse , “ poor [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse -- It is a grievous business . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Oh yes , [sir]2734-sir , ”[919-a worshipping wife] cried [she]919-a worshipping wife with ready sympathy , “ how [you]2734-sir must miss [her]84-miss woodhouse ! And [dear Emma]123-emma , too!--What a dreadful loss to [you]123-emma both!--I have been so grieved for you.--I could not imagine how [you]123-emma could possibly do without her.--It is a sad change indeed.--But [I]919-a worshipping wife hope [she]84-miss woodhouse is pretty well , [sir]2734-sir . ”[919-a worshipping wife]

“ Pretty well , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear -- [I]85-mr. woodhouse hope -- pretty well.--I do not know but that [the place]450-the place agrees with [her]84-miss woodhouse tolerably . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

[Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley here asked [Emma]123-emma quietly whether there were any doubts of the air of [Randalls]101-randalls .

“ Oh ! no -- none in the least . [I]85-mr. woodhouse never saw [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston better in [my]85-mr. woodhouse life -- never looking so well . [Papa]154-papa is only speaking [his]154-papa own regret . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Very much to the honour of both , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] was the handsome reply .

“ And do [you]2734-sir see [her]84-miss woodhouse , [sir]2734-sir , tolerably often ? ”[87-isabella] asked [Isabella]87-isabella in the plaintive tone which just suited [[her]87-isabella father]425-her father .

[Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse hesitated.--“Not near so often , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear , as [I]85-mr. woodhouse could wish . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Oh ! [papa]2708-papa , [we]3315-we have missed seeing [them]3316-they but one entire day since [they]3316-they married . Either in the morning or evening of every day , excepting one , have [we]3315-we seen either [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston or [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , and generally both , either at [Randalls]101-randalls or here -- and as [you]2708-papa may suppose , [Isabella]87-isabella , most frequently here . [They]3316-they are very , very kind in [their]3316-they visits . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston is really as kind as [herself]88-mrs. weston . [Papa]154-papa , if [you]2708-papa speak in that melancholy way , [you]2708-papa will be giving [Isabella]87-isabella a false idea of [us]3315-we all . [Every body]2749-every body must be aware that [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse must be missed , but [every body]2749-every body ought also to be assured that [Mr.]3319-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston do really prevent [our]3315-we missing [her]84-miss woodhouse by any means to the extent [we]3315-we [ourselves]3315-we anticipated -- which is the exact truth . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Just as it should be , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley , “ and just as [I]92-mr. knightley hoped it was from [your]87-isabella letters . “ Why , to be sure , ”[155-mr. woodhouse--“yes] said [Mr. Woodhouse--“yes]155-mr. woodhouse--“yes , certainly -- [I]155-mr. woodhouse--“yes can not deny that [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , [poor Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , does come and see [us]3322-us pretty often -- but then -- [she]88-mrs. weston is always obliged to go away again . ”[155-mr. woodhouse--“yes]

“ It would be very hard upon [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston if [she]88-mrs. weston did not , papa.--You quite forget [poor Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley think , indeed , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [John Knightley]92-mr. knightley pleasantly , “ that [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston has some little claim . “ [Me]2763-his wife , [[my]2763-his wife love]3321-my love , ”[2763-his wife] cried [[his]92-mr. knightley wife]2763-his wife , hearing and understanding only in part.-- “ Are [you]87-isabella talking about me?--I am sure [nobody]2718-nobody ought to be , or can be , a greater advocate for matrimony than [I]92-mr. knightley am ; and if it had not been for the misery of [her]87-isabella leaving [Hartfield]2-hartfield , [I]92-mr. knightley should never have thought of [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse but as [the most fortunate woman in [the world]403-the world]3329-the most fortunate woman in the world ; and as to slighting [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , that excellent [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , [I]92-mr. knightley think there is nothing [he]86-mr. weston does not deserve . “ Where is [the young man]532-the young man ? ”[92-mr. knightley] said [John Knightley]92-mr. knightley . “ Has [he]532-the young man been [here]2707-here on this occasion -- or has [he]532-the young man not ? ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [He]532-the young man has not been [here]2707-here yet , ”[123-emma] replied [Emma]123-emma . “ There was a strong expectation of [his]532-the young man coming soon after the marriage , but it ended in nothing ; and [I]123-emma have not heard [him]532-the young man mentioned lately . ”[123-emma]

“ But [you]123-emma should tell [them]3338-them of the letter , [[my]425-her father dear]2714-my dear , ”[425-her father] said [[her]123-emma father]425-her father . “ [He]532-the young man wrote a letter to [poor Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , to congratulate [her]88-mrs. weston , and a very proper , handsome letter it was . [She]88-mrs. weston shewed it to [me]425-her father . [I]425-her father thought it very well done of [him]532-the young man indeed . [He]532-the young man is but young , and [[his]532-the young man uncle]517-his uncle , perhaps-- ”[425-her father]

“ [[My]123-emma dear papa]2954-my dear papa , [he]532-the young man is three - and - twenty . [You]2954-my dear papa forget how time passes . ”[123-emma]

“ Three - and - twenty!--is [he]532-the young man indeed?--Well , [I]425-her father could not have thought it -- and [he]532-the young man was but two years old when [he]532-the young man lost [[his]532-the young man poor mother]3343-his poor mother ! Well , time does fly indeed!--and [my]425-her father memory is very bad . However , it was an exceeding good , pretty letter , and gave [Mr.]3344-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston a great deal of pleasure . C. [Weston Churchill]156-weston churchill . '--I remember that perfectly . ”[425-her father]

“ How very pleasing and proper of [him]532-the young man ! ”[122-mrs. john knightley] cried [the good - hearted Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley . “ [I]122-mrs. john knightley have no doubt of [his]532-the young man being [a most amiable young man]3346-a most amiable young man . But how sad it is that [he]532-the young man should not live at [home]562-home with [[his]532-the young man father]518-his father ! There is something so shocking in [a child]497-a child 's being taken away from [[his]532-the young man parents]3350-his parents and natural home ! [I]122-mrs. john knightley never could comprehend how [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston could part with [him]86-mr. weston . To give up [one 's child]3351-one 's child ! [I]122-mrs. john knightley really never could think well of [any body who proposed such a thing to any body else]3352-any body who proposed such a thing to any body else . ”[122-mrs. john knightley]

“ [Nobody]2718-nobody ever did think well of [the Churchills]100-the churchills , [I]92-mr. knightley fancy , ”[92-mr. knightley] observed [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley coolly . “ But [you]3354-you need not imagine [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston to have felt what [you]3354-you would feel in giving up [Henry or John]157-henry . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston is rather [an easy , cheerful - tempered man]3355-an easy , cheerful - tempered man , than [a man of strong feelings]3356-a man of strong feelings ; [he]86-mr. weston takes things as [he]86-mr. weston finds them , and makes enjoyment of them somehow or other , depending , [I]92-mr. knightley suspect , much more upon what is called society for [his]86-mr. weston comforts , that is , upon the power of eating and drinking , and playing whist with [[his]86-mr. weston neighbours]541-his neighbours five times a week , than upon family affection , or any thing that [home]562-home affords . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma could not like what bordered on a reflection on [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , and had half a mind to take it up ; but [she]123-emma struggled , and let it pass . [She]123-emma would keep the peace if possible ; and there was something honourable and valuable in the strong domestic habits , the all - sufficiency of [home]562-home to [himself]86-mr. weston , whence resulted [[her]123-emma brother]482-her brother 's disposition to look down on the common rate of social intercourse , and [those to whom it was important.--It]934-those to whom it was important.--it had a high claim to forbearance .

CHAPTER XII

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley was to dine with [them]935-we -- rather against the inclination of [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , who did not like that [any one]2903-any one should share with [him]92-mr. knightley in [Isabella]87-isabella 's first day . [Emma]123-emma 's sense of right however had decided it ; and besides the consideration of what was due to [each brother]937-each brother , [she]123-emma had particular pleasure , from the circumstance of the late disagreement between [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley and [herself]123-emma , in procuring [him]92-mr. knightley the proper invitation .

[She]123-emma hoped [they]935-we might now become [friends]579-friends again . [She]123-emma thought it was time to make up . Making - up indeed would not do . _ [She]123-emma _ certainly had not been in the wrong , and _ [he]92-mr. knightley _ would never own that [he]92-mr. knightley had . [Concession]158-concession must be out of the question ; but it was time to appear to forget that [they]935-we had ever quarrelled ; and [she]123-emma hoped it might rather assist the restoration of friendship , that when [he]92-mr. knightley came into [the room]701-the room [she]123-emma had one of [the children]591-the children with [her]123-emma -- [the youngest]941-the youngest , [a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making [her]941-the youngest first visit to [Hartfield]2-hartfield , and very happy to be danced about in [[her]941-the youngest aunt]3293-her aunt 's arms]942-a nice little girl about eight months old , who was now making her first visit to hartfield , and very happy to be danced about in her aunt 's arms . It did assist ; for though [he]92-mr. knightley began with grave looks and short questions , [he]92-mr. knightley was soon led on to talk of [them]591-the children all in the usual way , and to take [the child]498-the child out of [her]123-emma arms with all the unceremoniousness of perfect amity . [Emma]123-emma felt [they]935-we were [friends]579-friends again ; and the conviction giving [her]123-emma at first great satisfaction , and then a little sauciness , [she]123-emma could not help saying , as [he]92-mr. knightley was admiring [the baby]946-the baby ,

“ What a comfort it is , that [we]935-we think alike about [[our]935-we nephews]3359-our nephews and [nieces]3360-nieces . As to [men]3104-men and [women]3259-women , [our]935-we opinions are sometimes very different ; but with regard to [these children]3363-these children , [I]92-mr. knightley observe [we]935-we never disagree . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ If [you]92-mr. knightley were as much guided by nature in [your]92-mr. knightley estimate of [men]3104-men and [women]3259-women , and as little under the power of fancy and whim in [your]92-mr. knightley dealings with [them]3363-these children , as [you]92-mr. knightley are where [these children]3363-these children are concerned , [we]935-we might always think alike . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ To be sure -- [our]935-we discordancies must always arise from [my]92-mr. knightley being in the wrong . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Yes , ”[947-you] said [he]947-you , smiling--“and reason good . [I]947-you was sixteen years old when [you]948-you were born . ”[947-you]

“ A material difference then , ”[92-mr. knightley] [she]948-you replied--“and no doubt [you]947-you were much [my]947-you superior in judgment at that period of [our]935-we lives ; but does not the lapse of one - and - twenty years bring [our]935-we understandings a good deal nearer ? ”[947-you]

“ Yes -- a good deal _ nearer _ . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ But still , not near enough to give [me]947-you a chance of being right , if [we]935-we think differently . ”[947-you]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley have still the advantage of [you]947-you by sixteen years ' experience , and by not being [a pretty young woman]3367-a pretty young woman and [a spoiled child]3368-a spoiled child . Come , [[my]92-mr. knightley dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , let [us]935-we be [friends]579-friends , and say no more about it . Tell [[your]123-emma aunt]3371-your aunt , [little Emma]123-emma , that [she]3371-your aunt ought to set [you]123-emma a better example than to be renewing old grievances , and that if [she]3371-your aunt were not wrong before , [she]3371-your aunt is now . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ That 's true , ”[947-you] [she]949-she cried--“very true . [Little Emma]123-emma , grow up [a better woman]3372-a better woman than [[your]123-emma aunt]3371-your aunt . Be infinitely cleverer and not half so conceited . Now , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , a word or two more , and [I]92-mr. knightley have done . As far as good intentions went , [we]935-we were _ both _ right , and [I]92-mr. knightley must say that no effects on [my]92-mr. knightley side of the argument have yet proved wrong . [I]92-mr. knightley only want to know that [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin is not very , very bitterly disappointed . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [A man]2840-a man can not be more so , ”[949-she] was [his]949-she short , full answer .

“ Ah!--Indeed [I]92-mr. knightley am very sorry.--Come , shake hands with [me]92-mr. knightley . ”[92-mr. knightley]

This had just taken place and with great cordiality , when [John Knightley]92-mr. knightley made [his]92-mr. knightley appearance , and “ How [d'ye]3375-d'ye do , [George]126-george ? ”[92-mr. knightley] and “ [John]92-mr. knightley , how are [you]92-mr. knightley ? ”[92-mr. knightley] succeeded in the true English style , burying under a calmness that seemed all but indifference , the real attachment which would have led either of [them]950-them , if requisite , to do every thing for the good of the other .

The evening was quiet and conversable , as [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse declined cards entirely for the sake of comfortable talk with [[his]85-mr. woodhouse dear]951-his dear [Isabella]87-isabella , and [the little party]952-the little party made two natural divisions ; on one side [he]85-mr. woodhouse and [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter ; on the other the two [Mr. Knightleys]151-the mr. knightleys ; [[their]950-them subjects]954-their subjects totally distinct , or very rarely mixing -- and [Emma]123-emma only occasionally joining in one or the other .

[The brothers]955-the brothers talked of [their]955-the brothers own concerns and pursuits , but principally of those of [the elder]956-the elder , whose temper was by much the most communicative , and who was always [the greater talker]957-the greater talker . As [a magistrate]958-a magistrate , [he]85-mr. woodhouse had generally some point of law to consult [John]92-mr. knightley about , or , at least , some curious anecdote to give ; and as [a farmer]2807-a farmer , as keeping in hand [the home - farm at [Donwell]24-donwell]960-the home - farm at donwell , [he]85-mr. woodhouse had to tell what every field was to bear next year , and to give all such local information as could not fail of being interesting to [a brother whose [home]562-home [it]562-home had equally been the longest part of [his]85-mr. woodhouse life]961-a brother whose home it had equally been the longest part of his life , and whose attachments were strong . The plan of a drain , the change of a fence , the felling of a tree , and the destination of every acre for wheat , turnips , or spring corn , was entered into with as much equality of interest by [John]92-mr. knightley , as [his]92-mr. knightley cooler manners rendered possible ; and if [[his]92-mr. knightley willing brother]963-his willing brother ever left [him]92-mr. knightley any thing to inquire about , [his]92-mr. knightley inquiries even approached a tone of eagerness .

While [they]964-they were thus comfortably occupied , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse was enjoying a full flow of happy regrets and fearful affection with [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter .

“ [My]85-mr. woodhouse poor dear [Isabella]87-isabella , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [he]85-mr. woodhouse , fondly taking [her]2723-his daughter hand , and interrupting , for a few moments , [her]2723-his daughter busy labours for some one of [her]2723-his daughter five children--“How long it is , how terribly long since [you]87-isabella were here ! And how tired [you]87-isabella must be after [your]87-isabella journey ! [You]87-isabella must go to bed early , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear -- and [I]85-mr. woodhouse recommend a little gruel to [you]87-isabella before [you]87-isabella go.--You and [I]85-mr. woodhouse will have a nice basin of gruel together . [[My]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , suppose [we]3378-we all have a little gruel . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

[Emma]123-emma could not suppose any such thing , knowing as [she]123-emma did , that both [the Mr. Knightleys]151-the mr. knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article as herself;--and two basins only were ordered . After a little more discourse in praise of gruel , with some wondering at its not being taken every evening by every body , [he]151-the mr. knightleys proceeded to say , with an air of grave reflection ,

“ It was an awkward business , [[my]151-the mr. knightleys dear]2714-my dear , [your]87-isabella spending the autumn at [South End]25-south end instead of coming here . [I]151-the mr. knightleys never had much opinion of the sea air . ”[151-the mr. knightleys]

“ [Mr. Wingfield]159-mr. wingfield most strenuously recommended it , [sir]2734-sir -- or [we]3378-we should not have gone . [He]159-mr. wingfield recommended it for all [the children]591-the children , but particularly for the weakness in [little Bella]87-isabella 's throat,--both sea air and bathing . ”[151-the mr. knightleys]

“ Ah ! [[my]151-the mr. knightleys dear]2714-my dear , but [Perry]106-mr. perry had many doubts about [the sea]3383-the sea doing [her]87-isabella any good ; and as to [myself]151-the mr. knightleys , [I]151-the mr. knightleys have been long perfectly convinced , though perhaps [I]151-the mr. knightleys never told [you]2714-my dear so before , that [the sea]3383-the sea is very rarely of use to [any body]665-any body . [I]151-the mr. knightleys am sure it almost killed [me]151-the mr. knightleys once . ”[151-the mr. knightleys]

“ Come , come , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , feeling this to be an unsafe subject , “ [I]123-emma must beg [you]2714-my dear not to talk of [the sea]3383-the sea . It makes [me]123-emma envious and [miserable;--I who have never seen it]3387-miserable;--i who have never seen it ! [South End]25-south end is prohibited , if [you]2714-my dear please . [[My]123-emma dear]2714-my dear [Isabella]87-isabella , [I]123-emma have not heard [you]87-isabella make one inquiry about [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry yet ; and [he]106-mr. perry never forgets [you]87-isabella . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! good [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry -- how is [he]106-mr. perry , [sir]2734-sir ? ”[151-the mr. knightleys]

“ Why , pretty well ; but not quite well . [Poor Perry]160-poor perry is bilious , and [he]106-mr. perry has not time to take care of [himself]106-mr. perry -- [he]106-mr. perry tells [me]123-emma [he]106-mr. perry has not time to take care of [himself]106-mr. perry -- which is very sad -- but [he]106-mr. perry is always wanted all round [the country]611-the country . [I]123-emma suppose there is not [a man]2840-a man in such practice anywhere . But then there is [not so clever a man]3392-not so clever a man any where . ”[123-emma]

“ And [Mrs. Perry]104-mrs. perry and [the children]591-the children , how are [they]591-the children ? do [the children]591-the children grow ? “ [I]123-emma hope [he]106-mr. perry will be here to - morrow , for [I]123-emma have a question or two to ask [him]106-mr. perry about [myself]123-emma of some consequence . “ Oh ! [[my]151-the mr. knightleys dear [sir]2734-sir]3019-my dear sir , [her]87-isabella throat is so much better that [I]151-the mr. knightleys have hardly any uneasiness about it . Either bathing has been of the greatest service to [her]87-isabella , or else it is to be attributed to an excellent embrocation of [Mr. Wingfield]159-mr. wingfield 's , which [we]3398-we have been applying at times ever since August . ”[151-the mr. knightleys]

“ It is not very likely , [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear , that bathing should have been of use to [her]87-isabella -- and if [I]123-emma had known [you]2714-my dear were wanting an embrocation , [I]123-emma would have spoken to--[123-emma]

“ [You]2734-sir seem to [me]123-emma to have forgotten [Mrs.]3400-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ [I]123-emma have not heard one inquiry after [them]3401-them . ”[123-emma]

[I]123-emma hope they are quite well . [Good old Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates -- [I]123-emma will call upon [her]110-mrs. bates to - morrow , and take [[my]123-emma children.--They]3402-my children.--they are always so pleased to see [my]123-emma children.--And that excellent [Miss Bates!--such]3403-miss bates!--such thorough worthy people!--How are [they]161-the bateses , [sir]2734-sir ? ”[123-emma]

“ Why , pretty well , [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear , upon the whole . But [poor Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates had a bad cold about a month ago . ”[123-emma]

“ How sorry [I]123-emma am ! But colds were never so prevalent as they have been this autumn . [Mr. Wingfield]159-mr. wingfield told [me]123-emma that [he]159-mr. wingfield has never known them more general or heavy -- except when it has been quite an influenza . ”[123-emma]

“ That has been a good deal the case , [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear ; but not to the degree [you]2714-my dear mention . [Perry]106-mr. perry says that colds have been very general , but not so heavy as [he]159-mr. wingfield has very often known them in November . [Nobody]2718-nobody is healthy in [London]1-london , [nobody]2718-nobody can be . It is a dreadful thing to have [you]2714-my dear forced to live [there]448-there ! so far off!--and the air so bad ! ”[123-emma]

“ No , indeed--_we _ are not at all in a bad air . [[Our]3411-we part of [London]1-london]3412-our part of london is very superior to most others!--You must not confound [us]3411-we with [London]1-london in general , [[my]123-emma dear sir]3019-my dear sir . “ Ah ! [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear , it is not like [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse . [You]2714-my dear make the best of it -- but after [you]2714-my dear have been a week at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , [you]2714-my dear are all of [you]2714-my dear different creatures ; [you]2714-my dear do not look like the same . “ [I]123-emma am sorry to hear [you]2714-my dear say so , [sir]2734-sir ; but [I]123-emma assure [you]2714-my dear , excepting those little nervous head - aches and palpitations which [I]123-emma am never entirely free from anywhere , [I]123-emma am quite well [myself]123-emma ; and if [the children]591-the children were rather pale before [they]591-the children went to bed , it was only because [they]591-the children were a little more tired than usual , from [their]591-the children journey and the happiness of coming . [I]123-emma trust , at least , that [you]2714-my dear do not think [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley looking ill , ”[123-emma] turning [her]966-her eyes with affectionate anxiety towards [[her]966-her husband]441-her husband .

“ Middling , [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear ; [I]123-emma can not compliment [you]2714-my dear . [I]123-emma think [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley very far from looking well . ”[123-emma]

“ What is the matter , sir?--Did [you]2714-my dear speak to [me]92-mr. knightley ? ”[92-mr. knightley] cried [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley , hearing [his]441-her husband own name .

“ [I]441-her husband am sorry to find , [[my]441-her husband love]3321-my love , that [[my]441-her husband father]2740-my father does not think [you]2714-my dear looking well -- but [I]441-her husband hope it is only from being a little fatigued . “ [[My]441-her husband dear]2714-my dear Isabella,”--exclaimed[441-her husband] [he]441-her husband hastily--“pray do not concern [yourself]2714-my dear about [my]441-her husband looks . Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling [yourself]2714-my dear and [the children]591-the children , and let [me]441-her husband look as [I]441-her husband chuse . ”[441-her husband]

“ [I]123-emma did not thoroughly understand what [you]441-her husband were telling [[your]441-her husband brother]3332-your brother , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , “ about [[your]441-her husband friend [Mr. Graham]162-mr. graham 's intending to have [a bailiff from [Scotland]26-scotland]3432-a bailiff from scotland , to look after [[his]162-mr. graham new estate]3433-his new estate]3431-your friend mr. graham 's intending to have a bailiff from scotland , to look after his new estate . And [she]123-emma talked in this way so long and successfully that , when forced to give [her]123-emma attention again to [[her]123-emma father]425-her father and [sister]3216-sister , [she]123-emma had nothing worse to hear than [Isabella]87-isabella 's kind inquiry after [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax ; and [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , though no great favourite with [her]123-emma in general , [she]123-emma was at that moment very happy to assist in praising .

“ [That sweet , amiable Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax ! ”[163-mrs. john knightley.--“it] said [Mrs. John Knightley.--“It]163-mrs. john knightley.--“it is so long since [I]163-mrs. john knightley.--“it have seen [her]152-miss fairfax , except now and then for a moment accidentally in [town]2760-town !
