There [she]1105-she was welcomed , with the utmost delight , by [[her]1105-she father]425-her father , who had been trembling for the dangers of a solitary drive from [Vicarage Lane]21-vicarage lane -- turning a corner which [he]425-her father could never bear to think of -- and in strange hands -- [a mere common coachman]1110-a mere common coachman -- no [James]90-james ; and there it seemed as if [her]1105-she return only were wanted to make every thing go well : for [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley , ashamed of [his]92-mr. knightley ill - humour , was now all kindness and attention ; and so particularly solicitous for the comfort of [[her]1105-she father]425-her father , as to seem -- if not quite ready to join [him]425-her father in a basin of gruel -- perfectly sensible of its being exceedingly wholesome ; and the day was concluding in peace and comfort to all [[their]1106-they little party]1112-their little party , except herself.--But [her]1105-she mind had never been in such perturbation ; and it needed a very strong effort to appear attentive and cheerful till the usual hour of separating allowed [her]1105-she the relief of quiet reflection .

CHAPTER XVI

The hair was curled , and [the maid]1113-the maid sent away , and [Emma]123-emma sat down to think and be miserable.--It was a wretched business indeed!--Such an overthrow of every thing [she]123-emma had been wishing for!--Such a development of every thing most unwelcome!--Such a blow for [Harriet!--that]178-harriet!--that was the worst of all . Every part of it brought pain and humiliation , of some sort or other ; but , compared with the evil to [Harriet]111-harriet , all was light ; and [she]1105-she would gladly have submitted to feel yet more mistaken -- more in error -- more disgraced by mis - judgment , than [she]1105-she actually was , could the effects of [her]1105-she blunders have been confined to [herself]1105-she .

“ If [I]1114-his had not persuaded [Harriet]111-harriet into liking [the man]3033-the man , [I]1114-his could have borne any thing . [He]3033-the man might have doubled [his]3033-the man presumption to [me]1114-his -- but poor [Harriet]111-harriet ! ”[1114-his]

How [she]1105-she could have been so deceived!--He protested that [he]1114-his had never thought seriously of [Harriet]111-harriet -- never ! [She]1105-she looked back as well as [she]1105-she could ; but it was all confusion . [She]1105-she had taken up the idea , [she]1105-she supposed , and made every thing bend to it . [His]1114-his manners , however , must have been unmarked , wavering , dubious , or [she]1105-she could not have been so misled .

The picture!--How eager [he]1114-his had been about the picture!--and the charade!--and an hundred other circumstances;--how clearly [they]1115-they had seemed to point at [Harriet]111-harriet . To be sure , the charade , with its “ ready wit”--but[1115-they] then the “ soft eyes”--in[1115-they] fact it suited neither ; it was a jumble without taste or truth . Who could have seen through such thick - headed nonsense ?

Certainly [she]1105-she had often , especially of late , thought [his]1114-his manners to [herself]1105-she unnecessarily gallant ; but it had passed as [his]1114-his way , as a mere error of judgment , of knowledge , of taste , as one proof among others that [he]1114-his had not always lived in the best society , that with all the gentleness of [his]1114-his address , true elegance was sometimes wanting ; but , till this very day , [she]1105-she had never , for an instant , suspected it to mean any thing but grateful respect to [her]1105-she as [[Harriet]111-harriet 's friend]1116-harriet 's friend .

To [Mr. John Knightley]92-mr. knightley was [she]1105-she indebted for [her]1105-she first idea on the subject , for the first start of its possibility . There was no denying that [those brothers]1117-those brothers had penetration . [She]1105-she remembered what [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley had once said to [her]1105-she about [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , the caution [he]92-mr. knightley had given , the conviction [he]92-mr. knightley had professed that [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton would never marry indiscreetly ; and blushed to think how much truer a knowledge of [his]1114-his character had been there shewn than any [she]1105-she had reached [herself]1105-she . It was dreadfully mortifying ; but [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton was proving [himself]95-mr. elton , in many respects , the very reverse of what [she]1105-she had meant and believed [him]95-mr. elton ; proud , assuming , conceited ; very full of [his]95-mr. elton own claims , and little concerned about the feelings of [others]2773-others .

Contrary to the usual course of things , [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's wanting to pay [his]95-mr. elton addresses to [her]1105-she had sunk [him]95-mr. elton in [her]1105-she opinion . [His]95-mr. elton professions and [his]95-mr. elton proposals did [him]95-mr. elton no service . [She]1105-she thought nothing of [his]95-mr. elton attachment , and was insulted by [his]95-mr. elton hopes . [He]95-mr. elton wanted to marry well , and having the arrogance to raise [his]95-mr. elton eyes to [her]1105-she , pretended to be in love ; but [she]1105-she was perfectly easy as to [his]95-mr. elton not suffering any disappointment that need be cared for . There had been no real affection either in [his]95-mr. elton language or manners . Sighs and fine words had been given in abundance ; but [she]1105-she could hardly devise any set of expressions , or fancy any tone of voice , less allied with real love . [She]1105-she need not trouble [herself]1105-she to pity [him]95-mr. elton . [He]95-mr. elton only wanted to aggrandise and enrich [himself]95-mr. elton ; and if [Miss Woodhouse of Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse , [the heiress of thirty thousand pounds]1119-the heiress of thirty thousand pounds , were not quite so easily obtained as [he]95-mr. elton had fancied , [he]95-mr. elton would soon try for [Miss Somebody else]179-miss somebody else with twenty , or with ten .

But -- that [he]95-mr. elton should talk of encouragement , should consider [her]1105-she as aware of [his]95-mr. elton views , accepting [his]95-mr. elton attentions , meaning ( in short ) , to marry [him!--should]95-mr. elton suppose [himself]95-mr. elton [her]1105-she equal in connexion or mind!--look down upon [[her]1105-she friend]427-her friend , so well understanding the gradations of rank below [him]95-mr. elton , and be so blind to what rose above , as to fancy [himself]95-mr. elton shewing no presumption in addressing her!--It was most provoking .

Perhaps it was not fair to expect [him]95-mr. elton to feel how very much [he]95-mr. elton was [her]1105-she inferior in talent , and all the elegancies of mind . The very want of such equality might prevent [his]95-mr. elton perception of it ; but [he]95-mr. elton must know that in fortune and consequence [she]1105-she was greatly [[his]95-mr. elton superior]1121-his superior . [He]95-mr. elton must know that [the Woodhouses]180-the woodhouses had been settled for several generations at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , [the younger branch of [a very ancient family]1123-a very ancient family]1122-the younger branch of a very ancient family -- and that [the Eltons]143-the eltons were [nobody]2718-nobody . [The landed property of [Hartfield]2-hartfield]1125-the landed property of hartfield certainly was inconsiderable , being but a sort of notch in [the Donwell Abbey estate]1126-the donwell abbey estate , to which [all the rest of [Highbury]3-highbury]1127-all the rest of highbury belonged ; but [their]1128-their fortune , from other sources , was such as to make [them]1128-their scarcely secondary to [Donwell Abbey]8-donwell abbey itself , in every other kind of consequence ; and [the Woodhouses]447-the woodhouses had long held a high place in the consideration of [the neighbourhood which [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton had first entered not two years ago , to make [his]95-mr. elton way as [he]95-mr. elton could]1130-the neighbourhood which mr. elton had first entered not two years ago , to make his way as he could , without any alliances but in trade , or any thing to recommend [him]95-mr. elton to notice but [his]95-mr. elton situation and [his]95-mr. elton civility.--But [he]95-mr. elton had fancied [her]1131-i in love with [him]95-mr. elton ; that evidently must have been [his]95-mr. elton dependence ; and after raving a little about the seeming incongruity of gentle manners and a conceited head , [Emma]123-emma was obliged in common honesty to stop and admit that [her]123-emma own behaviour to [him]95-mr. elton had been so complaisant and obliging , so full of courtesy and attention , as ( supposing [her]123-emma real motive unperceived ) might warrant [a man of ordinary observation and delicacy]1132-a man of ordinary observation and delicacy , like [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , in fancying [himself]95-mr. elton [a very decided favourite]1133-a very decided favourite . If _ [she]1131-i _ had so misinterpreted [his]95-mr. elton feelings , [she]1131-i had little right to wonder that _ [he]95-mr. elton _ , with self - interest to blind [him]95-mr. elton , should have mistaken [hers]1131-i .

The first error and the worst lay at [her]1131-i door . It was foolish , it was wrong , to take so active a part in bringing [any two people]1134-any two people together . It was adventuring too far , assuming too much , making light of what ought to be serious , a trick of what ought to be simple . [She]1131-i was quite concerned and ashamed , and resolved to do such things no more .

“ Here have [I]1131-i , ”[1131-i] said [she]1131-i , “ actually talked [poor Harriet]111-harriet into being very much attached to [this man]2957-this man . [She]111-harriet might never have thought of [him]2957-this man but for [me]1131-i ; and certainly never would have thought of [him]2957-this man with hope , if [I]1131-i had not assured [her]111-harriet of [his]2957-this man attachment , for [she]111-harriet is as modest and humble as [I]1131-i used to think [him]2957-this man . Oh ! that [I]1131-i had been satisfied with persuading [her]111-harriet not to accept [young Martin]116-mr. martin . There [I]1131-i was quite right . That was well done of [me]1131-i ; but there [I]1131-i should have stopped , and left the rest to time and chance . [I]1131-i was introducing [her]111-harriet into good company , and giving [her]111-harriet the opportunity of pleasing [some one worth having]3619-some one worth having ; [I]1131-i ought not to have attempted more . But now , [poor girl]3620-poor girl , [her]111-harriet peace is cut up for some time . [I]1131-i have been but half [a friend to [her]111-harriet]3621-a friend to her ; and if [she]111-harriet were _ not _ to feel this disappointment so very much , [I]1131-i am sure [I]1131-i have not an idea of [any body else who would be at all desirable]3622-any body else who would be at all desirable for [her;--William Coxe -- Oh]181-her;--william coxe -- oh ! no , [I]1131-i could not endure [William Coxe]181-her;--william coxe -- oh -- [a pert young lawyer]3623-a pert young lawyer . ”[1131-i]

[She]1135-her stopt to blush and laugh at [her]1135-her own relapse , and then resumed a more serious , more dispiriting cogitation upon what had been , and might be , and must be . The distressing explanation [she]1135-her had to make to [Harriet]111-harriet , and all that poor [Harriet]111-harriet would be suffering , with the awkwardness of future meetings , the difficulties of continuing or discontinuing the acquaintance , of subduing feelings , concealing resentment , and avoiding eclat , were enough to occupy [her]1135-her in most unmirthful reflections some time longer , and [she]1135-her went to bed at last with nothing settled but the conviction of [her]1135-her having blundered most dreadfully .

To youth and natural cheerfulness like [Emma]123-emma 's , though under temporary gloom at night , the return of day will hardly fail to bring return of spirits . The youth and cheerfulness of morning are in happy analogy , and of powerful operation ; and if the distress be not poignant enough to keep the eyes unclosed , they will be sure to open to sensations of softened pain and brighter hope .

[Emma]123-emma got up on the morrow more disposed for comfort than [she]123-emma had gone to bed , more ready to see alleviations of the evil before [her]123-emma , and to depend on getting tolerably out of it .

It was a great consolation that [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton should not be really in love with [her]1135-her , or so particularly amiable as to make it shocking to disappoint [him]95-mr. elton -- that [Harriet]111-harriet 's nature should not be of that superior sort in which the feelings are most acute and retentive -- and that there could be no necessity for [any body]665-any body 's knowing what had passed except [the three principals]1137-the three principals , and especially for [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father 's being given a moment 's uneasiness about it .

These were very cheering thoughts ; and the sight of a great deal of snow on the ground did [her]111-harriet further service , for any thing was welcome that might justify [their]1137-the three principals all three being quite asunder at present .

The weather was most favourable for [her]111-harriet ; though Christmas Day , [she]111-harriet could not go to [church]593-church . [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse would have been miserable had [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter attempted it , and [she]111-harriet was therefore safe from either exciting or receiving unpleasant and most unsuitable ideas . The ground covered with snow , and the atmosphere in that unsettled state between frost and thaw , which is of all others the most unfriendly for exercise , every morning beginning in rain or snow , and every evening setting in to freeze , [she]111-harriet was for many days [a most honourable prisoner]1141-a most honourable prisoner . No intercourse with [Harriet]111-harriet possible but by note ; no church for [her]111-harriet on Sunday any more than on Christmas Day ; and no need to find excuses for [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's absenting [himself]95-mr. elton .

It was weather which might fairly confine every body at [home]562-home ; and though [she]111-harriet hoped and believed [him]95-mr. elton to be really taking comfort in some society or other , it was very pleasant to have [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father so well satisfied with [his]95-mr. elton being all alone in [[his]95-mr. elton own house]1089-his own house , too wise to stir out ; and to hear [him]95-mr. elton say to [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , whom no weather could keep entirely from [them,--]1145-them,--

“ Ah ! [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , why do not [you]92-mr. knightley stay at [home]562-home like [poor Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton ? ”[95-mr. elton]

These days of confinement would have been , but for [her]111-harriet private perplexities , remarkably comfortable , as such seclusion exactly suited [[her]111-harriet brother]482-her brother , whose feelings must always be of great importance to [[his]482-her brother companions]1147-his companions ; and [he]482-her brother had , besides , so thoroughly cleared off [his]482-her brother ill - humour at [Randalls]101-randalls , that [his]482-her brother amiableness never failed [him]482-her brother during the rest of [his]482-her brother stay at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . [He]482-her brother was always agreeable and obliging , and speaking pleasantly of every body . But with all the hopes of cheerfulness , and all the present comfort of delay , there was still such an evil hanging over [her]111-harriet in the hour of explanation with [Harriet]111-harriet , as made it impossible for [Emma]123-emma to be ever perfectly at ease .

CHAPTER XVII

[Mr.]1148-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley were not detained long at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . The weather soon improved enough for [those to move who must move]1149-those to move who must move ; and [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse having , as usual , tried to persuade [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter to stay behind with all [[her]2723-his daughter children]467-her children , was obliged to see [the whole party]1152-the whole party set off , and return to [his]85-mr. woodhouse lamentations over the destiny of [poor Isabella;--which poor [Isabella]87-isabella , passing [her]87-isabella life with those [she]87-isabella doated on , full of [their]1153-their merits , blind to [their]1153-their faults , and always innocently busy]87-isabella , might have been a model of right feminine happiness .

The evening of the very day on which [they]1154-they went brought a note from [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton to [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , a long , civil , ceremonious note , to say , with [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's best compliments , “ that [he]95-mr. elton was proposing to leave [Highbury]3-highbury the following morning in [his]95-mr. elton way to [Bath]30-bath ; where , in compliance with the pressing entreaties of [some friends]3625-some friends , [he]95-mr. elton had engaged to spend a few weeks , and very much regretted the impossibility [he]95-mr. elton was under , from various circumstances of weather and business , of taking a personal leave of [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , of whose friendly civilities [he]95-mr. elton should ever retain a grateful sense -- and had [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse any commands , should be happy to attend to [them]3626-them . ”[95-mr. elton]

[Emma]123-emma was most agreeably surprized.--Mr . [Elton]95-mr. elton 's absence just at this time was the very thing to be desired . [She]123-emma admired [him]95-mr. elton for contriving it , though not able to give [him]95-mr. elton much credit for the manner in which it was announced . [Resentment]182-resentment could not have been more plainly spoken than in a civility to [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , from which [she]123-emma was so pointedly excluded . [She]123-emma had not even a share in [his]95-mr. elton opening compliments.--Her name was not mentioned;--and there was so striking a change in all this , and such an ill - judged solemnity of leave - taking in [his]95-mr. elton graceful acknowledgments , as [she]123-emma thought , at first , could not escape [[her]123-emma father]425-her father 's suspicion .

It did , [however.--Her father]1157-however.--her father was quite taken up with the surprize of so sudden a journey , and [his]1157-however.--her father fears that [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton might never get safely to the end of it , and saw nothing extraordinary in [his]1157-however.--her father language . It was a very useful note , for it supplied [them]1158-them with fresh matter for thought and conversation during the rest of [their]1158-them lonely evening . [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse talked over [his]85-mr. woodhouse alarms , and [Emma]123-emma was in spirits to persuade [them]1158-them away with all [her]123-emma usual promptitude .

[She]123-emma now resolved to keep [Harriet]111-harriet no longer in the dark . [She]123-emma had reason to believe [her]111-harriet nearly recovered from [her]111-harriet cold , and it was desirable that [she]111-harriet should have as much time as possible for getting the better of [her]111-harriet other complaint before [the gentleman]680-the gentleman 's return . [She]123-emma went to [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's accordingly the very next day , to undergo the necessary penance of communication ; and a severe one it was.--She had to destroy all the hopes which [she]123-emma had been so industriously feeding -- to appear in the ungracious character of [the one preferred]1160-the one preferred -- and acknowledge [herself]123-emma grossly mistaken and mis - judging in all [her]123-emma ideas on one subject , all [her]123-emma observations , all [her]123-emma convictions , all [her]123-emma prophecies for the last six weeks .

The confession completely renewed [her]123-emma first shame -- and the sight of [Harriet]111-harriet 's tears made [her]123-emma think that [she]123-emma should never be in charity with [herself]123-emma again .

[Harriet]111-harriet bore the intelligence very well -- blaming [nobody]2718-nobody -- and in every thing testifying such an ingenuousness of disposition and lowly opinion of [herself]111-harriet , as must appear with particular advantage at that moment to [[her]111-harriet friend]427-her friend .

[Emma]123-emma was in the humour to value simplicity and modesty to the utmost ; and all that was amiable , all that ought to be attaching , seemed on [Harriet]111-harriet 's side , not [her]111-harriet own . [Harriet]111-harriet did not consider [herself]111-harriet as having any thing to complain of . The affection of [such a man as [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton]1163-such a man as mr. elton would have been too great a distinction.--She never could have deserved [him]95-mr. elton -- and [nobody but so partial and kind a friend]1164-nobody but so partial and kind a friend as [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse would have thought it possible .

[Her]111-harriet tears fell abundantly -- but [her]111-harriet grief was so truly artless , that no dignity could have made it more respectable in [Emma]123-emma 's eyes -- and [she]123-emma listened to [her]111-harriet and tried to console [her]111-harriet with all [her]123-emma heart and understanding -- really for the time convinced that [Harriet]111-harriet was [the superior creature of the two --]1165-the superior creature of the two -- and that to resemble [her]111-harriet would be more for [her]111-harriet own welfare and happiness than all that genius or intelligence could do .

It was rather too late in the day to set about being simple - minded and ignorant ; but [she]123-emma left [her]111-harriet with every previous resolution confirmed of being humble and discreet , and repressing imagination all the rest of [her]111-harriet life . [Her]111-harriet second duty now , inferior only to [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father 's claims , was to promote [Harriet]111-harriet 's comfort , and endeavour to prove [her]111-harriet own affection in some better method than by match - making . [She]123-emma got [her]111-harriet to [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse , and shewed [her]111-harriet the most unvarying kindness , striving to occupy and amuse [her]111-harriet , and by books and conversation , to drive [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton from [her]111-harriet thoughts .

Time , [she]111-harriet knew , must be allowed for this being thoroughly done ; and [she]111-harriet could suppose [herself]111-harriet but [an indifferent judge of such matters in general]1167-an indifferent judge of such matters in general , and very inadequate to sympathise in an attachment to [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton in particular ; but it seemed to [her]111-harriet reasonable that at [Harriet]111-harriet 's age , and with the entire extinction of all hope , such a progress might be made towards a state of composure by the time of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's return , as to allow [them]1168-them all to meet again in the common routine of acquaintance , without any danger of betraying sentiments or increasing [them]1169-them .

[Harriet]111-harriet did think [him]95-mr. elton all perfection , and maintained the non - existence of any body equal to [him]95-mr. elton in person or goodness -- and did , in truth , prove [herself]111-harriet more resolutely in love than [Emma]123-emma had foreseen ; but yet it appeared to [her]111-harriet so natural , so inevitable to strive against an inclination of that sort _ unrequited _ , that [she]111-harriet could not comprehend its continuing very long in equal force .

If [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , on [his]95-mr. elton return , made [his]95-mr. elton own indifference as evident and indubitable as [she]111-harriet could not doubt [he]95-mr. elton would anxiously do , [she]111-harriet could not imagine [Harriet]111-harriet 's persisting to place [her]111-harriet happiness in the sight or the recollection of [him]95-mr. elton .

[Their]1168-them being fixed , so absolutely fixed , in the same place , was bad for each , for all three . Not one of [them]1168-them had the power of removal , or of effecting any material change of society . [They]1168-them must encounter [each other]430-each other , and make the best of it .

[Harriet]111-harriet was farther unfortunate in the tone of [[her]111-harriet companions]1171-her companions at [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's ; [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton being the adoration of all [the teachers]641-the teachers and [great girls in [the school]643-the school]1173-great girls in the school ; and it must be at [Hartfield]2-hartfield only that [she]111-harriet could have any chance of hearing [him]95-mr. elton spoken of with cooling moderation or repellent truth . Where the wound had been given , there must the cure be found if anywhere ; and [Emma]123-emma felt that , till [she]123-emma saw [her]111-harriet in the way of cure , there could be no true peace for [herself]123-emma .

CHAPTER XVIII

[Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill did not come . When the time proposed drew near , [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's fears were justified in the arrival of a letter of excuse . For the present , [he]102-frank churchill could not be spared , to [his]102-frank churchill “ very great mortification and regret ; but still [he]102-frank churchill looked forward with the hope of coming to [Randalls]101-randalls at no distant period . ”[88-mrs. weston]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was exceedingly disappointed -- much more disappointed , in fact , than [[her]88-mrs. weston husband]441-her husband , though [her]88-mrs. weston dependence on seeing [the young man]532-the young man had been so much more sober : but a sanguine temper , though for ever expecting more good than occurs , does not always pay for its hopes by any proportionate depression . [It]1177-it soon flies over the present failure , and begins to hope again . For half an hour [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston was surprized and sorry ; but then [he]86-mr. weston began to perceive that [Frank]102-frank churchill 's coming two or three months later would be a much better plan ; better time of year ; better weather ; and that [he]86-mr. weston would be able , without any doubt , to stay considerably longer with [them]1178-their than if [he]86-mr. weston had come sooner .

These feelings rapidly restored [his]102-frank churchill comfort , while [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , of a more apprehensive disposition , foresaw nothing but a repetition of excuses and delays ; and after all [her]88-mrs. weston concern for what [[her]88-mrs. weston husband]441-her husband was to suffer , suffered a great deal more [herself]88-mrs. weston .

[Emma]123-emma was not at this time in a state of spirits to care really about [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's not coming , except as a disappointment at [Randalls]101-randalls . [The acquaintance]1180-the acquaintance at present had no charm for [her]123-emma . [She]123-emma wanted , rather , to be quiet , and out of temptation ; but still , as it was desirable that [she]123-emma should appear , in general , like [her]123-emma usual self , [she]123-emma took care to express as much interest in the circumstance , and enter as warmly into [Mr.]1181-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's disappointment , as might naturally belong to [their]1178-their friendship .

[She]123-emma was the first to announce it to [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; and exclaimed quite as much as was necessary , ( or , being acting a part , perhaps rather more , ) at the conduct of [the Churchills]100-the churchills , in keeping [him]102-frank churchill away . [She]123-emma then proceeded to say a good deal more than [she]123-emma felt , of the advantage of such an addition to [their]1178-their confined society in [Surry]31-surry ; the pleasure of looking at [somebody new]1182-somebody new ; the gala - day to [Highbury]3-highbury entire , which the sight of [him]102-frank churchill would have made ; and ending with reflections on [the Churchills]100-the churchills again , found [herself]123-emma directly involved in a disagreement with [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; and , to [her]123-emma great amusement , perceived that [she]123-emma was taking the other side of the question from [her]123-emma real opinion , and making use of [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's arguments against [herself]123-emma .

“ [The Churchills]100-the churchills are very likely in fault , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , coolly ; “ but [I]92-mr. knightley dare say [he]102-frank churchill might come if [he]102-frank churchill would . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]123-emma do not know why [you]123-emma should say so . [He]102-frank churchill wishes exceedingly to come ; but [[his]102-frank churchill uncle]517-his uncle and [aunt]3628-aunt will not spare [him]102-frank churchill . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley can not believe that [he]102-frank churchill has not the power of coming , if [he]102-frank churchill made a point of it . It is too unlikely , for [me]92-mr. knightley to believe it without proof . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ How odd [you]123-emma are ! What has [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill done , to make [you]92-mr. knightley suppose [him]102-frank churchill such [an unnatural creature]3629-an unnatural creature ? ”[123-emma]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley am not supposing [him]102-frank churchill at all [an unnatural creature]3629-an unnatural creature , in suspecting that [he]102-frank churchill may have learnt to be above [his]102-frank churchill connexions , and to care very little for any thing but [his]102-frank churchill own pleasure , from living with those who have always set [him]102-frank churchill the example of it . It is a great deal more natural than [one]2775-one could wish , that [a young man]2853-a young man , brought up by [those who are proud , luxurious , and selfish]3633-those who are proud , luxurious , and selfish , should be proud , luxurious , and selfish too . If [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had wanted to see [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father , [he]102-frank churchill would have contrived it between September and January . [A man at [his]3635-a man at his age age]3635-a man at his age -- what is [he?--three]3636-he?--three or four - and - twenty -- cannot be without the means of doing as much as that . It is impossible . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ That 's easily said , and easily felt by [you]92-mr. knightley , who have always been [[your]92-mr. knightley own master]3637-your own master . [You]92-mr. knightley are [the worst judge in [the world]403-the world]3638-the worst judge in the world , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , of the difficulties of dependence . [You]92-mr. knightley do not know what it is to have tempers to manage . ”[123-emma]

“ It is not to be conceived that [a man of three or four - and - twenty]3640-a man of three or four - and - twenty should not have liberty of mind or limb to that amount . [He]102-frank churchill can not want money -- [he]102-frank churchill can not want leisure . [We]3641-we know , on the contrary , that [he]102-frank churchill has so much of both , that [he]102-frank churchill is glad to get rid of [them]3642-them at [the idlest haunts in [the kingdom]3644-the kingdom]3643-the idlest haunts in the kingdom . [We]3641-we hear of [him]102-frank churchill for ever at [some watering - place]3645-some watering - place or other . A little while ago , [he]102-frank churchill was at [Weymouth]23-weymouth . This proves that [he]102-frank churchill can leave [the Churchills]100-the churchills . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Yes , sometimes [he]102-frank churchill can . ”[123-emma]

“ And those times are whenever [he]102-frank churchill thinks it worth [his]102-frank churchill while ; whenever there is any temptation of pleasure . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ It is very unfair to judge of [any body]665-any body 's conduct , without an intimate knowledge of [their]665-any body situation . [[Nobody]2718-nobody , who has not been in the interior of [a family]3649-a family]3648-nobody , who has not been in the interior of a family , can say what the difficulties of [any individual of that family]3650-any individual of that family may be . [We]3641-we ought to be acquainted with [Enscombe]7-enscombe , and with [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill 's temper , before [we]3641-we pretend to decide upon what [[her]98-mrs. churchill nephew]3651-her nephew can do . [He]102-frank churchill may , at times , be able to do a great deal more than [he]102-frank churchill can at [others]2773-others . ”[123-emma]

“ There is one thing , [Emma]123-emma , which [a man]2840-a man can always do , if [he]2840-a man chuses , and that is , [his]2840-a man duty ; not by manoeuvring and finessing , but by vigour and resolution . It is [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's duty to pay this attention to [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father . [He]102-frank churchill knows it to be so , by [his]102-frank churchill promises and messages ; but if [he]102-frank churchill wished to do it , it might be done . [A man who felt rightly]3655-a man who felt rightly would say at once , simply and resolutely , to [Mrs. Churchill--'Every]183-mrs. churchill--'every sacrifice of mere pleasure [you]123-emma will always find [me]92-mr. knightley ready to make to [your]123-emma convenience ; but [I]92-mr. knightley must go and see [[my]92-mr. knightley father]2740-my father immediately . [I]92-mr. knightley know [he]2740-my father would be hurt by [my]92-mr. knightley failing in such a mark of respect to [him]2740-my father on the present occasion . [I]92-mr. knightley shall , therefore , set off to - morrow . '--If [he]2740-my father would say so to [her]183-mrs. churchill--'every at once , in the tone of decision becoming [a man]2840-a man , there would be no opposition made to [his]2740-my father going . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ No , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , laughing ; “ but perhaps there might be some made to [his]2740-my father coming back again . Such language for [a young man]2853-a young man entirely dependent , to use!--Nobody but [you]123-emma , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , would imagine it possible . But [you]123-emma have not an idea of what is requisite in situations directly opposite to [your]123-emma own . [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill to be making such a speech as that to [the uncle]2765-the uncle and aunt , who have brought [him]2740-my father up , and are to provide for him!--Standing up in the middle of [the room]701-the room , [I]123-emma suppose , and speaking as loud as [he]2740-my father could!--How can [you]123-emma imagine such conduct practicable ? ”[123-emma]

“ Depend upon it , [Emma]123-emma , [a sensible man]2966-a sensible man would find no difficulty in it . [He]2966-a sensible man would feel [himself]2966-a sensible man in the right ; and the declaration -- made , of course , as [a man of sense]3662-a man of sense would make it , in a proper manner -- would do [him]2966-a sensible man more good , raise [him]2966-a sensible man higher , fix [his]2966-a sensible man interest stronger with [the people [he]2966-a sensible man depended on]3663-the people he depended on , than all that a line of shifts and expedients can ever do . Respect would be added to affection . [They]3663-the people he depended on would feel that [they]3663-the people he depended on could trust [him]2966-a sensible man ; that [the nephew who had done rightly by [[his]2966-a sensible man father]518-his father , would do rightly by [them]3663-the people he depended on]3664-the nephew who had done rightly by his father , would do rightly by them ; for [they]3663-the people he depended on know , as well as [he]2966-a sensible man does , as well as all [the world]403-the world must know , that [he]2966-a sensible man ought to pay this visit to [[his]2966-a sensible man father]518-his father ; and while meanly exerting [their]3663-the people he depended on power to delay it , are in [their]3663-the people he depended on hearts not thinking the better of [him]2966-a sensible man for submitting to [their]3663-the people he depended on whims . Respect for right conduct is felt by every body . If [he]2966-a sensible man would act in this sort of manner , on principle , consistently , regularly , [their]3663-the people he depended on little minds would bend to [his]2966-a sensible man . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]123-emma rather doubt that . [You]123-emma are very fond of bending little minds ; but where little minds belong to [rich people in authority]3668-rich people in authority , [I]123-emma think [they]3668-rich people in authority have a knack of swelling out , till [they]3668-rich people in authority are quite as unmanageable as [great ones]3669-great ones . [I]123-emma can imagine , that if [you]123-emma , as [you]123-emma are , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , were to be transported and placed all at once in [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's situation , [you]123-emma would be able to say and do just what [you]123-emma have been recommending for [him]102-frank churchill ; and it might have a very good effect . [The Churchills]100-the churchills might not have a word to say in return ; but then , [you]123-emma would have no habits of early obedience and long observance to break through . To [him]102-frank churchill who has , it might not be so easy to burst forth at once into perfect independence , and set all [their]3663-the people he depended on claims on [his]102-frank churchill gratitude and regard at nought . [He]102-frank churchill may have as strong a sense of what would be right , as [you]123-emma can have , without being so equal , under particular circumstances , to act up to it . ”[123-emma]

“ Then it would not be so strong a sense . If it failed to produce equal exertion , it could not be an equal conviction . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Oh , the difference of situation and habit ! [I]123-emma wish [you]123-emma would try to understand what [an amiable young man]3670-an amiable young man may be likely to feel in directly opposing those , whom as [child]3671-child and [boy]3672-boy [he]3670-an amiable young man has been looking up to all [his]3670-an amiable young man life . ”[123-emma]

“ [[Our]3673-their amiable young man]3674-our amiable young man is [a very weak young man]3675-a very weak young man , if this be the first occasion of [his]3674-our amiable young man carrying through a resolution to do right against the will of [others]2773-others . It ought to have been a habit with [him]102-frank churchill by this time , of following [his]102-frank churchill duty , instead of consulting expediency . [I]92-mr. knightley can allow for the fears of [the child]498-the child , but not of [the man]3033-the man . As [he]102-frank churchill became rational , [he]102-frank churchill ought to have roused [himself]102-frank churchill and shaken off all that was unworthy in [their]3673-their authority . [He]102-frank churchill ought to have opposed the first attempt on [their]3673-their side to make [him]102-frank churchill slight [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father . Had [he]102-frank churchill begun as [he]102-frank churchill ought , there would have been no difficulty now . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [We]3673-their shall never agree about [him]102-frank churchill , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma ; “ but that is nothing extraordinary . [I]123-emma have not the least idea of [his]102-frank churchill being [a weak young man]3680-a weak young man : [I]123-emma feel sure that [he]102-frank churchill is not . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston would not be blind to folly , though in [[his]86-mr. weston own son]3681-his own son ; but [he]102-frank churchill is very likely to have a more yielding , complying , mild disposition than would suit [your]123-emma notions of [man]774-man 's perfection . [I]123-emma dare say [he]102-frank churchill has ; and though it may cut [him]102-frank churchill off from some advantages , it will secure [him]102-frank churchill many others . ”[123-emma]

“ Yes ; all the advantages of sitting still when [he]102-frank churchill ought to move , and of leading a life of mere idle pleasure , and fancying [himself]102-frank churchill extremely expert in finding excuses for it . [He]102-frank churchill can sit down and write a fine flourishing letter , full of professions and falsehoods , and persuade [himself]102-frank churchill that [he]102-frank churchill has hit upon the very best method in the world of preserving peace at [home]562-home and preventing [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father 's having any right to complain . [His]102-frank churchill letters disgust [me]92-mr. knightley . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [Your]123-emma feelings are singular . They seem to satisfy every body else . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley suspect they do not satisfy [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . [They]3685-they hardly can satisfy [a woman]2864-a woman of [her]2864-a woman good sense and quick feelings : standing in [a mother]413-a mother 's place , but without [a mother]413-a mother 's affection to blind [her]2864-a woman . It is on [her]88-mrs. weston account that attention to [Randalls]101-randalls is doubly due , and [she]88-mrs. weston must doubly feel the omission . Had [she]88-mrs. weston been [a person of consequence]3689-a person of consequence [herself]88-mrs. weston , [he]102-frank churchill would have come [I]92-mr. knightley dare say ; and it would not have signified whether [he]102-frank churchill did or no . Can [you]123-emma think [[your]123-emma friend]2922-your friend behindhand in these sort of considerations ? Do [you]123-emma suppose [she]2922-your friend does not often say all this to [herself]2922-your friend ? No , [Emma]123-emma , [[your]123-emma amiable young man]3691-your amiable young man can be amiable only in French , not in English . [He]102-frank churchill may be very ' amiable , ' have very good manners , and be very agreeable ; but [he]102-frank churchill can have no English delicacy towards the feelings of [other people]456-other people : nothing really amiable about [him]102-frank churchill . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [You]92-mr. knightley seem determined to think ill of [him]102-frank churchill . ”[123-emma]

“ [Me!--not]92-mr. knightley at all , ”[92-mr. knightley] replied [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , rather displeased ; “ [I]92-mr. knightley do not want to think ill of [him]102-frank churchill . [I]92-mr. knightley should be as ready to acknowledge [his]102-frank churchill merits as [any other man]3693-any other man ; but [I]92-mr. knightley hear of none , except what are merely personal ; that [he]102-frank churchill is well - grown and good - looking , with smooth , plausible manners . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Well , if [he]102-frank churchill have nothing else to recommend [him]102-frank churchill , [he]102-frank churchill will be [a treasure at [Highbury]3-highbury]3694-a treasure at highbury . [We]3695-we do not often look upon [fine young men]3696-fine young men , well - bred and agreeable . [We]3695-we must not be nice and ask for all the virtues into the bargain . Can not [you]92-mr. knightley imagine , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , what a _ sensation _ [his]102-frank churchill coming will produce ? There will be but one subject throughout [the parishes of [Donwell]24-donwell and [Highbury]3-highbury]3697-the parishes of donwell and highbury ; but one interest -- one object of curiosity ; it will be all [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill ; [we]3695-we shall think and speak of [nobody else]3698-nobody else . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]92-mr. knightley will excuse [my]92-mr. knightley being so much over - powered . If [I]92-mr. knightley find [him]102-frank churchill conversable , [I]92-mr. knightley shall be glad of [his]102-frank churchill acquaintance ; but if [he]102-frank churchill is only [a chattering coxcomb]3699-a chattering coxcomb , [he]102-frank churchill will not occupy much of [my]92-mr. knightley time or thoughts . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [My]123-emma idea of [him]102-frank churchill is , that [he]102-frank churchill can adapt [his]102-frank churchill conversation to the taste of every body , and has the power as well as the wish of being universally agreeable . To [you]92-mr. knightley , [he]102-frank churchill will talk of farming ; to [me]123-emma , of drawing or music ; and so on to every body , having that general information on all subjects which will enable [him]102-frank churchill to follow the lead , or take the lead , just as propriety may require , and to speak extremely well on each ; that is [my]123-emma idea of [him]102-frank churchill . ”[123-emma]

“ And [mine]123-emma , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley warmly , “ is , that if [he]102-frank churchill turn out any thing like it , [he]102-frank churchill will be [the most insufferable fellow]3700-the most insufferable fellow breathing ! What ! at three - and - twenty to be [the king of [[his]102-frank churchill company]3702-his company]3701-the king of his company -- [the great man]3703-the great man -- [the practised politician]3704-the practised politician , who is to read every body 's character , and make every body 's talents conduce to the display of [his]102-frank churchill own superiority ; to be dispensing [his]102-frank churchill flatteries around , that [he]102-frank churchill may make all appear like fools compared with [himself]102-frank churchill ! [My]92-mr. knightley dear [Emma]123-emma , [your]123-emma own good sense could not endure such a puppy when it came to the point . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]123-emma will say no more about [him]102-frank churchill , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , “ [you]123-emma turn every thing to evil . [We]3705-we are both prejudiced ; [you]123-emma against , [I]123-emma for [him]102-frank churchill ; and [we]3705-we have no chance of agreeing till [he]102-frank churchill is really here . ”[123-emma]

“ Prejudiced ! [I]92-mr. knightley am not prejudiced . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ But [I]123-emma am very much , and without being at all ashamed of it . [My]123-emma love for [Mr.]3706-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston gives [me]123-emma a decided prejudice in [his]102-frank churchill favour . ”[123-emma]

“ [He]102-frank churchill is a person [I]92-mr. knightley never think of from one month 's end to another , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , with a degree of vexation , which made [Emma]123-emma immediately talk of something else , though [she]123-emma could not comprehend why [he]92-mr. knightley should be angry .

To take a dislike to [a young man]2853-a young man , only because [he]2853-a young man appeared to be of a different disposition from [himself]2853-a young man , was unworthy the real liberality of mind which [she]123-emma was always used to acknowledge in [him]2853-a young man ; for with all the high opinion of [himself]2853-a young man , which [she]123-emma had often laid to [his]2853-a young man charge , [she]123-emma had never before for a moment supposed it could make [him]2853-a young man unjust to the merit of another .

VOLUME II

CHAPTER I

[Emma]123-emma and [Harriet]111-harriet had been walking together one morning , and , in [Emma]123-emma 's opinion , had been talking enough of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton for that day . [She]123-emma could not think that [Harriet]111-harriet 's solace or [her]111-harriet own sins required more ; and [she]123-emma was therefore industriously getting rid of the subject as [they]1184-them returned;--but it burst out again when [she]123-emma thought [she]123-emma had succeeded , and after speaking some time of what [the poor]853-the poor must suffer in winter , and receiving no other answer than a very plaintive--“Mr . [Elton]95-mr. elton is so good to [the poor]853-the poor ! ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma found something else must be done .

[They]1184-them were just approaching [the house where lived [Mrs.]1187-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates]1186-the house where lived mrs. and miss bates . [She]123-emma determined to call upon [them]1184-them and seek safety in numbers . There was always sufficient reason for such an attention ; [Mrs.]1188-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates loved to be called on , and [she]123-emma knew [she]123-emma was considered by [the very few who presumed ever to see imperfection in [her]123-emma , as rather negligent in that respect , and as not contributing what [she]123-emma ought to the stock of [their]1184-them scanty comforts]1189-the very few who presumed ever to see imperfection in her , as rather negligent in that respect , and as not contributing what she ought to the stock of their scanty comforts .

[She]123-emma had had many a hint from [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley and some from [her]123-emma own heart , as to [her]123-emma deficiency -- but none were equal to counteract the persuasion of its being very disagreeable,--a waste of time -- [tiresome women]1190-tiresome women -- and all the horror of being in danger of falling in with [the second - rate and third - rate of [Highbury]3-highbury]1191-the second - rate and third - rate of highbury , who were calling on [them]1184-them for ever , and therefore [she]123-emma seldom went near [them]1184-them . But now [she]123-emma made the sudden resolution of not passing [their]1184-them door without going in -- observing , as [she]123-emma proposed it to [Harriet]111-harriet , that , as well as [she]123-emma could calculate , [they]1184-them were just now quite safe from any letter from [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax .

[The house]435-the house belonged to [people in business]1193-people in business . [Mrs.]1194-mrs. and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates occupied [the drawing - room floor]1195-the drawing - room floor ; and there , in [the very moderate - sized apartment , which was every thing to [them]1184-them]1196-the very moderate - sized apartment , which was every thing to them , [the visitors]1197-the visitors were most cordially and even gratefully welcomed ; [the quiet neat old lady , who with [her]1198-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up [her]1198-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse place to [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse]1198-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse , and [[her]1198-the quiet neat old lady , who with her knitting was seated in the warmest corner , wanting even to give up her place to miss woodhouse more active , talking daughter]1199-her more active , talking daughter , almost ready to overpower [them]1184-them with care and kindness , thanks for [their]1184-them visit , solicitude for [their]1184-them shoes , anxious inquiries after [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's health , cheerful communications about [[her]1199-her more active , talking daughter mother]410-her mother 's , and sweet - cake from the beaufet--“Mrs . [Cole]145-mr. cole had just been [there]448-there , just called in for ten minutes , and had been so good as to sit an hour with [them]1184-them , and _ [she]1199-her more active , talking daughter _ had taken a piece of cake and been so kind as to say [she]1199-her more active , talking daughter liked it very much ; and , therefore , [she]1199-her more active , talking daughter hoped [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse and [Miss Smith]111-harriet would do [them]1184-them the favour to eat a piece too . ”[95-mr. elton]

The mention of [the Coles]184-the coles was sure to be followed by that of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton . There was intimacy between [them]1184-them , and [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole had heard from [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton since [his]95-mr. elton going away . [Emma]123-emma knew what was coming ; [they]1184-them must have the letter over again , and settle how long [he]95-mr. elton had been gone , and how much [he]95-mr. elton was engaged in company , and what a favourite [he]95-mr. elton was wherever [he]95-mr. elton went , and how full [the Master of the Ceremonies]1201-the master of the ceremonies ' ball had been ; and [she]123-emma went through it very well , with all the interest and all the commendation that could be requisite , and always putting forward to prevent [Harriet]111-harriet 's being obliged to say a word .

This [she]123-emma had been prepared for when [she]123-emma entered [the house]435-the house ; but meant , having once talked [him]95-mr. elton handsomely over , to be no farther incommoded by any troublesome topic , and to wander at large amongst all [the Mistresses and Misses of [Highbury]3-highbury]1203-the mistresses and misses of highbury , and [their]1203-the mistresses and misses of highbury card - parties . [She]123-emma had not been prepared to have [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax succeed [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton ; but [he]95-mr. elton was actually hurried off by [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , [she]123-emma jumped away from [him]95-mr. elton at last abruptly to [the Coles]184-the coles , to usher in a letter from [[her]123-emma niece]1204-her niece .

“ Oh ! yes -- [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , [I]123-emma understand -- certainly as to dancing -- [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole was telling [me]123-emma that dancing at [the rooms at Bath]3709-the rooms at bath was -- [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole was so kind as to sit some time with [us]3710-us , talking of [Jane]105-miss bates ; for as soon as [she]185-mrs. cole came in , [she]185-mrs. cole began inquiring after [her]185-mrs. cole , [Jane]105-miss bates is so very great a favourite [there]448-there . Whenever [she]185-mrs. cole is with [us]3710-us , [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole does not know how to shew [her]185-mrs. cole kindness enough ; and [I]123-emma must say that [Jane]105-miss bates deserves it as much as [any body]665-any body can . And so [she]185-mrs. cole began inquiring after [her]185-mrs. cole directly , saying , ' [I]123-emma know [you]185-mrs. cole can not have heard from [Jane]105-miss bates lately , because it is not [her]105-miss bates time for writing ; ' and when [I]123-emma immediately said , ' But indeed [we]3710-us have , [we]3710-us had a letter this very morning , ' [I]123-emma do not know that [I]123-emma ever saw [any body more surprized]3713-any body more surprized . ' Have [you]185-mrs. cole , upon [your]185-mrs. cole honour ? ' said [she]185-mrs. cole ; ' well , that is quite unexpected . Do let [me]123-emma hear what [she]105-miss bates says . ' ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma 's politeness was at hand directly , to say , with smiling interest--

“ Have [you]185-mrs. cole heard from [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax so lately ? [I]123-emma am extremely happy . [I]123-emma hope [she]152-miss fairfax is well ? ”[123-emma]

“ Thank [you]185-mrs. cole . [You]185-mrs. cole are so kind ! ”[1205-the happily deceived aunt] replied [the happily deceived aunt]1205-the happily deceived aunt , while eagerly hunting for the letter.--“Oh ! here it is . [I]123-emma was sure it could not be far off ; but [I]123-emma had put [my]123-emma huswife upon it , [you]3714-you see , without being aware , and so it was quite hid , but [I]123-emma had it in [my]123-emma hand so very lately that [I]123-emma was almost sure it must be on the table . [I]123-emma was reading it to [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole , and since [she]185-mrs. cole went away , [I]123-emma was reading it again to [[my]123-emma mother]3715-my mother , for it is such a pleasure to [her]3715-my mother -- a letter from [Jane]152-miss fairfax -- that [she]3715-my mother can never hear it often enough ; so [I]123-emma knew it could not be far off , and here it is , only just under [my]123-emma huswife -- and since [you]3714-you are so kind as to wish to hear what [she]3715-my mother says;--but , first of all , [I]123-emma really must , in justice to [Jane]152-miss fairfax , apologise for [her]152-miss fairfax writing so short a letter -- only two pages [you]3714-you see -- hardly two -- and in general [she]152-miss fairfax fills the whole paper and crosses half . [[My]123-emma mother]3715-my mother often wonders that [I]123-emma can make it out so well . [She]3715-my mother often says , when the letter is first opened , ' Well , [Hetty]186-hetty , now [I]123-emma think [you]186-hetty will be put to it to make out all that checker - work'--don't [you]186-hetty , ma'am?--And then [I]123-emma tell [her]3715-my mother , [I]123-emma am sure [she]3715-my mother would contrive to make it out [herself]3715-my mother , if [she]3715-my mother had [nobody]2718-nobody to do it for [her]3715-my mother -- every word of it -- [I]123-emma am sure [she]3715-my mother would pore over it till [she]3715-my mother had made out every word . And , indeed , though [[my]123-emma mother]3715-my mother 's eyes are not so good as they were , [she]3715-my mother can see amazingly well still , thank [God]187-good god ! with the help of spectacles . It is such a blessing ! [[My]123-emma mother]3715-my mother 's are really very good indeed . [Jane]152-miss fairfax often says , when [she]152-miss fairfax is here , ' [I]123-emma am sure , [grandmama]3720-grandmama , [you]3720-grandmama must have had very strong eyes to see as [you]3720-grandmama do -- and so much fine work as [you]3720-grandmama have done too!--I only wish [my]123-emma eyes may last [me]123-emma as well . ' ”[123-emma]

All this spoken extremely fast obliged [Miss Bates]105-miss bates to stop for breath ; and [Emma]123-emma said something very civil about the excellence of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's handwriting .

“ [You]3720-grandmama are extremely kind , ”[105-miss bates] replied [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , highly gratified ; “ [you]3720-grandmama who are such [a judge , and write so beautifully]3721-a judge , and write so beautifully [yourself]3720-grandmama . [I]105-miss bates am sure there is [nobody]2718-nobody 's praise that could give [us]3723-us so much pleasure as [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse 's . [[My]105-miss bates mother]3715-my mother does not hear ; [she]3715-my mother is a little deaf [you]3720-grandmama know . [Ma'am]188-ma'am , ”[105-miss bates] addressing [her]123-emma , “ do [you]123-emma hear what [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse is so obliging to say about [Jane]105-miss bates 's handwriting ? ”[105-miss bates]

And [Emma]123-emma had the advantage of hearing [her]123-emma own silly compliment repeated twice over before [the good old lady]1206-the good old lady could comprehend it . [She]123-emma was pondering , in the meanwhile , upon the possibility , without seeming very rude , of making [her]123-emma escape from [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's letter , and had almost resolved on hurrying away directly under some slight excuse , when [Miss Bates]105-miss bates turned to [her]123-emma again and seized [her]123-emma attention .

“ [[My]105-miss bates mother]3715-my mother 's deafness is very trifling [you]3720-grandmama see -- just nothing at all . By only raising [my]105-miss bates voice , and saying any thing two or three times over , [she]3715-my mother is sure to hear ; but then [she]3715-my mother is used to [my]105-miss bates voice . But it is very remarkable that [she]3715-my mother should always hear [Jane]105-miss bates better than [she]3715-my mother does [me]105-miss bates . [Jane]105-miss bates speaks so distinct ! However , [she]105-miss bates will not find [[her]105-miss bates grandmama]819-her grandmama at all deafer than [she]105-miss bates was two years ago ; which is saying a great deal at [[my]105-miss bates mother]3715-my mother 's time of life -- and it really is full two years , [you]3720-grandmama know , since [she]105-miss bates was [here]2707-here . [We]3729-we never were so long without seeing [her]105-miss bates before , and as [I]105-miss bates was telling [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole , [we]3729-we shall hardly know how to make enough of [her]105-miss bates now . ”[105-miss bates]

“ Are [you]105-miss bates expecting [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax [here]2707-here soon ? ”[1207-i]

“ Oh yes ; next week . ”[105-miss bates]

“ [Indeed!--that]189-indeed!--that must be a very great pleasure . ”[1207-i]

“ Thank [you]105-miss bates . [You]3720-grandmama are very kind . Yes , next week . [Every body]2749-every body is so surprized ; and [every body]2749-every body says the same obliging things . [I]105-miss bates am sure [she]105-miss bates will be as happy to see [[her]105-miss bates friends]3093-her friends at [Highbury]3-highbury , as [they]3093-her friends can be to see [her]105-miss bates . Yes , Friday or Saturday ; [she]105-miss bates can not say which , because [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell will be wanting [the carriage]2719-the carriage [himself]164-colonel campbell one of those days . So very good of [them]3093-her friends to send [her]105-miss bates the whole way ! But [they]3093-her friends always do , [you]3720-grandmama know . Oh yes , Friday or Saturday next . That is what [she]105-miss bates writes about . That is the reason of [her]105-miss bates writing out of rule , as [we]3735-we call it ; for , in the common course , [we]3735-we should not have heard from [her]105-miss bates before next Tuesday or Wednesday . ”[105-miss bates]

“ Yes , so [I]1207-i imagined . [I]1207-i was afraid there could be little chance of [my]1207-i hearing any thing of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax to - day . ”[1207-i]

“ So obliging of [you]3720-grandmama ! No , [we]3735-we should not have heard , if it had not been for this particular circumstance , of [her]105-miss bates being to come here so soon . [[My]105-miss bates mother]3715-my mother is so delighted!--for [she]3715-my mother is to be three months with [us]3735-we at least . Three months , [she]3715-my mother says so , positively , as [I]105-miss bates am going to have the pleasure of reading to [you]3720-grandmama . The case is , [you]3720-grandmama see , that [the Campbells]190-the campbells are going to [Ireland]32-ireland . [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon has persuaded [[her]191-mrs. dixon father]425-her father and [mother]3738-mother to come over and see [her]191-mrs. dixon directly . [They]190-the campbells had not intended to go over till the summer , but [she]191-mrs. dixon is so impatient to see [them]190-the campbells again -- for till [she]191-mrs. dixon married , last October , [she]191-mrs. dixon was never away from [them]190-the campbells so much as a week , which must make it very strange to be in [different kingdoms]3739-different kingdoms , [I]105-miss bates was going to say , but [however different countries]3740-however different countries , and so [she]191-mrs. dixon wrote a very urgent letter to [[her]191-mrs. dixon mother]410-her mother -- or [[her]191-mrs. dixon father]425-her father , [I]105-miss bates declare [I]105-miss bates do not know which it was , but [we]3743-we shall see presently in [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's letter -- wrote in [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon 's name as well as [her]152-miss fairfax own , to press [their]190-the campbells coming over directly , and [they]190-the campbells would give [them]190-the campbells the meeting in [Dublin]33-dublin , and take [them]190-the campbells back to [[their]190-the campbells country seat]3744-their country seat , [Baly - craig]34-baly - craig , [a beautiful place]3745-a beautiful place , [I]105-miss bates fancy . [Jane]152-miss fairfax has heard a great deal of its beauty ; from [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , [I]105-miss bates mean -- [I]105-miss bates do not know that [she]152-miss fairfax ever heard about it from any body else ; but it was very natural , [you]3746-you know , that [he]192-mr. dixon should like to speak of [[his]192-mr. dixon own place]3747-his own place while [he]192-mr. dixon was paying [his]192-mr. dixon addresses -- and as [Jane]152-miss fairfax used to be very often walking out with [them]190-the campbells -- for [Colonel]164-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell were very particular about [[their]190-the campbells daughter]3438-their daughter 's not walking out often with only [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , for which [I]105-miss bates do not at all blame [them]190-the campbells ; of course [she]152-miss fairfax heard every thing [he]192-mr. dixon might be telling [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell about [[his]192-mr. dixon own home in [Ireland]32-ireland]3749-his own home in ireland ; and [I]105-miss bates think [she]152-miss fairfax wrote [us]3750-us word that [he]192-mr. dixon had shewn [them]190-the campbells some drawings of [the place]450-the place , views that [he]192-mr. dixon had taken [himself]192-mr. dixon . [He]192-mr. dixon is [a most amiable , charming young man]3752-a most amiable , charming young man , [I]105-miss bates believe . [Jane]152-miss fairfax was quite longing to go to [Ireland]32-ireland , from [his]192-mr. dixon account of things . ”[105-miss bates]

At this moment , an ingenious and animating suspicion entering [Emma]123-emma 's brain with regard to [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , this charming [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , and the not going to [Ireland]32-ireland , [she]1207-i said , with the insidious design of farther discovery ,

“ [You]192-mr. dixon must feel it very fortunate that [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax should be allowed to come to [you]192-mr. dixon at such a time . Considering the very particular friendship between [her]152-miss fairfax and [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon , [you]192-mr. dixon could hardly have expected [her]152-miss fairfax to be excused from accompanying [Colonel]3753-colonel and [Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell . ”[1207-i]

“ Very true , very true , indeed . The very thing that [we]3754-we have always been rather afraid of ; for [we]3754-we should not have liked to have [her]152-miss fairfax at such a distance from [us]3754-we , for months together -- not able to come if any thing was to happen . But [you]192-mr. dixon see , every thing turns out for the best . [They]3755-they want [her]152-miss fairfax ( [Mr.]3756-mr. and [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon ) excessively to come over with [Colonel]164-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell ; quite depend upon it ; nothing can be more kind or pressing than [their]3755-they _ joint _ invitation , [Jane]152-miss fairfax says , as [you]192-mr. dixon will hear presently ; [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon does not seem in the least backward in any attention . [He]192-mr. dixon is [a most charming young man]3757-a most charming young man . Ever since the service [he]192-mr. dixon rendered [Jane]152-miss fairfax at [Weymouth]23-weymouth , when [they]3755-they were out in that party on [the water]3758-the water , and [she]152-miss fairfax , by the sudden whirling round of something or other among the sails , would have been dashed into [the sea]3383-the sea at once , and actually was all but gone , if [he]192-mr. dixon had not , with the greatest presence of mind , caught hold of [her]152-miss fairfax habit-- ( [I]1207-i can never think of it without trembling!)--But ever since [we]3755-they had the history of that day , [I]1207-i have been so fond of [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon ! ”[1207-i]

“ But , in spite of all [[her]152-miss fairfax friends]3093-her friends ' urgency , and [her]152-miss fairfax own wish of seeing [Ireland]32-ireland , [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax prefers devoting the time to [you]192-mr. dixon and [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates ? ”[1207-i]

“ Yes -- entirely [her]152-miss fairfax own doing , entirely [her]152-miss fairfax own choice ; and [Colonel]164-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell think [she]152-miss fairfax does quite right , just what [they]3093-her friends should recommend ; and indeed [they]3093-her friends particularly _ wish _ [her]152-miss fairfax to try [her]152-miss fairfax native air , as [she]152-miss fairfax has not been quite so well as usual lately . ”[1207-i]

“ [I]1207-i am concerned to hear of it . [I]1207-i think [they]3093-her friends judge wisely . But [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon must be very much disappointed . [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon , [I]1207-i understand , has no remarkable degree of personal beauty ; is not , by any means , to be compared with [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . ”[1207-i]

“ Oh ! no . [You]192-mr. dixon are very obliging to say such things -- but certainly not . There is no comparison between them . [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell always was absolutely plain -- but extremely elegant and amiable . ”[1207-i]

“ Yes , that of course . ”[1207-i]

“ [Jane]152-miss fairfax caught a bad cold , poor thing ! so long ago as the 7th of November , ( as [I]1207-i am going to read to [you]192-mr. dixon , ) and has never been well since . A long time , is not it , for a cold to hang upon [her]152-miss fairfax ? [She]152-miss fairfax never mentioned it before , because [she]152-miss fairfax would not alarm [us]3761-us . Just like [her]152-miss fairfax ! so considerate!--But however , [she]152-miss fairfax is so far from well , that [[her]152-miss fairfax kind friends]3762-her kind friends [the Campbells]190-the campbells think [she]152-miss fairfax had better come [home]562-home , and try an air that always agrees with [her]152-miss fairfax ; and [they]190-the campbells have no doubt that three or four months at [Highbury]3-highbury will entirely cure [her]152-miss fairfax -- and it is certainly a great deal better that [she]152-miss fairfax should come [here]2707-here , than go to [Ireland]32-ireland , if [she]152-miss fairfax is unwell . [Nobody]2718-nobody could nurse [her]152-miss fairfax , as [we]3761-us should do . ”[1207-i]

“ It appears to [me]1207-i the most desirable arrangement in [the world]403-the world . ”[1207-i]

“ And so [she]152-miss fairfax is to come to [us]3761-us next Friday or Saturday , and [the Campbells]190-the campbells leave [town]2760-town in [their]190-the campbells way to [Holyhead]35-holyhead the Monday following -- as [you]3768-you will find from [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's letter . So sudden!--You may guess , dear [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , what a flurry it has thrown [me]1207-i in ! If it was not for the drawback of [her]152-miss fairfax illness -- but [I]1207-i am afraid [we]3761-us must expect to see [her]152-miss fairfax grown thin , and looking very poorly . [I]1207-i must tell [you]3768-you what an unlucky thing happened to [me]1207-i , as to that . [I]1207-i always make a point of reading [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's letters through to [myself]1207-i first , before [I]1207-i read [them]3769-them aloud to [[my]1207-i mother]3715-my mother , [you]3768-you know , for fear of there being any thing in them to distress [her]152-miss fairfax . [Jane]152-miss fairfax desired [me]1207-i to do it , so [I]1207-i always do : and so [I]1207-i began to - day with [my]1207-i usual caution ; but no sooner did [I]1207-i come to the mention of [her]152-miss fairfax being unwell , than [I]1207-i burst out , quite frightened , with ' Bless [me]1207-i ! poor [Jane]152-miss fairfax is ill!'--which [[my]1207-i mother]3715-my mother , being on the watch , heard distinctly , and was sadly alarmed at . However , when [I]1207-i read on , [I]1207-i found it was not near so bad as [I]1207-i had fancied at first ; and [I]1207-i make so light of it now to [her]152-miss fairfax , that [she]152-miss fairfax does not think much about it . But [I]1207-i can not imagine how [I]1207-i could be so off [my]1207-i guard . If [Jane]152-miss fairfax does not get well soon , [we]3772-we will call in [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry . [The expense]3773-the expense shall not be thought of ; and though [he]106-mr. perry is so liberal , and so fond of [Jane]152-miss fairfax that [I]1207-i dare say [he]106-mr. perry would not mean to charge any thing for attendance , [we]3772-we could not suffer it to be so , [you]3774-you know . [He]106-mr. perry has [a wife]2759-a wife and [family]3450-family to maintain , and is not to be giving away [his]106-mr. perry time . Well , now [I]1207-i have just given [you]3774-you a hint of what [Jane]152-miss fairfax writes about , [we]3772-we will turn to [her]152-miss fairfax letter , and [I]1207-i am sure [she]152-miss fairfax tells [her]152-miss fairfax own story a great deal better than [I]1207-i can tell it for [her]152-miss fairfax . ”[1207-i]

“ [I]123-emma am afraid [we]3772-we must be running away , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , glancing at [Harriet]111-harriet , and beginning to rise--“My [father]3777-father will be expecting [us]3772-we . [I]1207-i had no intention , [I]1207-i thought [I]1207-i had no power of staying more than five minutes , when [I]1207-i first entered [the house]435-the house . [I]1207-i merely called , because [I]1207-i would not pass the door without inquiring after [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates ; but [I]1207-i have been so pleasantly detained ! Now , however , [we]3772-we must wish [you]3779-you and [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates good morning . ”[1207-i]

And not all that could be urged to detain [her]123-emma succeeded . [She]123-emma regained [the street]1208-the street -- happy in this , that though much had been forced on [her]123-emma against [her]123-emma will , though [she]123-emma had in fact heard the whole substance of [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's letter , [she]123-emma had been able to escape the letter itself .

CHAPTER II

[Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax was [an orphan]1209-an orphan , [the only child of [[Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's youngest daughter]1211-mrs. bates 's youngest daughter]1210-the only child of mrs. bates 's youngest daughter .

The marriage of [Lieut . Fairfax of the ----regiment of infantry]1212-lieut . fairfax of the ----regiment of infantry , and [Miss Jane Bates]105-miss bates , had had its day of fame and pleasure , hope and interest ; but nothing now remained of it , save the melancholy remembrance of [him]1212-lieut . fairfax of the ----regiment of infantry dying in action abroad -- of [[his]1212-lieut . fairfax of the ----regiment of infantry widow]1213-his widow sinking under consumption and grief soon afterwards -- and [this girl]1214-this girl .

By birth [she]152-miss fairfax belonged to [Highbury]3-highbury : and when at three years old , on losing [[her]152-miss fairfax mother]410-her mother , [she]152-miss fairfax became [the property]1216-the property , the charge , the consolation , the foundling of [[her]152-miss fairfax grandmother]3294-her grandmother and [aunt]3628-aunt , there had seemed every probability of [her]152-miss fairfax being permanently fixed [there]448-there ; of [her]152-miss fairfax being taught only what very limited means could command , and growing up with no advantages of connexion or improvement , to be engrafted on what nature had given [her]152-miss fairfax in [a pleasing person]1220-a pleasing person , good understanding , and warm - hearted , well - meaning relations .

But the compassionate feelings of [a friend of [[her]152-miss fairfax father]425-her father]1221-a friend of her father gave a change to [her]152-miss fairfax destiny . This was [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell , who had very highly regarded [Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , as [an excellent officer and most deserving young man]1223-an excellent officer and most deserving young man ; and farther , had been indebted to [him]164-colonel campbell for such attentions , during a severe camp - fever , as [he]164-colonel campbell believed had saved [his]164-colonel campbell life . These were claims which [he]164-colonel campbell did not learn to overlook , though some years passed away from the death of [poor Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , before [his]164-colonel campbell own return to [England]36-england put any thing in [his]164-colonel campbell power . When [he]164-colonel campbell did return , [he]164-colonel campbell sought out [the child]498-the child and took notice of [her]498-the child . [He]164-colonel campbell was [a married man]1225-a married man , with [only one living child]1226-only one living child , [a girl]2892-a girl , about [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's age : and [Jane]152-miss fairfax became [[their]1228-their guest]1229-their guest , paying [them]1228-their long visits and growing a favourite with [all]449-all ; and before [she]152-miss fairfax was nine years old , [[his]164-colonel campbell daughter]2723-his daughter 's great fondness for [her]152-miss fairfax , and [his]164-colonel campbell own wish of being [a real friend]1232-a real friend , united to produce an offer from [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell of undertaking the whole charge of [her]152-miss fairfax education . It was accepted ; and from that period [Jane]152-miss fairfax had belonged to [[Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell 's family]1233-colonel campbell 's family , and had lived with [them]1233-colonel campbell 's family entirely , only visiting [[her]152-miss fairfax grandmother]3294-her grandmother from time to time .

The plan was that [she]152-miss fairfax should be brought up for educating [others]2773-others ; the very few hundred pounds which [she]152-miss fairfax inherited from [[her]152-miss fairfax father]425-her father making independence impossible . To provide for [her]152-miss fairfax otherwise was out of [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell 's power ; for though [his]164-colonel campbell income , by pay and appointments , was handsome , [his]164-colonel campbell fortune was moderate and must be all [[his]164-colonel campbell daughter]2723-his daughter 's ; but , by giving [her]152-miss fairfax an education , [he]164-colonel campbell hoped to be supplying the means of respectable subsistence hereafter .

Such was [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's history . [She]152-miss fairfax had fallen into good hands , known nothing but kindness from [the Campbells]190-the campbells , and been given an excellent education . Living constantly with [right - minded and well - informed people]1238-right - minded and well - informed people , [her]152-miss fairfax heart and understanding had received every advantage of discipline and culture ; and [[Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell 's residence]1239-colonel campbell 's residence being in [London]1-london , every lighter talent had been done full justice to , by the attendance of [first - rate masters]1240-first - rate masters . [Her]152-miss fairfax disposition and abilities were equally worthy of all that friendship could do ; and at eighteen or nineteen [she]152-miss fairfax was , as far as such an early age can be qualified for the care of [children]1241-children , fully competent to the office of instruction [herself]152-miss fairfax ; but [she]152-miss fairfax was too much beloved to be parted with . Neither [father]3777-father nor [mother]3738-mother could promote , and [the daughter]971-the daughter could not endure it . The evil day was put off . It was easy to decide that [she]152-miss fairfax was still too young ; and [Jane]152-miss fairfax remained with [them]1245-them , sharing , as [another daughter]1246-another daughter , in all the rational pleasures of an elegant society , and a judicious mixture of [home]562-home and amusement , with only the drawback of the future , the sobering suggestions of [her]152-miss fairfax own good understanding to remind [her]152-miss fairfax that all this might soon be over .
