The affection of [the whole family]1248-the whole family , the warm attachment of [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell in particular , was the more honourable to [each party]1249-each party from the circumstance of [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's decided superiority both in beauty and acquirements . That nature had given it in feature could not be unseen by [the young woman]1250-the young woman , nor could [her]152-miss fairfax higher powers of mind be unfelt by [the parents]640-the parents . [They]1252-they continued together with unabated regard however , till the marriage of [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell , who by that chance , that luck which so often defies anticipation in matrimonial affairs , giving attraction to what is moderate rather than to what is superior , engaged the affections of [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , [a young man]2853-a young man , rich and agreeable , almost as soon as [they]1252-they were acquainted ; and was eligibly and happily settled , while [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax had yet [her]152-miss fairfax bread to earn .

This event had very lately taken place ; too lately for any thing to be yet attempted by [[her]152-miss fairfax less fortunate friend]1254-her less fortunate friend towards entering on [her]152-miss fairfax path of duty ; though [she]152-miss fairfax had now reached the age which [her]152-miss fairfax own judgment had fixed on for beginning . [She]152-miss fairfax had long resolved that one - and - twenty should be the period . With the fortitude of [a devoted novitiate]1255-a devoted novitiate , [she]152-miss fairfax had resolved at one - and - twenty to complete the sacrifice , and retire from all the pleasures of life , of rational intercourse , equal society , peace and hope , to penance and mortification for ever .

The good sense of [Colonel and Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell could not oppose such a resolution , though [their]1252-they feelings did . As long as [they]1252-they lived , no exertions would be necessary , [[their]1252-they home]1256-their home might be hers for ever ; and for [their]1252-they own comfort [they]1252-they would have retained [her]152-miss fairfax wholly ; but this would be selfishness:--what must be at last , had better be soon . Perhaps [they]1252-they began to feel it might have been kinder and wiser to have resisted the temptation of any delay , and spared [her]152-miss fairfax from a taste of such enjoyments of ease and leisure as must now be relinquished . Still , however , affection was glad to catch at any reasonable excuse for not hurrying on the wretched moment . [She]152-miss fairfax had never been quite well since the time of [[their]1252-they daughter]3438-their daughter 's marriage ; and till [she]152-miss fairfax should have completely recovered [her]152-miss fairfax usual strength , [they]1252-they must forbid [her]152-miss fairfax engaging in duties , which , so far from being compatible with a weakened frame and varying spirits , seemed , under the most favourable circumstances , to require something more than human perfection of body and mind to be discharged with tolerable comfort .

With regard to [her]152-miss fairfax not accompanying [them]1252-they to [Ireland]32-ireland , [her]152-miss fairfax account to [[her]152-miss fairfax aunt]3293-her aunt contained nothing but truth , though there might be some truths not told . It was [her]152-miss fairfax own choice to give the time of [their]1252-they absence to [Highbury]3-highbury ; to spend , perhaps , [her]152-miss fairfax last months of perfect liberty with [those kind relations to whom [she]152-miss fairfax was so very dear]1259-those kind relations to whom she was so very dear : and [the Campbells]190-the campbells , whatever might be [their]190-the campbells motive or motives , whether single , or double , or treble , gave the arrangement [their]190-the campbells ready sanction , and said , that [they]190-the campbells depended more on a few months spent in [her]152-miss fairfax native air , for the recovery of [her]152-miss fairfax health , than on any thing else . Certain it was that [she]152-miss fairfax was to come ; and that [Highbury]3-highbury , instead of welcoming that perfect novelty which had been so long promised it -- [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill -- must put up for the present with [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , who could bring only the freshness of a two years ' absence .

[Emma]123-emma was sorry;--to have to pay civilities to [a person [she]123-emma did not like]1260-a person she did not like through three long months!--to be always doing more than [she]123-emma wished , and less than [she]123-emma ought ! Why [she]123-emma did not like [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax might be a difficult question to answer ; [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley had once told [her]123-emma it was because [she]123-emma saw in [her]123-emma [the really accomplished young woman]1261-the really accomplished young woman , which [she]123-emma wanted to be thought [herself]123-emma ; and though the accusation had been eagerly refuted at the time , there were moments of self - examination in which [her]123-emma conscience could not quite acquit [her]123-emma . But “ [she]123-emma could never get acquainted with [her]152-miss fairfax : [she]123-emma did not know how it was , but there was such coldness and reserve -- such apparent indifference whether [she]152-miss fairfax pleased or not -- and then , [[her]123-emma aunt]3293-her aunt was such an eternal talker!--and [she]152-miss fairfax was made such a fuss with by every body!--and it had been always imagined that [they]3781-they were to be so intimate -- because [their]3781-they ages were the same , [every body]2749-every body had supposed [they]3781-they must be so fond of [each other]430-each other . ”[123-emma] These were [her]123-emma reasons -- [she]123-emma had no better .

It was a dislike so little just -- every imputed fault was so magnified by fancy , that [she]123-emma never saw [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax the first time after any considerable absence , without feeling that [she]152-miss fairfax had injured [her]152-miss fairfax ; and now , when the due visit was paid , on [her]123-emma arrival , after a two years ' interval , [she]123-emma was particularly struck with the very appearance and manners , which for those two whole years [she]123-emma had been depreciating . [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax was very elegant , remarkably elegant ; and [she]152-miss fairfax had [herself]152-miss fairfax the highest value for elegance . [Her]152-miss fairfax height was pretty , just such as almost [every body]2749-every body would think tall , and [nobody]2718-nobody could think very tall ; [her]152-miss fairfax figure particularly graceful ; [her]152-miss fairfax size a most becoming medium , between fat and thin , though a slight appearance of ill - health seemed to point out the likeliest evil of the two . [Emma]123-emma could not but feel all this ; and then , [her]152-miss fairfax face -- [her]152-miss fairfax features -- there was more beauty in them altogether than [she]123-emma had remembered ; it was not regular , but it was very pleasing beauty . [Her]152-miss fairfax eyes , a deep grey , with dark eye - lashes and eyebrows , had never been denied [their]1264-their praise ; but the skin , which [she]152-miss fairfax had been used to cavil at , as wanting colour , had a clearness and delicacy which really needed no fuller bloom . It was a style of beauty , of which elegance was the reigning character , and as such , [she]152-miss fairfax must , in honour , by all [her]152-miss fairfax principles , admire it:--elegance , which , whether of person or of mind , [she]152-miss fairfax saw so little in [Highbury]3-highbury . There , not to be vulgar , was distinction , and merit .

In short , [she]152-miss fairfax sat , during the first visit , looking at [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax with twofold complacency ; the sense of pleasure and the sense of rendering justice , and was determining that [she]152-miss fairfax would dislike [her]152-miss fairfax no longer . When [she]152-miss fairfax took in [her]152-miss fairfax history , indeed , [her]152-miss fairfax situation , as well as [her]152-miss fairfax beauty ; when [she]152-miss fairfax considered what all this elegance was destined to , what [she]152-miss fairfax was going to sink from , how [she]152-miss fairfax was going to live , it seemed impossible to feel any thing but compassion and respect ; especially , if to every well - known particular entitling [her]152-miss fairfax to interest , were added the highly probable circumstance of an attachment to [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , which [she]152-miss fairfax had so naturally started to [herself]152-miss fairfax . In that case , nothing could be more pitiable or more honourable than the sacrifices [she]152-miss fairfax had resolved on . [Emma]123-emma was very willing now to acquit [her]152-miss fairfax of having seduced [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon 's actions from [[his]192-mr. dixon wife]2763-his wife , or of any thing mischievous which [her]152-miss fairfax imagination had suggested at first . If it were love , it might be simple , single , successless love on [her]152-miss fairfax side alone . [She]152-miss fairfax might have been unconsciously sucking in the sad poison , while [a sharer of [his]192-mr. dixon conversation with [[her]152-miss fairfax friend]427-her friend]1266-a sharer of his conversation with her friend ; and from the best , the purest of motives , might now be denying [herself]152-miss fairfax this visit to [Ireland]32-ireland , and resolving to divide [herself]152-miss fairfax effectually from [him]192-mr. dixon and [his]192-mr. dixon connexions by soon beginning [her]152-miss fairfax career of laborious duty .

Upon the whole , [Emma]123-emma left [her]152-miss fairfax with such softened , charitable feelings , as made [her]152-miss fairfax look around in walking [home]562-home , and lament that [Highbury]3-highbury afforded [no young man]1269-no young man worthy of giving [her]152-miss fairfax independence ; nobody that [she]152-miss fairfax could wish to scheme about for [her]152-miss fairfax .

These were charming feelings -- but not lasting . Before [she]152-miss fairfax had committed [herself]152-miss fairfax by any public profession of eternal friendship for [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , or done more towards a recantation of past prejudices and errors , than saying to [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , “ [She]152-miss fairfax certainly is handsome ; [she]152-miss fairfax is better than handsome ! ”[152-miss fairfax] [Jane]152-miss fairfax had spent an evening at [Hartfield]2-hartfield with [[her]152-miss fairfax grandmother]3294-her grandmother and [aunt]3628-aunt , and every thing was relapsing much into its usual state . Former provocations reappeared . [The aunt]520-the aunt was as tiresome as ever ; more tiresome , because anxiety for [her]520-the aunt health was now added to admiration of [her]520-the aunt powers ; and [they]1273-they had to listen to the description of exactly how little bread and butter [she]520-the aunt ate for breakfast , and how small a slice of mutton for dinner , as well as to see exhibitions of new caps and new workbags for [[her]152-miss fairfax mother]410-her mother and [herself]152-miss fairfax ; and [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's offences rose again . [They]1273-they had music ; [Emma]123-emma was obliged to play ; and the thanks and praise which necessarily followed appeared to [her]123-emma an affectation of candour , an air of greatness , meaning only to shew off in higher style [her]123-emma own very superior performance . [She]123-emma was , besides , which was the worst of all , so cold , so cautious ! There was no getting at [her]123-emma real opinion . Wrapt up in a cloak of politeness , [she]123-emma seemed determined to hazard nothing . [She]123-emma was disgustingly , was suspiciously reserved .

If any thing could be more , where all was most , [she]123-emma was more reserved on the subject of [Weymouth]23-weymouth and [the Dixons]195-the dixons than any thing . [She]123-emma seemed bent on giving no real insight into [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon 's character , or [her]123-emma own value for [his]192-mr. dixon company , or opinion of the suitableness of the match . It was all general approbation and smoothness ; nothing delineated or distinguished . It did [her]123-emma no service however . [Her]123-emma caution was thrown away . [Emma]123-emma saw its artifice , and returned to [her]123-emma first surmises . There probably _ was _ something more to conceal than [her]123-emma own preference ; [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , perhaps , had been very near changing [one friend]1275-one friend for the other , or been fixed only to [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell , for the sake of the future twelve thousand pounds .

The like reserve prevailed on other topics . [She]123-emma and [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had been at [Weymouth]23-weymouth at the same time . It was known that [they]1276-they were a little acquainted ; but not a syllable of real information could [Emma]123-emma procure as to what [he]192-mr. dixon truly was . “ Was [he]192-mr. dixon handsome?”--“She[123-emma] believed [he]192-mr. dixon was reckoned [a very fine young man]524-a very fine young man . ” “[192-mr. dixon] Was [he]192-mr. dixon agreeable?”--“He was generally thought so . ”[192-mr. dixon] “ Did [he]192-mr. dixon appear [a sensible young man]673-a sensible young man ; [a young man of information?”--“At[192-mr. dixon] a watering - place]3785-a young man of information?”--“at a watering - place , or in a common [London]1-london acquaintance , it was difficult to decide on such points . Manners were all that could be safely judged of , under a much longer knowledge than [they]1276-they had yet had of [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill . [She]123-emma believed [every body]2749-every body found [his]192-mr. dixon manners pleasing . ” [Emma]123-emma could not forgive [her]123-emma .[2749-every body]

CHAPTER III

[Emma]123-emma could not forgive [her;--but]1279-her;--but as neither provocation nor resentment were discerned by [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , who had been of [the party , and had seen only proper attention and pleasing behaviour on each side]1280-the party , and had seen only proper attention and pleasing behaviour on each side , [he]92-mr. knightley was expressing the next morning , being at [Hartfield]2-hartfield again on business with [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , [his]85-mr. woodhouse approbation of the whole ; not so openly as [he]85-mr. woodhouse might have done had [[her]123-emma father]425-her father been out of [the room]701-the room , but speaking plain enough to be very intelligible to [Emma]123-emma . [He]425-her father had been used to think [her]123-emma unjust to [Jane]152-miss fairfax , and had now great pleasure in marking an improvement .

“ A very pleasant evening , ”[425-her father] [he]425-her father began , as soon as [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse had been talked into what was necessary , told that [he]425-her father understood , and the papers swept away;--“particularly pleasant . [You]123-emma and [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax gave [us]3786-us some very good music . [I]425-her father do not know a more luxurious state , [sir]2734-sir , than sitting at [one]2775-one 's ease to be entertained a whole evening by [two such young women]3789-two such young women ; sometimes with music and sometimes with conversation . [I]425-her father am sure [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax must have found the evening pleasant , [Emma]123-emma . [You]123-emma left nothing undone . [I]425-her father was glad [you]123-emma made [her]152-miss fairfax play so much , for having no instrument at [[her]152-miss fairfax grandmother]3294-her grandmother 's , it must have been a real indulgence . ”[425-her father]

“ [I]123-emma am happy [you]123-emma approved , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , smiling ; “ but [I]123-emma hope [I]123-emma am not often deficient in what is due to [guests]3791-guests at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . ”[123-emma]

“ No , [[my]425-her father dear]2714-my dear , ”[425-her father] said [[her]123-emma father]425-her father instantly ; “ _ that _ [I]425-her father am sure [you]123-emma are not . There is [nobody]2718-nobody half so attentive and civil as [you]123-emma are . If any thing , [you]123-emma are too attentive . The muffin last night -- if it had been handed round once , [I]425-her father think it would have been enough . ”[425-her father]

“ No , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , nearly at the same time ; “ [you]123-emma are not often deficient ; not often deficient either in manner or comprehension . [I]92-mr. knightley think [you]123-emma understand [me]92-mr. knightley , therefore . ”[92-mr. knightley]

An arch look expressed--“I understand [you]92-mr. knightley well enough ; ”[123-emma] but [she]123-emma said only , “ [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax is reserved . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]425-her father always told [you]92-mr. knightley [she]152-miss fairfax was -- a little ; but [you]92-mr. knightley will soon overcome all that part of [her]152-miss fairfax reserve which ought to be overcome , all that has its foundation in diffidence . What arises from discretion must be honoured . ”[425-her father]

“ [You]92-mr. knightley think [her]152-miss fairfax diffident . [I]123-emma do not see it . ”[123-emma]

“ [[My]92-mr. knightley dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley , moving from [his]92-mr. knightley chair into one close by [her]123-emma , “ [you]123-emma are not going to tell [me]92-mr. knightley , [I]92-mr. knightley hope , that [you]123-emma had not a pleasant evening . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Oh ! no ; [I]123-emma was pleased with [my]123-emma own perseverance in asking questions ; and amused to think how little information [I]123-emma obtained . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley am disappointed , ”[92-mr. knightley] was [his]92-mr. knightley only answer .

“ [I]85-mr. woodhouse hope [every body]2749-every body had a pleasant evening , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , in [his]85-mr. woodhouse quiet way . “ [I]85-mr. woodhouse had . Once , [I]85-mr. woodhouse felt the fire rather too much ; but then [I]85-mr. woodhouse moved back [my]85-mr. woodhouse chair a little , a very little , and it did not disturb [me]85-mr. woodhouse . [Miss Bates]105-miss bates was very chatty and good - humoured , as [she]105-miss bates always is , though [she]105-miss bates speaks rather too quick . However , [she]105-miss bates is very agreeable , and [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates too , in a different way . [I]85-mr. woodhouse like [old friends]3796-old friends ; and [Miss Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax is [a very pretty sort of young lady]3797-a very pretty sort of young lady , [a very pretty and a very well - behaved young lady]3798-a very pretty and a very well - behaved young lady indeed . [She]152-miss fairfax must have found the evening agreeable , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , because [she]152-miss fairfax had [Emma]123-emma . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ True , [sir]2734-sir ; and [Emma]123-emma , because [she]152-miss fairfax had [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma saw [his]1284-his anxiety , and wishing to appease it , at least for the present , said , and with a sincerity which [no one]3090-no one could question--

“ [She]152-miss fairfax is [a sort of elegant creature that one can not keep one]3800-a sort of elegant creature that one can not keep one 's eyes from . [I]123-emma am always watching [her]152-miss fairfax to admire ; and [I]123-emma do pity [her]152-miss fairfax from [my]123-emma heart . ”[123-emma]

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley looked as if [he]92-mr. knightley were more gratified than [he]92-mr. knightley cared to express ; and before [he]92-mr. knightley could make any reply , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , whose thoughts were on [the Bates]110-mrs. bates 's , said--

“ It is a great pity that [their]3801-their circumstances should be so confined ! a great pity indeed ! and [I]85-mr. woodhouse have often wished -- but it is so little one can venture to do -- small , trifling presents , of any thing uncommon -- Now [we]3802-we have killed [a porker]3803-a porker , and [Emma]123-emma thinks of sending [them]3801-their a loin or a leg ; it is very small and delicate -- [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse pork is not like any other pork -- but still it is pork -- and , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , unless one could be sure of [their]3801-their making it into steaks , nicely fried , as [ours]3802-we are fried , without the smallest grease , and not roast it , for no stomach can bear roast pork -- [I]85-mr. woodhouse think [we]3802-we had better send the leg -- do not [you]123-emma think so , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear ? ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [[My]85-mr. woodhouse dear papa]2954-my dear papa , [I]85-mr. woodhouse sent the whole hind - quarter . [I]85-mr. woodhouse knew [you]2954-my dear papa would wish it . There will be the leg to be salted , [you]2954-my dear papa know , which is so very nice , and the loin to be dressed directly in any manner [they]3801-their like . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ That 's right , [[my]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear , very right . [I]85-mr. woodhouse had not thought of it before , but that is the best way . [They]3801-their must not over - salt the leg ; and then , if it is not over - salted , and if it is very thoroughly boiled , just as [Serle]112-serle boils [ours]3802-we , and eaten very moderately of , with a boiled turnip , and a little carrot or parsnip , [I]85-mr. woodhouse do not consider it unwholesome . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [Emma]123-emma , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley presently , “ [I]92-mr. knightley have a piece of news for [you]123-emma . [You]2954-my dear papa like news -- and [I]92-mr. knightley heard an article in [my]92-mr. knightley way hither that [I]92-mr. knightley think will interest [you]2954-my dear papa . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ News ! Oh ! yes , [I]92-mr. knightley always like news . What is it?--why do [you]123-emma smile so?--where did [you]123-emma hear it?--at [Randalls]101-randalls ? ”[92-mr. knightley]

[He]92-mr. knightley had time only to say ,

“ No , not at [Randalls]101-randalls ; [I]92-mr. knightley have not been near [Randalls]101-randalls , ”[92-mr. knightley] when the door was thrown open , and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates and [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax walked into [the room]701-the room . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley soon saw that [he]92-mr. knightley had lost [his]92-mr. knightley moment , and that not another syllable of communication could rest with [him]92-mr. knightley .

“ Oh ! [[my]92-mr. knightley dear sir]3019-my dear sir , how are [you]3019-my dear sir this morning ? [[My]92-mr. knightley dear]2714-my dear [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse -- [I]92-mr. knightley come quite over - powered . Such a beautiful hind - quarter of pork ! [You]3019-my dear sir are too bountiful ! Have [you]3019-my dear sir heard the news ? [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton is going to be married . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma had not had time even to think of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , and [she]123-emma was so completely surprized that [she]123-emma could not avoid a little start , and a little blush , at the sound .

“ There is [[my]92-mr. knightley news:--I]3810-my news:--i thought it would interest [you]3019-my dear sir , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , with a smile which implied a conviction of some part of what had passed between [them]1287-them .

“ But where could _ [you]92-mr. knightley _ hear it ? ”[105-miss bates] cried [Miss Bates]105-miss bates . “ Where could [you]92-mr. knightley possibly hear it , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ? For it is not five minutes since [I]105-miss bates received [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole 's note -- no , it can not be more than five -- or at least ten -- for [I]105-miss bates had got [my]105-miss bates bonnet and spencer on , just ready to come out -- [I]105-miss bates was only gone down to speak to [Patty]196-patty again about the pork -- [Jane]105-miss bates was standing in [the passage]3811-the passage -- were not [you]92-mr. knightley , Jane?--for [[my]105-miss bates mother]3715-my mother was so afraid that [we]1287-them had not any salting - pan large enough . So [I]105-miss bates said [I]105-miss bates would go down and see , and [Jane]105-miss bates said , ' Shall [I]105-miss bates go down instead ? for [I]105-miss bates think [you]92-mr. knightley have a little cold , and [Patty]196-patty has been washing [the kitchen]3813-the kitchen . '--'Oh ! [my]105-miss bates dear , ' said [I]105-miss bates -- well , and just then came the note . [A Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins -- that 's all [I]105-miss bates know . [A Miss Hawkins of Bath]197-miss hawkins . But , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , how could [you]92-mr. knightley possibly have heard it ? for the very moment [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole told [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole of it , [she]185-mrs. cole sat down and wrote to [me]105-miss bates . [A Miss Hawkins--]198-a miss hawkins-- ”[105-miss bates]

“ [I]105-miss bates was with [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole on business an hour and a half ago . [He]145-mr. cole had just read [Elton]95-mr. elton 's letter as [I]105-miss bates was shewn in , and handed it to [me]105-miss bates directly . ”[3817-mr. woodhouse--“indeed]

“ Well , [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear [Jane]105-miss bates , [I]123-emma believe [we]3861-we must be running away . The weather does not look well , and [grandmama]3720-grandmama will be uneasy . [Emma]123-emma , alone with [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , had half [her]123-emma attention wanted by [him]425-her father while [he]425-her father lamented that [young people]1290-young people would be in such a hurry to marry -- and to marry [strangers]1291-strangers too -- and the other half [she]123-emma could give to [her]123-emma own view of the subject . It was to [herself]123-emma an amusing and a very welcome piece of news , as proving that [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton could not have suffered long ; but [she]123-emma was sorry for [Harriet]111-harriet : [Harriet]111-harriet must feel it -- and all that [she]123-emma could hope was , by giving the first information [herself]123-emma , to save [her]123-emma from hearing it abruptly from [others]2773-others . It was now about the time that [she]123-emma was likely to call . If [she]123-emma were to meet [Miss Bates]105-miss bates in [her]105-miss bates way!--and upon its beginning to rain , [Emma]123-emma was obliged to expect that the weather would be detaining [her]123-emma at [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's]720-mrs. goddard 's , and that the intelligence would undoubtedly rush upon [her]123-emma without preparation .

The shower was heavy , but short ; and it had not been over five minutes , when in came [Harriet]111-harriet , with just the heated , agitated look which hurrying thither with a full heart was likely to give ; and the “ Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , what do [you]93-miss woodhouse think has happened ! ”[111-harriet] which instantly burst forth , had all the evidence of corresponding perturbation . As the blow was given , [Emma]123-emma felt that [she]123-emma could not now [shew]123-emma greater kindness than in listening ; and [Harriet]111-harriet , unchecked , ran eagerly through what [she]111-harriet had to tell . “ [She]123-emma had set out from [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's]720-mrs. goddard 's half an hour ago -- [she]123-emma had been afraid it would rain -- [she]123-emma had been afraid it would pour down every moment -- but [she]123-emma thought [she]123-emma might get to [Hartfield]2-hartfield first -- [she]123-emma had hurried on as fast as possible ; but then , as [she]123-emma was passing by [the house where [a young woman]3868-a young woman was making up a gown for [her]123-emma]3867-the house where a young woman was making up a gown for her , [she]123-emma thought [she]123-emma would just step in and see how it went on ; and though [she]123-emma did not seem to stay half a moment there , soon after [she]123-emma came out it began to rain , and [she]123-emma did not know what to do ; so [she]123-emma ran on directly , as fast as [she]123-emma could , and took shelter at [Ford's]37-ford's . [”--Ford[1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper] 's]3869-”--ford 's was [the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper , and [[haberdasher]1295-haberdasher 's shop united]1296-haberdasher 's shop united ; [the shop first in size and fashion in the place.--“And]3870-the shop first in size and fashion in the place.--“and so , there [she]123-emma had set , without an idea of any thing in [the world]403-the world , full ten minutes , perhaps -- when , all of a sudden , who should come in -- to be sure it was so very odd!--but [they]3872-they always dealt at [Ford's]37-ford's -- who should come in , but [Elizabeth Martin]120-elizabeth and [her]120-elizabeth brother!--Dear [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse ! only think . [She]120-elizabeth did not do any of it in the same way that [she]120-elizabeth used ; [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper could see [she]120-elizabeth was altered ; but , however , [she]120-elizabeth seemed to _ try _ to be very friendly , and [we]3880-we shook hands , and stood talking some time ; but [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper know no more what [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper said -- [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was in such a tremble!--I remember [she]120-elizabeth said [she]120-elizabeth was sorry [we]3880-we never met now ; which [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought almost too kind ! [Dear]3874-dear , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was absolutely miserable ! By that time , it was beginning to hold up , and [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was determined that nothing should stop [me]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper from getting away -- and then -- only think!--I found [he]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was coming up towards [me]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper too -- slowly [you]3874-dear know , and as if [he]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper did not quite know what to do ; and so [he]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper came and spoke , and [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper answered -- and [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper stood for a minute , feeling dreadfully , [you]3874-dear know , one ca n't tell how ; and then [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper took courage , and said it did not rain , and [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper must go ; and so off [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper set ; and [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper had not got three yards from the door , when [he]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper came after [me]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper , only to say , if [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was going to [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse , [he]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper had much better go round by [[Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole 's stables]3882-mr. cole 's stables , for [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper should find the near way quite floated by this rain . Oh ! dear , [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper thought it would have been the death of [me]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper ! So [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper said , [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was very much obliged to [him]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper : [you]3874-dear know [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper could not do less ; and then [he]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper went back to [Elizabeth]120-elizabeth , and [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper came round by [the stables]3883-the stables -- [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper believe [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper did -- but [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper hardly knew where [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper was , or any thing about it . [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [I]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper would rather done any thing than have it happen : and yet , [you]3874-dear know , there was a sort of satisfaction in seeing [him]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper behave so pleasantly and so kindly . And [Elizabeth]120-elizabeth , too . Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , do talk to [me]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper and make [me]1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper comfortable again . ”[1294-the principal woollen - draper , linen - draper]

Very sincerely did [Emma]123-emma wish to do so ; but it was not immediately in [her]123-emma power . [She]123-emma was obliged to stop and think . [She]123-emma was not thoroughly comfortable [herself]123-emma . [The young man]532-the young man 's conduct , and [[his]532-the young man sister]1298-his sister 's , seemed the result of real feeling , and [she]123-emma could not but pity [them]1299-them . As [Harriet]111-harriet described it , there had been an interesting mixture of wounded affection and genuine delicacy in [their]1299-them behaviour . But [she]111-harriet had believed [them]1299-them to be well - meaning , [worthy people]1300-worthy people before ; and what difference did this make in the evils of the connexion ? It was folly to be disturbed by it . Of course , [he]532-the young man must be sorry to lose [her]111-harriet -- [they]1299-them must be all sorry . Ambition , as well as love , had probably been mortified . [They]1299-them might all have hoped to rise by [Harriet]111-harriet 's acquaintance : and besides , what was the value of [Harriet]111-harriet 's description?--So easily pleased -- so little discerning;--what signified [her]111-harriet praise ?

[She]123-emma exerted [herself]123-emma , and did try to make [her]111-harriet comfortable , by considering all that had passed as a mere trifle , and quite unworthy of being dwelt on ,

“ It might be distressing , for the moment , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma ; “ but [you]111-harriet seem to have behaved extremely well ; and it is over -- and may never -- can never , as a first meeting , occur again , and therefore [you]111-harriet need not think about it . ”[123-emma]

[Harriet]111-harriet said , “ very true , ”[111-harriet] and [she]111-harriet “ would not think about it ; ”[111-harriet] but still [she]111-harriet talked of it -- still [she]111-harriet could talk of nothing else ; and [Emma]123-emma , at last , in order to put [the Martins]113-the martins out of [her]123-emma head , was obliged to hurry on the news , which [she]123-emma had meant to give with so much tender caution ; hardly knowing [herself]123-emma whether to rejoice or be angry , ashamed or only amused , at such a state of mind in poor [Harriet]111-harriet -- such a conclusion of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's importance with [her]111-harriet !

[Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's rights , however , gradually revived . Though [she]123-emma did not feel the first intelligence as [she]123-emma might have done the day before , or an hour before , its interest soon increased ; and before [their]1301-their first conversation was over , [she]123-emma had talked [herself]123-emma into all the sensations of curiosity , wonder and regret , pain and pleasure , as to this fortunate [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins , which could conduce to place [the Martins]1302-the martins under proper subordination in [her]123-emma fancy .

[Emma]123-emma learned to be rather glad that there had been such a meeting . It had been serviceable in deadening the first shock , without retaining any influence to alarm . As [Harriet]111-harriet now lived , [the Martins]1302-the martins could not get at [her]111-harriet , without seeking [her]111-harriet , where hitherto [they]1302-the martins had wanted either the courage or the condescension to seek [her]111-harriet ; for since [her]123-emma refusal of [the brother]1304-the brother , [the sisters]2828-the sisters never had been at [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's]720-mrs. goddard 's ; and [a twelvemonth]1307-a twelvemonth might pass without [their]2828-the sisters being thrown together again , with any necessity , or even any power of speech .

CHAPTER IV

Human nature is so well disposed towards [those who are in interesting situations]1308-those who are in interesting situations , that [a young person , who either marries or dies]1309-a young person , who either marries or dies , is sure of being kindly spoken of .

A week had not passed since [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins 's name was first mentioned in [Highbury]3-highbury , before [she]197-miss hawkins was , by some means or other , discovered to have every recommendation of [person]1310-person and mind ; to be handsome , elegant , highly accomplished , and perfectly amiable : and when [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton [himself]95-mr. elton arrived to triumph in [his]95-mr. elton happy prospects , and circulate the fame of [her]197-miss hawkins merits , there was very little more for [him]95-mr. elton to do , than to tell [her]197-miss hawkins Christian name , and say whose music [she]197-miss hawkins principally played .

[Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton returned , [a very happy man]1311-a very happy man . [He]95-mr. elton had gone away rejected and mortified -- disappointed in a very sanguine hope , after a series of what appeared to [him]95-mr. elton strong encouragement ; and not only losing [the right lady]1312-the right lady , but finding [himself]95-mr. elton debased to the level of [a very wrong one]1313-a very wrong one . [He]95-mr. elton had gone away deeply offended -- [he]95-mr. elton came back engaged to another -- and to [another as superior]1314-another as superior , of course , to the first , as under such circumstances what is gained always is to what is lost . [He]95-mr. elton came back gay and self - satisfied , eager and busy , caring nothing for [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , and defying [Miss Smith]111-harriet .

[The charming Augusta Hawkins]204-augusta , in addition to all the usual advantages of perfect beauty and merit , was in possession of an independent fortune , of so many thousands as would always be called ten ; a point of some dignity , as well as some convenience : the story told well ; [he]95-mr. elton had not thrown [himself]95-mr. elton away -- [he]95-mr. elton had gained [a woman of 10,000 l.]1315-a woman of 10,000 l. or thereabouts ; and [he]95-mr. elton had gained [her]1315-a woman of 10,000 l. with such delightful rapidity -- the first hour of introduction had been so very soon followed by distinguishing notice ; the history which [he]95-mr. elton had to give [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole of the rise and progress of the affair was so glorious -- the steps so quick , from the accidental rencontre , to the dinner at [Mr. Green]205-mr. green 's , and the party at [Mrs. Brown's]206-mrs. brown's -- smiles and blushes rising in importance -- with consciousness and agitation richly scattered -- [the lady]3048-the lady had been so easily impressed -- so sweetly disposed -- had in short , to use a most intelligible phrase , been so very ready to have [him]95-mr. elton , that vanity and prudence were equally contented .

[He]95-mr. elton had caught both substance and shadow -- both fortune and affection , and was just [the happy man [he]95-mr. elton ought to be]1317-the happy man he ought to be ; talking only of [himself]95-mr. elton and [his]95-mr. elton own concerns -- expecting to be congratulated -- ready to be laughed at -- and , with cordial , fearless smiles , now addressing all [the young ladies of [the place]450-the place]1318-the young ladies of the place , to whom , a few weeks ago , [he]95-mr. elton would have been more cautiously gallant .

The wedding was no distant event , as [the parties]1320-the parties had only [themselves]1320-the parties to please , and nothing but the necessary preparations to wait for ; and when [he]95-mr. elton set out for Bath again , there was a general expectation , which a certain glance of [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole 's did not seem to contradict , that when [he]95-mr. elton next entered [Highbury]3-highbury [he]95-mr. elton would bring [[his]95-mr. elton bride]1321-his bride .

During [his]95-mr. elton present short stay , [Emma]123-emma had barely seen [him]95-mr. elton ; but just enough to feel that the first meeting was over , and to give [her]123-emma the impression of [his]95-mr. elton not being improved by the mixture of pique and pretension , now spread over [his]95-mr. elton air . [She]123-emma was , in fact , beginning very much to wonder that [she]123-emma had ever thought [him]95-mr. elton pleasing at all ; and [his]95-mr. elton sight was so inseparably connected with some very disagreeable feelings , that , except in a moral light , as a penance , a lesson , a source of profitable humiliation to [her]123-emma own mind , [she]123-emma would have been thankful to be assured of never seeing [him]95-mr. elton again . [She]123-emma wished [him]95-mr. elton very well ; but [he]95-mr. elton gave [her]123-emma pain , and [his]95-mr. elton welfare twenty miles off would administer most satisfaction .

The pain of [his]95-mr. elton continued residence in [Highbury]3-highbury , however , must certainly be lessened by [his]95-mr. elton marriage . Many vain solicitudes would be prevented -- many awkwardnesses smoothed by it . [A _ Mrs. _ _ Elton]207-mrs. elton _ would be an excuse for any change of intercourse ; former intimacy might sink without remark . It would be almost beginning [their]1322-their life of civility again .

Of [the lady]3048-the lady , individually , [Emma]123-emma thought very little . [She]3048-the lady was good enough for [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , no doubt ; accomplished enough for [Highbury]3-highbury -- handsome enough -- to look plain , probably , by [Harriet]111-harriet 's side . As to connexion , there [Emma]123-emma was perfectly easy ; persuaded , that after all [his]95-mr. elton own vaunted claims and disdain of [Harriet]111-harriet , [he]95-mr. elton had done nothing . On that article , truth seemed attainable . _ What _ [she]3048-the lady was , must be uncertain ; but _ who _ [she]3048-the lady was , might be found out ; and setting aside the 10,000 l. , it did not appear that [she]3048-the lady was at all [[Harriet]111-harriet 's superior]1324-harriet 's superior . [She]3048-the lady brought no name , no blood , no alliance . [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins was [the youngest of the two daughters of [a [Bristol]40-bristol -- merchant]1326-a bristol -- merchant]1325-the youngest of the two daughters of a bristol -- merchant , of course , [he]1326-a bristol -- merchant must be called ; but , as the whole of the profits of [his]1326-a bristol -- merchant mercantile life appeared so very moderate , it was not unfair to guess the dignity of [his]1326-a bristol -- merchant line of trade had been very moderate also . Part of every winter [she]197-miss hawkins had been used to spend in [Bath]30-bath ; but [Bristol]40-bristol was [[her]197-miss hawkins home]638-her home , [the very heart of [Bristol]40-bristol]1328-the very heart of bristol ; for though [the father]1329-the father and [mother]3738-mother had died some years ago , [an uncle]1331-an uncle remained -- in the law line -- nothing more distinctly honourable was hazarded of [him]1331-an uncle , than that [he]1331-an uncle was in the law line ; and with [him]1331-an uncle [the daughter]971-the daughter had lived . [Emma]123-emma guessed [him]1331-an uncle to be the drudge of [some attorney]1333-some attorney , and too stupid to rise . And all the grandeur of the connexion seemed dependent on [the elder sister]1334-the elder sister , who was _ very _ _ well _ _ married _ , to [a gentleman in [a _ great _ _ way _]1336-a _ great _ _ way _ , near [Bristol]40-bristol , who kept [two carriages]3588-two carriages]1335-a gentleman in a _ great _ _ way _ , near bristol , who kept two carriages ! That was the wind - up of the history ; that was the glory of [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins .

Could [she]123-emma but have given [Harriet]111-harriet [her]123-emma feelings about it all ! [She]123-emma had talked [her]111-harriet into love ; but , alas ! [she]111-harriet was not so easily to be talked out of it . The charm of an object to occupy the many vacancies of [Harriet]111-harriet 's mind was not to be talked away . [He]1331-an uncle might be superseded by another ; [he]1331-an uncle certainly would indeed ; nothing could be clearer ; even a [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin would have been sufficient ; but nothing else , [she]111-harriet feared , would cure [her]111-harriet . [Harriet]111-harriet was one of those , who , having once begun , would be always in love . And now , [poor girl]3620-poor girl ! [she]111-harriet was considerably worse from this reappearance of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton . [She]111-harriet was always having a glimpse of [him]95-mr. elton somewhere or other . [Emma]123-emma saw [him]95-mr. elton only once ; but two or three times every day [Harriet]111-harriet was sure _ just _ to meet with [him]95-mr. elton , or _ just _ to miss [him]95-mr. elton , _ just _ to hear [his]95-mr. elton voice , or see [his]95-mr. elton shoulder , _ just _ to have something occur to preserve [him]95-mr. elton in [her]111-harriet fancy , in all the favouring warmth of surprize and conjecture . [She]111-harriet was , moreover , perpetually hearing about [him]95-mr. elton ; for , excepting when at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , [she]111-harriet was always among those who saw no fault in [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , and found nothing so interesting as the discussion of [his]95-mr. elton concerns ; and every report , therefore , every guess -- all that had already occurred , all that might occur in the arrangement of [his]95-mr. elton affairs , comprehending income , [servants]1339-servants , and furniture , was continually in agitation around [her]111-harriet . [Her]111-harriet regard was receiving strength by invariable praise of [him]95-mr. elton , and [her]111-harriet regrets kept alive , and feelings irritated by ceaseless repetitions of [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins 's happiness , and continual observation of , how much [he]95-mr. elton seemed attached!--his air as [he]95-mr. elton walked by [the house]435-the house -- the very sitting of [his]95-mr. elton hat , being all in proof of how much [he]95-mr. elton was in love !

Had it been allowable entertainment , had there been no pain to [[her]111-harriet friend]427-her friend , or reproach to [herself]111-harriet , in the waverings of [Harriet]111-harriet 's mind , [Emma]123-emma would have been amused by its variations . Sometimes [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton predominated , sometimes [the Martins]1302-the martins ; and each was occasionally useful as a check to [the other]739-the other . [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's engagement had been the cure of the agitation of meeting [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin . The unhappiness produced by the knowledge of that engagement had been a little put aside by [Elizabeth Martin]120-elizabeth 's calling at [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's a few days afterwards . [Harriet]111-harriet had not been at [home]562-home ; but a note had been prepared and left for [her]111-harriet , written in the very style to touch ; a small mixture of reproach , with a great deal of kindness ; and till [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton [himself]95-mr. elton appeared , [she]111-harriet had been much occupied by it , continually pondering over what could be done in return , and wishing to do more than [she]111-harriet dared to confess . But [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , in person , had driven away all such cares . While [he]95-mr. elton staid , [the Martins]113-the martins were forgotten ; and on the very morning of [his]95-mr. elton setting off for [Bath]30-bath again , [Emma]123-emma , to dissipate some of the distress it occasioned , judged it best for [her]123-emma to return [Elizabeth Martin]120-elizabeth 's visit .

How that visit was to be acknowledged -- what would be necessary -- and what might be safest , had been a point of some doubtful consideration . Absolute neglect of [the mother and sisters]1345-the mother and sisters , when invited to come , would be ingratitude . It must not be : and yet the danger of a renewal of the acquaintance-- !

After much thinking , [she]123-emma could determine on nothing better , than [Harriet]111-harriet 's returning the visit ; but in a way that , if [they]1345-the mother and sisters had understanding , should convince [them]1345-the mother and sisters that it was to be only a formal acquaintance . [She]123-emma meant to take [her]111-harriet in [the carriage]2719-the carriage , leave [her]111-harriet at [the Abbey Mill]1347-the abbey mill , while [she]123-emma drove a little farther , and call for [her]111-harriet again so soon , as to allow no time for insidious applications or dangerous recurrences to the past , and give the most decided proof of what degree of intimacy was chosen for the future .

[She]123-emma could think of nothing better : and though there was something in it which [her]123-emma own heart could not approve -- something of ingratitude , merely glossed over -- it must be done , or what would become of [Harriet]111-harriet ?

CHAPTER [V

Small heart]208-v small heart had [Harriet]111-harriet for visiting . Only half an hour before [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend called for [her]111-harriet at [[Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's]720-mrs. goddard 's , [her]123-emma evil stars had led [her]111-harriet to the very spot where , at that moment , a trunk , directed to _ [The Rev. Philip Elton , White - Hart , Bath _]1350-the rev. philip elton , white - hart , bath _ , was to be seen under the operation of being lifted into [the butcher]1351-the butcher 's cart , which was to convey it to where [the coaches past]1352-the coaches past ; and every thing in [this world]1353-this world , excepting that trunk and the direction , was consequently a blank .

[She]111-harriet went , however ; and when [they]1354-they reached [the farm]1355-the farm , and [she]111-harriet was to be put down , at the end of the broad , neat gravel walk , which led between espalier apple - trees to the front door , the sight of every thing which had given [her]111-harriet so much pleasure the autumn before , was beginning to revive a little local agitation ; and when [they]1354-they parted , [Emma]123-emma observed [her]111-harriet to be looking around with a sort of fearful curiosity , which determined [her]111-harriet not to allow the visit to exceed the proposed quarter of an hour . [She]111-harriet went on [herself]111-harriet , to give that portion of time to [an old servant who was married , and settled in [Donwell]24-donwell]1356-an old servant who was married , and settled in donwell .

The quarter of an hour brought [her]111-harriet punctually to the white gate again ; and [Miss Smith]111-harriet receiving [her]111-harriet summons , was with [her]111-harriet without delay , and unattended by [any alarming young man]1357-any alarming young man . [She]111-harriet came solitarily down [the gravel walk]1358-the gravel walk -- [a Miss Martin]209-a miss martin just appearing at the door , and parting with [her]111-harriet seemingly with ceremonious civility .

[Harriet]111-harriet could not very soon give an intelligible account . [She]111-harriet was feeling too much ; but at last [Emma]123-emma collected from [her]111-harriet enough to understand the sort of meeting , and the sort of pain it was creating . [She]123-emma had seen only [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin and [the two girls]1359-the two girls . [They]1360-they had received [her]123-emma doubtingly , if not coolly ; and nothing beyond the merest commonplace had been talked almost all the time -- till just at last , when [Mrs. Martin]114-mrs. martin 's saying , all of a sudden , that [she]114-mrs. martin thought [Miss Smith]111-harriet was grown , had brought on a more interesting subject , and a warmer manner . In [that very room]1361-that very room [she]123-emma had been measured last September , with [[her]123-emma two friends]1362-her two friends . There were the pencilled marks and memorandums on the wainscot by the window . _ [He]1363-he _ had done it . [They]1360-they all seemed to remember the day , the hour , the party , the occasion -- to feel the same consciousness , the same regrets -- to be ready to return to the same good understanding ; and [they]1360-they were just growing again like [themselves]1360-they , ( [Harriet]111-harriet , as [Emma]123-emma must suspect , as ready as the best of [them]1360-they to be cordial and happy , ) when [the carriage]2719-the carriage reappeared , and all was over . The style of the visit , and the shortness of it , were then felt to be decisive . Fourteen minutes to be given to those with whom [she]123-emma had thankfully passed six weeks not six months ago!--Emma could not but picture it all , and feel how justly [they]1360-they might resent , how naturally [Harriet]111-harriet must suffer . It was a bad business . [She]123-emma would have given a great deal , or endured a great deal , to have had [the Martins]113-the martins in a higher rank of life . [They]113-the martins were so deserving , that a _ little _ higher should have been enough : but as it was , how could [she]123-emma have done otherwise?--Impossible!--She could not repent . [They]113-the martins must be separated ; but there was a great deal of pain in the process -- so much to [herself]123-emma at this time , that [she]123-emma soon felt the necessity of a little consolation , and resolved on going [home]562-home by way of [Randalls]101-randalls to procure it . [Her]123-emma mind was quite sick of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton and [the Martins]113-the martins . The refreshment of [Randalls]101-randalls was absolutely necessary .

It was a good scheme ; but on driving to the door [they]113-the martins heard that [neither “ master]3884-neither “ master nor [mistress]3885-mistress was at [home]562-home ; ”[3884-neither “ master] [they]113-the martins had both been out some time ; [the man]3033-the man believed [they]113-the martins were gone to [Hartfield]2-hartfield .

“ This is too bad , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , as [they]113-the martins turned away . “ And now [we]113-the martins shall just miss [them]113-the martins ; too [provoking!--I]3887-provoking!--i do not know when [I]123-emma have been so disappointed . ”[123-emma] And [she]123-emma leaned back in the corner , to indulge [her]123-emma murmurs , or to reason them away ; probably a little of both -- such being the commonest process of a not ill - disposed mind . Presently [the carriage stopt]1367-the carriage stopt ; [she]123-emma looked up ; it was stopt by [Mr.]1368-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , who were standing to speak to [her]123-emma . There was instant pleasure in the sight of [them]113-the martins , and still greater pleasure was conveyed in sound -- for [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston immediately accosted [her]123-emma with ,

“ How d'ye do?--how d'ye do?--We have been sitting with [[your]123-emma father]3597-your father -- glad to see [him]3597-your father so well . [Frank]102-frank churchill comes to - morrow -- [I]86-mr. weston had a letter this morning -- [we]113-the martins see [him]3597-your father to - morrow by dinner - time to a certainty -- [he]3597-your father is at [Oxford]42-oxford to - day , and [he]3597-your father comes for a whole fortnight ; [I]86-mr. weston knew it would be so . If [he]3597-your father had come at Christmas [he]3597-your father could not have staid three days ; [I]86-mr. weston was always glad [he]3597-your father did not come at Christmas ; now [we]113-the martins are going to have just the right weather for [him]3597-your father , fine , dry , settled weather . [We]113-the martins shall enjoy [him]3597-your father completely ; every thing has turned out exactly as [we]113-the martins could wish . ”[86-mr. weston]

There was no resisting such news , no possibility of avoiding the influence of such a happy face as [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's , confirmed as it all was by the words and the countenance of [[his]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife , fewer and quieter , but not less to the purpose . To know that _ [she]2763-his wife _ thought [his]86-mr. weston coming certain was enough to make [Emma]123-emma consider it so , and sincerely did [she]123-emma rejoice in [their]1370-their joy . It was a most delightful reanimation of exhausted spirits . The worn - out past was sunk in the freshness of what was coming ; and in the rapidity of half a moment 's thought , [she]123-emma hoped [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton would now be talked of no more .

[Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston gave [her]123-emma the history of the engagements at [Enscombe]7-enscombe , which allowed [[his]86-mr. weston son]523-his son to answer for having an entire fortnight at [his]86-mr. weston command , as well as the route and the method of [his]86-mr. weston journey ; and [she]123-emma listened , and smiled , and congratulated .

“ [I]86-mr. weston shall soon bring [him]86-mr. weston over to [Hartfield]2-hartfield , ”[86-mr. weston] said [he]86-mr. weston , at the conclusion .

[Emma]123-emma could imagine [she]123-emma saw a touch of the arm at this speech , from [[his]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife .

“ [We]3889-we had better move on , [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma , “ [we]3889-we are detaining [the girls]642-the girls . ”[123-emma]

“ Well , well , [I]86-mr. weston am ready;”--and[86-mr. weston] turning again to [Emma]123-emma , “ but [you]123-emma must not be expecting [such a _ very _ fine young man]3891-such a _ very _ fine young man ; [you]123-emma have only had _ [my]86-mr. weston _ account [you]123-emma know ; [I]86-mr. weston dare say [he]3891-such a _ very _ fine young man is really nothing extraordinary:”--though[86-mr. weston] [his]86-mr. weston own sparkling eyes at the moment were speaking a very different conviction .

[Emma]123-emma could look perfectly unconscious and innocent , and answer in a manner that appropriated nothing .

“ Think of [me]88-mrs. weston to - morrow , [[my]88-mrs. weston dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , about four o'clock , ”[88-mrs. weston] was [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's parting injunction ; spoken with some anxiety , and meant only for [her]123-emma .

“ Four o'clock!--depend upon it [he]3891-such a _ very _ fine young man will be [here]2707-here by three , ”[86-mr. weston] was [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's quick amendment ; and so ended a most satisfactory meeting . [Emma]123-emma 's spirits were mounted quite up to happiness ; every thing wore a different air ; [James]90-james and [his]1373-his horses seemed not half so sluggish as before . When [she]123-emma looked at the hedges , [she]123-emma thought [the elder]956-the elder at least must soon be coming out ; and when [she]123-emma turned round to [Harriet]111-harriet , [she]123-emma saw something like a look of spring , a tender smile even there .

“ Will [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill pass through [Bath]30-bath as well as Oxford?”--was[123-emma] a question , however , which did not augur much .

But neither geography nor tranquillity could come all at once , and [Emma]123-emma was now in a humour to resolve that [they]1375-they should both come in time .

The morning of the interesting day arrived , and [[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's faithful pupil]1376-mrs. weston 's faithful pupil did not forget either at ten , or eleven , or twelve o'clock , that [she]1376-mrs. weston 's faithful pupil was to think of [her]1376-mrs. weston 's faithful pupil at four .

“ [[My]123-emma dear]2714-my dear , dear anxious friend,”--said[123-emma] [she]123-emma , in mental soliloquy , while walking [downstairs]1377-downstairs from [[her]123-emma own room]3195-her own room , “ always overcareful for every body 's comfort but [your]2714-my dear own ; [I]123-emma see [you]2714-my dear now in all [your]2714-my dear little fidgets , going again and again into [[his]102-frank churchill room]3895-his room , to be sure that all is right . ”[123-emma] The clock struck twelve as [she]123-emma passed through [the hall]1379-the hall . “ ' Tis twelve ; [I]123-emma shall not forget to think of [you]2714-my dear four hours hence ; and by this time to - morrow , perhaps , or a little later , [I]123-emma may be thinking of the possibility of [their]1380-two gentlemen sitting with her father all calling [here]2707-here . [I]123-emma am sure [they]1380-two gentlemen sitting with her father will bring [him]425-her father soon . ”[123-emma]

[She]123-emma opened the parlour door , and saw [two gentlemen sitting with [[her]123-emma father]425-her father]1380-two gentlemen sitting with her father -- [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston and [[his]86-mr. weston son]523-his son . [They]1380-two gentlemen sitting with her father had been arrived only a few minutes , and [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston had scarcely finished [his]86-mr. weston explanation of [Frank]102-frank churchill 's being a day before [his]86-mr. weston time , and [[her]123-emma father]425-her father was yet in the midst of [his]425-her father very civil welcome and congratulations , when [she]123-emma appeared , to have [her]123-emma share of surprize , introduction , and pleasure .

[The Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill so long talked of , so high in interest , was actually before [her]123-emma -- [he]102-frank churchill was presented to [her]123-emma , and [she]123-emma did not think too much had been said in [his]102-frank churchill praise ; [he]102-frank churchill was [a _ very _ good looking young man]1384-a _ very _ good looking young man ; height , air , address , all were unexceptionable , and [his]102-frank churchill countenance had a great deal of the spirit and liveliness of [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father 's ; [he]102-frank churchill looked quick and sensible . [She]123-emma felt immediately that [she]123-emma should like [him]102-frank churchill ; and there was a well - bred ease of manner , and a readiness to talk , which convinced [her]123-emma that [he]102-frank churchill came intending to be acquainted with [her]123-emma , and that acquainted [they]1386-they soon must be .

[He]102-frank churchill had reached [Randalls]101-randalls the evening before . [She]123-emma was pleased with the eagerness to arrive which had made [him]102-frank churchill alter [his]102-frank churchill plan , and travel earlier , later , and quicker , that [he]102-frank churchill might gain half a day .

“ [I]86-mr. weston told [you]123-emma yesterday , ”[86-mr. weston] cried [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston with exultation , “ [I]86-mr. weston told [you]123-emma all that [he]102-frank churchill would be [here]2707-here before the time named . [I]86-mr. weston remembered what [I]86-mr. weston used to do [myself]86-mr. weston . One can not creep upon a journey ; [one]2775-one can not help getting on faster than [one]2775-one has planned ; and the pleasure of coming in upon [[one]2775-one 's friends]3901-one 's friends before the look - out begins , is worth a great deal more than any little exertion it needs . ”[86-mr. weston]

“ It is a great pleasure where [one]2775-one can indulge in it , ”[532-the young man] said [the young man]532-the young man , “ though there are not many houses that [I]532-the young man should presume on so far ; but in coming _ [home _]3903-home _ [I]532-the young man felt [I]532-the young man might do any thing . ”[532-the young man]

The word _ [home]562-home _ made [[his]532-the young man father]518-his father look on [him]532-the young man with fresh complacency . [Emma]123-emma was directly sure that [he]532-the young man knew how to make [himself]532-the young man agreeable ; the conviction was strengthened by what followed . [He]532-the young man was very much pleased with [Randalls]101-randalls , thought [it]101-randalls [a most admirably arranged house]1390-a most admirably arranged house , would hardly allow [it]101-randalls even to be very small , admired the situation , the walk to [Highbury]3-highbury , [Highbury]3-highbury [itself]3-highbury , [Hartfield]2-hartfield still more , and professed [himself]532-the young man to have always felt the sort of interest in [the country which none but [one]2775-one 's _ own _ country]1391-the country which none but one 's _ own _ country gives , and the greatest curiosity to visit [it]1391-the country which none but one 's _ own _ country . That [he]532-the young man should never have been able to indulge so amiable a feeling before , passed suspiciously through [Emma]123-emma 's brain ; but still , if it were a falsehood , it was a pleasant one , and pleasantly handled . [His]532-the young man manner had no air of study or exaggeration . [He]532-the young man did really look and speak as if in a state of no common enjoyment .

[[Their]1393-their subjects]954-their subjects in general were such as belong to an opening acquaintance . On [his]532-the young man side were the inquiries,--“Was [she]3904-she a horsewoman?--Pleasant rides?--Pleasant walks?--Had [they]1393-their a large neighbourhood?--Highbury , perhaps , afforded society enough?--There were [several very pretty houses]3905-several very pretty houses in and about it.--Balls -- had [they]1393-their balls?--Was it [a musical society]3906-a musical society ? ”[532-the young man]

But when satisfied on all these points , and [their]1393-their acquaintance proportionably advanced , [he]532-the young man contrived to find an opportunity , while [[their]1393-their two fathers]1395-their two fathers were engaged with [each other]430-each other , of introducing [[his]532-the young man mother - in - law]1397-his mother - in - law , and speaking of [her]1397-his mother - in - law with so much handsome praise , so much warm admiration , so much gratitude for the happiness [she]1397-his mother - in - law secured to [[his]532-the young man father]518-his father , and [her]1397-his mother - in - law very kind reception of [himself]532-the young man , as was an additional proof of [his]532-the young man knowing how to please -- and of [his]532-the young man certainly thinking it worth while to try to please [her]1397-his mother - in - law . [He]532-the young man did not advance a word of praise beyond what [she]1397-his mother - in - law knew to be thoroughly deserved by [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ; but , undoubtedly [he]532-the young man could know very little of the matter . [He]532-the young man understood what would be welcome ; [he]532-the young man could be sure of little else . “ [[His]532-the young man father]518-his father 's marriage , ”[532-the young man] [he]532-the young man said , “ had been the wisest measure , [every friend]3908-every friend must rejoice in it ; and [the family from whom]3909-the family from whom [he]532-the young man had received such a blessing must be ever considered as having conferred the highest obligation on [him]532-the young man . ”[532-the young man]

[He]532-the young man got as near as [he]532-the young man could to thanking [her]1397-his mother - in - law for [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse 's merits , without seeming quite to forget that in the common course of things it was to be rather supposed that [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse had formed [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse 's character , than [Miss Woodhouse Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse 's . And at last , as if resolved to qualify [his]532-the young man opinion completely for travelling round to its object , [he]532-the young man wound it all up with astonishment at the youth and beauty of [[her]1397-his mother - in - law person]616-her person .

“ Elegant , agreeable manners , [I]532-the young man was prepared for , ”[532-the young man] said [he]532-the young man ; “ but [I]532-the young man confess that , considering every thing , [I]532-the young man had not expected more than [a very tolerably well - looking woman of a certain age]3910-a very tolerably well - looking woman of a certain age ; [I]532-the young man did not know that [I]532-the young man was to find [a pretty young woman]3367-a pretty young woman in [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . ”[532-the young man]

“ [You]532-the young man can not see too much perfection in [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston for [my]123-emma feelings , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma ; “ were [you]532-the young man to guess [her]88-mrs. weston to be _ eighteen _ , [I]123-emma should listen with pleasure ; but _ [she]88-mrs. weston _ would be ready to quarrel with [you]532-the young man for using such words . Do n't let [her]88-mrs. weston imagine that [you]532-the young man have spoken of [her]88-mrs. weston as [a pretty young woman]3367-a pretty young woman . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]1400-he hope [I]1400-he should know better , ”[1400-he] [he]1400-he replied ; “ no , depend upon it , ( with a gallant bow , ) that in addressing [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston [I]1400-he should understand whom [I]1400-he might praise without any danger of being thought extravagant in [my]1400-he terms . ”[1400-he]

[Emma]123-emma wondered whether the same suspicion of what might be expected from [their]1401-their knowing each other , which had taken strong possession of [her]123-emma mind , had ever crossed [his]1400-he ; and whether [his]1400-he compliments were to be considered as marks of acquiescence , or proofs of defiance . [She]123-emma must see more of [him]1400-he to understand [his]1400-he ways ; at present [she]123-emma only felt they were agreeable .

[She]123-emma had no doubt of what [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston was often thinking about . [His]1400-he quick eye [she]123-emma detected again and again glancing towards [them]1401-their with a happy expression ; and even , when [he]1400-he might have determined not to look , [she]123-emma was confident that [he]1400-he was often listening .

[[Her]123-emma own father]1402-her own father 's perfect exemption from any thought of the kind , the entire deficiency in [him]1400-he of all such sort of penetration or suspicion , was a most comfortable circumstance . Happily [he]1400-he was not farther from approving matrimony than from foreseeing it.--Though always objecting to every marriage that was arranged , [he]1400-he never suffered beforehand from the apprehension of any ; it seemed as if [he]1400-he could not think so ill of [any two persons]1403-any two persons ' understanding as to suppose [they]1403-any two persons meant to marry till it were proved against [them]1403-any two persons . [She]123-emma blessed the favouring blindness . [He]1400-he could now , without the drawback of a single unpleasant surmise , without a glance forward at any possible treachery in [[his]1400-he guest]1404-his guest , give way to all [his]1400-he natural kind - hearted civility in solicitous inquiries after [[Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's accommodation]1405-mr. frank churchill 's accommodation on [his]1400-he journey , through the sad evils of sleeping two nights on [the road]846-the road , and express very genuine unmixed anxiety to know that [he]1400-he had certainly escaped catching cold -- which , however , [he]1400-he could not allow [him]1400-he to feel quite assured of [himself]1400-he till after another night .

A reasonable visit paid , [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston began to move.--“He must be going . [He]1400-he had business at [the Crown]43-the crown about [his]1400-he hay , and a great many errands for [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston at [Ford 's]212-ford 's , but [he]1400-he need not hurry any body else . ”[86-mr. weston] [[His]86-mr. weston son]523-his son , too well bred to hear the hint , rose immediately also , saying ,

“ As [you]86-mr. weston are going farther on business , [sir]2734-sir , [I]86-mr. weston will take the opportunity of paying a visit , which must be paid some day or other , and therefore may as well be paid now . [I]86-mr. weston have the honour of being acquainted with [a neighbour of yours]3914-a neighbour of yours , ( turning to [Emma]123-emma , ) [a lady residing in or near [Highbury]3-highbury]3915-a lady residing in or near highbury ; [a family of the name of Fairfax]3916-a family of the name of fairfax . [I]86-mr. weston shall have no difficulty , [I]86-mr. weston suppose , in finding [the house]435-the house ; though [Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , [I]86-mr. weston believe , is not the proper name -- [I]86-mr. weston should rather say [Barnes]210-barnes , or [Bates]105-miss bates . Do [you]86-mr. weston know [any family of that name]3918-any family of that name ? ”[86-mr. weston]

“ To be sure [we]3919-we do , ”[518-his father] cried [[his]1408-his father]518-his father ; “ [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates -- [we]3919-we passed [[her]110-mrs. bates house]717-her house -- [I]518-his father saw [Miss Bates]105-miss bates at the window . True , true , [you]86-mr. weston are acquainted with [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax ; [I]518-his father remember [you]86-mr. weston knew [her]152-miss fairfax at [Weymouth]23-weymouth , and [a fine girl]3921-a fine girl [she]152-miss fairfax is . Call upon [her]152-miss fairfax , by all means . ”[518-his father]

“ There is no necessity for [my]532-the young man calling this morning , ”[532-the young man] said [the young man]532-the young man ; “ another day would do as well ; but there was that degree of acquaintance at [Weymouth]23-weymouth which-- ”[532-the young man]

“ Oh ! go to - day , go to - day . Do not defer it . What is right to be done can not be done too soon . And , besides , [I]518-his father must give [you]86-mr. weston a hint , [Frank]102-frank churchill ; any want of attention to [her]152-miss fairfax _ here _ should be carefully avoided . [You]86-mr. weston saw [her]152-miss fairfax with [the Campbells]190-the campbells , when [she]152-miss fairfax was the equal of [every body [she]152-miss fairfax mixed with]3922-every body she mixed with , but here [she]152-miss fairfax is with [a poor old grandmother , who has barely enough to live on]3923-a poor old grandmother , who has barely enough to live on . If [you]86-mr. weston do not call early it will be a slight . ”[518-his father]

[The son]2764-the son looked convinced .

“ [I]123-emma have heard [her]152-miss fairfax speak of the acquaintance , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma ; “ [she]152-miss fairfax is [a very elegant young woman]3924-a very elegant young woman . ”[123-emma]

[He]2764-the son agreed to it , but with so quiet a “ Yes , ”[518-his father] as inclined [her]123-emma almost to doubt [his]2764-the son real concurrence ; and yet there must be a very distinct sort of elegance for the fashionable world , if [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax could be thought only ordinarily gifted with it .

“ If [you]2764-the son were never particularly struck by [her]152-miss fairfax manners before , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma , “ [I]123-emma think [you]2764-the son will to - day . [You]2764-the son will see [her]152-miss fairfax to advantage ; see [her]152-miss fairfax and hear [her]152-miss fairfax -- no , [I]123-emma am afraid [you]2764-the son will not hear [her]152-miss fairfax at all , for [she]152-miss fairfax has [an aunt who never holds [her]152-miss fairfax tongue]3925-an aunt who never holds her tongue . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]2764-the son are acquainted with [Miss Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , [sir]2734-sir , are [you]2764-the son ? ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , always the last to make [his]85-mr. woodhouse way in conversation ; “ then give [me]85-mr. woodhouse leave to assure [you]2764-the son that [you]2764-the son will find [her]152-miss fairfax [a very agreeable young lady]3927-a very agreeable young lady . [She]152-miss fairfax is staying [here]2707-here on a visit to [[her]152-miss fairfax grandmama]819-her grandmama and [aunt]3628-aunt , [very worthy people]3931-very worthy people ; [I]85-mr. woodhouse have known [them]3931-very worthy people all [my]85-mr. woodhouse life . [They]3931-very worthy people will be extremely glad to see [you]2764-the son , [I]85-mr. woodhouse am sure ; and [one of [[my]85-mr. woodhouse servants]3933-my servants]3932-one of my servants shall go with [you]2764-the son to shew [you]2764-the son the way . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [[My]123-emma dear sir]3019-my dear sir , upon no account in [the world]403-the world ; [[my]123-emma father]2740-my father can direct [me]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

“ But [[your]2764-the son father]3597-your father is not going so far ; [he]3597-your father is only going to the Crown , quite on the other side of [the street]1208-the street , and there are [a great many houses]3939-a great many houses ; [you]2764-the son might be very much at a loss , and it is a very dirty walk , unless [you]2764-the son keep on the footpath ; but [[my]85-mr. woodhouse coachman]3940-my coachman can tell [you]2764-the son where [you]2764-the son had best cross [the street]1208-the street . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

[Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill still declined it , looking as serious as [he]102-frank churchill could , and [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father gave [his]518-his father hearty support by calling out , “ [[My]518-his father good friend]3942-my good friend , this is quite unnecessary ; [Frank]102-frank churchill knows a puddle of water when [he]102-frank churchill sees it , and as to [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's , [he]102-frank churchill may get there from [the Crown]43-the crown in a hop , step , and jump . ”[518-his father]

[They]1413-they were permitted to go alone ; and with a cordial nod from [one]2775-one , and a graceful bow from the other , [the two gentlemen]1415-the two gentlemen took leave . [Emma]123-emma remained very well pleased with this beginning of the acquaintance , and could now engage to think of [them]1413-they all at [Randalls]101-randalls any hour of the day , with full confidence in [their]1413-they comfort .

CHAPTER VI

The next morning brought [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill again . [He]102-frank churchill came with [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , to whom and to [Highbury]3-highbury [he]102-frank churchill seemed to take very cordially . [He]102-frank churchill had been sitting with [her]88-mrs. weston , it appeared , most companionably at [home]562-home , till [her]88-mrs. weston usual hour of exercise ; and on being desired to chuse [their]1413-they walk , immediately fixed on [Highbury.--“He]211-highbury.--“he did not doubt there being very pleasant walks in every direction , but if left to [him]102-frank churchill , [he]102-frank churchill should always chuse the same .
