[Highbury]3-highbury , [that airy , cheerful , happy - looking Highbury]3943-that airy , cheerful , happy - looking highbury , would be [his]102-frank churchill constant attraction . ”--Highbury[88-mrs. weston] , with [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , stood for [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; and [she]88-mrs. weston trusted to [its]2-hartfield bearing the same construction with [him]102-frank churchill . [They]1413-they walked thither directly .

[Emma]123-emma had hardly expected [them]1413-they : for [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , who had called in for half a minute , in order to hear that [[his]86-mr. weston son]523-his son was very handsome , knew nothing of [their]1413-they plans ; and it was an agreeable surprize to [her]88-mrs. weston , therefore , to perceive [them]1413-they walking up to [the house]435-the house together , arm in arm . [She]88-mrs. weston was wanting to see [him]102-frank churchill again , and especially to see [him]102-frank churchill in company with [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , upon [his]102-frank churchill behaviour to whom [her]88-mrs. weston opinion of [him]102-frank churchill was to depend . If [he]102-frank churchill were deficient there , nothing should make amends for it . But on seeing [them]1413-they together , [she]88-mrs. weston became perfectly satisfied . It was not merely in fine words or hyperbolical compliment that [he]102-frank churchill paid [his]102-frank churchill duty ; nothing could be more proper or pleasing than [his]102-frank churchill whole manner to [her]88-mrs. weston -- nothing could more agreeably denote [his]102-frank churchill wish of considering [her]88-mrs. weston as [a friend]416-a friend and securing [her]88-mrs. weston affection . And there was time enough for [Emma]123-emma to form a reasonable judgment , as [their]1413-they visit included all the rest of the morning . [They]1413-they were all three walking about together for an hour or two -- first round [the shrubberies of [Hartfield]2-hartfield]1420-the shrubberies of hartfield , and afterwards in [Highbury]3-highbury . [He]102-frank churchill was delighted with every thing ; admired [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse sufficiently for [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's ear ; and when [their]1413-they going farther was resolved on , confessed [his]102-frank churchill wish to be made acquainted with [the whole village]1421-the whole village , and found matter of commendation and interest much oftener than [Emma]123-emma could have supposed .

Some of the objects of [his]102-frank churchill curiosity spoke very amiable feelings . [He]102-frank churchill begged to be shewn [the house which [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father]1422-the house which his father had lived in so long , and which had been [the home of [[his]102-frank churchill father 's father]1425-his father 's father]1424-the home of his father 's father ; and on recollecting that [an old woman who had nursed [him]102-frank churchill]1426-an old woman who had nursed him was still living , walked in quest of [[her]1426-an old woman who had nursed him cottage]1427-her cottage from one end of [the street]1208-the street to the other ; and though in some points of pursuit or observation there was no positive merit , [they]1413-they shewed , altogether , a good - will towards [Highbury]3-highbury in general , which must be very like a merit to those [he]102-frank churchill was with .

[Emma]123-emma watched and decided , that with such feelings as were now shewn , it could not be fairly supposed that [he]102-frank churchill had been ever voluntarily absenting [himself]102-frank churchill ; that [he]102-frank churchill had not been acting a part , or making a parade of insincere professions ; and that [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley certainly had not done [him]102-frank churchill justice .

[Their]1413-they first pause was at [the Crown Inn]1429-the crown inn , [an inconsiderable house]1430-an inconsiderable house , though [the principal one of the sort]1431-the principal one of the sort , where a couple of pair of post - horses were kept , more for the convenience of [the neighbourhood]1432-the neighbourhood than from any run on [the road]846-the road ; and [[his]102-frank churchill companions]1147-his companions had not expected to be detained by any interest excited there ; but in passing it [they]1413-they gave the history of [the large room]1435-the large room visibly added ; [it]1435-the large room had been built many years ago for [a ball - room]1436-a ball - room , and while [the neighbourhood]1432-the neighbourhood had been in a particularly populous , dancing state , had been occasionally used as such;--but such brilliant days had long passed away , and now the highest purpose for which [it]1435-the large room was ever wanted was to accommodate a whist club established among [the gentlemen]1438-the gentlemen and [half - gentlemen of [the place]450-the place]1439-half - gentlemen of the place . [He]102-frank churchill was immediately interested . Its character as [a ball - room]1436-a ball - room caught [him]102-frank churchill ; and instead of passing on , [he]102-frank churchill stopt for several minutes at the two superior sashed windows which were open , to look in and contemplate [its]1435-the large room capabilities , and lament that its original purpose should have ceased . [He]102-frank churchill saw no fault in [the room]701-the room , [he]102-frank churchill would acknowledge none which [they]1413-they suggested . No , it was long enough , broad enough , handsome enough . [It]701-the room would hold the very number for comfort . [They]1413-they ought to have balls [there]448-there at least every fortnight through the winter . Why had not [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse revived the former good old days of [the room?--She who could do any thing in [Highbury]3-highbury]1444-the room?--she who could do any thing in highbury ! The want of [proper families]1445-proper families in [the place]450-the place , and the conviction that none beyond [the place]450-the place and [[its]450-the place immediate environs]1448-its immediate environs could be tempted to attend , were mentioned ; but [he]102-frank churchill was not satisfied . [He]102-frank churchill could not be persuaded that [so many good - looking houses as [he]102-frank churchill saw around [him]102-frank churchill]1449-so many good - looking houses as he saw around him , could not furnish numbers enough for such a meeting ; and even when particulars were given and [families]1450-families described , [he]102-frank churchill was still unwilling to admit that the inconvenience of such a mixture would be any thing , or that there would be the smallest difficulty in every body 's returning into [their]1413-they proper place the next morning . [He]102-frank churchill argued like [a young man very much bent on dancing]1451-a young man very much bent on dancing ; and [Emma]123-emma was rather surprized to see the constitution of [the Weston]86-mr. weston prevail so decidedly against the habits of [the Churchills]100-the churchills . [He]102-frank churchill seemed to have all the life and spirit , cheerful feelings , and social inclinations of [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father , and nothing of the pride or reserve of [Enscombe]7-enscombe . Of pride , indeed , there was , perhaps , scarcely enough ; [his]102-frank churchill indifference to a confusion of rank , bordered too much on inelegance of mind . [He]102-frank churchill could be [no judge]1453-no judge , however , of the evil [he]102-frank churchill was holding cheap . It was but an effusion of lively spirits .

At last [he]102-frank churchill was persuaded to move on from the front of [the Crown]43-the crown ; and being now almost facing [the house where [the Bateses]161-the bateses lodged]1454-the house where the bateses lodged , [Emma]123-emma recollected [his]102-frank churchill intended visit the day before , and asked [him]102-frank churchill if [he]102-frank churchill had paid it .

“ Yes , oh ! yes”--he[123-emma] replied ; “ [I]123-emma was just going to mention it . [A very successful visit:--I]3944-a very successful visit:--i saw [all the three ladies]3945-all the three ladies ; and felt very much obliged to [you]123-emma for [your]123-emma preparatory hint . If [the talking aunt]3946-the talking aunt had taken [me]123-emma quite by surprize , it must have been the death of [me]123-emma . As it was , [I]123-emma was only betrayed into paying a most unreasonable visit . Ten minutes would have been all that was necessary , perhaps all that was proper ; and [I]123-emma had told [[my]123-emma father]2740-my father [I]123-emma should certainly be at [home]562-home before [him]2740-my father -- but there was no getting away , no pause ; and , to [my]123-emma utter astonishment , [I]123-emma found , when [he]2740-my father ( finding [me]123-emma nowhere else ) joined [me]123-emma there at last , that [I]123-emma had been actually sitting with [them]3949-them very nearly three - quarters of an hour . [The good lady]3950-the good lady had not given [me]123-emma the possibility of escape before . ”[123-emma]

“ And how did [you]2740-my father think [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax looking ? ”[123-emma]

“ Ill , very ill -- that is , if [a young lady]2768-a young lady can ever be allowed to look ill . But the expression is hardly admissible , [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , is it ? [Ladies]3480-ladies can never look ill . And , seriously , [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax is naturally so pale , as almost always to give the appearance of ill health.--A most deplorable want of complexion . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma would not agree to this , and began a warm defence of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's complexion . “ It was certainly never brilliant , but [she]152-miss fairfax would not allow it to have a sickly hue in general ; and there was a softness and delicacy in [her]152-miss fairfax skin which gave peculiar elegance to the character of [her]152-miss fairfax face . ”[123-emma] [He]1455-i listened with all due deference ; acknowledged that [he]1455-i had heard [many people]3446-many people say the same -- but yet [he]1455-i must confess , that to [him]1455-i nothing could make amends for the want of the fine glow of health . Where features were indifferent , a fine complexion gave beauty to [them]1457-them all ; and where [they]1457-them were good , the effect was -- fortunately [he]1455-i need not attempt to describe what the effect was .

“ Well , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ there is no disputing about taste.--At least [you]1455-i admire [her]152-miss fairfax except [her]152-miss fairfax complexion . ”[123-emma]

[He]1455-i shook [his]1455-i head and laughed.--“I can not separate [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [her]152-miss fairfax complexion . ”[1455-i]

“ Did [you]1455-i see [her]152-miss fairfax often at [Weymouth]23-weymouth ? Were [you]1455-i often in the same society ? ”[1455-i]

At this moment [they]1458-they were approaching [Ford]212-ford 's 's , and [he]1455-i hastily exclaimed , “ Ha ! this must be the very shop that [every body]2749-every body attends every day of [their]2749-every body lives , as [[my]1455-i father]2740-my father informs [me]1455-i . [He]2740-my father comes to [Highbury]3-highbury [himself]2740-my father , [he]2740-my father says , six days out of the seven , and has always business at [Ford 's]212-ford 's . If it be not inconvenient to [you]3955-you , pray let [us]1458-they go in , that [I]1455-i may prove [myself]1455-i to belong to [the place]450-the place , to be [a true citizen of [Highbury]3-highbury]3957-a true citizen of highbury . [I]1455-i must buy something at [Ford 's]212-ford 's . [It]3958-it will be taking out [my]1455-i freedom.--I dare say [they]3959-they sell gloves . ”[1455-i]

“ Oh ! yes , gloves and every thing . [I]1455-i do admire [your]3955-you patriotism . [You]3955-you will be adored in [Highbury]3-highbury . [You]3955-you were very popular before [you]3955-you came , because [you]3955-you were [[Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's son]3960-mr. weston 's son -- but lay out half a guinea at [Ford 's]212-ford 's , and [your]3955-you popularity will stand upon [your]3955-you own virtues . ”[1455-i]

[They]1459-they went in ; and while the sleek , well - tied parcels of “ [Men 's Beavers ”[1455-i] and “ York Tan ”]3961-men 's beavers ” and “ york tan ”[1455-i] were bringing down and displaying on the counter , [he]1460-i said--“But [I]1455-i beg [your]3955-you pardon , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [you]3955-you were speaking to [me]1455-i , [you]3955-you were saying something at the very moment of this burst of [my]1455-i _ amor _ _ patriae _ . Do not let [me]1455-i lose it . [I]1455-i assure [you]3955-you the utmost stretch of public fame would not make [me]1455-i amends for the loss of any happiness in private life . ”[1455-i]

“ [I]1460-i merely asked , whether [you]3955-you had known much of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [[her]152-miss fairfax party]3962-her party at [Weymouth]23-weymouth . ”[1460-i]

“ And now that [I]1455-i understand [your]3955-you question , [I]1455-i must pronounce it to be a very unfair one . It is always [the lady]3048-the lady 's right to decide on the degree of acquaintance . [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax must already have given [her]152-miss fairfax account.--I shall not commit [myself]1455-i by claiming more than [she]152-miss fairfax may chuse to allow . ”[1455-i]

“ Upon [my]1460-i word ! [you]3955-you answer as discreetly as [she]152-miss fairfax could do [herself]152-miss fairfax . But [her]152-miss fairfax account of every thing leaves so much to be guessed , [she]152-miss fairfax is so very reserved , so very unwilling to give the least information about any body , that [I]1460-i really think [you]3955-you may say what [you]3955-you like of [your]3955-you acquaintance with [her]152-miss fairfax . ”[1460-i]

“ May [I]1455-i , indeed?--Then [I]1455-i will speak the truth , and nothing suits [me]1455-i so well . [I]1455-i met [her]152-miss fairfax frequently at [Weymouth]23-weymouth . [I]1455-i had known [the Campbells]3964-the campbells a little in [town]2760-town ; and at [Weymouth]23-weymouth [we]3966-we were very much in the same set . [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell is [a very agreeable man]3967-a very agreeable man , and [Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell [a friendly , warm - hearted woman]3968-a friendly , warm - hearted woman . [I]1455-i like [them]3964-the campbells all . ”[1455-i]

“ [You]1455-i know [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's situation in life , [I]1460-i conclude ; what [she]152-miss fairfax is destined to be ? ”[1460-i]

“ Yes--(rather hesitatingly)--I believe [I]1455-i do . ”[1455-i]

“ [You]1455-i get upon [delicate subjects]3969-delicate subjects , [Emma]123-emma , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston smiling ; “ remember that [I]88-mrs. weston am here.--Mr . [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill hardly knows what to say when [you]1455-i speak of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's situation in life . [I]88-mrs. weston will move a little farther off . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [I]123-emma certainly do forget to think of _ [her]152-miss fairfax _ , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ as having ever been any thing but [[my]123-emma friend]3149-my friend and [[my]123-emma dearest friend]3971-my dearest friend . ”[123-emma]

[He]1461-i looked as if [he]1461-i fully understood and honoured such a sentiment .

When the gloves were bought , and [they]1462-we had quitted [the shop]3873-the shop again , “ Did [you]1455-i ever hear [the young lady [we]1462-we were speaking of]3972-the young lady we were speaking of , [play]3973-play ? ”[102-frank churchill] said [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill .

“ Ever hear [her]152-miss fairfax ! ”[123-emma] repeated [Emma]123-emma . “ [You]1461-i forget how much [she]152-miss fairfax belongs to [Highbury]3-highbury . [I]123-emma have heard [her]152-miss fairfax every year of [our]1462-we lives since [we]1462-we both began . [She]152-miss fairfax plays charmingly . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]1461-i think so , do you?--I wanted the opinion of [some one who could really judge]3974-some one who could really judge . [She]152-miss fairfax appeared to [me]1461-i to play well , that is , with considerable taste , but [I]1461-i know nothing of the matter myself.--I am excessively fond of music , but without the smallest skill or right of judging of any body 's performance.--I have been used to hear [her]152-miss fairfax 's admired ; and [I]1461-i remember one proof of [her]152-miss fairfax being thought to play [well:--a man]3975-well:--a man , [a very musical man]3976-a very musical man , and in love with [another woman]3977-another woman -- engaged to [her]152-miss fairfax -- on the point of marriage -- would yet never ask [that other woman]3978-that other woman to sit down to the instrument , if [the lady in question]3979-the lady in question could sit down instead -- never seemed to like to hear one if [he]3975-well:--a man could hear the other . That , [I]1461-i thought , in [a man of known musical talent]3980-a man of known musical talent , was some proof . ”[1461-i]

“ Proof indeed ! ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , highly amused.--“Mr . [Dixon]192-mr. dixon is very musical , is [he]192-mr. dixon ? [We]3981-we shall know more about [them]3982-them all , in half an hour , from [you]123-emma , than [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax would have vouchsafed in half a year . ”[123-emma]

“ Yes , [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon and [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell were [the persons]3983-the persons ; and [I]1461-i thought it a very strong proof . ”[1461-i]

“ Certainly -- very strong it was ; to own the truth , a great deal stronger than , if _ [I]123-emma _ had been [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell , would have been at all agreeable to [me]123-emma . [I]123-emma could not excuse [a man]2840-a man 's having more music than love -- more ear than eye -- a more acute sensibility to fine sounds than to [my]123-emma feelings . How did [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell appear to like it ? ”[123-emma]

“ [It]192-mr. dixon was [[her]193-miss campbell very particular friend]3985-her very particular friend , [you]123-emma know . ”[1461-i]

“ Poor comfort ! ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , laughing . “ [One]2775-one would rather have [a stranger]3987-a stranger preferred than [one 's very particular friend]3988-one 's very particular friend -- with [a stranger]3987-a stranger it might not recur again -- but the misery of having [a very particular friend]3990-a very particular friend always at hand , to do every thing better than [one]2775-one does oneself!--Poor [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon ! Well , [I]123-emma am glad [she]193-miss campbell is gone to settle in [Ireland]32-ireland . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]123-emma are right . It was not very flattering to [Miss Campbell]193-miss campbell ; but [she]193-miss campbell really did not seem to feel it . ”[1461-i]

“ So much the better -- or so much the worse:--I do not know which . But be it sweetness or be it stupidity in [her]193-miss campbell -- quickness of friendship , or dulness of feeling -- there was one person , [I]123-emma think , who must have felt it : [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax [herself]152-miss fairfax . [She]152-miss fairfax must have felt the improper and dangerous distinction . ”[123-emma]

“ As to that -- [I]1461-i do not-- ”[1461-i]

“ Oh ! do not imagine that [I]123-emma expect an account of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's sensations from [you]123-emma , or from any body else . [They]3992-they are known to [no human being]3993-no human being , [I]123-emma guess , but [herself]152-miss fairfax . But if [she]152-miss fairfax continued to play whenever [she]152-miss fairfax was asked by [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , one may guess what [one chuses]3994-one chuses . ”[123-emma]

“ There appeared such a perfectly good understanding among [them]3995-them all-- ”[1464-i] [he]1464-i began rather quickly , but checking [himself]1464-i , added , “ however , it is impossible for [me]1464-i to say on what terms [they]3995-them really were -- how it might all be behind the scenes . [I]1464-i can only say that there was smoothness outwardly . But [you]123-emma , who have known [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax from [a child]497-a child , must be a better judge of [her]152-miss fairfax character , and of how [she]152-miss fairfax is likely to conduct [herself]152-miss fairfax in critical situations , than [I]1464-i can be . ”[1464-i]

“ [I]123-emma have known [her]152-miss fairfax from [a child]497-a child , undoubtedly ; [we]3998-we have been [children]1241-children and [women together]4000-women together ; and it is natural to suppose that [we]3998-we should be intimate,--that [we]3998-we should have taken to each other whenever [she]152-miss fairfax visited [[her]152-miss fairfax friends]3093-her friends . But [we]3998-we never did . [I]123-emma hardly know how it has happened ; a little , perhaps , from that wickedness on [my]123-emma side which was prone to take disgust towards [a girl so idolized and so cried up as [she]152-miss fairfax always was , by [[her]152-miss fairfax aunt]3293-her aunt and [grandmother]4004-grandmother , and all [their]3093-her friends set]4002-a girl so idolized and so cried up as she always was , by her aunt and grandmother , and all their set . And then , [her]152-miss fairfax reserve -- [I]123-emma never could attach [myself]123-emma to [any one so completely reserved]4005-any one so completely reserved . ”[123-emma]

“ It is a most repulsive quality , indeed , ”[1465-he] said [he]1465-he . “ Oftentimes very convenient , no doubt , but never pleasing . There is safety in reserve , but no attraction . [One]2775-one can not love [a reserved person]4007-a reserved person . ”[1465-he]

“ Not till the reserve ceases towards [oneself]2775-one ; and then the attraction may be the greater . But [I]1465-he must be more in want of [a friend]416-a friend , or [an agreeable companion]4009-an agreeable companion , than [I]1465-he have yet been , to take the trouble of conquering any body 's reserve to procure one . Intimacy between [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [me]1465-he is quite out of the question . [I]1465-he have no reason to think ill of [her]152-miss fairfax -- not the least -- except that such extreme and perpetual cautiousness of word and manner , such a dread of giving a distinct idea about any body , is apt to suggest suspicions of there being something to conceal . ”[1465-he]

[He]1465-he perfectly agreed with [her]1466-her : and after walking together so long , and thinking so much alike , [Emma]123-emma felt [herself]123-emma so well acquainted with [him]1465-he , that [she]123-emma could hardly believe it to be only [their]1467-their second meeting . [He]1465-he was not exactly what [she]123-emma had expected ; less of [the man of [the world]403-the world]1468-the man of the world in some of [his]1465-he notions , less of [the spoiled child of fortune]1470-the spoiled child of fortune , therefore better than [she]123-emma had expected . [His]1465-he ideas seemed more moderate -- [his]1465-he feelings warmer . [She]123-emma was particularly struck by [his]1465-he manner of considering [[Mr. Elton]1471-mr. elton 's house]1472-mr. elton 's house , which , as well as [the church]3170-the church , [he]1465-he would go and look at , and would not join [them]1474-them in finding much fault with . No , [he]1465-he could not believe it [a bad house]1475-a bad house ; [not such a house as [a man]2840-a man]1476-not such a house as a man was to be pitied for having . If [it]1472-mr. elton 's house were to be shared with [the woman [he]1465-he loved]1478-the woman he loved , [he]1465-he could not think [any man]3263-any man to be pitied for having [that house]1480-that house . There must be ample room in [it]1480-that house for every real comfort . [The man]3033-the man must be [a blockhead who wanted more]1482-a blockhead who wanted more .

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston laughed , and said [he]1465-he did not know what [he]1465-he was talking about . Used only to [a large house]1483-a large house [himself]1465-he , and without ever thinking how many advantages and [accommodations]1484-accommodations were attached to [its]1483-a large house size , [he]1465-he could be no judge of the privations inevitably belonging to [a small one]1485-a small one . But [Emma]123-emma , in [her]123-emma own mind , determined that [he]1465-he _ did _ know what [he]1465-he was talking about , and that [he]1465-he shewed a very amiable inclination to settle early in life , and to marry , from worthy motives . [He]1465-he might not be aware of the inroads on domestic peace to be occasioned by [[no housekeeper]1486-no housekeeper 's room]1487-no housekeeper 's room , or [[a bad butler]1488-a bad butler 's pantry]1489-a bad butler 's pantry , but no doubt [he]1465-he did perfectly feel that [Enscombe]7-enscombe could not make [him]1465-he happy , and that whenever [he]1465-he were attached , [he]1465-he would willingly give up much of wealth to be allowed an early establishment .

CHAPTER VII

[Emma]123-emma 's very good opinion of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill was a little shaken the following day , by hearing that [he]102-frank churchill was gone off to [London]1-london , merely to have [his]102-frank churchill hair cut . A sudden freak seemed to have seized [him]102-frank churchill at breakfast , and [he]102-frank churchill had sent for a chaise and set off , intending to return to dinner , but with no more important view that appeared than having [his]102-frank churchill hair cut . There was certainly no harm in [his]102-frank churchill travelling sixteen miles twice over on such an errand ; but there was an air of foppery and nonsense in it which [she]123-emma could not approve . It did not accord with the rationality of plan , the moderation in expense , or even the unselfish warmth of heart , which [she]123-emma had believed [herself]123-emma to discern in [him]102-frank churchill yesterday . Vanity , extravagance , love of change , restlessness of temper , which must be doing something , good or bad ; heedlessness as to the pleasure of [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , indifferent as to how [his]102-frank churchill conduct might appear in general ; [he]102-frank churchill became liable to all these charges . [[His]102-frank churchill father]518-his father only called [him]102-frank churchill [a coxcomb]1492-a coxcomb , and thought it a very good story ; but that [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston did not like it , was clear enough , by [her]88-mrs. weston passing it over as quickly as possible , and making no other comment than that “ [all young people]4010-all young people would have [their]4010-all young people little whims . ”[88-mrs. weston]

With the exception of this little blot , [Emma]123-emma found that [his]102-frank churchill visit hitherto had given [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend only good ideas of [him]102-frank churchill . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was very ready to say how attentive and pleasant a companion [he]102-frank churchill made [himself]102-frank churchill -- how much [she]88-mrs. weston saw to like in [his]102-frank churchill disposition altogether . [He]102-frank churchill appeared to have a very open temper -- certainly [a very cheerful and lively one]1494-a very cheerful and lively one ; [she]88-mrs. weston could observe nothing wrong in [his]102-frank churchill notions , a great deal decidedly right ; [he]102-frank churchill spoke of [[his]102-frank churchill uncle]517-his uncle with warm regard , was fond of talking of [him]517-his uncle -- said [he]517-his uncle would be [the best man in [the world]403-the world]1496-the best man in the world if [he]517-his uncle were left to [himself]517-his uncle ; and though there was no being attached to [the aunt]520-the aunt , [he]102-frank churchill acknowledged [her]520-the aunt kindness with gratitude , and seemed to mean always to speak of [her]520-the aunt with respect . This was all very promising ; and , but for such an unfortunate fancy for having [his]102-frank churchill hair cut , there was nothing to denote [him]102-frank churchill unworthy of the distinguished honour which [her]88-mrs. weston imagination had given [him]102-frank churchill ; the honour , if not of being really in love with [her]520-the aunt , of being at least very near it , and saved only by [her]88-mrs. weston own indifference--(for still [her]88-mrs. weston resolution held of never marrying)--the honour , in short , of being marked out for [her]520-the aunt by all [their]1499-their joint acquaintance .

[Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , on [his]86-mr. weston side , added a virtue to the account which must have some weight . [He]86-mr. weston gave [her]88-mrs. weston to understand that [Frank]102-frank churchill admired [her]88-mrs. weston extremely -- thought [her]88-mrs. weston very beautiful and very charming ; and with so much to be said for [him]102-frank churchill altogether , [she]88-mrs. weston found [she]88-mrs. weston must not judge [him]102-frank churchill harshly . As [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston observed , “ [all young people]4010-all young people would have [their]4010-all young people little whims . ”[88-mrs. weston]

There was [one person among [his]86-mr. weston new acquaintance]1500-one person among his new acquaintance in [Surry]31-surry , not so leniently disposed . In general [he]102-frank churchill was judged , throughout [the parishes of [Donwell]24-donwell and [Highbury]3-highbury]3697-the parishes of donwell and highbury , with great candour ; liberal allowances were made for the little excesses of [such a handsome young man]1502-such a handsome young man -- [one who smiled so often and bowed so well]1503-one who smiled so often and bowed so well ; but there was one spirit among [them]3697-the parishes of donwell and highbury not to be softened , from its power of censure , by bows or smiles -- [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . The circumstance was told [him]102-frank churchill at [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; for the moment , [he]102-frank churchill was silent ; but [Emma]123-emma heard [him]102-frank churchill almost immediately afterwards say to [himself]102-frank churchill , over a newspaper [he]102-frank churchill held in [his]102-frank churchill hand , “ Hum ! just the trifling , silly fellow [I]102-frank churchill took [him]102-frank churchill for . ”[102-frank churchill] [She]123-emma had half a mind to resent ; but an instant 's observation convinced [her]123-emma that it was really said only to relieve [his]102-frank churchill own feelings , and not meant to provoke ; and therefore [she]123-emma let it pass .

Although in one instance [the bearers of not good tidings]1504-the bearers of not good tidings , [Mr.]1505-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's visit this morning was in another respect particularly opportune . Something occurred while [they]1506-they were at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , to make [Emma]123-emma want [their]1506-they advice ; and , which was still more lucky , [she]123-emma wanted exactly the advice [they]1506-they gave .

This was the occurrence:--The [Coles]184-the coles had been settled some years in [Highbury]3-highbury , and were [very good sort of people]620-very good sort of people -- friendly , liberal , and unpretending ; but , on the other hand , [they]184-the coles were of low origin , in trade , and only moderately genteel . On [their]184-the coles first coming into [the country]611-the country , [they]184-the coles had lived in proportion to [their]184-the coles income , quietly , keeping little company , and that little unexpensively ; but the last year or two had brought [them]184-the coles a considerable increase of means -- [the house in [town]2760-town]1509-the house in town had yielded greater profits , and fortune in general had smiled on [them]184-the coles . With [their]184-the coles wealth , [their]184-the coles views increased ; [their]184-the coles want of [a larger house]1511-a larger house , [their]184-the coles inclination for more company . [They]184-the coles added to [[their]184-the coles house]1512-their house , to [[their]184-the coles number of [servants]1339-servants]1513-their number of servants , to [their]184-the coles expenses of every sort ; and by this time were , in fortune and style of living , second only to [the family at [Hartfield]2-hartfield]1515-the family at hartfield . [Their]184-the coles love of society , and [[their]184-the coles new dining - room]1516-their new dining - room , prepared every body for [their]184-the coles keeping dinner - company ; and a few parties , chiefly among [the single men]1517-the single men , had already taken place . [The regular and best families]1518-the regular and best families [Emma]123-emma could hardly suppose [they]184-the coles would presume to invite -- neither [Donwell]24-donwell , nor [Hartfield]2-hartfield , nor [Randalls]101-randalls . Nothing should tempt _ [her]123-emma _ to go , if [they]184-the coles did ; and [she]123-emma regretted that [[her]123-emma father]425-her father 's known habits would be giving [her]123-emma refusal less meaning than [she]123-emma could wish . [The Coles]184-the coles were very respectable in [their]184-the coles way , but [they]184-the coles ought to be taught that it was not for [them]184-the coles to arrange the terms on which [the superior families]1520-the superior families would visit [them]184-the coles . This lesson , [she]123-emma very much feared , [they]184-the coles would receive only from [herself]123-emma ; [she]123-emma had little hope of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , none of [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston .

But [she]123-emma had made up [her]123-emma mind how to meet this presumption so many weeks before it appeared , that when the insult came at last , it found [her]123-emma very differently affected . [Donwell]24-donwell and [Randalls]101-randalls had received [their]184-the coles invitation , and none had come for [[her]123-emma father]425-her father and [herself]123-emma ; and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's accounting for it with “ [I]88-mrs. weston suppose [they]184-the coles will not take the liberty with [you]123-emma ; [they]184-the coles know [you]123-emma do not dine out , ”[88-mrs. weston] was not quite sufficient . [She]123-emma felt that [she]123-emma should like to have had the power of refusal ; and afterwards , as the idea of [the party to be assembled]1522-the party to be assembled [there]448-there , consisting precisely of [those whose society was dearest to [her]123-emma]1524-those whose society was dearest to her , occurred again and again , [she]123-emma did not know that [she]123-emma might not have been tempted to accept . [Harriet]111-harriet was to be [there]448-there in the evening , and [the Bateses]161-the bateses . [They]1526-they had been speaking of it as [they]1526-they walked about [Highbury]3-highbury the day before , and [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had most earnestly lamented [her]111-harriet absence . Might not the evening end in a dance ? had been a question of [his]102-frank churchill . The bare possibility of it acted as a farther irritation on [her]123-emma spirits ; and [her]123-emma being left in solitary grandeur , even supposing the omission to be intended as a compliment , was but poor comfort .

It was the arrival of this very invitation while [the Westons]108-the westons were at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , which made [their]1526-they presence so acceptable ; for though [her]123-emma first remark , on reading it , was that “ of course it must be declined , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma so very soon proceeded to ask [them]1526-they what [they]1526-they advised [her]123-emma to do , that [their]1526-they advice for [her]123-emma going was most prompt and successful .

[She]123-emma owned that , considering every thing , [she]123-emma was not absolutely without inclination for the party . [The Coles]184-the coles expressed [themselves]184-the coles so properly -- there was so much real attention in the manner of it -- so much consideration for [[her]123-emma father]425-her father . “ [They]1526-they would have solicited the honour earlier , but had been waiting the arrival of a folding - screen from [London]1-london , which [they]1526-they hoped might keep [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse from any draught of air , and therefore induce [him]425-her father the more readily to give [them]1526-they the honour of [his]425-her father company . ”[123-emma] Upon the whole , [she]123-emma was very persuadable ; and it being briefly settled among [themselves]184-the coles how it might be done without neglecting [his]425-her father comfort -- how certainly [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard , if not [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates , might be depended on for bearing [him]425-her father company -- [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse was to be talked into an acquiescence of [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter 's going out to dinner on a day now near at hand , and spending the whole evening away from [him]425-her father . As for _ [his]425-her father _ going , [Emma]123-emma did not wish [him]425-her father to think it possible , the hours would be too late , and the party too numerous . [He]425-her father was soon pretty well resigned .

“ [I]88-mrs. weston am not fond of dinner - visiting , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [he--“I]214-he--“i never was . No more is [Emma]123-emma . Late hours do not agree with [us]184-the coles . [I]88-mrs. weston am sorry [Mr.]4012-mr. and [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole should have done it . [I]88-mrs. weston think it would be much better if [they]4013-they would come in one afternoon next summer , and take [their]4013-they tea with [us]184-the coles -- take [us]184-the coles in [their]4013-they afternoon walk ; which [they]4013-they might do , as [our]184-the coles hours are so reasonable , and yet get [home]562-home without being out in the damp of the evening . The dews of a summer evening are what [I]88-mrs. weston would not expose [any body]665-any body to . However , as [they]4013-they are so very desirous to have dear [Emma]123-emma dine with [them]4013-they , and as [you]4016-you will both be [there]448-there , and [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley too , to take care of [her]123-emma , [I]88-mrs. weston can not wish to prevent it , provided the weather be what it ought , neither damp , nor cold , nor windy . ”[88-mrs. weston] Then turning to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , with a look of gentle reproach--“Ah ! [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse , if [you]4016-you had not married , [you]4016-you would have staid at [home]562-home with [me]88-mrs. weston . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Well , [sir]2734-sir , ”[86-mr. weston] cried [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , “ as [I]86-mr. weston took [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse away , it is incumbent on [me]86-mr. weston to supply [[her]84-miss woodhouse place]4020-her place , if [I]86-mr. weston can ; and [I]86-mr. weston will step to [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard in a moment , if [you]2734-sir wish it . ”[86-mr. weston]

But the idea of any thing to be done in a _ moment _ , was increasing , not lessening , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's agitation . [The ladies]627-the ladies knew better how to allay it . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston must be quiet , and every thing deliberately arranged .

With this treatment , [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse was soon composed enough for talking as usual . “ [He]85-mr. woodhouse should be happy to see [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard . [He]85-mr. woodhouse had a great regard for [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard ; and [Emma]123-emma should write a line , and invite [her]109-mrs. goddard . [James]90-james could take the note . But first of all , there must be an answer written to [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ [You]2734-sir will make [my]1530-i excuses , [[my]1530-i dear]2714-my dear , as civilly as possible . [You]2734-sir will say that [I]1530-i am quite [an invalid]4022-an invalid , and go no where , and therefore must decline [their]627-the ladies obliging invitation ; beginning with [my]1530-i _ compliments _ , of course . But [you]2734-sir will do every thing right . [I]1530-i need not tell [you]2734-sir what is to be done . [We]4023-we must remember to let [James]90-james know that [the carriage]2719-the carriage will be wanted on Tuesday . [I]1530-i shall have no fears for [you]2734-sir with [him]1530-i . [We]4023-we have never been there above once since the new approach was made ; but still [I]1530-i have no doubt that [James]90-james will take [you]2734-sir very safely . And when [you]2734-sir get [there]448-there , [you]2734-sir must tell [him]1530-i at what time [you]2734-sir would have [him]1530-i come for [you]2734-sir again ; and [you]2734-sir had better name an early hour . [You]2734-sir will not like staying late . [You]2734-sir will get very tired when tea is over . ”[1530-i]

“ But [you]1530-i would not wish [me]85-mr. woodhouse to come away before [I]85-mr. woodhouse am tired , [papa]2708-papa ? ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Oh ! no , [[my]1530-i love]3321-my love ; but [you]2734-sir will soon be tired . There will be [a great many people]4028-a great many people talking at once . [You]2734-sir will not like the noise . ”[1530-i]

“ But , [[my]86-mr. weston dear sir]3019-my dear sir , ”[86-mr. weston] cried [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , “ if [Emma]123-emma comes away early , it will be breaking up the party . ”[86-mr. weston]

“ And no great harm if it does , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse . “ The sooner every party breaks up , the better . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ But [you]2734-sir do not consider how it may appear to [the Coles]184-the coles . [Emma]123-emma 's going away directly after tea might be giving offence . [They]184-the coles are [good - natured people]4030-good - natured people , and think little of [their]184-the coles own claims ; but still [they]184-the coles must feel that [any body]665-any body 's hurrying away is no great compliment ; and [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse 's doing it would be more thought of than [any other person]4032-any other person 's in [the room]701-the room . [You]2734-sir would not wish to disappoint and mortify [the Coles]184-the coles , [I]1530-i am sure , [sir]2734-sir ; [friendly , good sort of people as ever lived]4035-friendly , good sort of people as ever lived , and who have been [[your]2734-sir neighbours]4036-your neighbours these _ ten _ years . ”[1530-i]

“ No , upon no account in [the world]403-the world , [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston ; [I]85-mr. woodhouse am much obliged to [you]86-mr. weston for reminding [me]85-mr. woodhouse . [I]85-mr. woodhouse should be extremely sorry to be giving [them]184-the coles any pain . [I]85-mr. woodhouse know what [worthy people]1300-worthy people [they]184-the coles are . [Perry]104-mrs. perry tells [me]85-mr. woodhouse that [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole never touches malt liquor . [You]2734-sir would not think it to look at [him]145-mr. cole , but [he]145-mr. cole is bilious -- [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole is very bilious . No , [I]85-mr. woodhouse would not be the means of giving [them]184-the coles any pain . [[My]85-mr. woodhouse dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , [we]4040-we must consider this . [I]85-mr. woodhouse am sure , rather than run the risk of hurting [Mr.]4041-mr. and [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole , [you]123-emma would stay a little longer than [you]123-emma might wish . [You]123-emma will not regard being tired . [You]123-emma will be perfectly safe , [you]123-emma know , among [[your]123-emma friends]3174-your friends . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Oh yes , [papa]2708-papa . [I]1530-i have no fears at all for [myself]1530-i ; and [I]1530-i should have no scruples of staying as late as [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , but on [your]2708-papa account . [I]1530-i am only afraid of [your]2708-papa sitting up for [me]1530-i . [I]1530-i am not afraid of [your]2708-papa not being exceedingly comfortable with [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard . [She]109-mrs. goddard loves piquet , [you]2708-papa know ; but when [she]109-mrs. goddard is gone [home]562-home , [I]1530-i am afraid [you]2708-papa will be sitting up by [yourself]2708-papa , instead of going to bed at [your]2708-papa usual time -- and the idea of that would entirely destroy [my]1530-i comfort . [You]2708-papa must promise [me]1530-i not to sit up . ”[1530-i]

[He]1530-i did , on the condition of some promises on [her]1531-her side : such as that , if [she]1531-her came [home]562-home cold , [she]1531-her would be sure to warm [herself]1531-her thoroughly ; if hungry , that [she]1531-her would take something to eat ; that [[her]1531-her own maid]1533-her own maid should sit up for [her]1531-her ; and that [Serle]112-serle and [the butler]1534-the butler should see that every thing were safe in [the house]435-the house , as usual .

CHAPTER VIII

[Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill came back again ; and if [he]102-frank churchill kept [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father 's dinner waiting , it was not known at [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; for [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was too anxious for [his]102-frank churchill being a favourite with [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , to betray any imperfection which could be concealed .

[He]102-frank churchill came back , had had [his]102-frank churchill hair cut , and laughed at [himself]102-frank churchill with a very good grace , but without seeming really at all ashamed of what [he]102-frank churchill had done . [He]102-frank churchill had no reason to wish [his]102-frank churchill hair longer , to conceal any confusion of face ; no reason to wish the money unspent , to improve [his]102-frank churchill spirits . [He]102-frank churchill was quite as undaunted and as lively as ever ; and , after seeing [him]102-frank churchill , [Emma]123-emma thus moralised to [herself:--]1537-herself:--

“ [I]123-emma do not know whether it ought to be so , but certainly silly things do cease to be silly if they are done by [sensible people]4045-sensible people in an impudent way . Wickedness is always wickedness , but folly is not always folly.--It depends upon the character of [those who handle it]4046-those who handle it . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , [he]102-frank churchill is _ not _ [a trifling , silly young man]4047-a trifling , silly young man . If [he]102-frank churchill were , [he]102-frank churchill would have done this differently . [He]102-frank churchill would either have gloried in the achievement , or been ashamed of it . There would have been either the ostentation of a coxcomb , or the evasions of a mind too weak to defend its own vanities.--No , [I]123-emma am perfectly sure that [he]102-frank churchill is not trifling or silly . ”[123-emma]

With [Tuesday]215-tuesday came the agreeable prospect of seeing [him]102-frank churchill again , and for a longer time than hitherto ; of judging of [his]102-frank churchill general manners , and by inference , of the meaning of [his]102-frank churchill manners towards [herself]123-emma ; of guessing how soon it might be necessary for [her]123-emma to throw coldness into [her]123-emma air ; and of fancying what the observations of all those might be , who were now seeing [them]1538-them together for the first time .

[She]123-emma meant to be very happy , in spite of the scene being laid at [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole 's ; and without being able to forget that among the failings of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , even in the days of [his]95-mr. elton favour , none had disturbed [her]123-emma more than [his]95-mr. elton propensity to dine with [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole .

[[Her]123-emma father]425-her father 's comfort was amply secured , [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates as well as [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard being able to come ; and [her]123-emma last pleasing duty , before [she]123-emma left [the house]435-the house , was to pay [her]123-emma respects to [them]1538-them as [they]1538-them sat together after dinner ; and while [[her]123-emma father]425-her father was fondly noticing the beauty of [her]123-emma dress , to make [the two ladies]1542-the two ladies all the amends in [her]123-emma power , by helping [them]1542-the two ladies to large slices of cake and full glasses of wine , for whatever unwilling self - denial [his]425-her father care of [their]1542-the two ladies constitution might have obliged [them]1542-the two ladies to practise during the meal.--She had provided a plentiful dinner for [them]1542-the two ladies ; [she]123-emma wished [she]123-emma could know that [they]1542-the two ladies had been allowed to eat it .

[She]123-emma followed [another carriage]1543-another carriage to [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole 's door ; and was pleased to see that it was [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's ; for [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley keeping no horses , having little spare money and a great deal of health , activity , and independence , was too apt , in [Emma]123-emma 's opinion , to get about as [he]92-mr. knightley could , and not use [[his]92-mr. knightley carriage]1005-his carriage so often as became [the owner of [Donwell Abbey]8-donwell abbey]1545-the owner of donwell abbey . [She]123-emma had an opportunity now of speaking [her]123-emma approbation while warm from [her]123-emma heart , for [he]92-mr. knightley stopped to hand [her]123-emma out .

“ This is coming as [you]92-mr. knightley should do , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma ; “ like [a gentleman.--I]4048-a gentleman.--i am quite glad to see [you]92-mr. knightley . ”[123-emma]

[He]92-mr. knightley thanked [her]123-emma , observing , “ How lucky that [we]4049-we should arrive at the same moment ! for , if [we]4049-we had met first in [the drawing - room]3531-the drawing - room , [I]92-mr. knightley doubt whether [you]92-mr. knightley would have discerned [me]92-mr. knightley to be more of [a gentleman]2822-a gentleman than usual.--You might not have distinguished how [I]92-mr. knightley came , by [my]92-mr. knightley look or manner . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Yes [I]1546-i should , [I]1546-i am sure [I]1546-i should . There is always a look of consciousness or bustle when [people]2986-people come in a way which [they]2986-people know to be beneath [them]2986-people . [You]92-mr. knightley think [you]92-mr. knightley carry it off very well , [I]1546-i dare say , but with [you]92-mr. knightley it is a sort of bravado , an air of affected unconcern ; [I]1546-i always observe it whenever [I]1546-i meet [you]92-mr. knightley under those circumstances . _ Now _ [you]92-mr. knightley have nothing to try for . [You]92-mr. knightley are not afraid of being supposed ashamed . [You]92-mr. knightley are not striving to look taller than [any body else]1042-any body else . _ Now _ [I]1546-i shall really be very happy to walk into [the same room]4054-the same room with [you]92-mr. knightley . ”[1546-i]

“ [Nonsensical girl]4055-nonsensical girl ! ”[1546-i] was [his]1546-i reply , but not at all in anger .

[Emma]123-emma had as much reason to be satisfied with the rest of the party as with [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . [She]123-emma was received with a cordial respect which could not but please , and given all the consequence [she]123-emma could wish for . When [the Westons]108-the westons arrived , the kindest looks of love , the strongest of admiration were for [her]123-emma , from both [husband]1547-husband and [wife]1548-wife ; [the son]2764-the son approached [her]123-emma with a cheerful eagerness which marked [her]123-emma as [his]2764-the son peculiar object , and at dinner [she]123-emma found [him]2764-the son seated by [her]123-emma -- and , as [she]123-emma firmly believed , not without some dexterity on [his]2764-the son side .

The party was rather large , as it included [one other family]1550-one other family , [a proper unobjectionable country family , whom [the Coles]184-the coles had the advantage of naming among [[their]184-the coles acquaintance]1552-their acquaintance]1551-a proper unobjectionable country family , whom the coles had the advantage of naming among their acquaintance , and [the male part of [[Mr. Cox]216-mr. cox 's family]1554-mr. cox 's family]1553-the male part of mr. cox 's family , [the lawyer of [Highbury]3-highbury]1555-the lawyer of highbury . [The less worthy females]1556-the less worthy females were to come in the evening , with [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , and [Miss Smith]111-harriet ; but already , at dinner , [they]1556-the less worthy females were too numerous for any subject of conversation to be general ; and , while politics and [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton were talked over , [Emma]123-emma could fairly surrender all [her]123-emma attention to the pleasantness of [[her]123-emma neighbour]1557-her neighbour . The first remote sound to which [she]123-emma felt [herself]123-emma obliged to attend , was the name of [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole seemed to be relating something of [her]123-emma that was expected to be very interesting . [She]123-emma listened , and found it well worth listening to . [That very dear part of [Emma]123-emma]1558-that very dear part of emma , [her]123-emma fancy , received an amusing supply . [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole was telling that [she]185-mrs. cole had been calling on [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , and as soon as [she]185-mrs. cole entered [the room]701-the room had been struck by the sight of a pianoforte -- a very elegant looking instrument -- not a grand , but a large - sized square pianoforte ; and the substance of the story , the end of all the dialogue which ensued of surprize , and inquiry , and congratulations on [her]185-mrs. cole side , and explanations on [Miss Bates]105-miss bates 's , was , that this pianoforte had arrived from [Broadwood]46-broadwood 's the day before , to the great astonishment of [both aunt]1560-both aunt and [niece]1561-niece -- entirely unexpected ; that at first , by [Miss Bates]105-miss bates 's account , [Jane]105-miss bates [herself]105-miss bates was quite at a loss , quite bewildered to think who could possibly have ordered it -- but now , [they]1562-their were both perfectly satisfied that it could be from only one quarter;--of course it must be from [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell .

“ [One]2775-one can suppose nothing else , ”[185-mrs. cole] added [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole , “ and [I]185-mrs. cole was only surprized that there could ever have been a doubt . But [Jane]105-miss bates , it seems , had a letter from [them]1562-their very lately , and not a word was said about it . [She]105-miss bates knows [their]1562-their ways best ; but [I]185-mrs. cole should not consider [their]1562-their silence as any reason for [their]1562-their not meaning to make the present . [They]1562-their might chuse to surprize [her]105-miss bates . ”[185-mrs. cole]

[Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole had many to agree with [her]185-mrs. cole ; [every body who spoke on the subject]1563-every body who spoke on the subject was equally convinced that it must come from [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell , and equally rejoiced that such a present had been made ; and there were enough ready to speak to allow [Emma]123-emma to think [her]123-emma own way , and still listen to [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole .

“ [I]84-miss woodhouse declare , [I]84-miss woodhouse do not know when [I]84-miss woodhouse have heard any thing that has given [me]84-miss woodhouse more satisfaction!--It always has quite hurt [me]84-miss woodhouse that [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , who plays so delightfully , should not have an instrument . It seemed quite a shame , especially considering how many houses there are where fine instruments are absolutely thrown away . This is like giving [ourselves]4057-our a slap , to be sure ! and it was but yesterday [I]84-miss woodhouse was telling [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole , [I]84-miss woodhouse really was ashamed to look at [our]4057-our new grand pianoforte in [the drawing - room]3531-the drawing - room , while [I]84-miss woodhouse do not know one note from another , and [our]4057-our [little girls , who are but just beginning]4059-little girls , who are but just beginning , perhaps may never make any thing of it ; and there is poor [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , who is [mistress of music]4060-mistress of music , has not any thing of the nature of an instrument , not even the pitifullest old spinet in [the world]403-the world , to amuse [herself]152-miss fairfax with.--I was saying this to [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole but yesterday , and [he]145-mr. cole quite agreed with [me]84-miss woodhouse ; only [he]145-mr. cole is so particularly fond of music that [he]145-mr. cole could not help indulging [himself]145-mr. cole in the purchase , hoping that [some of [[our]4057-our good neighbours]4063-our good neighbours]4062-some of our good neighbours might be so obliging occasionally to put it to a better use than [we]4057-our can ; and that really is the reason why the instrument was bought -- or else [I]84-miss woodhouse am sure [we]4057-our ought to be ashamed of it.--We are in great hopes that [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse may be prevailed with to try it this evening . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

[Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse made the proper acquiescence ; and finding that nothing more was to be entrapped from any communication of [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole 's , turned to [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill .

“ Why do [you]102-frank churchill smile ? ”[185-mrs. cole] said [she]185-mrs. cole .

“ Nay , why do [you]102-frank churchill ? ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [Me!--I]102-frank churchill suppose [I]84-miss woodhouse smile for pleasure at [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell 's being so rich and so liberal.--It is a handsome present . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ Very . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [I]84-miss woodhouse rather wonder that it was never made before . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ Perhaps [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax has never been staying [here]2707-here so long before . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ Or that [he]145-mr. cole did not give [her]152-miss fairfax the use of [their]4065-their own instrument -- which must now be shut up in [London]1-london , untouched by any body . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ That is a grand pianoforte , and [he]145-mr. cole might think it too large for [[Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's house]4066-mrs. bates 's house . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [You]102-frank churchill may _ say _ what [you]102-frank churchill chuse -- but [your]102-frank churchill countenance testifies that [your]102-frank churchill _ thoughts _ on this subject are very much like [mine]102-frank churchill . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [I]84-miss woodhouse do not know . [I]84-miss woodhouse rather believe [you]102-frank churchill are giving [me]84-miss woodhouse more credit for acuteness than [I]84-miss woodhouse deserve . [I]84-miss woodhouse smile because [you]102-frank churchill smile , and shall probably suspect whatever [I]84-miss woodhouse find [you]102-frank churchill suspect ; but at present [I]84-miss woodhouse do not see what there is to question . If [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell is not [the person]4067-the person , who can be ? ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ What do [you]102-frank churchill say to [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon ? ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon ! very true indeed . [I]84-miss woodhouse had not thought of [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon . [She]191-mrs. dixon must know as well as [[her]191-mrs. dixon father]425-her father , how acceptable an instrument would be ; and perhaps the mode of it , the mystery , [the surprize]4069-the surprize , is more like [a young woman]3868-a young woman 's scheme than [an elderly man]4071-an elderly man 's . It is [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon , [I]84-miss woodhouse dare say . [I]84-miss woodhouse told [you]102-frank churchill that [your]102-frank churchill suspicions would guide [mine]84-miss woodhouse . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ If so , [you]102-frank churchill must extend [your]102-frank churchill suspicions and comprehend _ [Mr _ . Dixon]192-mr. dixon in them . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [Mr. Dixon.--Very]217-mr. dixon.--very well . Yes , [I]84-miss woodhouse immediately perceive that it must be the joint present of [Mr.]4072-mr. and [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon . [We]4073-we were speaking the other day , [you]102-frank churchill know , of [his]4072-mr. being so warm an admirer of [her]191-mrs. dixon performance . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ Yes , and what [you]102-frank churchill told [me]84-miss woodhouse on that head , confirmed an idea which [I]84-miss woodhouse had entertained before.--I do not mean to reflect upon the good intentions of either [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon or [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , but [I]84-miss woodhouse can not help suspecting either that , after making [his]4072-mr. proposals to [[her]191-mrs. dixon friend]427-her friend , [he]4072-mr. had the misfortune to fall in love with _ [her]191-mrs. dixon _ , or that [he]4072-mr. became conscious of a little attachment on [her]191-mrs. dixon side . [One]2775-one might guess twenty things without guessing exactly the right ; but [I]84-miss woodhouse am sure there must be a particular cause for [her]191-mrs. dixon chusing to come to [Highbury]3-highbury instead of going with [the Campbells]190-the campbells to [Ireland]32-ireland . Here , [she]191-mrs. dixon must be leading a life of privation and penance ; there it would have been all enjoyment . As to the pretence of trying [her]191-mrs. dixon native air , [I]84-miss woodhouse look upon that as a mere excuse.--In the summer it might have passed ; but what can [any body]665-any body 's native air do for [them]665-any body in the months of January , February , and March ? Good fires and [carriages]3506-carriages would be much more to the purpose in most cases of delicate health , and [I]84-miss woodhouse dare say in [her]191-mrs. dixon 's . [I]84-miss woodhouse do not require [you]4078-you to adopt all [my]84-miss woodhouse suspicions , though [you]4078-you make so noble a profession of doing it , but [I]84-miss woodhouse honestly tell [you]4078-you what they are . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ And , upon [my]84-miss woodhouse word , [they]665-any body have an air of great probability . [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon 's preference of [her]191-mrs. dixon music to [[her]191-mrs. dixon friend]427-her friend 's , [I]84-miss woodhouse can answer for being very decided . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ And then , [he]192-mr. dixon saved [her]191-mrs. dixon life . Did [you]4078-you ever hear of [that?--A water party]4080-that?--a water party ; and by some accident [she]191-mrs. dixon was falling overboard . [He]192-mr. dixon caught [her]191-mrs. dixon . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [He]192-mr. dixon did . [I]84-miss woodhouse was [there]448-there -- [one of the party]4082-one of the party . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ Were [you]4078-you really?--Well!--But [you]4078-you observed nothing of course , for it seems to be a new idea to you.--If [I]84-miss woodhouse had been [there]448-there , [I]84-miss woodhouse think [I]84-miss woodhouse should have made some discoveries . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

“ [I]84-miss woodhouse dare say [you]4078-you would ; but [I]84-miss woodhouse , simple [I]84-miss woodhouse , saw nothing but the fact , that [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax was nearly dashed from [the vessel]4084-the vessel and that [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon caught her.--It was the work of a moment . And though the consequent shock and alarm was very great and much more durable -- indeed [I]84-miss woodhouse believe it was half an hour before any of [us]1564-we were comfortable again -- yet that was too general a sensation for any thing of peculiar anxiety to be observable . [I]84-miss woodhouse do not mean to say , however , that [you]4078-you might not have made discoveries . ”[84-miss woodhouse]

The conversation was here interrupted . [They]1564-we were called on to share in the awkwardness of a rather long interval between the courses , and obliged to be as formal and as orderly as [the others]870-the others ; but when the table was again safely covered , when every corner dish was placed exactly right , and occupation and ease were generally restored , [Emma]123-emma said ,

“ The arrival of [this pianoforte]4085-this pianoforte is decisive with [me]123-emma . [I]123-emma wanted to know a little more , and this tells [me]123-emma quite enough . Depend upon it , [we]1564-we shall soon hear that it is a present from [Mr.]4086-mr. and [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon . ”[123-emma]

“ And if [the Dixons]195-the dixons should absolutely deny all knowledge of it [we]1564-we must conclude it to come from [the Campbells]190-the campbells . ”[123-emma]

“ No , [I]123-emma am sure it is not from [the Campbells]190-the campbells . [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax knows it is not from [the Campbells]190-the campbells , or [they]190-the campbells would have been guessed at first . [She]152-miss fairfax would not have been puzzled , had [she]152-miss fairfax dared fix on [them]190-the campbells . [I]123-emma may not have convinced [you]4087-you perhaps , but [I]123-emma am perfectly convinced [myself]123-emma that [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon is [a principal in the business]4088-a principal in the business . ”[123-emma]

“ Indeed [you]4087-you injure [me]123-emma if [you]4087-you suppose [me]123-emma unconvinced . [Your]4087-you reasonings carry [my]123-emma judgment along with them entirely . At first , while [I]123-emma supposed [you]4087-you satisfied that [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell was [the giver]4089-the giver , [I]123-emma saw it only as paternal kindness , and thought it the most natural thing in [the world]403-the world . But when [you]4087-you mentioned [Mrs. Dixon]191-mrs. dixon , [I]123-emma felt how much more probable that it should be the tribute of warm female friendship . And now [I]123-emma can see it in no other light than as an offering of love . ”[123-emma]

There was no occasion to press the matter farther . The conviction seemed real ; [he]1566-he looked as if [he]1566-he felt it . [She]1567-she said no more , [other subjects]1568-other subjects took [their]1568-other subjects turn ; and the rest of the dinner passed away ; the dessert succeeded , [the children]591-the children came in , and were talked to and admired amid the usual rate of conversation ; a few clever things said , a few downright silly , but by much the larger proportion neither [the one nor the other]1570-the one nor the other -- nothing worse than everyday remarks , dull repetitions , old news , and heavy jokes .

[The ladies]627-the ladies had not been long in [the drawing - room]3531-the drawing - room , before [the other ladies]1573-the other ladies , in [their]1573-the other ladies different divisions , arrived . [Emma]123-emma watched the entree of [[her]123-emma own particular little friend]1574-her own particular little friend ; and if [she]123-emma could not exult in [her]123-emma dignity and grace , [she]123-emma could not only love the blooming sweetness and the artless manner , but could most heartily rejoice in that light , cheerful , unsentimental disposition which allowed [her]123-emma so many alleviations of pleasure , in the midst of the pangs of disappointed affection . There [she]123-emma sat -- and who would have guessed how many tears [she]123-emma had been lately shedding ? To be in company , nicely dressed [herself]123-emma and seeing [others nicely dressed , to sit and smile and look pretty , and say nothing]1575-others nicely dressed , to sit and smile and look pretty , and say nothing , was enough for the happiness of the present hour . [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax did look and move superior ; but [Emma]123-emma suspected [she]123-emma might have been glad to change feelings with [Harriet]111-harriet , very glad to have purchased the mortification of having loved -- yes , of having loved even [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton in vain -- by the surrender of all the dangerous pleasure of knowing [herself]123-emma beloved by [the husband of [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend]1576-the husband of her friend .

In so large a party it was not necessary that [Emma]123-emma should approach [her]111-harriet . [She]123-emma did not wish to speak of the pianoforte , [she]123-emma felt too much in the secret [herself]123-emma , to think the appearance of curiosity or interest fair , and therefore purposely kept at a distance ; but by [the others]870-the others , the subject was almost immediately introduced , and [she]123-emma saw the blush of consciousness with which congratulations were received , the blush of guilt which accompanied the name of “ [[my]88-mrs. weston excellent friend]4091-my excellent friend [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell . ”[88-mrs. weston]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , kind - hearted and musical , was particularly interested by the circumstance , and [Emma]123-emma could not help being amused at [her]88-mrs. weston perseverance in dwelling on the subject ; and having so much to ask and to say as to tone , touch , and pedal , totally unsuspicious of that wish of saying as little about it as possible , which [she]88-mrs. weston plainly read in [the fair heroine]1579-the fair heroine 's countenance .

[They]1580-they were soon joined by [some of [the gentlemen]1438-the gentlemen]1581-some of the gentlemen ; and the very first of the early was [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill . In [he]102-frank churchill walked , [the first and the handsomest]1583-the first and the handsomest ; and after paying [his]102-frank churchill compliments en passant to [Miss Bates]105-miss bates and [[her]105-miss bates niece]1204-her niece , made [his]102-frank churchill way directly to the opposite side of the circle , where sat [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse ; and till [he]102-frank churchill could find a seat by [her]84-miss woodhouse , would not sit at all . [Emma]123-emma divined what every body present must be thinking . [She]123-emma was [his]102-frank churchill object , and every body must perceive it . Smiles of intelligence passed between [her]123-emma and [the gentleman]680-the gentleman on first glancing towards [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax ; but it was most prudent to avoid speech . [He]102-frank churchill told [her]123-emma that [he]102-frank churchill had been impatient to leave [the dining - room]1589-the dining - room -- hated sitting long -- was always the first to move when [he]102-frank churchill could -- that [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , [Mr. Cox]216-mr. cox , and [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole , were left very busy over parish business -- that as long as [he]102-frank churchill had staid , however , it had been pleasant enough , as [he]102-frank churchill had found [them]1591-them in general a set of [gentlemanlike , sensible men]1592-gentlemanlike , sensible men ; and spoke so handsomely of [Highbury]3-highbury altogether -- thought it so abundant in [agreeable families]1593-agreeable families -- that [Emma]123-emma began to feel [she]123-emma had been used to despise [the place]450-the place rather too much . [She]123-emma questioned [him]102-frank churchill as to the society in [Yorkshire]47-yorkshire -- the extent of [the neighbourhood]1432-the neighbourhood about [Enscombe]7-enscombe , and the sort ; and could make out from [his]102-frank churchill answers that , as far as [Enscombe]7-enscombe was concerned , there was very little going on , that [their]1596-their visitings were among a range of [great families]1597-great families , none very near ; and that even when days were fixed , and invitations accepted , it was an even chance that [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill were not in health and spirits for going ; that [they]1596-their made a point of visiting [no fresh person]1598-no fresh person ; and that , though [he]102-frank churchill had [his]102-frank churchill separate engagements , it was not without difficulty , without considerable address _ at _ _ times _ , that [he]102-frank churchill could get away , or introduce [an acquaintance]1599-an acquaintance for a night .

[She]123-emma saw that [Enscombe]7-enscombe could not satisfy , and that [Highbury]3-highbury , taken at its best , might reasonably please [a young man who had more retirement at [home]562-home than [he]102-frank churchill liked]1600-a young man who had more retirement at home than he liked . [His]102-frank churchill importance at [Enscombe]7-enscombe was very evident . [He]102-frank churchill did not boast , but it naturally betrayed [itself]1602-itself , that [he]102-frank churchill had persuaded [[his]102-frank churchill aunt]3548-his aunt where [[his]102-frank churchill uncle]517-his uncle could do nothing , and on [her]3548-his aunt laughing and noticing it , [he]102-frank churchill owned that [he]102-frank churchill believed ( excepting one or two points ) [he]102-frank churchill could _ with _ _ time _ persuade [her]3548-his aunt to any thing . One of those points on which [his]102-frank churchill influence failed , [he]102-frank churchill then mentioned . [He]102-frank churchill had wanted very much to go abroad -- had been very eager indeed to be allowed to travel -- but [she]3548-his aunt would not hear of it . This had happened the year before . _ Now _ , [he]102-frank churchill said , [he]102-frank churchill was beginning to have no longer the same wish .

The unpersuadable point , which [he]102-frank churchill did not mention , [Emma]123-emma guessed to be good behaviour to [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father .

“ [I]102-frank churchill have made a most wretched discovery , ”[102-frank churchill] said [he]102-frank churchill , after a short pause.-- “ [I]102-frank churchill have been [here]2707-here a week to - morrow -- half [my]102-frank churchill time . “ This is the luxury of a large party , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [she:--“one]88-mrs. weston can get near every body , and say every thing . “ Very true.--Well , a little while ago it occurred to [me]88-mrs. weston how very sad it would be to have [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax walking [home]562-home again , late at night , and cold as the nights are now . ' [I]88-mrs. weston was quite surprized;--very glad , [I]88-mrs. weston am sure ; but really quite surprized . “ Very likely , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [Emma--“nothing]219-emma--“nothing more likely . [He]92-mr. knightley is not [a gallant man]4115-a gallant man , but [he]92-mr. knightley is [a very humane one]4116-a very humane one ; and this , considering [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's ill - health , would appear a case of humanity to [him;--and]4117-him;--and for an act of unostentatious kindness , there is nobody whom [I]88-mrs. weston would fix on more than on [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . [I]88-mrs. weston know [he]92-mr. knightley had horses to - day -- for [we]4118-we arrived together ; and [I]88-mrs. weston laughed at [him]92-mr. knightley about it , but [he]92-mr. knightley said not a word that could betray . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Well , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , smiling , “ [you]88-mrs. weston give [him]92-mr. knightley credit for more simple , disinterested benevolence in this instance than [I]88-mrs. weston do ; for while [Miss Bates]105-miss bates was speaking , a suspicion darted into [my]88-mrs. weston head , and [I]88-mrs. weston have never been able to get it out again . “ [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley and [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax ! ”[123-emma] exclaimed [Emma]123-emma . “ [Dear Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , how could [you]88-mrs. weston think of such a thing?--Mr . [Knightley!--Mr]4119-knightley!--mr . “ [My]88-mrs. weston dear [Emma]123-emma , [I]88-mrs. weston have told [you]88-mrs. weston what led [me]88-mrs. weston to think of it . “ Yes , [I]123-emma would . [I]123-emma could not bear to have [Henry]157-henry supplanted.--Mr .
