[Emma]123-emma found it really time to be at [home]562-home ; the visit had already lasted long ; and on examining watches , so much of the morning was perceived to be gone , that [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston and [[her]88-mrs. weston companion]672-her companion taking leave also , could allow [themselves]1680-themselves only to walk with [the two young ladies]1681-the two young ladies to [Hartfield]2-hartfield gates , before [they]1680-themselves set off for [Randalls]101-randalls .

CHAPTER XI

It may be possible to do without dancing entirely . Instances have been known of [young people]1290-young people passing many , many months successively , without being at any ball of any description , and no material injury accrue either to body or mind;--but when a beginning is made -- when the felicities of rapid motion have once been , though slightly , felt -- it must be a very heavy set that does not ask for more .

[Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had danced once at [Highbury]3-highbury , and longed to dance again ; and the last half - hour of an evening which [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse was persuaded to spend with [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter at [Randalls]101-randalls , was passed by [the two young people]1684-the two young people in schemes on the subject . [Frank]102-frank churchill 's was the first idea ; and [his]102-frank churchill the greatest zeal in pursuing it ; for [the lady]3048-the lady was the best judge of the difficulties , and the most solicitous for accommodation and appearance . But still [she]3048-the lady had inclination enough for shewing [people]2986-people again how delightfully [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill and [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse danced -- for doing that in which [she]3048-the lady need not blush to compare [herself]3048-the lady with [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax -- and even for simple dancing itself , without any of the wicked aids of vanity -- to assist [him]102-frank churchill first in pacing out [the room [they]1684-the two young people were in]1687-the room they were in to see what it could be made to hold -- and then in taking the dimensions of [the other parlour]1688-the other parlour , in the hope of discovering , in spite of all that [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston could say of [their]1684-the two young people exactly equal size , that it was a little the largest .

[His]102-frank churchill first proposition and request , that the dance begun at [Mr. Cole]145-mr. cole 's should be finished [there]448-there -- that [the same party]1690-the same party should be collected , and [the same musician]1691-the same musician engaged , met with the readiest acquiescence . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston entered into the idea with thorough enjoyment , and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston most willingly undertook to play as long as [they]1684-the two young people could wish to dance ; and the interesting employment had followed , of reckoning up exactly who there would be , and portioning out the indispensable division of space to [every couple]1692-every couple .

“ [You]86-mr. weston and [Miss Smith]111-harriet , and [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , will be three , and [the two Miss Coxes five]4259-the two miss coxes five , ”[1627-somebody else] had been repeated many times over . “ And there will be [the two Gilberts]4260-the two gilberts , [young Cox]216-mr. cox , [[my]1627-somebody else father]2740-my father , and [myself]1627-somebody else , besides [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . Yes , that will be quite enough for pleasure . [You]86-mr. weston and [Miss Smith]111-harriet , and [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , will be three , and [the two Miss Coxes five]4259-the two miss coxes five ; and for [five couple]4263-five couple there will be plenty of [room]4264-room . ”[1627-somebody else]

But soon it came to be on one side ,

“ But will there be good room for five couple?--I really do not think there will . ”[604-somebody]

On another ,

“ And after all , [five couple]4263-five couple are not enough to make it worth while to stand up . [Five couple]4263-five couple are nothing , when [one]2775-one thinks seriously about it . It will not do to _ invite [_ five couple]4268-_ five couple . It can be allowable only as the thought of the moment . ”[604-somebody]

[Somebody]604-somebody said that _ [Miss _ Gilbert]240-miss _ gilbert was expected at [[her]240-miss _ gilbert brother]482-her brother 's , and must be invited with the rest . [Somebody else]1627-somebody else believed _ [Mrs _ . Gilbert]114-mrs. martin would have danced the other evening , if [she]240-miss _ gilbert had been asked . A word was put in for [a second young Cox]1696-a second young cox ; and at last , [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston naming [one family of [cousins who must be included]1698-cousins who must be included]1697-one family of cousins who must be included , and [another of very old acquaintance who could not be left out]1699-another of very old acquaintance who could not be left out , it became a certainty that [the five couple]1700-the five couple would be at least ten , and a very interesting speculation in what possible manner [they]1700-the five couple could be disposed of .

The doors of [the two rooms]1701-the two rooms were just opposite each other . “ Might not [they]1700-the five couple use [both rooms]4269-both rooms , and dance across [the passage]3811-the passage ? ”[123-emma] It seemed the best scheme ; and yet it was not so good but that many of [them]1700-the five couple wanted a better . [Emma]123-emma said it would be awkward ; [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was in distress about the supper ; and [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse opposed it earnestly , on the score of health . It made [him]86-mr. weston so very unhappy , indeed , that it could not be persevered in .

“ Oh ! no , ”[86-mr. weston] said [he]86-mr. weston ; “ it would be the extreme of imprudence . [I]86-mr. weston could not bear it for [Emma!--Emma]241-emma!--emma is not strong . [She]241-emma!--emma would catch a dreadful cold . So would poor little [Harriet]111-harriet . So [you]4271-you would all . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , [you]88-mrs. weston would be quite laid up ; do not let [them]1700-the five couple talk of such a wild thing . Pray do not let [them]1700-the five couple talk of it . [That young man]4272-that young man ( speaking lower ) is very thoughtless . Do not tell [[his]4272-that young man father]518-his father , but [that young man]4272-that young man is not quite the thing . [He]4272-that young man has been opening the doors very often this evening , and keeping them open very inconsiderately . [He]4272-that young man does not think of the draught . [I]86-mr. weston do not mean to set [you]88-mrs. weston against [him]4272-that young man , but indeed [he]4272-that young man is not quite the thing ! ”[86-mr. weston]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was sorry for such a charge . [She]88-mrs. weston knew the importance of it , and said every thing in [her]88-mrs. weston power to do it away . Every door was now closed , the passage plan given up , and the first scheme of dancing only in [the room]701-the room [they]1703-we were in resorted to again ; and with such good - will on [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's part , that the space which a quarter of an hour before had been deemed barely sufficient for [five couple]4263-five couple , was now endeavoured to be made out quite enough for ten .

“ [We]1703-we were too magnificent , ”[102-frank churchill] said [he]102-frank churchill . “ [We]1703-we allowed unnecessary room . [Ten couple]4275-ten couple may stand [here]2707-here very well . ”[102-frank churchill]

[Emma]123-emma demurred . “ It would be [a crowd]4277-a crowd -- [a sad crowd]4278-a sad crowd ; and what could be worse than dancing without space to turn in ? ”[123-emma]

“ Very true , ”[102-frank churchill] [he]102-frank churchill gravely replied ; “ it was very bad . ”[102-frank churchill] But still [he]102-frank churchill went on measuring , and still [he]102-frank churchill ended with ,

“ [I]102-frank churchill think there will be very tolerable room for [ten couple]4275-ten couple . ”[102-frank churchill]

“ No , no , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma , “ [you]102-frank churchill are quite unreasonable . It would be dreadful to be standing so close ! Nothing can be farther from pleasure than to be dancing in a crowd -- and a crowd in [a little room]4280-a little room ! ”[123-emma]

“ There is no denying it , ”[102-frank churchill] [he]102-frank churchill replied . “ [I]102-frank churchill agree with [you]102-frank churchill exactly . A crowd in [a little room]4280-a little room -- [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [you]93-miss woodhouse have the art of giving pictures in a few words . Exquisite , quite exquisite!--Still , however , having proceeded so far , [one]2775-one is unwilling to give the matter up . It would be a disappointment to [[my]102-frank churchill father]2740-my father -- and altogether -- [I]102-frank churchill do not know that -- [I]102-frank churchill am rather of opinion that [ten couple]4275-ten couple might stand here very well . ”[102-frank churchill]

[Emma]123-emma perceived that the nature of [his]102-frank churchill gallantry was a little self - willed , and that [he]102-frank churchill would rather oppose than lose the pleasure of dancing with [her]123-emma ; but [she]123-emma took the compliment , and forgave the rest . Had [she]123-emma intended ever to _ marry _ [him]102-frank churchill , it might have been worth while to pause and consider , and try to understand the value of [his]102-frank churchill preference , and the character of [his]102-frank churchill temper ; but for all the purposes of [their]1705-their acquaintance , [he]102-frank churchill was quite amiable enough .

Before the middle of the next day , [he]102-frank churchill was at [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; and [he]102-frank churchill entered [the room]701-the room with such an agreeable smile as certified the continuance of the scheme . It soon appeared that [he]102-frank churchill came to announce an improvement .

“ Well , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , ”[102-frank churchill] [he]102-frank churchill almost immediately began , “ [your]93-miss woodhouse inclination for dancing has not been quite frightened away , [I]102-frank churchill hope , by the terrors of [[[my]102-frank churchill father]2740-my father 's little rooms]4286-my father 's little rooms . [I]102-frank churchill bring a new proposal on the subject:--a thought of [[my]102-frank churchill father]2740-my father 's , which waits only [your]93-miss woodhouse approbation to be acted upon . May [I]102-frank churchill hope for the honour of [your]93-miss woodhouse hand for the two first dances of this little projected ball , to be given , not at [Randalls]101-randalls , but at [the Crown Inn]1429-the crown inn ? ”[102-frank churchill]

“ [The Crown]43-the crown ! ”[1707-i]

“ Yes ; if [you]93-miss woodhouse and [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse see no objection , and [I]102-frank churchill trust [you]93-miss woodhouse can not , [[my]102-frank churchill father]2740-my father hopes [[his]2740-my father friends]2761-his friends will be so kind as to visit [him]2740-my father [there]448-there . Better accommodations , [he]2740-my father can promise [them]2761-his friends , and not a less grateful welcome than at [Randalls]101-randalls . It is [his]2740-my father own idea . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston sees no objection to it , provided [you]93-miss woodhouse are satisfied . This is what [we]4292-we all feel . Oh ! [you]93-miss woodhouse were perfectly right ! [Ten couple]4275-ten couple , in [either of [the Randalls rooms]4295-the randalls rooms]4294-either of the randalls rooms , would have been insufferable!--Dreadful!--I felt how right [you]93-miss woodhouse were the whole time , but was too anxious for securing _ any _ _ thing _ to like to yield . Is not it a good exchange?--You consent -- [I]102-frank churchill hope [you]93-miss woodhouse consent ? ”[102-frank churchill]

“ It appears to [me]1707-i a plan that [nobody]2718-nobody can object to , if [Mr.]4297-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston do not . [I]1707-i think it admirable ; and , as far as [I]1707-i can answer for [myself]1707-i , shall be most happy -- It seems the only improvement that could be . [Papa]154-papa , do [you]154-papa not think it an excellent improvement ? ”[1707-i]

[She]1707-i was obliged to repeat and explain it , before it was fully comprehended ; and then , being quite new , farther representations were necessary to make it acceptable .

“ No ; [he]4297-mr. thought it very far from an improvement -- a very bad plan -- much worse than the other . [A room]4298-a room at [an inn]4299-an inn was always damp and dangerous ; never properly aired , or fit to be inhabited . If [they]4275-ten couple must dance , [they]4275-ten couple had better dance at [Randalls]101-randalls . [He]4297-mr. had never been in [the room at [the Crown]43-the crown in [his]4297-mr. life]4300-the room at the crown in his life -- did not know [the people who kept it by sight.--Oh]4301-the people who kept it by sight.--oh ! no -- a very bad plan . [They]4275-ten couple would catch worse colds at the Crown than anywhere . ”[102-frank churchill]

“ [I]102-frank churchill was going to observe , [sir]2734-sir , ”[102-frank churchill] said [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , “ that one of the great recommendations of this change would be the very little danger of any body 's catching cold -- so much less danger at the Crown than at [Randalls]101-randalls ! [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry might have reason to regret the alteration , but [nobody else]3698-nobody else could . ”[102-frank churchill]

“ [Sir]2734-sir , ”[85-mr. woodhouse] said [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , rather warmly , “ [you]2734-sir are very much mistaken if [you]2734-sir suppose [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry to be that sort of character . [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry is extremely concerned when any of [us]4305-us are ill . But [I]85-mr. woodhouse do not understand how [the room at the Crown]4306-the room at the crown can be safer for [you]2734-sir than [[[your]2734-sir father]3597-your father 's house]4308-your father 's house . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ From the very circumstance of its being larger , [sir]2734-sir . [We]4305-us shall have no occasion to open the windows at all -- not once the whole evening ; and it is that dreadful habit of opening the windows , letting in cold air upon heated bodies , which ( as [you]2734-sir well know , [sir]2734-sir ) does the mischief . ”[102-frank churchill]

“ Open the windows!--but surely , [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill , [nobody]2718-nobody would think of opening the windows at [Randalls]101-randalls . [Nobody]2718-nobody could be so imprudent ! [I]85-mr. woodhouse never heard of such a thing . Dancing with open windows!--I am sure , neither [[your]2734-sir father]3597-your father nor [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ( poor [Miss Taylor]84-miss woodhouse that was ) would suffer it . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ Ah ! [sir]2734-sir -- but [a thoughtless young person]4315-a thoughtless young person will sometimes step behind a window - curtain , and throw up a sash , without its being suspected . [I]102-frank churchill have often known it done [myself]102-frank churchill . ”[102-frank churchill]

“ Have [you]2734-sir indeed , sir?--Bless [me]85-mr. woodhouse ! [I]85-mr. woodhouse never could have supposed it . But [I]85-mr. woodhouse live out of [the world]403-the world , and am often astonished at what [I]85-mr. woodhouse hear . However , this does make a difference ; and , perhaps , when [we]4317-we come to talk it over -- but these sort of things require a good deal of consideration . [One]2775-one can not resolve upon [them]4319-them in a hurry . If [Mr.]4320-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston will be so obliging as to call [here]2707-here one morning , [we]4317-we may talk it over , and see what can be done . ”[85-mr. woodhouse]

“ But , unfortunately , [sir]2734-sir , [my]102-frank churchill time is so limited-- ”[102-frank churchill]

“ Oh ! ”[123-emma] interrupted [Emma]123-emma , “ there will be plenty of time for talking every thing over . There is no hurry at all . If it can be contrived to be at [the Crown]43-the crown , [papa]2708-papa , it will be very convenient for the horses . [They]4324-they will be so near [[their]4324-they own stable]4325-their own stable . ”[123-emma]

“ So [they]4324-they will , [[my]102-frank churchill dear]2714-my dear . That is a great thing . Not that [James]90-james ever complains ; but it is right to spare [our]4317-we horses when [we]4317-we can . If [I]102-frank churchill could be sure of [the rooms]4327-the rooms being thoroughly aired -- but is [Mrs. Stokes]242-mrs. stokes to be trusted ? [I]102-frank churchill doubt it . [I]102-frank churchill do not know [her]242-mrs. stokes , even by sight . ”[102-frank churchill]

“ [I]123-emma can answer for every thing of that nature , [sir]2734-sir , because it will be under [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's care . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston undertakes to direct the whole . ”[123-emma]

“ There , papa!--Now [you]123-emma must be satisfied -- [[Our]4317-we own dear]4329-our own dear [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , who is carefulness itself . Do not [you]123-emma remember what [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry said , so many years ago , when [I]102-frank churchill had the measles ? ' If _ [Miss _ _ Taylor]84-miss woodhouse _ undertakes to wrap [Miss Emma]123-emma up , [you]123-emma need not have any fears , [sir]2734-sir . ' How often have [I]102-frank churchill heard [you]2734-sir speak of it as such a compliment to [her]123-emma ! ”[102-frank churchill]

“ Aye , very true . [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry did say so . [I]123-emma shall never forget it . [Poor little Emma]123-emma ! [You]123-emma were very bad with the measles ; that is , [you]123-emma would have been very bad , but for [Perry]106-mr. perry 's great attention . [He]106-mr. perry came four times a day for a week . [He]106-mr. perry said , from the first , it was a very good sort -- which was [our]4331-our great comfort ; but the measles are a dreadful complaint . [I]123-emma hope whenever [[poor Isabella]87-isabella 's little ones]4332-poor isabella 's little ones have the measles , [she]87-isabella will send for [Perry]106-mr. perry . ”[123-emma]

“ [[My]102-frank churchill father]2740-my father and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston are at the Crown at this moment , ”[102-frank churchill] said [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , “ examining the capabilities of [the house]435-the house . [I]102-frank churchill left [them]4332-poor isabella 's little ones [there]448-there and came on to [Hartfield]2-hartfield , impatient for [your]123-emma opinion , and hoping [you]123-emma might be persuaded to join [them]4332-poor isabella 's little ones and give [your]123-emma advice on the spot . [I]102-frank churchill was desired to say so from [both]887-both . It would be the greatest pleasure to [them]4332-poor isabella 's little ones , if [you]123-emma could allow [me]102-frank churchill to attend [you]123-emma [there]448-there . [They]4332-poor isabella 's little ones can do nothing satisfactorily without [you]123-emma . ”[102-frank churchill]

[Emma]123-emma was most happy to be called to such a council ; and [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , engaging to think it all over while [she]123-emma was gone , [the two young people]1684-the two young people set off together without delay for the Crown . There were [Mr.]1710-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ; delighted to see [her]123-emma and receive [her]123-emma approbation , very busy and very happy in [their]1684-the two young people different way ; [she]123-emma , in some little distress ; and [he]425-her father , finding every thing perfect .

“ [Emma]123-emma , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma , “ this paper is worse than [I]123-emma expected . Look ! in places [you]123-emma see it is dreadfully dirty ; and the wainscot is more yellow and forlorn than any thing [I]123-emma could have imagined . ”[123-emma]

“ [[My]441-her husband dear]2714-my dear , [you]2714-my dear are too particular , ”[441-her husband] said [[her]123-emma husband]441-her husband . “ What does all that signify ? [You]123-emma will see nothing of it by candlelight . It will be as clean as [Randalls]101-randalls by candlelight . [We]4339-we never see any thing of it on [our]4339-we club - nights . ”[441-her husband]

[The ladies here]1712-the ladies here probably exchanged looks which meant , “ [Men]3104-men never know when things are dirty or not ; ”[1438-the gentlemen] and [the gentlemen]1438-the gentlemen perhaps thought each to [himself]1438-the gentlemen , “ [Women]3259-women will have [their]3259-women little nonsenses and needless cares . ”[1438-the gentlemen]

One perplexity , however , arose , which [the gentlemen]1438-the gentlemen did not disdain . It regarded [a supper - room]1715-a supper - room . At the time of [the ballroom]1716-the ballroom 's being built , suppers had not been in question ; and [a small card - room adjoining]1717-a small card - room adjoining , was the only addition . What was to be done ? [This card - room]1718-this card - room would be wanted as [a card - room]1719-a card - room now ; or , if cards were conveniently voted unnecessary by [their]1720-their four selves , still was it not too small for any comfortable supper ? [Another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose]1721-another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose ; but [it]1721-another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose was at the other end of [the house]435-the house , and a long awkward passage must be gone through to get at [it]1721-another room of much better size might be secured for the purpose . This made a difficulty . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was afraid of draughts for [the young people]1723-the young people in [that passage]1724-that passage ; and neither [Emma]123-emma nor [the gentlemen]1438-the gentlemen could tolerate the prospect of being miserably crowded at supper .

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston proposed having no regular supper ; merely sandwiches , & c. , set out in [the little room]1726-the little room ; but that was scouted as a wretched suggestion . A private dance , without sitting down to supper , was pronounced an infamous fraud upon the rights of [men]3104-men and [women]3259-women ; and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston must not speak of it again . [She]88-mrs. weston then took another line of expediency , and looking into [the doubtful room]1729-the doubtful room , observed ,

“ [I]88-mrs. weston do not think it _ is _ so very small . [We]4342-our shall not be many , [you]86-mr. weston know . ”[88-mrs. weston]

And [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston at the same time , walking briskly with long steps through [the passage]3811-the passage , was calling out ,

“ [You]86-mr. weston talk a great deal of the length of [this passage]4343-this passage , [[my]88-mrs. weston dear]2714-my dear . It is a mere nothing after all ; and not the least draught from the stairs . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [I]88-mrs. weston wish , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , “ one could know which arrangement [[our]4342-our guests]4345-our guests in general would like best . To do what would be most generally pleasing must be [our]4342-our object -- if one could but tell what that would be . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Yes , very true , ”[102-frank churchill] cried [Frank]102-frank churchill , “ very true . [You]86-mr. weston want [[your]86-mr. weston neighbours]4036-your neighbours ' opinions . [I]102-frank churchill do not wonder at [you]86-mr. weston . If one could ascertain what [the chief of [them]4036-your neighbours]4347-the chief of them -- [the Coles]184-the coles , for instance . [They]184-the coles are not far off . Shall [I]102-frank churchill call upon [them]184-the coles ? Or [Miss Bates]105-miss bates ? [She]105-miss bates is still nearer.--And [I]102-frank churchill do not know whether [Miss Bates]105-miss bates is not as likely to understand the inclinations of [the rest of [the people]4349-the people]4348-the rest of the people as any body . [I]102-frank churchill think [we]4350-we do want a larger council . Suppose [I]102-frank churchill go and invite [Miss Bates]105-miss bates to join [us]4350-we ? ”[102-frank churchill]

“ Well -- if [you]86-mr. weston please , ”[88-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston rather hesitating , “ if [you]86-mr. weston think [she]105-miss bates will be of any use . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [You]86-mr. weston will get nothing to the purpose from [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma . “ [She]105-miss bates will be all delight and gratitude , but [she]105-miss bates will tell [you]86-mr. weston nothing . [She]105-miss bates will not even listen to [your]86-mr. weston questions . [I]123-emma see no advantage in consulting [Miss Bates]105-miss bates . ”[123-emma]

“ But [she]105-miss bates is so amusing , so extremely amusing ! [I]88-mrs. weston am very fond of hearing [Miss Bates]105-miss bates talk . And [I]88-mrs. weston need not bring [the whole family]1248-the whole family , [you]86-mr. weston know . ”[88-mrs. weston]

Here [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston joined [them]1731-them , and on hearing what was proposed , gave [it]1732-it [his]86-mr. weston decided approbation .

“ Aye , do , [Frank.--Go]244-frank.--go and fetch [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , and let [us]1731-them end the matter at once . [She]105-miss bates will enjoy the scheme , [I]88-mrs. weston am sure ; and [I]88-mrs. weston do not know [a properer person]4352-a properer person for shewing [us]1731-them how to do away difficulties . Fetch [Miss Bates]105-miss bates . [We]1731-them are growing a little too nice . [She]105-miss bates is a standing lesson of how to be happy . But fetch [them]1731-them both . Invite [them]1731-them both . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Both [sir]2734-sir ! Can [the old lady]4354-the old lady ? ”[86-mr. weston] ...

“ [The old lady]4354-the old lady ! No , [the young lady]3152-the young lady , to be sure . [I]88-mrs. weston shall think [you]244-frank.--go [a great blockhead]4357-a great blockhead , [Frank]102-frank churchill , if [you]244-frank.--go bring [the aunt]520-the aunt without [the niece]4359-the niece . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Oh ! [I]88-mrs. weston beg [your]244-frank.--go pardon , [sir]2734-sir . [I]88-mrs. weston did not immediately recollect . Undoubtedly if [you]244-frank.--go wish it , [I]88-mrs. weston will endeavour to persuade [them]4361-them both . ”[88-mrs. weston] And away [he]1733-he ran .

Long before [he]1733-he reappeared , attending [the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt]1734-the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt , and [her]1734-the short , neat , brisk - moving aunt elegant niece,--Mrs . [Weston]86-mr. weston , like [a sweet - tempered woman]1735-a sweet - tempered woman and [a good wife]2884-a good wife , had examined [the passage]3811-the passage again , and found the evils of it much less than [she]2884-a good wife had supposed before -- indeed very trifling ; and here ended the difficulties of decision . All the rest , in speculation at least , was perfectly smooth . All the minor arrangements of table and chair , lights and music , tea and supper , made themselves ; or were left as mere trifles to be settled at any time between [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston and [Mrs. Stokes.--Every body invited]1738-mrs. stokes.--every body invited , was certainly to come ; [Frank]102-frank churchill had already written to [Enscombe]7-enscombe to propose staying a few days beyond [his]1733-he fortnight , which could not possibly be refused . And a delightful dance it was to be .

Most cordially , when [Miss Bates]105-miss bates arrived , did [she]105-miss bates agree that it must . As [a counsellor]1739-a counsellor [she]105-miss bates was not wanted ; but as [an approver]1740-an approver , ( a much safer character , ) [she]105-miss bates was truly welcome . [Her]105-miss bates approbation , at once general and minute , warm and incessant , could not but please ; and for another half - hour [they]1741-they were all walking to and fro , between [the different rooms]1742-the different rooms , some suggesting , [some attending]1743-some attending , and all in happy enjoyment of the future . [The party]2949-the party did not break up without [Emma]123-emma 's being positively secured for the two first dances by [the hero of the evening]1745-the hero of the evening , nor without [her]123-emma overhearing [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston whisper to [[his]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife , “ [He]86-mr. weston has asked [her]123-emma , [[my]86-mr. weston dear]2714-my dear . That 's right . [I]86-mr. weston knew [he]86-mr. weston would ! ”[86-mr. weston]

CHAPTER XII

One thing only was wanting to make the prospect of the ball completely satisfactory to [Emma]123-emma -- its being fixed for a day within the granted term of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's stay in [Surry]31-surry ; for , in spite of [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's confidence , [she]123-emma could not think it so very impossible that [the Churchills]100-the churchills might not allow [[their]1747-their nephew]1748-their nephew to remain a day beyond [his]1748-their nephew fortnight . But this was not judged feasible . The preparations must take [their]1747-their time , nothing could be properly ready till the third week were entered on , and for a few days [they]1747-their must be planning , proceeding and hoping in uncertainty -- at the risk -- in [her]123-emma opinion , the great risk , of its being all in vain .

[Enscombe]7-enscombe however was gracious , gracious in fact , if not in word . [His]7-enscombe wish of staying longer evidently did not please ; but it was not opposed . All was safe and prosperous ; and as the removal of one solicitude generally makes way for another , [Emma]123-emma , being now certain of [her]123-emma ball , began to adopt as the next vexation [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's provoking indifference about it . Either because [he]7-enscombe did not dance [himself]7-enscombe , or because the plan had been formed without [his]7-enscombe being consulted , [he]7-enscombe seemed resolved that it should not interest [him]7-enscombe , determined against its exciting any present curiosity , or affording [him]7-enscombe any future amusement . To [her]123-emma voluntary communications [Emma]123-emma could get no more approving reply , than ,

“ Very well . If [the Westons]108-the westons think it worth while to be at all this trouble for a few hours of noisy entertainment , [I]123-emma have nothing to say against it , but that [they]1747-their shall not chuse pleasures for me.--Oh ! yes , [I]123-emma must be [there]448-there ; [I]123-emma could not refuse ; and [I]123-emma will keep as much awake as [I]123-emma can ; but [I]123-emma would rather be at [home]562-home , looking over [William Larkins]234-william larkins 's week 's account ; much rather , [I]123-emma confess.--Pleasure in seeing dancing!--not [I]123-emma , indeed -- [I]123-emma never look at it -- [I]123-emma do not know who does.--Fine dancing , [I]123-emma believe , like virtue , must be its own reward . [Those who are standing by]4365-those who are standing by are usually thinking of something very different . ”[123-emma]

This [Emma]123-emma felt was aimed at [her]123-emma ; and it made [her]123-emma quite angry . It was not in compliment to [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax however that [he]1749-he was so indifferent , or so indignant ; [he]1749-he was not guided by _ [her]152-miss fairfax _ feelings in reprobating the ball , for _ [she]152-miss fairfax _ enjoyed the thought of it to an extraordinary degree . It made [her]152-miss fairfax animated -- open hearted -- [she]152-miss fairfax voluntarily said;--

“ Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , [I]152-miss fairfax hope nothing may happen to prevent the ball . What a disappointment it would be ! [I]152-miss fairfax do look forward to it , [I]152-miss fairfax own , with _ very _ great pleasure . ”[152-miss fairfax]

It was not to oblige [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax therefore that [he]1749-he would have preferred the society of [William Larkins]234-william larkins . [No!--she]245-no!--she was more and more convinced that [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was quite mistaken in that surmise . There was a great deal of friendly and of compassionate attachment on [his]1749-he side -- but no love .

Alas ! there was soon no leisure for quarrelling with [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . Two days of joyful security were immediately followed by the over - throw of every thing . A letter arrived from [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill to urge [[his]102-frank churchill nephew]1750-his nephew 's instant return . [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill was unwell -- far too unwell to do without [him]1750-his nephew ; [she]98-mrs. churchill had been in a very suffering state ( so said [[her]98-mrs. churchill husband]441-her husband ) when writing to [[her]98-mrs. churchill nephew]3651-her nephew two days before , though from [her]98-mrs. churchill usual unwillingness to give pain , and constant habit of never thinking of [herself]98-mrs. churchill , [she]98-mrs. churchill had not mentioned it ; but now [she]98-mrs. churchill was too ill to trifle , and must entreat [him]1750-his nephew to set off for [Enscombe]7-enscombe without delay .

The substance of this letter was forwarded to [Emma]123-emma , in a note from [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , instantly . As to [his]1750-his nephew going , it was inevitable . [He]1750-his nephew must be gone within a few hours , though without feeling any real alarm for [[his]1750-his nephew aunt]3548-his aunt , to lessen [his]1750-his nephew repugnance . [He]1750-his nephew knew [her]3548-his aunt illnesses ; they never occurred but for [her]3548-his aunt own convenience .

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston added , “ that [he]1750-his nephew could only allow [himself]1750-his nephew time to hurry to [Highbury]3-highbury , after breakfast , and take leave of [the few friends there whom [he]1750-his nephew could suppose to feel any interest in [him]1750-his nephew]4366-the few friends there whom he could suppose to feel any interest in him ; and that [he]1750-his nephew might be expected at [Hartfield]2-hartfield very soon . ”[88-mrs. weston]

This wretched note was the finale of [Emma]123-emma 's breakfast . When once it had been read , there was no doing any thing , but lament and exclaim . The loss of the ball -- the loss of [the young man]532-the young man -- and all that [the young man]532-the young man might be feeling!--It was too wretched!--Such a delightful evening as it would have been!--Every body so happy ! and [she]123-emma and [[her]123-emma partner]1756-her partner the happiest!--“I said it would be so , ”[1756-her partner] was the only consolation .

[[Her]123-emma father]425-her father 's feelings were quite distinct . [He]425-her father thought principally of [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill 's illness , and wanted to know how [she]3548-his aunt was treated ; and as for the ball , it was shocking to have dear [Emma]123-emma disappointed ; but [they]1758-they would all be safer at [home]562-home .

[Emma]123-emma was ready for [[her]123-emma visitor]1760-her visitor some time before [he]1760-her visitor appeared ; but if this reflected at all upon [his]1760-her visitor impatience , [his]1760-her visitor sorrowful look and total want of spirits when [he]1760-her visitor did come might redeem [him]1760-her visitor . [He]1760-her visitor felt the going away almost too much to speak of it . [His]1760-her visitor dejection was most evident . [He]1760-her visitor sat really lost in thought for the first few minutes ; and when rousing [himself]1760-her visitor , it was only to say ,

“ Of all horrid things , leave - taking is the worst . ”[1760-her visitor]

“ But [you]1760-her visitor will come again , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma . “ This will not be [your]1760-her visitor only visit to [Randalls]101-randalls . ”[123-emma]

“ Ah!--(shaking [his]1760-her visitor head)--the uncertainty of when [I]1760-her visitor may be able to return!--I shall try for it with a zeal!--It will be the object of all [my]1760-her visitor thoughts and cares!--and if [[my]1760-her visitor uncle]4367-my uncle and [aunt]3628-aunt go to [town]2760-town this spring -- but [I]1760-her visitor am afraid -- [they]4370-they did not stir last spring -- [I]1760-her visitor am afraid it is a custom gone for ever . ”[1760-her visitor]

“ [Our]4371-we poor ball must be quite given up . ”[123-emma]

“ Ah ! that ball!--why did [we]4371-we wait for any thing?--why not seize the pleasure at once?--How often is happiness destroyed by preparation , foolish preparation!--You told [us]4371-we it would be so.--Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , why are [you]84-miss woodhouse always so right ? ”[1760-her visitor]

“ Indeed , [I]123-emma am very sorry to be right in this instance . [I]123-emma would much rather have been merry than wise . ”[123-emma]

“ If [I]1760-her visitor can come again , [we]4371-we are still to have [our]4371-we ball . [[My]1760-her visitor father]2740-my father depends on it . Do not forget [your]84-miss woodhouse engagement . ”[1760-her visitor]

[Emma]123-emma looked graciously .

“ Such a fortnight as it has been ! ”[1761-you] [he]1761-you continued ; “ every day more precious and more delightful than the day before!--every day making [me]1761-you less fit to bear any other place . [Happy those , who can remain at [Highbury]3-highbury]4373-happy those , who can remain at highbury ! ”[1761-you]

“ As [you]1761-you do [us]4371-we such ample justice now , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , laughing , “ [I]123-emma will venture to ask , whether [you]1761-you did not come a little doubtfully at first ? Do not [we]4371-we rather surpass [your]1761-you expectations ? [I]123-emma am sure [we]4371-we do . [I]123-emma am sure [you]1761-you did not much expect to like [us]4371-we . [You]1761-you would not have been so long in coming , if [you]1761-you had had a pleasant idea of [Highbury]3-highbury . ”[123-emma]

[He]1761-you laughed rather consciously ; and though denying the sentiment , [Emma]123-emma was convinced that it had been so .

“ And [you]1761-you must be off this very morning ? ”[1761-you]

“ Yes ; [[my]1761-you father]2740-my father is to join [me]1761-you here : [we]4371-we shall walk back together , and [I]1761-you must be off immediately . [I]1761-you am almost afraid that every moment will bring [him]2740-my father . ”[1761-you]

“ Not five minutes to spare even for [[your]1761-you friends]3174-your friends [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates ? How unlucky ! [Miss Bates]105-miss bates 's powerful , argumentative mind might have strengthened [yours]1761-you . ”[1761-you]

“ Yes -- [I]1761-you _ have _ called [there]448-there ; passing the door , [I]1761-you thought it better . It was a right thing to do . [I]1761-you went in for three minutes , and was detained by [Miss Bates]105-miss bates 's being absent . [She]105-miss bates was out ; and [I]1761-you felt it impossible not to wait till [she]105-miss bates came in . [She]105-miss bates is [a woman that one]4377-a woman that one may , that [one _]4378-one _ must _ laugh at ; but that [one]2775-one would not wish to slight . It was better to pay [my]1761-you visit , then”--[1761-you]

[He]1762-he hesitated , got up , walked to a window .

“ In short , ”[1762-he] said [he]1762-he , “ perhaps , [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse -- [I]1762-he think [you]1763-she can hardly be quite without suspicion”--[1762-he]

[He]1762-he looked at [her]1763-she , as if wanting to read [her]1763-she thoughts . [She]1763-she hardly knew what to say . It seemed like the forerunner of something absolutely serious , which [she]1763-she did not wish . Forcing [herself]1763-she to speak , therefore , in the hope of putting it by , [she]1763-she calmly said ,

“ [You]1762-he are quite in the right ; it was most natural to pay [your]1762-he visit , then”--[1763-she]

[He]1762-he was silent . [She]1763-she believed [he]1762-he was looking at [her]1763-she ; probably reflecting on what [she]1763-she had said , and trying to understand the manner . [She]1763-she heard [him]1762-he sigh . It was natural for [him]1762-he to feel that [he]1762-he had _ cause _ to sigh . [He]1762-he could not believe [her]1763-she to be encouraging [him]1762-he . A few awkward moments passed , and [he]1762-he sat down again ; and in a more determined manner said ,

“ It was something to feel that all the rest of [my]1762-he time might be given to [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse . [My]1762-he regard for [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse is most warm”--[1762-he]

[He]1762-he stopt again , rose again , and seemed quite embarrassed.--He was more in love with [her]1763-she than [Emma]123-emma had supposed ; and who can say how it might have ended , if [[his]1762-he father]518-his father had not made [his]518-his father appearance ? [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse soon followed ; and the necessity of exertion made [him]85-mr. woodhouse composed .

A very few minutes more , however , completed the present trial . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , always alert when business was to be done , and as incapable of procrastinating any evil that was inevitable , as of foreseeing any that was doubtful , said , “ It was time to go ; ”[532-the young man] and [the young man]532-the young man , though [he]532-the young man might and did sigh , could not but agree , to take leave .

“ [I]86-mr. weston shall hear about [you]4380-you all , ”[86-mr. weston] said [he]86-mr. weston ; “ that is [my]86-mr. weston chief consolation . [I]86-mr. weston shall hear of every thing that is going on among [you]4380-you . [I]86-mr. weston have engaged [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston to correspond with [me]86-mr. weston . [She]88-mrs. weston has been so kind as to promise it . Oh ! the blessing of [a female correspondent]4381-a female correspondent , when [one]2775-one is really interested in [the absent!--she]246-the absent!--she will tell [me]86-mr. weston every thing . In [her]88-mrs. weston letters [I]86-mr. weston shall be at dear [Highbury]3-highbury again . ”[86-mr. weston]

A very friendly shake of the hand , a very earnest “ Good - bye , ”[247-short] closed the speech , and the door had soon shut out [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill . [Short]247-short had been the notice -- short [their]1766-their meeting ; [he]86-mr. weston was gone ; and [Emma]123-emma felt so sorry to part , and foresaw so great a loss to [[their]1766-their little society]1767-their little society from [his]86-mr. weston absence as to begin to be afraid of being too sorry , and feeling it too much .

It was a sad change . [They]1766-their had been meeting almost every day since [his]86-mr. weston arrival . Certainly [his]86-mr. weston being at [Randalls]101-randalls had given great spirit to the last two weeks -- indescribable spirit ; the idea , the expectation of seeing [him]86-mr. weston which every morning had brought , the assurance of [his]86-mr. weston attentions , [his]86-mr. weston liveliness , [his]86-mr. weston manners ! It had been a very happy fortnight , and forlorn must be the sinking from it into the common course of [Hartfield]2-hartfield days . To complete every other recommendation , [he]86-mr. weston had _ almost _ told [her]123-emma that [he]86-mr. weston loved [her]123-emma . What strength , or what constancy of affection [he]86-mr. weston might be subject to , was another point ; but at present [she]123-emma could not doubt [his]86-mr. weston having a decidedly warm admiration , a conscious preference of [herself]123-emma ; and this persuasion , joined to all the rest , made [her]123-emma think that [she]123-emma _ must _ be a little in love with [him]86-mr. weston , in spite of every previous determination against it .

“ [I]123-emma certainly must , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma . “ This sensation of listlessness , weariness , stupidity , this disinclination to sit down and employ [myself]123-emma , this feeling of every thing 's being dull and insipid about the house!-- [I]123-emma must be in love ; [I]123-emma should be [the oddest creature in [the world]403-the world]4383-the oddest creature in the world if [I]123-emma were not -- for a few weeks at least . Well ! evil to [some]4385-some is always good to [others]2773-others . [I]123-emma shall have [many fellow - mourners]4387-many fellow - mourners for the ball , if not for [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill ; but [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley will be happy . [He]92-mr. knightley may spend the evening with [his]92-mr. knightley dear [William Larkins]234-william larkins now if [he]92-mr. knightley likes . ”[123-emma]

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , however , [shewed]1768-shewed no triumphant happiness . [He]92-mr. knightley could not say that [he]92-mr. knightley was sorry on [his]92-mr. knightley own account ; [his]92-mr. knightley very cheerful look would have contradicted [him]92-mr. knightley if [he]92-mr. knightley had ; but [he]92-mr. knightley said , and very steadily , that [he]92-mr. knightley was sorry for the disappointment of [the others]870-the others , and with considerable kindness added ,

“ [You]1770-she , [Emma]123-emma , who have so few opportunities of dancing , [you]1770-she are really out of luck ; [you]1770-she are very much out of luck ! ”[92-mr. knightley]

It was some days before [she]1770-she saw [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , to judge of [her]1770-she honest regret in this woeful change ; but when [they]1771-they did meet , [her]1770-she composure was odious . [She]1770-she had been particularly unwell , however , suffering from headache to a degree , which made [[her]1770-she aunt]3293-her aunt declare , that had the ball taken place , [she]1770-she did not think [Jane]152-miss fairfax could have attended it ; and it was charity to impute some of [her]1770-she unbecoming indifference to the languor of ill - health .

[CHAPTER XIII

Emma]123-emma continued to entertain no doubt of [her]1770-she being in love . [Her]1770-she ideas only varied as to the how much . At first , [she]1770-she thought it was a good deal ; and afterwards , but little . [She]1770-she had great pleasure in hearing [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill talked of ; and , for [his]102-frank churchill sake , greater pleasure than ever in seeing [Mr.]1773-mr. and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ; [she]1770-she was very often thinking of [him]102-frank churchill , and quite impatient for a letter , that [she]1770-she might know how [he]102-frank churchill was , how were [his]102-frank churchill spirits , how was [[his]102-frank churchill aunt]3548-his aunt , and what was the chance of [his]102-frank churchill coming to [Randalls]101-randalls again this spring . But , on the other hand , [she]1770-she could not admit [herself]1770-she to be unhappy , nor , after the first morning , to be less disposed for employment than usual ; [she]1770-she was still busy and cheerful ; and , pleasing as [he]102-frank churchill was , [she]1770-she could yet imagine [him]102-frank churchill to have faults ; and farther , though thinking of [him]102-frank churchill so much , and , as [she]1770-she sat drawing or working , forming a thousand amusing schemes for the progress and close of [their]1775-their attachment , fancying interesting dialogues , and inventing elegant letters ; the conclusion of every imaginary declaration on [his]102-frank churchill side was that [she]1770-she _ refused _ _ [him]102-frank churchill _ . [Their]1775-their affection was always to subside into friendship . Every thing tender and charming was to mark [their]1775-their parting ; but still [they]1775-their were to part . When [she]1770-she became sensible of this , it struck [her]1770-she that [she]1770-she could not be very much in love ; for in spite of [her]1770-she previous and fixed determination never to quit [[her]1770-she father]425-her father , never to marry , a strong attachment certainly must produce more of a struggle than [she]1770-she could foresee in [her]1770-she own feelings .

“ [I]1770-she do not find [myself]1770-she making any use of the word _ sacrifice _ , ”[1770-she] said she.--“In not one of all [my]1770-she clever replies , [my]1770-she delicate negatives , is there any allusion to making a sacrifice . [I]1770-she do suspect that [he]1777-he is not really necessary to [my]1770-she happiness . So much the better . [I]1770-she certainly will not persuade [myself]1770-she to feel more than [I]1770-she do . [I]1770-she am quite enough in love . [I]1770-she should be sorry to be more . ”[1770-she]

Upon the whole , [she]1770-she was equally contented with [her]1770-she view of [his]1777-he feelings .

“ _ [He]1777-he _ is undoubtedly very much in love -- every thing denotes it -- very much in love indeed!--and when [he]1777-he comes again , if [his]1777-he affection continue , [I]1770-she must be on [my]1770-she guard not to encourage it.--It would be most inexcusable to do otherwise , as [my]1770-she own mind is quite made up . Not that [I]1770-she imagine [he]1777-he can think [I]1770-she have been encouraging [him]1777-he hitherto . No , if [he]1777-he had believed [me]1770-she at all to share [his]1777-he feelings , [he]1777-he would not have been so wretched . Could [he]1777-he have thought [himself]1777-he encouraged , [his]1777-he looks and language at parting would have been different.--Still , however , [I]1770-she must be on [my]1770-she guard . This is in the supposition of [his]1777-he attachment continuing what it now is ; but [I]1770-she do not know that [I]1770-she expect it will ; [I]1770-she do not look upon [him]1777-he to be quite [the sort of man]4388-the sort of man -- [I]1770-she do not altogether build upon [his]1777-he steadiness or constancy.--His feelings are warm , but [I]1770-she can imagine them rather changeable.--Every consideration of the subject , in short , makes [me]1770-she thankful that [my]1770-she happiness is not more deeply involved.--I shall do very well again after a little while -- and then , it will be a good thing over ; for [they]4389-they say every body is in love once in [their]4389-they lives , and [I]1770-she shall have been let off easily . ”[1770-she]

When [his]1778-his letter to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston arrived , [Emma]123-emma had the perusal of it ; and [she]123-emma read it with a degree of pleasure and admiration which made [her]123-emma at first shake [her]123-emma head over [her]123-emma own sensations , and think [she]123-emma had undervalued [their]1779-their strength . It was a long , well - written letter , giving the particulars of [his]1778-his journey and of [his]1778-his feelings , expressing all the affection , gratitude , and respect which was natural and honourable , and describing every thing exterior and local that could be supposed attractive , with spirit and precision . No suspicious flourishes now of apology or concern ; it was the language of real feeling towards [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ; and the transition from [Highbury]3-highbury to [Enscombe]7-enscombe , the contrast between the places in some of the first blessings of social life was just enough touched on to shew how keenly it was felt , and how much more might have been said but for the restraints of propriety.--The charm of [her]88-mrs. weston own name was not wanting . _ [Miss _ _ Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse _ appeared more than once , and never without a something of pleasing connexion , either a compliment to [her]93-miss woodhouse taste , or a remembrance of what [she]93-miss woodhouse had said ; and in the very last time of its meeting [her]93-miss woodhouse eye , unadorned as it was by any such broad wreath of gallantry , [she]93-miss woodhouse yet could discern the effect of [her]93-miss woodhouse influence and acknowledge the greatest compliment perhaps of all conveyed . Compressed into the very lowest vacant corner were these words--“I had not a spare moment on Tuesday , as [you]4390-you know , for [[Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse 's beautiful little friend]4391-miss woodhouse 's beautiful little friend . Pray make [my]123-emma excuses and adieus to [her]4391-miss woodhouse 's beautiful little friend . ”[123-emma] This , [Emma]123-emma could not doubt , was all for [herself]123-emma . [Harriet]111-harriet was remembered only from being _ [[her]123-emma _ friend]1780-her _ friend . [His]1781-his information and prospects as to [Enscombe]7-enscombe were neither worse nor better than had been anticipated ; [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill was recovering , and [he]1781-his dared not yet , even in [his]1781-his own imagination , fix a time for coming to [Randalls]101-randalls again .

Gratifying , however , and stimulative as was the letter in the material part , its sentiments , [she]123-emma yet found , when it was folded up and returned to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , that it had not added any lasting warmth , that [she]123-emma could still do without [the writer]727-the writer , and that [he]1781-his must learn to do without [her]123-emma . [Her]123-emma intentions were unchanged . [Her]123-emma resolution of refusal only grew more interesting by the addition of a scheme for [his]1781-his subsequent consolation and happiness . [His]1781-his recollection of [Harriet]111-harriet , and the words which clothed it , [the “ beautiful little friend]4392-the “ beautiful little friend , ”[4392-the “ beautiful little friend] suggested to [her]123-emma the idea of [Harriet]111-harriet 's succeeding [her]111-harriet in [his]1781-his affections . Was it impossible?--No.--Harriet undoubtedly was greatly [his]1781-his inferior in understanding ; but [he]1781-his had been very much struck with the loveliness of [her]111-harriet face and the warm simplicity of [her]111-harriet manner ; and all the probabilities of circumstance and connexion were in [her]111-harriet favour.--For [Harriet]111-harriet , it would be advantageous and delightful indeed .

“ [I]111-harriet must not dwell upon it , ”[111-harriet] said she.--“I must not think of it . [I]111-harriet know the danger of indulging such speculations . But stranger things have happened ; and when [we]4393-we cease to care for [each other]430-each other as [we]4393-we do now , it will be the means of confirming [us]4393-we in that sort of true disinterested friendship which [I]111-harriet can already look forward to with pleasure . ”[111-harriet]

It was well to have a comfort in store on [Harriet]111-harriet 's behalf , though it might be wise to let the fancy touch it seldom ; for evil in that quarter was at hand . As [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's arrival had succeeded [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's engagement in the conversation of [Highbury]3-highbury , as the latest interest had entirely borne down the first , so now upon [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's disappearance , [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's concerns were assuming the most irresistible form.--His wedding - day was named . [He]95-mr. elton would soon be among [them]1783-them again ; [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton and [[his]95-mr. elton bride]1321-his bride . There was hardly time to talk over the first letter from [Enscombe]7-enscombe before “ [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton and [[his]95-mr. elton bride]1321-his bride ”[2749-every body] was in [every body]2749-every body 's mouth , and [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill was forgotten . [Emma]123-emma grew sick at the sound . [She]123-emma had had three weeks of happy exemption from [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton ; and [Harriet]111-harriet 's mind , [she]123-emma had been willing to hope , had been lately gaining strength . With [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's ball in view at least , there had been a great deal of insensibility to other things ; but it was now too evident that [she]123-emma had not attained such a state of composure as could stand against the actual approach -- [new carriage]1786-new carriage , bell - ringing , and all .

Poor [Harriet]111-harriet was in a flutter of spirits which required all the reasonings and soothings and attentions of every kind that [Emma]123-emma could give . [Emma]123-emma felt that [she]123-emma could not do too much for [her]111-harriet , that [Harriet]111-harriet had a right to all [her]111-harriet ingenuity and all [her]111-harriet patience ; but it was heavy work to be for ever convincing without producing any effect , for ever agreed to , without being able to make [their]1787-them opinions the same . [Harriet]111-harriet listened submissively , and said “ it was very true -- it was just as [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse described -- it was not worth while to think about [them]1787-them -- and [she]93-miss woodhouse would not think about [them]1787-them any longer ”[111-harriet] but no change of subject could avail , and the next half - hour saw [her]111-harriet as anxious and restless about [the Eltons]143-the eltons as before . At last [Emma]123-emma attacked [her]111-harriet on another ground .

“ [Your]111-harriet allowing [yourself]111-harriet to be so occupied and so unhappy about [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's marrying , [Harriet]111-harriet , is the strongest reproach [you]111-harriet can make _ [me]123-emma _ . [You]111-harriet could not give [me]123-emma a greater reproof for the mistake [I]123-emma fell into . It was all [my]123-emma doing , [I]123-emma know . [I]123-emma have not forgotten it , [I]123-emma assure you.--Deceived [myself]123-emma , [I]123-emma did very miserably deceive [you]111-harriet -- and it will be a painful reflection to [me]123-emma for ever . Do not imagine [me]123-emma in danger of forgetting it . ”[123-emma]

[Harriet]111-harriet felt this too much to utter more than a few words of eager exclamation . [Emma]123-emma continued ,

“ [I]123-emma have not said , exert [yourself]111-harriet [Harriet]111-harriet for [my]123-emma sake ; think less , talk less of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton for [my]123-emma sake ; because for [your]111-harriet own sake rather , [I]123-emma would wish it to be done , for the sake of what is more important than [my]123-emma comfort , a habit of self - command in [you]111-harriet , a consideration of what is [your]111-harriet duty , an attention to propriety , an endeavour to avoid the suspicions of [others]2773-others , to save [your]111-harriet health and credit , and restore [your]111-harriet tranquillity . These are the motives which [I]123-emma have been pressing on [you]111-harriet . They are very important -- and sorry [I]123-emma am that [you]111-harriet can not feel [them]4397-them sufficiently to act upon [them]4397-them . [My]123-emma being saved from pain is a very secondary consideration . [I]123-emma want [you]111-harriet to save [yourself]111-harriet from greater pain . Perhaps [I]123-emma may sometimes have felt that [Harriet]111-harriet would not forget what was due -- or rather what would be kind by [me]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

This appeal to [her]1788-her affections did more than all the rest . The idea of wanting gratitude and consideration for [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , whom [she]1788-her really loved extremely , made [her]1788-her wretched for a while , and when the violence of grief was comforted away , still remained powerful enough to prompt to what was right and support [her]1788-her in it very tolerably .

“ [You]93-miss woodhouse , who have been [the best friend [I]123-emma ever had in [my]123-emma life]4398-the best friend i ever had in my life -- Want gratitude to you!--Nobody is equal to you!--I care for [nobody]2718-nobody as [I]123-emma do for you!--Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , how ungrateful [I]123-emma have been ! ”[123-emma]

Such expressions , assisted as they were by every thing that look and manner could do , made [Emma]123-emma feel that [she]123-emma had never loved [Harriet]111-harriet so well , nor valued [her]111-harriet affection so highly before .

“ There is no charm equal to tenderness of heart , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma afterwards to [herself]123-emma . “ There is nothing to be compared to it . Warmth and tenderness of heart , with an affectionate , open manner , will beat all the clearness of head in [the world]403-the world , for attraction , [I]123-emma am sure it will . It is tenderness of heart which makes [[my]123-emma dear father]4401-my dear father so generally beloved -- which gives [Isabella]87-isabella all [her]87-isabella popularity.--I have it not -- but [I]123-emma know how to prize and respect it.--Harriet is [my]123-emma superior in all the charm and all the felicity it gives . [Dear Harriet!--I]249-dear harriet!--i would not change [you]249-dear harriet!--i for the clearest - headed , longest - sighted , best - judging female breathing . Oh ! the coldness of [a Jane Fairfax!--Harriet]250-a jane fairfax!--harriet is worth a hundred such -- And for [a wife]2759-a wife -- [[a sensible man]2966-a sensible man 's wife]4404-a sensible man 's wife -- it is invaluable . [I]123-emma mention no names ; but happy [the man who changes [Emma]123-emma for [Harriet]111-harriet]4405-the man who changes emma for harriet ! ”[123-emma]

CHAPTER XIV

[Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton was first seen at [church]593-church : but though devotion might be interrupted , curiosity could not be satisfied by [a bride in a pew]1790-a bride in a pew , and it must be left for the visits in form which were then to be paid , to settle whether [she]1790-a bride in a pew were very pretty indeed , or only rather pretty , or not pretty at all .

[Emma]123-emma had feelings , less of curiosity than of pride or propriety , to make [her]123-emma resolve on not being the last to pay [her]123-emma respects ; and [she]123-emma made a point of [Harriet]111-harriet 's going with [her]123-emma , that the worst of the business might be gone through as soon as possible .

[She]123-emma could not enter [the house]435-the house again , could not be in [the same room to which [she]123-emma had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago , to lace up [her]123-emma boot , without _ recollecting _]1792-the same room to which she had with such vain artifice retreated three months ago , to lace up her boot , without _ recollecting _ . A thousand vexatious thoughts would recur . Compliments , charades , and horrible blunders ; and it was not to be supposed that [poor Harriet]111-harriet should not be recollecting too ; but [she]111-harriet behaved very well , and was only rather pale and silent . The visit was of course short ; and there was so much embarrassment and occupation of mind to shorten it , that [Emma]123-emma would not allow [herself]123-emma entirely to form an opinion of [the lady]3048-the lady , and on no account to give one , beyond the nothing - meaning terms of being “ elegantly dressed , and very pleasing . ”[123-emma]

[She]123-emma did not really like [her]3048-the lady . [She]123-emma would not be in a hurry to find fault , but [she]123-emma suspected that there was no elegance;--ease , but not elegance.-- [She]123-emma was almost sure that for [a young woman]3868-a young woman , [a stranger]3987-a stranger , [a bride]1796-a bride , there was too much ease . [[Her]3048-the lady person]616-her person was rather good ; [her]3048-the lady face not unpretty ; but neither feature , nor air , nor voice , nor manner , were elegant . [Emma]123-emma thought at least it would turn out so .

As for [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , [his]95-mr. elton manners did not appear -- but no , [she]123-emma would not permit a hasty or a witty word from [herself]123-emma about [his]95-mr. elton manners . It was an awkward ceremony at any time to be receiving wedding visits , and [a man]2840-a man had need be all grace to acquit [himself]2840-a man well through it . [The woman]1799-the woman was better off ; [she]1799-the woman might have the assistance of fine clothes , and the privilege of bashfulness , but [the man]3033-the man had only [his]3033-the man own good sense to depend on ; and when [she]123-emma considered how peculiarly unlucky poor [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton was in being in [the same room]4054-the same room at once with [the woman [he]95-mr. elton had just married]1802-the woman he had just married , [the woman [he]95-mr. elton had wanted to marry]1803-the woman he had wanted to marry , and [the woman whom [he]95-mr. elton had been expected to marry]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry , [she]123-emma must allow [him]95-mr. elton to have the right to look as little wise , and to be as much affectedly , and as little really easy as could be .

“ Well , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , ”[111-harriet] said [Harriet]111-harriet , when [they]1805-they had quitted [the house]435-the house , and after waiting in vain for [[her]111-harriet friend]427-her friend to begin ; “ Well , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , ( with a gentle sigh , ) what do [you]93-miss woodhouse think of her?--Is not [she]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry very charming ? ”[111-harriet]

There was a little hesitation in [Emma]123-emma 's answer .

“ Oh ! yes -- very -- [a very pleasing young woman]4406-a very pleasing young woman . ”[111-harriet]

“ [I]111-harriet think [her]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry beautiful , quite beautiful . ”[111-harriet]

“ Very nicely dressed , indeed ; a remarkably elegant gown . ”[111-harriet]

“ [I]111-harriet am not at all surprized that [he]95-mr. elton should have fallen in love . ”[111-harriet]

“ Oh ! no -- there is nothing to surprize one at all.--A pretty fortune ; and [she]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry came in [his]95-mr. elton way . ”[111-harriet]

“ [I]111-harriet dare say , ”[111-harriet] returned [Harriet]111-harriet , sighing again , “ [I]111-harriet dare say [she]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry was very much attached to [him]95-mr. elton . ”[111-harriet]

“ Perhaps [she]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry might ; but it is not [every man]3111-every man 's fate to marry [the woman who loves [him]3111-every man best]4408-the woman who loves him best . [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins perhaps wanted [a home]4409-a home , and thought this the best offer [she]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry was likely to have . ”[111-harriet]

“ Yes , ”[111-harriet] said [Harriet]111-harriet earnestly , “ and well [she]1804-the woman whom he had been expected to marry might , [nobody]2718-nobody could ever have a better . Well , [I]111-harriet wish [them]4411-them happy with all [my]111-harriet heart . And now , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [I]111-harriet do not think [I]111-harriet shall mind seeing [them]4411-them again . [He]95-mr. elton is just as superior as ever;--but being married , [you]93-miss woodhouse know , it is quite a different thing . No , indeed , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [you]93-miss woodhouse need not be afraid ; [I]111-harriet can sit and admire [him]95-mr. elton now without any great misery . To know that [he]95-mr. elton has not thrown [himself]95-mr. elton away , is such [a comfort!--She]4412-a comfort!--she does seem [a charming young woman]4413-a charming young woman , just what [he]95-mr. elton deserves . [Happy creature]4414-happy creature ! [He]95-mr. elton called [her]4414-happy creature ' [Augusta]204-augusta . ' How delightful ! ”[111-harriet]

When the visit was returned , [Emma]123-emma made up [her]123-emma mind . [She]123-emma could then see more and judge better . From [Harriet]111-harriet 's happening not to be at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , and [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father 's being present to engage [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , [she]123-emma had a quarter of an hour of [the lady]3048-the lady 's conversation to [herself]123-emma , and could composedly attend to [her]111-harriet ; and the quarter of an hour quite convinced [her]123-emma that [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton was [a vain woman]1810-a vain woman , extremely well satisfied with [herself]207-mrs. elton , and thinking much of [her]207-mrs. elton own importance ; that [she]207-mrs. elton meant to shine and be very superior , but with manners which had been formed in a bad school , pert and familiar ; that all [her]207-mrs. elton notions were drawn from one set of [people]2986-people , and one style of living ; that if not foolish [she]207-mrs. elton was ignorant , and that [her]207-mrs. elton society would certainly do [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton no good .

[Harriet]111-harriet would have been a better match . If not wise or refined [herself]111-harriet , [she]111-harriet would have connected [him]95-mr. elton with [those who were]1812-those who were ; but [Miss Hawkins]197-miss hawkins , it might be fairly supposed from [her]197-miss hawkins easy conceit , had been the best of [her]197-miss hawkins own set . [The rich brother - in - law near [Bristol]40-bristol]1813-the rich brother - in - law near bristol was the pride of [the alliance]1814-the alliance , and [his]1813-the rich brother - in - law near bristol place and [[his]1813-the rich brother - in - law near bristol carriages]1815-his carriages were the pride of [him]1813-the rich brother - in - law near bristol .

The very first subject after being seated was [Maple Grove]51-maple grove , “ [[My]207-mrs. elton brother]2939-my brother [Mr. Suckling]251-mr. suckling 's seat;”--a[207-mrs. elton] comparison of [Hartfield]2-hartfield to [Maple Grove]51-maple grove . [The grounds of [Hartfield]2-hartfield]1816-the grounds of hartfield were small , but neat and pretty ; and [the house]435-the house was modern and well - built . [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton seemed most favourably impressed by the size of [the room]701-the room , the entrance , and all that [she]207-mrs. elton could see or imagine . “ Very like [Maple Grove]51-maple grove indeed!--She was quite struck by [the likeness!--That room]4416-the likeness!--that room was the very shape and size of [the morning - room at [Maple Grove]51-maple grove]4417-the morning - room at maple grove ; [[[her]207-mrs. elton sister]407-her sister 's favourite room]4419-her sister 's favourite room . ”--Mr[207-mrs. elton] . [Elton]207-mrs. elton was appealed to.--“Was not it astonishingly like?--She could really almost fancy [herself]207-mrs. elton at [Maple Grove]51-maple grove . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ And the staircase -- [You]4420-you know , as [I]207-mrs. elton came in , [I]207-mrs. elton observed how very like the staircase was ; placed exactly in [the same part of [the house]435-the house]4421-the same part of the house . [I]207-mrs. elton really could not help exclaiming ! [I]207-mrs. elton assure [you]4420-you , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , it is very delightful to [me]207-mrs. elton , to be reminded of [a place [I]207-mrs. elton am so extremely partial to as [Maple Grove]51-maple grove]4423-a place i am so extremely partial to as maple grove . [Every body who sees it]4426-every body who sees it is struck by [its]448-there beauty ; but to [me]207-mrs. elton , [it]448-there has been quite [a home]4409-a home . Whenever [you]4420-you are transplanted , like [me]207-mrs. elton , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [you]4420-you will understand how very delightful it is to meet with any thing at all like what one has left behind . [I]207-mrs. elton always say this is quite one of the evils of matrimony . ”[207-mrs. elton]

[Emma]123-emma made as slight a reply as [she]123-emma could ; but it was fully sufficient for [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , who only wanted to be talking [herself]207-mrs. elton .

“ So extremely like [Maple Grove]51-maple grove ! And it is not merely [the house]435-the house -- [the grounds]4429-the grounds , [I]207-mrs. elton assure [you]4420-you , as far as [I]207-mrs. elton could observe , are strikingly like . The laurels at [Maple Grove]51-maple grove are in the same profusion as here , and stand very much in the same way -- just across [the lawn]4430-the lawn ; and [I]207-mrs. elton had a glimpse of a fine large tree , with a bench round it , which put [me]207-mrs. elton so exactly in mind ! [[My]207-mrs. elton brother and sister]4431-my brother and sister will be enchanted with [this place]4432-this place . [People who have [extensive grounds]4434-extensive grounds [themselves]1819-people who had extensive grounds themselves]4433-people who have extensive grounds themselves are always pleased with any thing in the same style . ”[207-mrs. elton]

[Emma]123-emma doubted the truth of this sentiment . [She]123-emma had a great idea that [people who had [extensive grounds]4434-extensive grounds [themselves]1819-people who had extensive grounds themselves]1819-people who had extensive grounds themselves cared very little for the extensive grounds of [any body else]1042-any body else ; but it was not worth while to attack an error so double - dyed , and therefore only said in reply ,

“ When [you]4420-you have seen more of [this country]2827-this country , [I]207-mrs. elton am afraid [you]4420-you will think [you]4420-you have overrated [Hartfield]2-hartfield . [Surry]31-surry is full of beauties . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ Oh ! yes , [I]207-mrs. elton am quite aware of that . [It]31-surry is [the garden of [England]36-england]4436-the garden of england , [you]4420-you know . [Surry]31-surry is [the garden of [England]36-england]4436-the garden of england . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ Yes ; but [we]4438-we must not rest [our]4438-we claims on that distinction . [Many counties]4439-many counties , [I]207-mrs. elton believe , are called [the garden of [England]36-england]4436-the garden of england , as well as [Surry]31-surry . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ No , [I]207-mrs. elton fancy not , ”[207-mrs. elton] replied [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , with a most satisfied smile . “ [I]207-mrs. elton never heard [any county]4441-any county but [Surry]31-surry called so . ”[207-mrs. elton]

[Emma]123-emma was silenced .

“ [[My]207-mrs. elton brother]2939-my brother and sister have promised [us]4438-we a visit in the spring , or summer at farthest , ”[207-mrs. elton] continued [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton ; “ and that will be [our]4438-we time for exploring . While [they]4443-their are with [us]4438-we , [we]4438-we shall explore a great deal , [I]207-mrs. elton dare say . [They]4443-their will have [[their]4443-their barouche - landau]4444-their barouche - landau , of course , which holds four perfectly ; and therefore , without saying any thing of _ [our]4438-we _ carriage , [we]4438-we should be able to explore the different beauties extremely well . [They]4443-their would hardly come in [their]4443-their chaise , [I]207-mrs. elton think , at that season of the year . [We]4438-we explored to [King's - Weston]52-king's - weston twice last summer , in that way , most delightfully , just after [their]4443-their first having [the barouche - landau]4445-the barouche - landau . [You]4448-you have many parties of that kind here , [I]207-mrs. elton suppose , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , every summer ? ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ No ; not immediately here . [We]4438-we are rather out of distance of the very striking beauties which attract the sort of parties [you]4448-you speak of ; and [we]4438-we are [a very quiet set of people]4451-a very quiet set of people , [I]207-mrs. elton believe ; more disposed to stay at [home]562-home than engage in schemes of pleasure . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ Ah ! there is nothing like staying at [home]562-home for real comfort . [Nobody]2718-nobody can be more devoted to [home]562-home than [I]207-mrs. elton am . [I]207-mrs. elton was quite a proverb for it at [Maple Grove]51-maple grove . Many a time has [Selina]252-selina said , when [she]252-selina has been going to [Bristol]40-bristol , ' [I]207-mrs. elton really can not get [this girl]1214-this girl to move from [the house]435-the house . [I]207-mrs. elton absolutely must go in by [myself]207-mrs. elton , though [I]207-mrs. elton hate being stuck up in [the barouche - landau]4445-the barouche - landau without [a companion]2862-a companion ; but [Augusta]204-augusta , [I]207-mrs. elton believe , with [her]204-augusta own good - will , would never stir beyond [the park paling]4460-the park paling . ' Many a time has [she]204-augusta said so ; and yet [I]207-mrs. elton am no advocate for entire seclusion . [I]207-mrs. elton think , on the contrary , when [people]2986-people shut [themselves]2986-people up entirely from society , it is a very bad thing ; and that it is much more advisable to mix in [the world]403-the world in a proper degree , without living in it either too much or too little . [I]207-mrs. elton perfectly understand [your]1214-this girl situation , however , [Miss Woodhouse--(looking]4463-miss woodhouse--(looking towards [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse ) , [[Your]1214-this girl father]3597-your father 's state of health must be a great drawback .
