[She]98-mrs. churchill had never been admitted before to be seriously ill . The event acquitted [her]98-mrs. churchill of all the fancifulness , and all the selfishness of imaginary complaints .

“ [Poor Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill ! no doubt [she]98-mrs. churchill had been suffering a great deal : more than [any body]665-any body had ever supposed -- and continual pain would try the temper . It was a sad event -- a great shock -- with all [her]98-mrs. churchill faults , what would [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill do without [her]98-mrs. churchill ? [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill 's loss would be dreadful indeed . [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill would never get over it . ”--Even[86-mr. weston] [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston shook [his]86-mr. weston head , and looked solemn , and said , “ Ah ! [poor woman , who would have thought it]5212-poor woman , who would have thought it ! ”[86-mr. weston] and resolved , that [his]86-mr. weston mourning should be as handsome as possible ; and [[his]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife sat sighing and moralising over [her]2763-his wife broad hems with a commiseration and good sense , true and steady . How it would affect [Frank]102-frank churchill was among the earliest thoughts of both . It was also a very early speculation with [Emma]123-emma . The character of [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill , the grief of [[her]2763-his wife husband]441-her husband -- [her]2763-his wife mind glanced over [them]2349-their both with awe and compassion -- and then rested with lightened feelings on how [Frank]102-frank churchill might be affected by the event , how benefited , how freed . [She]2763-his wife saw in a moment all the possible good . Now , an attachment to [Harriet Smith]111-harriet would have nothing to encounter . [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill , independent of [[his]102-frank churchill wife]2763-his wife , was feared by [nobody]2718-nobody ; [an easy , guidable man]2352-an easy , guidable man , to be persuaded into any thing by [[his]102-frank churchill nephew]1750-his nephew . All that remained to be wished was , that [the nephew]3571-the nephew should form the attachment , as , with all [her]2763-his wife goodwill in the cause , [Emma]123-emma could feel no certainty of its being already formed .

[Harriet]111-harriet behaved extremely well on the occasion , with great self - command . What ever [she]111-harriet might feel of brighter hope , [she]111-harriet betrayed nothing . [Emma]123-emma was gratified , to observe such a proof in [her]111-harriet of strengthened character , and refrained from any allusion that might endanger its maintenance . [They]2349-their spoke , therefore , of [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill 's death with mutual forbearance .

Short letters from [Frank]102-frank churchill were received at [Randalls]101-randalls , communicating all that was immediately important of [their]2349-their state and plans . [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill was better than could be expected ; and [their]2349-their first removal , on the departure of the funeral for [Yorkshire]47-yorkshire , was to be to [the house of [a very old friend in [Windsor]75-windsor , to whom [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years]2356-a very old friend in windsor , to whom mr. churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years]2355-the house of a very old friend in windsor , to whom mr. churchill had been promising a visit the last ten years . At present , there was nothing to be done for [Harriet]111-harriet ; good wishes for the future were all that could yet be possible on [Emma]123-emma 's side .

It was a more pressing concern to [shew]2357-shew attention to [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , whose prospects were closing , while [Harriet]111-harriet 's opened , and whose engagements now allowed of no delay in any one at [Highbury]3-highbury , who wished to shew [her]111-harriet kindness -- and with [Emma]123-emma it was grown into a first wish . [She]123-emma had scarcely a stronger regret than for [her]123-emma past coldness ; and [the person , whom [she]123-emma had been so many months neglecting , was now the very one on whom [she]123-emma would have lavished every distinction of regard or sympathy]2358-the person , whom she had been so many months neglecting , was now the very one on whom she would have lavished every distinction of regard or sympathy . [She]123-emma wanted to be of use to [her]123-emma ; wanted to shew a value for [her]123-emma society , and testify respect and consideration . [She]123-emma resolved to prevail on [her]123-emma to spend a day at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . A note was written to urge it . The invitation was refused , and by a verbal message . “ [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax was not well enough to write ; ”[123-emma] and when [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry called at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , the same morning , it appeared that [she]123-emma was so much indisposed as to have been visited , though against [her]123-emma own consent , by [himself]106-mr. perry , and that [she]123-emma was suffering under severe headaches , and a nervous fever to a degree , which made [him]106-mr. perry doubt the possibility of [her]123-emma going to [Mrs. Smallridge]330-mrs. smallridge 's at the time proposed . [Her]123-emma health seemed for the moment completely deranged -- appetite quite gone -- and though there were no absolutely alarming symptoms , nothing touching the pulmonary complaint , which was the standing apprehension of [the family]433-the family , [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry was uneasy about [her]123-emma . [He]106-mr. perry thought [she]123-emma had undertaken more than [she]123-emma was equal to , and that [she]123-emma felt it so [herself]123-emma , though [she]123-emma would not own it . [Her]123-emma spirits seemed overcome . [[Her]123-emma present home]2360-her present home , [he]106-mr. perry could not but observe , was unfavourable to a nervous disorder:--confined always to one room;--he could have wished it otherwise -- and [[her]123-emma good aunt]2361-her good aunt , though [[his]106-mr. perry very old friend]2362-his very old friend , [he]106-mr. perry must acknowledge to be not the best companion for [an invalid of that description]2363-an invalid of that description . [Her]123-emma care and attention could not be questioned ; they were , in fact , only too great . [He]106-mr. perry very much feared that [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax derived more evil than good from [them]2364-them . [Emma]123-emma listened with the warmest concern ; grieved for [her]123-emma more and more , and looked around eager to discover some way of being useful . To take [her]123-emma -- be it only an hour or two -- from [[her]123-emma aunt]3293-her aunt , to give [her]123-emma change of air and scene , and quiet rational conversation , even for an hour or two , might do [her]123-emma good ; and the following morning [she]123-emma wrote again to say , in the most feeling language [she]123-emma could command , that [she]123-emma would call for [her]123-emma in [the carriage]2719-the carriage at any hour that [Jane]152-miss fairfax would name -- mentioning that [she]123-emma had [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry 's decided opinion , in favour of such exercise for [[his]106-mr. perry patient]2367-his patient . The answer was only in this short note :

“ [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's compliments and thanks , but is quite unequal to any exercise . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma felt that [her]123-emma own note had deserved something better ; but it was impossible to quarrel with words , whose tremulous inequality shewed indisposition so plainly , and [she]123-emma thought only of how [she]123-emma might best counteract this unwillingness to be seen or assisted . In spite of the answer , therefore , [she]123-emma ordered [the carriage]2719-the carriage , and drove to [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's , in the hope that [Jane]152-miss fairfax would be induced to join [her]123-emma -- but it would not [do;--Miss Bates]110-mrs. bates came to the carriage door , all gratitude , and agreeing with [her]110-mrs. bates most earnestly in thinking an airing might be of the greatest service -- and every thing that message could do was tried -- but all in vain . [Miss Bates]105-miss bates was obliged to return without success ; [Jane]105-miss bates was quite unpersuadable ; the mere proposal of going out seemed to make [her]110-mrs. bates worse.--Emma wished [she]110-mrs. bates could have seen [her]105-miss bates , and tried [her]110-mrs. bates own powers ; but , almost before [she]105-miss bates could hint the wish , [Miss Bates]105-miss bates made it appear that [she]105-miss bates had promised [[her]105-miss bates niece]1204-her niece on no account to let [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse in . “ Indeed , the truth was , that poor dear [Jane]105-miss bates could not bear to see any body -- any body at all -- [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , indeed , could not be denied -- and [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole had made such a point -- and [Mrs. Perry]104-mrs. perry had said so much -- but , except [them]2370-them , [Jane]105-miss bates would really see [nobody]2718-nobody . ”[105-miss bates]

[Emma]123-emma did not want to be classed with [the Mrs. Eltons]339-the mrs. eltons , [the Mrs. Perrys]107-the little perrys , and [the Mrs. Coles]184-the coles , who would force [themselves]2370-them anywhere ; neither could [she]123-emma feel any right of preference [herself]123-emma -- [she]123-emma submitted , therefore , and only questioned [Miss Bates]105-miss bates farther as to [[her]105-miss bates niece]1204-her niece 's appetite and diet , which [she]105-miss bates longed to be able to assist . On that subject [poor Miss Bates]105-miss bates was very unhappy , and very communicative ; [Jane]105-miss bates would hardly eat any thing:--Mr . [Perry]104-mrs. perry recommended nourishing food ; but every thing [they]2370-them could command ( and never had any body such [good neighbours]578-good neighbours ) was distasteful .

[Emma]123-emma , on reaching [home]562-home , called [the housekeeper]883-the housekeeper directly , to an examination of [[her]883-the housekeeper stores]2375-her stores ; and [some arrowroot of very superior quality]2376-some arrowroot of very superior quality was speedily despatched to [Miss Bates]105-miss bates with a most friendly note . In half an hour the arrowroot was returned , with a thousand thanks from [Miss Bates]105-miss bates , but “ [dear Jane]105-miss bates would not be satisfied without its being sent back ; it was a thing [she]152-miss fairfax could not take -- and , moreover , [she]152-miss fairfax insisted on [her]152-miss fairfax saying , that [she]152-miss fairfax was not at all in want of any thing . ”[105-miss bates]

When [Emma]123-emma afterwards heard that [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax had been seen wandering about [the meadows]2377-the meadows , at some distance from [Highbury]3-highbury , on the afternoon of the very day on which [she]152-miss fairfax had , under the plea of being unequal to any exercise , so peremptorily refused to go out with [her]152-miss fairfax in [the carriage]2719-the carriage , [she]123-emma could have no doubt -- putting every thing together -- that [Jane]152-miss fairfax was resolved to receive no kindness from _ [her]152-miss fairfax _ . [She]123-emma was sorry , very sorry . [Her]123-emma heart was grieved for a state which seemed but the more pitiable from this sort of irritation of spirits , inconsistency of action , and inequality of powers ; and it mortified [her]123-emma that [she]123-emma was given so little credit for proper feeling , or esteemed so little worthy as [a friend]416-a friend : but [she]123-emma had the consolation of knowing that [her]123-emma intentions were good , and of being able to say to [herself]123-emma , that could [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley have been privy to all [her]123-emma attempts of assisting [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , could [he]92-mr. knightley even have seen into [her]123-emma heart , [he]92-mr. knightley would not , on this occasion , have found any thing to reprove .

CHAPTER X

One morning , about ten days after [Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill 's decease , [Emma]123-emma was called [downstairs]1377-downstairs to [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , who “ could not stay five minutes , and wanted particularly to speak with [her]123-emma . ”--He[86-mr. weston] met [her]123-emma at [the parlour]659-the parlour - door , and hardly asking [her]123-emma how [she]123-emma did , in the natural key of [his]86-mr. weston voice , sunk it immediately , to say , unheard by [[her]123-emma father]425-her father ,

“ Can [you]86-mr. weston come to [Randalls]101-randalls at any time this morning?--Do , if it be possible . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston wants to see [you]86-mr. weston . [She]88-mrs. weston must see [you]86-mr. weston . ”[86-mr. weston]

“ Is [she]88-mrs. weston unwell ? ”[86-mr. weston]

“ No , no , not at all -- only a little agitated . [She]88-mrs. weston would have ordered [the carriage]2719-the carriage , and come to [you]86-mr. weston , but [she]88-mrs. weston must see [you]86-mr. weston _ alone _ , and that [you]86-mr. weston know--(nodding towards [her]88-mrs. weston father)--Humph!--Can [you]86-mr. weston come ? ”[86-mr. weston]

“ Certainly . This moment , if [you]86-mr. weston please . It is impossible to refuse what [you]86-mr. weston ask in such a way . But what can be the matter?--Is [she]88-mrs. weston really not ill ? ”[86-mr. weston]

“ Depend upon [me]86-mr. weston -- but ask no more questions . [You]86-mr. weston will know it all in time . The most unaccountable business ! But hush , hush ! ”[86-mr. weston]

To guess what all this meant , was impossible even for [Emma]123-emma . Something really important seemed announced by [his]2383-his looks ; but , as [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend was well , [she]123-emma endeavoured not to be uneasy , and settling it with [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , that [she]123-emma would take [her]123-emma walk now , [she]123-emma and [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston were soon out of [the house]435-the house together and on [their]2387-their way at a quick pace for [Randalls]101-randalls .

“ Now,”--said[123-emma] [Emma]123-emma , when [they]2387-their were fairly beyond the sweep gates,--“now [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , do let [me]123-emma know what has happened . ”[123-emma]

“ No , no,”--he[123-emma] gravely replied.--“Don't ask [me]123-emma . [I]123-emma promised [[my]123-emma wife]5114-my wife to leave it all to [her]5114-my wife . [She]5114-my wife will break it to [you]123-emma better than [I]123-emma can . Do not be impatient , [Emma]123-emma ; it will all come out too soon . ”[123-emma]

“ Break it to [me]123-emma , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , standing still with [terror.--“Good God!--Mr . Weston]340-terror.--“good god!--mr . weston , tell [me]123-emma at once.--Something has happened in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . [I]123-emma know it has . Tell [me]123-emma , [I]123-emma charge [you]86-mr. weston tell [me]123-emma this moment what it is . ”[123-emma]

“ No , indeed [you]86-mr. weston are mistaken . ”--[123-emma]

“ [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston do not trifle with me.--Consider how many of [[my]123-emma dearest friends]5216-my dearest friends are now in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square . Which of [them]5216-my dearest friends is it?--I charge [you]123-emma by all that is sacred , not to attempt concealment . ”[123-emma]

“ Upon [my]123-emma word , [Emma]123-emma . ”--[123-emma]

“ [Your]123-emma word!--why not [your]123-emma honour!--why not say upon [your]123-emma honour , that it has nothing to do with any of [them]5216-my dearest friends ? [Good Heavens!--What]341-good heavens!--what can be to be _ broke _ to [me]123-emma , that does not relate to [one of [that family]5218-that family]5217-one of that family ? ”[123-emma]

“ Upon [my]2388-i honour , ”[2388-i] said [he]2388-i very seriously , “ it does not . It is not in the smallest degree connected with [any human being of the name of [Knightley]92-mr. knightley]5219-any human being of the name of knightley . ”[2388-i]

[Emma]123-emma 's courage returned , and [she]123-emma walked on .

“ [I]2388-i was wrong , ”[2388-i] [he]2388-i continued , “ in talking of its being _ broke _ to [you]123-emma . [I]2388-i should not have used the expression . In fact , it does not concern [you]123-emma -- it concerns only [myself,--that]5220-myself,--that is , [we]5221-we hope.--Humph!--In short , [[my]2388-i dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , there is no occasion to be so uneasy about it . [I]2388-i do n't say that it is not a disagreeable business -- but things might be much worse.--If [we]5221-we walk fast , [we]5221-we shall soon be at [Randalls]101-randalls . ”[2388-i]

[Emma]123-emma found that [she]123-emma must wait ; and now it required little effort . [She]123-emma asked no more questions therefore , merely employed [her]123-emma own fancy , and that soon pointed out to [her]123-emma the probability of its being some money concern -- something just come to light , of a disagreeable nature in the circumstances of the family,--something which the late event at [Richmond]61-richmond had brought forward . [Her]123-emma fancy was very active . [Half a dozen natural children]2389-half a dozen natural children , perhaps -- and poor [Frank]102-frank churchill cut off!--This , though very undesirable , would be no matter of agony to [her]123-emma . It inspired little more than an animating curiosity .

“ Who is [that gentleman on horseback]5223-that gentleman on horseback ? ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma , as [they]2390-they proceeded -- speaking more to assist [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston in keeping [his]86-mr. weston secret , than with any other view .

“ [I]123-emma do not know.--One of [the Otways.--Not Frank;--it]342-the otways.--not frank;--it is not [Frank]102-frank churchill , [I]123-emma assure [you]86-mr. weston . [You]86-mr. weston will not see [him]102-frank churchill . [He]102-frank churchill is half way to [Windsor]75-windsor by this time . ”[123-emma]

“ Has [[your]86-mr. weston son]3557-your son been with [you]86-mr. weston , then ? ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! yes -- did not [you]123-emma know?--Well , well , never mind . ”[123-emma]

For a moment [he]86-mr. weston was silent ; and then added , in a tone much more guarded and demure ,

“ Yes , [Frank]102-frank churchill came over this morning , just to ask [us]2390-they how [we]2390-they did . ”[86-mr. weston]

[They]2390-they hurried on , and were speedily at [Randalls.--“Well]343-randalls.--“well , [[my]86-mr. weston dear]2714-my dear , ”[86-mr. weston] said [he]86-mr. weston , as [they]2390-they entered the room--“I have brought [her]3557-your son , and now [I]86-mr. weston hope [you]2714-my dear will soon be better . [I]86-mr. weston shall leave [you]2714-my dear together . There is no use in delay . [I]86-mr. weston shall not be far off , if [you]2714-my dear want [me]86-mr. weston . ”--And[86-mr. weston] [Emma]123-emma distinctly heard [him]86-mr. weston add , in a lower tone , before [he]86-mr. weston quitted the room,--“I have been as good as [my]86-mr. weston word . [She]3557-your son has not the least idea . ”[86-mr. weston]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was looking so ill , and had an air of so much perturbation , that [Emma]123-emma 's uneasiness increased ; and the moment [they]2390-they were alone , [she]88-mrs. weston eagerly said ,

“ What is it [[my]88-mrs. weston dear friend]5226-my dear friend ? Something of a very unpleasant nature , [I]88-mrs. weston find , has occurred;--do let [me]88-mrs. weston know directly what it is . [I]88-mrs. weston have been walking all this way in complete suspense . [We]2390-they both abhor suspense . Do not let [mine]88-mrs. weston continue longer . It will do [you]2714-my dear good to speak of [your]2714-my dear distress , whatever it may be . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Have [you]123-emma indeed no idea ? ”[88-mrs. weston] said [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston in a trembling voice . “ Can not [you]123-emma , [[my]88-mrs. weston dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma -- cannot [you]123-emma form a guess as to what [you]123-emma are to hear ? ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ So far as that it relates to [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , [I]88-mrs. weston do guess . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [You]123-emma are right . It does relate to [him]102-frank churchill , and [I]88-mrs. weston will tell [you]2714-my dear directly ; ”[88-mrs. weston] ( resuming [her]88-mrs. weston work , and seeming resolved against looking up . ) “ [He]102-frank churchill has been [here]2707-here this very morning , on a most extraordinary errand . It is impossible to express [our]5229-our surprize . [He]102-frank churchill came to speak to [[his]102-frank churchill father]518-his father on a subject,--to announce an attachment-- ”[88-mrs. weston]

[She]88-mrs. weston stopped to breathe . [Emma]123-emma thought first of [herself]123-emma , and then of [Harriet]111-harriet .

“ More than an attachment , indeed , ”[88-mrs. weston] resumed [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ; “ an engagement -- a positive engagement.--What will [you]123-emma say , [Emma]123-emma -- what will [any body]665-any body say , when it is known that [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill and [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax are engaged;--nay , that [they]5232-they have been long engaged ! ”[88-mrs. weston]

[Emma]123-emma even jumped with surprize;--and , horror - struck , exclaimed ,

“ [Jane Fairfax!--Good God]344-jane fairfax!--good god ! [You]123-emma are not serious ? [You]123-emma do not mean it ? ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [You]123-emma may well be amazed , ”[88-mrs. weston] returned [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , still averting [her]88-mrs. weston eyes , and talking on with eagerness , that [Emma]123-emma might have time to recover-- “ [You]123-emma may well be amazed . But it is even so . There has been a solemn engagement between [them]5232-they ever since [October]345-october -- formed at [Weymouth]23-weymouth , and kept a secret from every body . Not a creature knowing it but [themselves]5232-they -- neither [the Campbells]190-the campbells , nor [[her]152-miss fairfax family]2871-her family , nor his.--It is so wonderful , that though perfectly convinced of the fact , it is yet almost incredible to [myself]88-mrs. weston . [I]88-mrs. weston can hardly believe [it.--I]123-emma thought [I]88-mrs. weston knew [him]2391-him . ”[88-mrs. weston]

[Emma]123-emma scarcely heard what was [said.--Her]123-emma mind was divided between two ideas -- [her]123-emma own former conversations with [him]2391-him about [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax ; and [poor Harriet;--and]346-poor harriet;--and for some time [she]123-emma could only exclaim , and require confirmation , repeated confirmation .

“ Well , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma at last , trying to recover [herself]123-emma ; “ this is a circumstance which [I]123-emma must think of at least half a day , before [I]123-emma can at all comprehend it . What!--engaged to [her]152-miss fairfax all the winter -- before either of [them]5234-them came to [Highbury]3-highbury ? ”[123-emma]

“ Engaged since October,--secretly engaged.--It has hurt [me]123-emma , [Emma]123-emma , very much . [It]5235-it has hurt [[his]2391-him father]518-his father equally . _ Some _ _ part _ of [his]2391-him conduct [we]5237-we can not excuse . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma pondered a moment , and then replied , “ [I]123-emma will not pretend _ not _ to understand [you]88-mrs. weston ; and to give [you]88-mrs. weston all the relief in [my]123-emma power , be assured that no such effect has followed [his]2391-him attentions to [me]123-emma , as [you]88-mrs. weston are apprehensive of . ”[123-emma]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston looked up , afraid to believe ; but [Emma]123-emma 's countenance was as steady as [her]123-emma words .

“ That [you]88-mrs. weston may have less difficulty in believing this boast , of [my]123-emma present perfect indifference , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma continued , “ [I]123-emma will farther tell [you]88-mrs. weston , that there was a period in the early part of [our]5237-we acquaintance , when [I]123-emma did like [him]2391-him , when [I]123-emma was very much disposed to be attached to [him]2391-him -- nay , was attached -- and how it came to cease , is perhaps the wonder . Fortunately , however , it did cease . [I]123-emma have really for some time past , for at least these three months , cared nothing about [him]2391-him . [You]88-mrs. weston may believe [me]123-emma , [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . This is the simple truth . ”[123-emma]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston kissed [her]123-emma with tears of joy ; and when [she]88-mrs. weston could find utterance , assured [her]123-emma , that this protestation had done [her]123-emma more good than any thing else in [the world]403-the world could do .

“ [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston will be almost as much relieved as [myself]123-emma , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma . “ On this point [we]5237-we have been wretched . It was [our]5237-we darling wish that [you]88-mrs. weston might be attached to [each other]430-each other -- and [we]5237-we were persuaded that it was so.-- Imagine what [we]5237-we have been feeling on [your]88-mrs. weston account . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]88-mrs. weston have escaped ; and that [I]88-mrs. weston should escape , may be a matter of grateful wonder to [you]88-mrs. weston and [myself]88-mrs. weston . But this does not acquit _ [him]86-mr. weston _ , [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ; and [I]88-mrs. weston must say , that [I]88-mrs. weston think [him]86-mr. weston greatly to blame . What right had [he]86-mr. weston to come among [us]5237-we with affection and faith engaged , and with manners so _ very _ disengaged ? What right had [he]86-mr. weston to endeavour to please , as [he]86-mr. weston certainly did -- to distinguish [any one young woman with persevering attention]5239-any one young woman with persevering attention , as [he]86-mr. weston certainly did -- while [he]86-mr. weston really belonged to [another?--How]5240-another?--how could [he]86-mr. weston tell what mischief [he]86-mr. weston might be doing?--How could [he]86-mr. weston tell that [he]86-mr. weston might not be making [me]88-mrs. weston in love with [him?--very]5241-him?--very wrong , very wrong indeed . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ From something that [he]86-mr. weston said , [[my]123-emma dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , [I]123-emma rather imagine-- ”[123-emma]

“ And how could _ [she]123-emma _ bear such behaviour ! Composure with [a witness]5243-a witness ! to look on , while repeated attentions were offering to [another woman]3977-another woman , before [her]123-emma face , and not resent it.--That is a degree of placidity , which [I]88-mrs. weston can neither comprehend nor respect . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ There were misunderstandings between [them]5245-them , [Emma]123-emma ; [he]86-mr. weston said so expressly . [He]86-mr. weston had not time to enter into much explanation . [He]86-mr. weston was [here]2707-here only a quarter of an hour , and in a state of agitation which did not allow the full use even of the time [he]86-mr. weston could stay -- but that there had been misunderstandings [he]86-mr. weston decidedly said . The present crisis , indeed , seemed to be brought on by [them]5245-them ; and those misunderstandings might very possibly arise from the impropriety of [his]86-mr. weston conduct . ”[123-emma]

“ Impropriety ! Oh ! [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston -- it is too calm a censure . Much , much beyond impropriety!--It has sunk [him]86-mr. weston , [I]88-mrs. weston can not say how it has sunk [him]86-mr. weston in [my]88-mrs. weston opinion . So unlike what [a man]2840-a man should be!--None of that upright integrity , that strict adherence to truth and principle , that disdain of trick and littleness , which [a man]2840-a man should display in every transaction of [his]2840-a man life . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Nay , [dear Emma]123-emma , now [I]123-emma must take [his]86-mr. weston part ; for though [he]86-mr. weston has been wrong in this instance , [I]123-emma have known [him]86-mr. weston long enough to answer for [his]86-mr. weston having many , very many , good qualities ; and-- ”[123-emma]

“ [Good God]187-good god ! ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , not attending to her.--“Mrs . [Smallridge]330-mrs. smallridge , too ! [Jane]152-miss fairfax actually on the point of going as [governess]412-governess ! What could [he]86-mr. weston mean by such horrible indelicacy ? To suffer [her]152-miss fairfax to engage [herself]152-miss fairfax -- to suffer [her]152-miss fairfax even to think of such a measure ! ”[123-emma]

“ [He]86-mr. weston knew nothing about it , [Emma]123-emma . On this article [I]123-emma can fully acquit [him]86-mr. weston . It was a private resolution of [hers]152-miss fairfax , not communicated to [him]86-mr. weston -- or at least not communicated in a way to carry conviction.--Till yesterday , [I]123-emma know [he]86-mr. weston said [he]86-mr. weston was in the dark as to [her]152-miss fairfax plans . [They]5250-they burst on [him]86-mr. weston , [I]123-emma do not know how , but by some letter or message -- and it was the discovery of what [she]152-miss fairfax was doing , of this very project of [hers]152-miss fairfax , which determined [him]86-mr. weston to come forward at once , own it all to [[his]86-mr. weston uncle]517-his uncle , throw [himself]86-mr. weston on [his]86-mr. weston kindness , and , in short , put an end to the miserable state of concealment that had been carrying on so long . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma began to listen better .

“ [I]88-mrs. weston am to hear from [him]86-mr. weston soon , ”[88-mrs. weston] continued [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . “ [He]86-mr. weston told [me]88-mrs. weston at parting , that [he]86-mr. weston should soon write ; and [he]86-mr. weston spoke in a manner which seemed to promise [me]88-mrs. weston many particulars that could not be given now . Let [us]5252-us wait , therefore , for this letter . It may bring many extenuations . It may make many things intelligible and excusable which now are not to be understood . Do n't let [us]5252-us be severe , do n't let [us]5252-us be in a hurry to condemn [him]86-mr. weston . Let [us]5252-us have patience . [I]88-mrs. weston must love [him]86-mr. weston ; and now that [I]88-mrs. weston am satisfied on one point , the one material point , [I]88-mrs. weston am sincerely anxious for its all turning out well , and ready to hope that it may . [They]5253-they must both have suffered a great deal under such a system of secresy and concealment . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ _ [His]86-mr. weston _ sufferings , ”[123-emma] replied [Emma]123-emma dryly , “ do not appear to have done [him]86-mr. weston much harm . Well , and how did [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill take it ? ”[123-emma]

“ Most favourably for [[his]86-mr. weston nephew]1750-his nephew -- gave [his]86-mr. weston consent with scarcely a difficulty . Conceive what the events of a week have done in [that family]5218-that family ! While [poor Mrs. Churchill]98-mrs. churchill lived , [I]88-mrs. weston suppose there could not have been a hope , a chance , a possibility;--but scarcely are [her]98-mrs. churchill remains at rest in [the family vault]5256-the family vault , than [[her]98-mrs. churchill husband]441-her husband is persuaded to act exactly opposite to what [she]98-mrs. churchill would have required . What a blessing it is , when undue influence does not survive the grave!--He gave [his]86-mr. weston consent with very little persuasion . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Ah ! ”[123-emma] thought [Emma]123-emma , “ [he]86-mr. weston would have done as much for [Harriet]111-harriet . ”[123-emma]

“ This was settled last night , and [Frank]102-frank churchill was off with the light this morning . [He]102-frank churchill stopped at [Highbury]3-highbury , at [[the Bates]105-miss bates 's]5258-the bates 's , [I]88-mrs. weston fancy , some time -- and then came on hither ; but was in such a hurry to get back to [[his]102-frank churchill uncle]517-his uncle , to whom [he]102-frank churchill is just now more necessary than ever , that , as [I]88-mrs. weston tell [you]5260-you , [he]102-frank churchill could stay with [us]5261-us but a quarter of an hour.--He was very much agitated -- very much , indeed -- to a degree that made [him]102-frank churchill appear quite a different creature from any thing [I]88-mrs. weston had ever seen [him]102-frank churchill before.--In addition to all the rest , there had been the shock of finding [her]111-harriet so very unwell , which [he]102-frank churchill had had no previous suspicion of -- and there was every appearance of [his]102-frank churchill having been feeling a great deal . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ And do [you]123-emma really believe the affair to have been carrying on with such perfect [secresy?--The Campbells]190-the campbells , [the Dixons]195-the dixons , did none of [them]190-the campbells know of the engagement ? ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma could not speak the name of [Dixon]191-mrs. dixon without a little blush .

“ [None]5262-none ; [not one]5263-not one . [He]102-frank churchill positively said that it had been known to no being in [the world]403-the world but [[their]190-the campbells two selves]2140-their two selves . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ Well , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ [I]123-emma suppose [we]5266-us shall gradually grow reconciled to the idea , and [I]123-emma wish [them]190-the campbells very happy . But [I]123-emma shall always think it a very abominable sort of proceeding . What has it been but a system of hypocrisy and deceit,--espionage , and treachery?--To come among [us]5266-us with professions of openness and simplicity ; and such a league in secret to judge [us]5266-us all!--Here have [we]5266-us been , the whole winter and spring , completely duped , fancying [ourselves]5266-us all on an equal footing of truth and honour , with [two people in the midst of [us]5266-us]5267-two people in the midst of us [who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both to hear.--They]5268-who may have been carrying round , comparing and sitting in judgment on sentiments and words that were never meant for both to hear.--they must take the consequence , if [they]5267-two people in the midst of us have heard [each other]430-each other spoken of in a way not perfectly agreeable ! ”[123-emma]

“ [I]88-mrs. weston am quite easy on that head , ”[88-mrs. weston] replied [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . “ [I]88-mrs. weston am very sure that [I]88-mrs. weston never said any thing of either to the other , which [both]887-both might not have heard . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [You]88-mrs. weston are in luck.--Your only blunder was confined to [my]123-emma ear , when [you]88-mrs. weston imagined [a certain friend of ours]5271-a certain friend of ours in love with [the lady]3048-the lady . ”[123-emma]

“ True . But as [I]88-mrs. weston have always had a thoroughly good opinion of [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , [I]88-mrs. weston never could , under any blunder , have spoken ill of [her]152-miss fairfax ; and as to speaking ill of [him]86-mr. weston , there [I]88-mrs. weston must have been safe . ”[88-mrs. weston]

At this moment [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston appeared at a little distance from the window , evidently on the watch . [[His]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife gave [him]86-mr. weston a look which invited [him]86-mr. weston in ; and , while [he]86-mr. weston was coming round , added , “ Now , dearest [Emma]123-emma , let [me]2763-his wife intreat [you]123-emma to say and look every thing that may set [his]86-mr. weston heart at ease , and incline [him]86-mr. weston to be satisfied with the match . Let [us]5273-us make the best of it -- and , indeed , almost every thing may be fairly said in [her]2763-his wife favour . It is not a connexion to gratify ; but if [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill does not feel that , why should [we]5273-us ? and it may be a very fortunate circumstance for [him]86-mr. weston , for [Frank]102-frank churchill , [I]2763-his wife mean , that [he]86-mr. weston should have attached [himself]86-mr. weston to [a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment]5274-a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment as [I]2763-his wife have always given [her]5274-a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment credit for -- and still am disposed to give [her]5274-a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment credit for , in spite of this one great deviation from the strict rule of right . And how much may be said in [her]5274-a girl of such steadiness of character and good judgment situation for even that error ! ”[2763-his wife]

“ Much , indeed ! ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma feelingly . “ If [a woman]2864-a woman can ever be excused for thinking only of [herself]2864-a woman , it is in a situation like [Jane Fairfax's.--Of]347-jane fairfax's.--of such , one may almost say , that ' [the world]403-the world is not [their]403-the world 's , nor [the world]403-the world 's law . ' ”[123-emma]

[She]123-emma met [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston on [his]86-mr. weston entrance , with a smiling countenance , exclaiming ,

“ A very pretty trick [you]86-mr. weston have been playing [me]86-mr. weston , upon [my]86-mr. weston word ! This was a device , [I]86-mr. weston suppose , to sport with [my]86-mr. weston curiosity , and exercise [my]86-mr. weston talent of guessing . But [you]86-mr. weston really frightened [me]86-mr. weston . [I]86-mr. weston thought [you]86-mr. weston had lost half [[your]86-mr. weston property]5278-your property , at least . And here , instead of its being a matter of condolence , it turns out to be one of congratulation.--I congratulate [you]86-mr. weston , [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , with all [my]86-mr. weston heart , on the prospect of having [one of [the most lovely and accomplished young women in [England]36-england]5280-the most lovely and accomplished young women in england for [[your]86-mr. weston daughter]5281-your daughter]5279-one of the most lovely and accomplished young women in england for your daughter . ”[86-mr. weston]

A glance or two between [him]2394-his and [[his]2394-his wife]2763-his wife , convinced [him]2394-his that all was as right as this speech proclaimed ; and its happy effect on [his]2394-his spirits was immediate . [His]2394-his air and voice recovered [their]2396-their usual briskness : [he]2394-his shook [her]2763-his wife heartily and gratefully by the hand , and entered on the subject in a manner to prove , that [he]2394-his now only wanted time and persuasion to think the engagement no very bad thing . [[His]2394-his companions]1147-his companions suggested only what could palliate imprudence , or smooth objections ; and by the time [they]2396-their had talked it all over together , and [he]2394-his had talked it all over again with [Emma]123-emma , in [their]2396-their walk back to [Hartfield]2-hartfield , [he]2394-his was become perfectly reconciled , and not far from thinking it the very best thing that [Frank]102-frank churchill could possibly have done .

CHAPTER XI

“ [Harriet]111-harriet , [poor Harriet!”--Those]348-poor harriet!”--those[2394-his] were the words ; in them lay the tormenting ideas which [Emma]123-emma could not get rid of , and which constituted the real misery of the business to [her]123-emma . [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had behaved very ill by [herself]2763-his wife -- very ill in many ways,--but it was not so much _ [his]102-frank churchill _ behaviour as [her]2763-his wife _ own _ , which made [her]2763-his wife so angry with [him]102-frank churchill . It was the scrape which [he]102-frank churchill had drawn [her]2763-his wife into on [Harriet]111-harriet 's account , that gave the deepest hue to [his]102-frank churchill offence.--Poor [Harriet]111-harriet ! to be a second time the dupe of [her]2763-his wife misconceptions and flattery . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley had spoken prophetically , when [he]92-mr. knightley once said , “ [Emma]123-emma , [you]123-emma have been [no friend]5282-no friend to [Harriet Smith]111-harriet . ”--She[92-mr. knightley] was afraid [she]2763-his wife had done [her]2763-his wife nothing but disservice.--It was true that [she]2763-his wife had not to charge [herself]2763-his wife , in this instance as in the former , with being [the sole and original author of the mischief]2398-the sole and original author of the mischief ; with having suggested such feelings as might otherwise never have entered [Harriet]111-harriet 's imagination ; for [Harriet]111-harriet had acknowledged [her]111-harriet admiration and preference of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill before [she]111-harriet had ever given [her]111-harriet a hint on the subject ; but [she]111-harriet felt completely guilty of having encouraged what [she]111-harriet might have repressed . [She]111-harriet might have prevented the indulgence and increase of such sentiments . [Her]111-harriet influence would have been enough . And now [she]111-harriet was very conscious that [she]111-harriet ought to have prevented them.--She felt that [she]111-harriet had been risking [[her]111-harriet friend]427-her friend 's happiness on most insufficient grounds . Common sense would have directed [her]111-harriet to tell [Harriet]111-harriet , that [she]111-harriet must not allow [herself]111-harriet to think of [him]102-frank churchill , and that there were five hundred chances to one against [his]102-frank churchill ever caring for her.--“But , with common sense , ”[111-harriet] [she]111-harriet added , “ [I]111-harriet am afraid [I]111-harriet have had little to do . ”[111-harriet]

[She]111-harriet was extremely angry with [herself]111-harriet . If [she]111-harriet could not have been angry with [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill too , it would have been dreadful.--As for [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , [she]111-harriet might at least relieve [her]111-harriet feelings from any present solicitude on [her]111-harriet account . [Harriet]111-harriet would be anxiety enough ; [she]111-harriet need no longer be unhappy about [Jane]152-miss fairfax , whose troubles and whose ill - health having , of course , the same origin , must be equally under cure.--Her days of insignificance and evil were over.--She would soon be well , and happy , and prosperous.--Emma could now imagine why [her]111-harriet own attentions had been slighted . This discovery laid many smaller matters open . No doubt it had been from [jealousy.--In Jane]152-miss fairfax 's eyes [she]152-miss fairfax had been [a rival]2400-a rival ; and well might any thing [she]152-miss fairfax could offer of assistance or regard be repulsed . An airing in [the Hartfield carriage]2401-the hartfield carriage would have been the rack , and arrowroot from [the Hartfield storeroom]2402-the hartfield storeroom must have been poison . [She]111-harriet understood it all ; and as far as [her]111-harriet mind could disengage itself from the injustice and selfishness of angry feelings , [she]111-harriet acknowledged that [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax would have neither elevation nor happiness beyond [[her]111-harriet desert]2403-her desert . But poor [Harriet]111-harriet was such an engrossing charge ! There was little sympathy to be spared for any body else . [Emma]123-emma was sadly fearful that this second disappointment would be more severe than the first . Considering the very superior claims of the object , it ought ; and judging by its apparently stronger effect on [Harriet]111-harriet 's mind , producing reserve and self - command , it would.--She must communicate the painful truth , however , and as soon as possible . An injunction of secresy had been among [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's parting words . “ For the present , the whole affair was to be completely a secret . [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill had made a point of it , as a token of respect to [the wife [he]102-frank churchill had so very recently lost]5283-the wife he had so very recently lost ; and [every body]2749-every body admitted it to be no more than due decorum . ”--Emma[86-mr. weston] had promised ; but still [Harriet]111-harriet must be excepted . It was [her]111-harriet superior duty .

In spite of [her]111-harriet vexation , [she]111-harriet could not help feeling it almost ridiculous , that [she]111-harriet should have the very same distressing and delicate office to perform by [Harriet]111-harriet , which [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston had just gone through by [herself]88-mrs. weston . The intelligence , which had been so anxiously announced to [her]111-harriet , [she]111-harriet was now to be anxiously announcing to another . [Her]111-harriet heart beat quick on hearing [Harriet]111-harriet 's footstep and voice ; so , [she]111-harriet supposed , had poor [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston felt when _ [she]88-mrs. weston _ was approaching [Randalls]101-randalls . Could the event of the disclosure bear an equal resemblance!--But of that , unfortunately , there could be no chance .

“ Well , [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse ! ”[111-harriet] cried [Harriet]111-harriet , coming eagerly into the room--“is not this the oddest news that ever was ? ”[111-harriet]

“ What news do [you]111-harriet mean ? ”[123-emma] replied [Emma]123-emma , unable to guess , by look or voice , whether [Harriet]111-harriet could indeed have received any hint .

“ About [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . Did [you]123-emma ever hear any thing so strange ? [Oh!--you]123-emma need not be afraid of owning it to [me]111-harriet , for [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston has told [me]111-harriet [himself]86-mr. weston . [I]111-harriet met [him]86-mr. weston just now . [He]86-mr. weston told [me]111-harriet it was to be a great secret ; and , therefore , [I]111-harriet should not think of mentioning it to any body but [you]123-emma , but [he]86-mr. weston said [you]123-emma knew it . ”[111-harriet]

“ What did [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston tell you?”--said[123-emma] [Emma]123-emma , still perplexed .

“ Oh ! [he]86-mr. weston told [me]111-harriet all about it ; that [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill are to be married , and that [they]5285-they have been privately engaged to [one another]2744-one another this long while . How very odd ! ”[111-harriet]

It was , indeed , so odd ; [Harriet]111-harriet 's behaviour was so extremely odd , that [Emma]123-emma did not know how to understand it . [Her]111-harriet character appeared absolutely changed . [She]111-harriet seemed to propose [shewing]2404-shewing no agitation , or disappointment , or peculiar concern in the discovery . [Emma]123-emma looked at [her]111-harriet , quite unable to speak .

“ Had [you]123-emma any idea , ”[111-harriet] cried [Harriet]111-harriet , “ of [his]102-frank churchill being in love with her?--You , perhaps , might.--You ( blushing as [she]111-harriet spoke ) who can see into every body 's heart ; but [nobody else--]5287-nobody else-- ”[111-harriet]

“ Upon [my]123-emma word , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ [I]123-emma begin to doubt [my]123-emma having any such talent . Can [you]111-harriet seriously ask [me]123-emma , [Harriet]111-harriet , whether [I]123-emma imagined [him]102-frank churchill attached to [another woman]3977-another woman at the very time that [I]123-emma was -- tacitly , if not openly -- encouraging [you]111-harriet to give way to [your]111-harriet own feelings?--I never had the slightest suspicion , till within the last hour , of [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's having the least regard for [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . [You]111-harriet may be very sure that if [I]123-emma had , [I]123-emma should have cautioned [you]111-harriet accordingly . ”[123-emma]

“ [Me]111-harriet ! ”[111-harriet] cried [Harriet]111-harriet , colouring , and astonished . “ Why should [you]123-emma caution me?--You do not think [I]111-harriet care about [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill . ”[111-harriet]

“ [I]123-emma am delighted to hear [you]123-emma speak so stoutly on the subject , ”[123-emma] replied [Emma]123-emma , smiling ; “ but [you]123-emma do not mean to deny that there was a time -- and not very distant either -- when [you]123-emma gave [me]123-emma reason to understand that [you]123-emma did care about [him]102-frank churchill ? ”[123-emma]

“ [Him!--never]349-him!--never , never . [Dear Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , how could [you]123-emma so mistake [me]111-harriet ? ”[111-harriet] turning away distressed .

“ [Harriet]111-harriet ! ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , after a moment 's pause--“What do [you]111-harriet mean?--Good [Heaven]173-good heaven ! what do [you]111-harriet mean?--Mistake you!--Am [I]123-emma to suppose then?-- ”[123-emma]

[She]123-emma could not speak another word.--Her voice was lost ; and [she]123-emma sat down , waiting in great terror till [Harriet]111-harriet should answer .

[Harriet]111-harriet , who was standing at some distance , and with face turned from [her]111-harriet , did not immediately say any thing ; and when [she]111-harriet did speak , it was in a voice nearly as agitated as [Emma]123-emma 's .

“ [I]111-harriet should not have thought it possible , ”[111-harriet] [she]111-harriet began , “ that [you]123-emma could have misunderstood [me]111-harriet ! [I]111-harriet know [we]5289-we agreed never to name [him]5290-him -- but considering how infinitely superior [he]5290-him is to every body else , [I]111-harriet should not have thought it possible that [I]111-harriet could be supposed to mean [any other person]4032-any other person . [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , indeed ! [I]111-harriet do not know who would ever look at [him]5290-him in the company of the other . [I]111-harriet hope [I]111-harriet have a better taste than to think of [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , who is like [nobody]2718-nobody by [his]5290-him side . And that [you]123-emma should have been so mistaken , is amazing!--I am sure , but for believing that [you]123-emma entirely approved and meant to encourage [me]111-harriet in [my]111-harriet attachment , [I]111-harriet should have considered it at first too great a presumption almost , to dare to think of [him]5290-him . At first , if [you]123-emma had not told [me]111-harriet that more wonderful things had happened ; that there had been matches of greater disparity ( those were [your]123-emma very words);--I should not have dared to give way to -- [I]111-harriet should not have thought it possible -- But if _ [you]123-emma _ , who had been always acquainted with [him--]5290-him ”[111-harriet]

“ [Harriet]111-harriet ! ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , collecting [herself]123-emma resolutely--“Let [us]5293-us understand [each other]430-each other now , without the possibility of farther mistake . Are [you]123-emma speaking of -- [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ? ”[111-harriet]

“ To be sure [I]111-harriet am . [I]111-harriet never could have an idea of any body else -- and so [I]111-harriet thought [you]123-emma knew . When [we]5293-us talked about [him]5290-him , it was as clear as possible . ”[111-harriet]

“ Not quite , ”[123-emma] returned [Emma]123-emma , with forced calmness , “ for all that [you]123-emma then said , appeared to [me]123-emma to relate to [a different person]5295-a different person . [I]123-emma could almost assert that [you]123-emma had _ named _ [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill . [I]123-emma am sure the service [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had rendered [you]123-emma , in protecting [you]123-emma from the gipsies , was spoken of . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , how [you]123-emma do forget ! ”[111-harriet]

“ [[My]123-emma dear]2714-my dear [Harriet]111-harriet , [I]123-emma perfectly remember the substance of what [I]123-emma said on the occasion . [I]123-emma told [you]111-harriet that [I]123-emma did not wonder at [your]111-harriet attachment ; that considering the service [he]102-frank churchill had rendered [you]111-harriet , it was extremely natural:--and [you]111-harriet agreed to it , expressing [yourself]111-harriet very warmly as to [your]111-harriet sense of that service , and mentioning even what [your]111-harriet sensations had been in seeing [him]102-frank churchill come forward to [your]111-harriet rescue.--The impression of it is strong on [my]123-emma memory . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh , [dear]3874-dear , ”[111-harriet] cried [Harriet]111-harriet , “ now [I]111-harriet recollect what [you]3874-dear mean ; but [I]111-harriet was thinking of something very different at the time . It was not the gipsies -- it was not [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill that [I]111-harriet meant . No ! ( with some elevation ) [I]111-harriet was thinking of a much more precious circumstance -- of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's coming and asking [me]111-harriet to dance , when [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton would not stand up with [me]111-harriet ; and when there was [no other partner in [the room]701-the room]5298-no other partner in the room . That was the kind action ; that was the noble benevolence and generosity ; that was the service which made [me]111-harriet begin to feel how superior [he]102-frank churchill was to every other being upon [earth]5300-earth . ”[111-harriet]

“ [Good God]187-good god ! ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , “ this has been a most unfortunate -- most deplorable mistake!--What is to be done ? ”[123-emma]

“ [You]3874-dear would not have encouraged [me]123-emma , then , if [you]3874-dear had understood [me]123-emma ? At least , however , [I]123-emma can not be worse off than [I]123-emma should have been , if the other had been [the person]4067-the person ; and now -- it _ is _ possible-- ”[123-emma]

[She]123-emma paused a few moments . [Emma]123-emma could not speak .

“ [I]123-emma do not wonder , [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma resumed , “ that [you]84-miss woodhouse should feel a great difference between the two , as to [me]123-emma or as to any body . [You]84-miss woodhouse must think one five hundred million times more above [me]123-emma than the other . But [I]123-emma hope , [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , that supposing -- that if -- strange as it may appear-- . But [you]84-miss woodhouse know they were [your]84-miss woodhouse own words , that _ more _ wonderful things had happened , matches of _ greater _ disparity had taken place than between [Mr. Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill and [me]123-emma ; and , therefore , it seems as if such a thing even as this , may have occurred before -- and if [I]123-emma should be so fortunate , beyond expression , as to -- if [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley should really -- if _ [he]92-mr. knightley _ does not mind the disparity , [I]123-emma hope , [dear Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , [you]84-miss woodhouse will not set [yourself]84-miss woodhouse against it , and try to put difficulties in the way . But [you]84-miss woodhouse are too good for that , [I]123-emma am sure . ”[123-emma]

[Harriet]111-harriet was standing at one of the windows . [Emma]123-emma turned round to look at [her]111-harriet in consternation , and hastily said ,

“ Have [you]111-harriet any idea of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's returning [your]111-harriet affection ? ”[123-emma]

“ Yes , ”[111-harriet] replied [Harriet]111-harriet modestly , but not [fearfully--“I]111-harriet must say that [I]111-harriet have . ”[111-harriet]

[Emma]123-emma 's eyes were instantly withdrawn ; and [she]123-emma sat silently meditating , in a fixed attitude , for a few minutes . A few minutes were sufficient for making [her]123-emma acquainted with [her]123-emma own heart . A mind like [hers]123-emma , once opening to suspicion , made rapid progress . [She]123-emma touched -- [she]123-emma admitted -- [she]123-emma acknowledged the whole truth . Why was it so much worse that [Harriet]111-harriet should be in love with [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , than with [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill ? Why was the evil so dreadfully increased by [Harriet]111-harriet 's having some hope of a return ? It darted through [her]123-emma , with the speed of an arrow , that [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley must marry [no one]3090-no one but [herself]123-emma !

[Her]123-emma own conduct , as well as [her]123-emma own heart , was before [her]123-emma in the same few minutes . [She]123-emma saw it all with a clearness which had never blessed [her]123-emma before . How improperly had [she]123-emma been acting by [Harriet]111-harriet ! How inconsiderate , how indelicate , how irrational , how unfeeling had been [her]123-emma conduct ! What blindness , what madness , had led [her]123-emma on ! It struck [her]123-emma with dreadful force , and [she]123-emma was ready to give it every bad name in [the world]403-the world . Some portion of respect for [herself]123-emma , however , in spite of all these demerits -- some concern for [her]123-emma own appearance , and a strong sense of justice by [Harriet--(there]350-harriet--(there would be no need of _ compassion _ to [the girl who believed [herself]2407-the girl who believed herself loved by mr. knightley loved by [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley]2407-the girl who believed herself loved by mr. knightley -- but justice required that [she]2407-the girl who believed herself loved by mr. knightley should not be made unhappy by any coldness now , ) gave [Emma]123-emma the resolution to sit and endure farther with calmness , with even apparent kindness.--For [her]123-emma own advantage indeed , it was fit that the utmost extent of [Harriet]111-harriet 's hopes should be enquired into ; and [Harriet]111-harriet had done nothing to forfeit the regard and interest which had been so voluntarily formed and maintained -- or to deserve to be slighted by [the person]4067-the person , whose counsels had never led [her]123-emma right.--Rousing from reflection , therefore , and subduing [her]123-emma emotion , [she]123-emma turned to [Harriet]111-harriet again , and , in a more inviting accent , renewed the conversation ; for as to the subject which had first introduced it , the wonderful story of [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , that was quite sunk and lost.--Neither of [them]2409-them thought but of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley and [themselves]2409-them .

[Harriet]111-harriet , who had been standing in no unhappy reverie , was yet very glad to be called from it , by the now encouraging manner of [such a judge]2410-such a judge , and [such a friend as [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse]2411-such a friend as miss woodhouse , and only wanted invitation , to give the history of [her]111-harriet hopes with great , though trembling delight.--Emma 's tremblings as [she]111-harriet asked , and as [she]111-harriet listened , were better concealed than [Harriet]111-harriet 's , but they were not less . [Her]111-harriet voice was not unsteady ; but [her]111-harriet mind was in all the perturbation that such a development of self , such a burst of threatening evil , such a confusion of sudden and perplexing emotions , must create.--She listened with much inward suffering , but with great outward patience , to [Harriet]111-harriet 's detail.--Methodical , or well arranged , or very well delivered , it could not be expected to be ; but it contained , when separated from all the feebleness and tautology of the narration , a substance to sink [her]111-harriet spirit -- especially with the corroborating circumstances , which [her]111-harriet own memory brought in favour of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's most improved opinion of [Harriet]111-harriet .

[Harriet]111-harriet had been conscious of a difference in [his]92-mr. knightley behaviour ever since those two decisive dances.--Emma knew that [he]92-mr. knightley had , on that occasion , found [her]111-harriet much superior to [his]92-mr. knightley expectation . From that evening , or at least from the time of [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse 's encouraging [her]111-harriet to think of [him]92-mr. knightley , [Harriet]111-harriet had begun to be sensible of [his]92-mr. knightley talking to [her]111-harriet much more than [he]92-mr. knightley had been used to do , and of [his]92-mr. knightley having indeed quite a different manner towards [her]111-harriet ; a manner of kindness and sweetness!--Latterly [she]111-harriet had been more and more aware of it . When [they]2412-they had been all walking together , [he]92-mr. knightley had so often come and walked by [her]111-harriet , and talked so very delightfully!--He seemed to want to be acquainted with [her]111-harriet . [Emma]123-emma knew it to have been very much the case . [She]123-emma had often observed the change , to almost the same extent.--Harriet repeated expressions of approbation and praise from [him]92-mr. knightley -- and [Emma]123-emma felt [them]2413-them to be in the closest agreement with what [she]123-emma had known of [his]92-mr. knightley opinion of [Harriet]111-harriet . [He]92-mr. knightley praised [her]111-harriet for being without art or affectation , for having simple , honest , generous , feelings.--She knew that [he]92-mr. knightley saw such recommendations in [Harriet]111-harriet ; [he]92-mr. knightley had dwelt on them to [her]111-harriet more than once.--Much that lived in [Harriet]111-harriet 's memory , many little particulars of the notice [she]111-harriet had received from [him]92-mr. knightley , a look , a speech , a removal from one chair to another , a compliment implied , a preference inferred , had been unnoticed , because unsuspected , by [Emma]123-emma . Circumstances that might swell to half an hour 's relation , and contained multiplied proofs to [her]111-harriet who had seen [them]2413-them , had passed undiscerned by [her]111-harriet who now heard [them]2413-them ; but the two latest occurrences to be mentioned , the two of strongest promise to [Harriet]111-harriet , were not without some degree of witness from [Emma]123-emma herself.--The first , was [his]92-mr. knightley walking with [her]123-emma apart from the others , in the lime - walk at [Donwell]24-donwell , where [they]2414-they had been walking some time before [Emma]123-emma came , and [he]92-mr. knightley had taken pains ( as [she]111-harriet was convinced ) to draw [her]123-emma from the rest to [himself]92-mr. knightley -- and at first , [he]92-mr. knightley had talked to [her]123-emma in a more particular way than [he]92-mr. knightley had ever done before , in a very particular way indeed!--(Harriet could not recall it without a blush . ) [He]92-mr. knightley seemed to be almost asking [her]123-emma , whether [her]123-emma affections were engaged.--But as soon as [she]123-emma ( [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse ) appeared likely to join [them]2414-they , [he]92-mr. knightley changed the subject , and began talking about farming:--The second , was [his]92-mr. knightley having sat talking with [her]123-emma nearly half an hour before [Emma]123-emma came back from [her]123-emma visit , the very last morning of [his]92-mr. knightley being at [Hartfield]2-hartfield -- though , when [he]92-mr. knightley first came in , [he]92-mr. knightley had said that [he]92-mr. knightley could not stay five minutes -- and [his]92-mr. knightley having told [her]123-emma , during [their]2415-their conversation , that though [he]92-mr. knightley must go to [London]1-london , it was very much against [his]92-mr. knightley inclination that [he]92-mr. knightley left [home]562-home at all , which was much more ( as [Emma]123-emma felt ) than [he]92-mr. knightley had acknowledged to _ [her]123-emma _ . The superior degree of confidence towards [Harriet]111-harriet , which this one article marked , gave [her]111-harriet severe pain .

On the subject of the first of the two circumstances , [she]111-harriet did , after a little reflection , venture the following question . “ Might [he]92-mr. knightley not?--Is not it possible , that when enquiring , as [you]111-harriet thought , into the state of [your]111-harriet affections , [he]92-mr. knightley might be alluding to [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin -- [he]92-mr. knightley might have [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin 's interest in view ? But [Harriet]111-harriet rejected the suspicion with spirit .[111-harriet]

“ [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin ! No indeed!--There was not a hint of [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin . [I]111-harriet hope [I]111-harriet know better now , than to care for [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin , or to be suspected of it . ”[111-harriet]

When [Harriet]111-harriet had closed [her]111-harriet evidence , [she]111-harriet appealed to [[her]111-harriet dear]2417-her dear [Miss Woodhouse]84-miss woodhouse , to say whether [she]111-harriet had not good ground for hope .

“ [I]111-harriet never should have presumed to think of it at first , ”[111-harriet] said [she]111-harriet , “ but for [you]111-harriet . [You]111-harriet told [me]111-harriet to observe [him]116-mr. martin carefully , and let [his]116-mr. martin behaviour be the rule of [mine]111-harriet -- and so [I]111-harriet have . But now [I]111-harriet seem to feel that [I]111-harriet may deserve [him]116-mr. martin ; and that if [he]116-mr. martin does chuse [me]111-harriet , it will not be any thing so very wonderful . ”[111-harriet]

The bitter feelings occasioned by this speech , the many bitter feelings , made the utmost exertion necessary on [Emma]123-emma 's side , to enable [her]111-harriet to say on reply ,

“ [Harriet]111-harriet , [I]111-harriet will only venture to declare , that [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley is [the last man in [the world]403-the world]5302-the last man in the world , who would intentionally give [any woman]3096-any woman the idea of [his]92-mr. knightley feeling for [her]3096-any woman more than [he]92-mr. knightley really does . ”[111-harriet]

[Harriet]111-harriet seemed ready to worship [[her]111-harriet friend]427-her friend for a sentence so satisfactory ; and [Emma]123-emma was only saved from raptures and fondness , which at that moment would have been dreadful penance , by the sound of [[her]123-emma father]425-her father 's footsteps . [He]425-her father was coming through [the hall]1379-the hall . [Harriet]111-harriet was too much agitated to encounter [him]425-her father . “ [She]111-harriet could not compose herself-- [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse would be alarmed -- [she]111-harriet had better go;”--with[111-harriet] most ready encouragement from [[her]111-harriet friend]427-her friend , therefore , [she]111-harriet passed off through another door -- and the moment [she]111-harriet was gone , this was the spontaneous burst of [Emma]123-emma 's feelings : “ Oh God ! that [I]123-emma had never seen [her]123-emma ! ”[123-emma]

The rest of the day , the following night , were hardly enough for [her]123-emma thoughts.--She was bewildered amidst the confusion of all that had rushed on [her]123-emma within the last few hours . Every moment had brought a fresh surprize ; and every surprize must be matter of humiliation to her.--How to understand it all ! How to understand the deceptions [she]111-harriet had been thus practising on [herself]111-harriet , and living under!--The blunders , the blindness of [her]111-harriet own head and heart!--she sat still , [she]111-harriet walked about , [she]111-harriet tried [[her]111-harriet own room]3195-her own room , [she]111-harriet tried the shrubbery -- in every place , every posture , [she]111-harriet perceived that [she]111-harriet had acted most weakly ; that [she]111-harriet had been imposed on by [others]2773-others in a most mortifying degree ; that [she]111-harriet had been imposing on [herself]111-harriet in a degree yet more mortifying ; that [she]111-harriet was wretched , and should probably find this day but the beginning of wretchedness .

To understand , thoroughly understand [her]111-harriet own heart , was the first endeavour . To that point went every leisure moment which [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father 's claims on [her]111-harriet allowed , and every moment of involuntary absence of mind .

How long had [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley been so dear to [her]111-harriet , as every feeling declared [him]92-mr. knightley now to be ? When had [his]92-mr. knightley influence , such influence begun?-- When had [he]92-mr. knightley succeeded to that place in [her]111-harriet affection , which [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill had once , for a short period , occupied?--She looked back ; [she]111-harriet compared [the two]3078-the two -- compared [them]3078-the two , as [they]3078-the two had always stood in [her]111-harriet estimation , from the time of [the latter]1655-the latter 's becoming known to [her]111-harriet -- and as they must at any time have been compared by [her]111-harriet , had it -- oh ! had it , by [any blessed felicity]2427-any blessed felicity , occurred to [her]111-harriet , to institute the comparison.--She saw that there never had been a time when [she]111-harriet did not consider [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley as infinitely the superior , or when [his]92-mr. knightley regard for [her]111-harriet had not been infinitely the most dear . [She]111-harriet saw , that in persuading [herself]111-harriet , in fancying , in acting to the contrary , [she]111-harriet had been entirely under a delusion , totally ignorant of [her]111-harriet own heart -- and , in short , that [she]111-harriet had never really cared for [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill at all !

This was the conclusion of the first series of reflection . This was the knowledge of [herself]111-harriet , on the first question of inquiry , which [she]111-harriet reached ; and without being long in reaching it.--She was most sorrowfully indignant ; ashamed of every sensation but the one revealed to [her]111-harriet -- [her]111-harriet affection for [Mr. Knightley.--Every]351-mr. knightley.--every other part of [her]111-harriet mind was disgusting .

With insufferable vanity had [she]111-harriet believed [herself]111-harriet in the secret of every body 's feelings ; with unpardonable arrogance proposed to arrange every body 's destiny . [She]111-harriet was proved to have been universally mistaken ; and [she]111-harriet had not quite done nothing -- for [she]111-harriet had done mischief . [She]111-harriet had brought evil on [Harriet]111-harriet , on [herself]111-harriet , and [she]111-harriet too much feared , on [Mr. Knightley.--Were]352-mr. knightley.--were this most unequal of all connexions to take place , on [her]111-harriet must rest all the reproach of having given it a beginning ; for [his]351-mr. knightley.--every attachment , [she]111-harriet must believe to be produced only by a consciousness of [Harriet's;--and]353-harriet's;--and even were this not the case , [he]351-mr. knightley.--every would never have known [Harriet]111-harriet at all but for [her]111-harriet folly .

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley and [Harriet Smith!--It]354-harriet was a union to distance every wonder of the kind.--The attachment of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill and [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax became commonplace , threadbare , stale in the comparison , exciting no surprize , presenting no disparity , affording nothing to be said or thought.--Mr . [Knightley]92-mr. knightley and [Harriet Smith!--Such]354-harriet an elevation on [her]111-harriet side ! Such a debasement on [his]351-mr. knightley.--every ! It was horrible to [Emma]123-emma to think how it must sink [him]351-mr. knightley.--every in the general opinion , to foresee the smiles , the sneers , the merriment it would prompt at [his]351-mr. knightley.--every expense ; the mortification and disdain of [[his]351-mr. knightley.--every brother]824-his brother , the thousand inconveniences to himself.--Could it be?--No ; it was impossible . And yet it was far , very far , from impossible.--Was it a new circumstance for [a man of first - rate abilities to be captivated by very inferior powers]2429-a man of first - rate abilities to be captivated by very inferior powers ? Was it new for one , perhaps too busy to seek , to be the prize of [a girl who would seek him?--Was it new for any thing in [this world]1353-this world to be unequal , inconsistent , incongruous -- or for chance and circumstance ( as second causes ) to direct the human fate]2430-a girl who would seek him?--was it new for any thing in this world to be unequal , inconsistent , incongruous -- or for chance and circumstance ( as second causes ) to direct the human fate ?

Oh ! had [she]111-harriet never brought [Harriet]354-harriet forward ! Had [she]111-harriet left [her]354-harriet where [she]354-harriet ought , and where [he]92-mr. knightley had told [her]354-harriet [she]354-harriet ought!--Had [she]354-harriet not , with a folly which no tongue could express , prevented [her]354-harriet marrying [the unexceptionable young man who would have made [her]354-harriet happy and respectable in the line of life to which [she]354-harriet ought to belong]2432-the unexceptionable young man who would have made her happy and respectable in the line of life to which she ought to belong -- all would have been safe ; none of this dreadful sequel would have been .

How [Harriet]354-harriet could ever have had the presumption to raise [her]354-harriet thoughts to [Mr. Knightley!--How]355-mr. knightley!--how [she]354-harriet could dare to fancy [herself]354-harriet the chosen of [such a man]2885-such a man till actually assured of it!--But [Harriet]354-harriet was less humble , had fewer scruples than formerly.--Her inferiority , whether of mind or situation , seemed little felt.--She had seemed more sensible of [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's being to stoop in marrying [her]354-harriet , than [she]354-harriet now seemed of [Mr. Knightley's.--Alas]356-mr. knightley's.--alas ! was not that [her]354-harriet own doing too ? Who had been at pains to give [Harriet]354-harriet notions of self - consequence but herself?--Who but [herself]354-harriet had taught [her]354-harriet , that [she]354-harriet was to elevate [herself]354-harriet if possible , and that [her]354-harriet claims were great to a high worldly establishment?--If [Harriet]354-harriet , from being humble , were grown vain , it was [her]354-harriet doing too .

CHAPTER XII

Till now that [she]354-harriet was threatened with its loss , [Emma]123-emma had never known how much of [her]354-harriet happiness depended on being _ first _ with [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , first in interest and affection.--Satisfied that it was so , and feeling it [her]354-harriet due , [she]354-harriet had enjoyed it without reflection ; and only in the dread of being supplanted , found how inexpressibly important it had been.--Long , very long , [she]354-harriet felt [she]354-harriet had been first ; for , having no female connexions of [his]92-mr. knightley own , there had been only [Isabella]87-isabella whose claims could be compared with [hers]354-harriet , and [she]354-harriet had always known exactly how far [he]92-mr. knightley loved and esteemed [Isabella]87-isabella . [She]354-harriet had [herself]354-harriet been first with [him]92-mr. knightley for many years past . [She]354-harriet had not deserved it ; [she]354-harriet had often been negligent or perverse , slighting [his]92-mr. knightley advice , or even wilfully opposing [him]92-mr. knightley , insensible of half [his]92-mr. knightley merits , and quarrelling with [him]92-mr. knightley because [he]92-mr. knightley would not acknowledge [her]354-harriet false and insolent estimate of [her]354-harriet own -- but still , from family attachment and habit , and thorough excellence of mind , [he]92-mr. knightley had loved [her]354-harriet , and watched over [her]354-harriet from [a girl]2892-a girl , with an endeavour to improve [her]354-harriet , and an anxiety for [her]354-harriet doing right , which [no other creature]2435-no other creature had at all shared . In spite of all [her]354-harriet faults , [she]354-harriet knew [she]354-harriet was dear to [him]92-mr. knightley ; might [she]354-harriet not say , very dear?--When the suggestions of hope , however , which must follow here , presented [themselves]2436-themselves , [she]354-harriet could not presume to indulge them . [Harriet Smith]111-harriet might think [herself]111-harriet not unworthy of being peculiarly , exclusively , passionately loved by [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . _ [She]111-harriet _ could not . [She]111-harriet could not flatter [herself]111-harriet with any idea of blindness in [his]92-mr. knightley attachment to _ [her]111-harriet _ . [She]111-harriet had received a very recent proof of its impartiality.--How shocked had [he]92-mr. knightley been by [her]111-harriet behaviour to [Miss Bates]105-miss bates ! How directly , how strongly had [he]92-mr. knightley expressed [himself]92-mr. knightley to [her]354-harriet on the subject!--Not too strongly for the offence -- but far , far too strongly to issue from any feeling softer than upright justice and clear - sighted goodwill.--She had no hope , nothing to deserve the name of hope , that [he]92-mr. knightley could have that sort of affection for [herself]354-harriet which was now in question ; but there was a hope ( at times a slight one , at times much stronger , ) that [Harriet]111-harriet might have deceived [herself]111-harriet , and be overrating [his]92-mr. knightley regard for _ her_.--Wish it [she]111-harriet must , for [his]92-mr. knightley sake -- be the consequence nothing to [herself]111-harriet , but [his]92-mr. knightley remaining single all [his]92-mr. knightley life . Could [she]111-harriet be secure of that , indeed , of [his]92-mr. knightley never marrying at all , [she]111-harriet believed [she]111-harriet should be perfectly satisfied.--Let [him]92-mr. knightley but continue the same [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley to [her]111-harriet and [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father , the same [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley to [all the world]4602-all the world ; let [Donwell]24-donwell and [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse lose none of [their]2439-them precious intercourse of friendship and confidence , and [her]111-harriet peace would be fully secured.--Marriage , in fact , would not do for [her]111-harriet . It would be incompatible with what [she]111-harriet owed to [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father , and with what [she]111-harriet felt for [him]92-mr. knightley . Nothing should separate [her]111-harriet from [[her]111-harriet father]425-her father . [She]111-harriet would not marry , even if [she]111-harriet were asked by [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley .

It must be [her]111-harriet ardent wish that [Harriet]111-harriet might be disappointed ; and [she]111-harriet hoped , that when able to see [them]2439-them together again , [she]111-harriet might at least be able to ascertain what the chances for it were.--She should see [them]2439-them henceforward with the closest observance ; and wretchedly as [she]111-harriet had hitherto misunderstood even those [she]111-harriet was watching , [she]111-harriet did not know how to admit that [she]111-harriet could be blinded here.--He was expected back every day . The power of observation would be soon given -- frightfully soon it appeared when [her]111-harriet thoughts were in one course .
