In the meanwhile , [she]111-harriet resolved against seeing [Harriet.--It]328-harriet.--it would do neither of [them]2439-them good , it would do the subject no good , to be talking of it [farther.--She]111-harriet was resolved not to be convinced , as long as [she]111-harriet could doubt , and yet had no authority for opposing [Harriet]111-harriet 's confidence . To talk would be only to irritate.--She wrote to [her]111-harriet , therefore , kindly , but decisively , to beg that [she]111-harriet would not , at present , come to [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; acknowledging it to be [her]111-harriet conviction , that all farther confidential discussion of _ one _ topic had better be avoided ; and hoping , that if a few days were allowed to pass before [they]2439-them met again , except in the company of [others]2773-others -- [she]111-harriet objected only to a tete - a - tete -- [they]2439-them might be able to act as if [they]2439-them had forgotten the conversation of yesterday.--Harriet submitted , and approved , and was grateful .

This point was just arranged , when [a visitor]459-a visitor arrived to tear [Emma]123-emma 's thoughts a little from the one subject which had engrossed [them]2439-them , sleeping or waking , the last twenty - four hours -- [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , who had been calling on [[her]88-mrs. weston daughter - in - law]2444-her daughter - in - law elect , and took [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse in [her]88-mrs. weston way [home]562-home , almost as much in duty to [Emma]123-emma as in pleasure to [herself]123-emma , to relate all the particulars of so interesting an interview .

[Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston had accompanied [her]111-harriet to [[Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's]2446-mrs. bates 's , and gone through [his]86-mr. weston share of this essential attention most handsomely ; but [she]111-harriet having then induced [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax to join [her]111-harriet in an airing , was now returned with much more to say , and much more to say with satisfaction , than a quarter of an hour spent in [[Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's parlour]2447-mrs. bates 's parlour , with all the encumbrance of awkward feelings , could have afforded .

A little curiosity [Emma]123-emma had ; and [she]123-emma made the most of it while [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend related . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston had set off to pay the visit in a good deal of agitation [herself]88-mrs. weston ; and in the first place had wished not to go at all at present , to be allowed merely to write to [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax instead , and to defer this ceremonious call till a little time had passed , and [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill could be reconciled to the engagement 's becoming known ; as , considering every thing , [she]111-harriet thought such a visit could not be paid without leading to reports:--but [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston had thought differently ; [he]86-mr. weston was extremely anxious to shew [his]86-mr. weston approbation to [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [[her]152-miss fairfax family]2871-her family , and did not conceive that any suspicion could be excited by it ; or if it were , that it would be of any consequence ; for “ such things , ”[86-mr. weston] [he]86-mr. weston observed , “ always got about . ”[86-mr. weston] [Emma]123-emma smiled , and felt that [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston had very good reason for saying so . [They]2450-they had gone , in short -- and very great had been the evident distress and confusion of [the lady]3048-the lady . [She]3048-the lady had hardly been able to speak a word , and every look and action had shewn how deeply [she]3048-the lady was suffering from consciousness . The quiet , heart - felt satisfaction of [the old lady]4354-the old lady , and the rapturous delight of [[her]4354-the old lady daughter]568-her daughter -- who proved even too joyous to talk as usual , had been a gratifying , yet almost an affecting , scene . [They]2450-they were both so truly respectable in [their]2450-they happiness , so disinterested in every sensation ; thought so much of [Jane]152-miss fairfax ; so much of every body , and so little of [themselves]2450-they , that every kindly feeling was at work for [them]2450-they . [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's recent illness had offered a fair plea for [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston to invite [her]3048-the lady to an airing ; [she]3048-the lady had drawn back and declined at first , but , on being pressed had yielded ; and , in the course of [their]2450-they drive , [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston had , by gentle encouragement , overcome so much of [her]3048-the lady embarrassment , as to bring [her]3048-the lady to converse on the important subject . Apologies for [her]3048-the lady seemingly ungracious silence in [their]2450-they first reception , and the warmest expressions of the gratitude [she]3048-the lady was always feeling towards [herself]3048-the lady and [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , must necessarily open the cause ; but when these effusions were put by , [they]2450-they had talked a good deal of the present and of the future state of the engagement . [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was convinced that such conversation must be the greatest relief to [[her]88-mrs. weston companion]672-her companion , pent up within [her]88-mrs. weston own mind as every thing had so long been , and was very much pleased with all that [she]88-mrs. weston had said on the subject .

“ On the misery of what [she]3048-the lady had suffered , during the concealment of so many months , ”[88-mrs. weston] continued [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , “ [she]3048-the lady was energetic . This was one of [her]3048-the lady expressions . ' [I]88-mrs. weston will not say , that since [I]88-mrs. weston entered into the engagement [I]88-mrs. weston have not had some happy moments ; but [I]88-mrs. weston can say , that [I]88-mrs. weston have never known the blessing of one tranquil hour:'--and the quivering lip , [Emma]123-emma , which uttered it , was an attestation that [I]88-mrs. weston felt at [my]88-mrs. weston heart . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [Poor girl]3620-poor girl ! ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma . “ [She]3048-the lady thinks [herself]3048-the lady wrong , then , for having consented to a private engagement ? ”[123-emma]

“ Wrong ! [No one]3090-no one , [I]88-mrs. weston believe , can blame [her]3048-the lady more than [she]3048-the lady is disposed to blame [herself]3048-the lady . ' The consequence , ' said [she]88-mrs. weston , ' has been a state of perpetual suffering to [me]88-mrs. weston ; and so it ought . But after all the punishment that misconduct can bring , it is still not less misconduct . Pain is no expiation . [I]88-mrs. weston never can be blameless . [I]88-mrs. weston have been acting contrary to all [my]88-mrs. weston sense of right ; and the fortunate turn that every thing has taken , and the kindness [I]88-mrs. weston am now receiving , is what [my]88-mrs. weston conscience tells [me]88-mrs. weston ought not to be . ' ' Do not imagine , [madam]3610-madam , ' [she]88-mrs. weston continued , ' that [I]88-mrs. weston was taught wrong . Do not let any reflection fall on the principles or the care of [the friends who brought [me]88-mrs. weston up]5308-the friends who brought me up . The error has been all [my]88-mrs. weston own ; and [I]88-mrs. weston do assure [you]3610-madam that , with all the excuse that present circumstances may appear to give , [I]88-mrs. weston shall yet dread making the story known to [Colonel Campbell]164-colonel campbell . ' ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [Poor girl]3620-poor girl ! ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma again . “ [She]3620-poor girl loves [him]164-colonel campbell then excessively , [I]123-emma suppose . It must have been from attachment only , that [she]3620-poor girl could be led to form the engagement . [Her]3620-poor girl affection must have overpowered [her]3620-poor girl judgment . ”[123-emma]

“ Yes , [I]88-mrs. weston have no doubt of [her]3620-poor girl being extremely attached to [him]164-colonel campbell . ”[88-mrs. weston]

“ [I]123-emma am afraid , ”[123-emma] returned [Emma]123-emma , sighing , “ that [I]123-emma must often have contributed to make [her]3620-poor girl unhappy . ”[123-emma]

“ On [your]3610-madam side , [[my]123-emma love]3321-my love , it was very innocently done . But [she]3620-poor girl probably had something of that in [her]3620-poor girl thoughts , when alluding to the misunderstandings which [he]164-colonel campbell had given [us]5311-us hints of before . One natural consequence of the evil [she]3620-poor girl had involved [herself]3620-poor girl in , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma said , “ was that of making [her]3620-poor girl _ unreasonable _ . The consciousness of having done amiss , had exposed [her]3620-poor girl to a thousand inquietudes , and made [her]3620-poor girl captious and irritable to a degree that must have been -- that had been -- hard for [him]164-colonel campbell to bear . ' [I]123-emma did not make the allowances , ' said [she]123-emma , ' which [I]123-emma ought to have done , for [his]164-colonel campbell temper and spirits -- [his]164-colonel campbell delightful spirits , and that gaiety , that playfulness of disposition , which , under any other circumstances , would , [I]123-emma am sure , have been as constantly bewitching to [me]123-emma , as they were at first . ' [She]3620-poor girl then began to speak of [you]3321-my love , and of the great kindness [you]3321-my love had shewn [her]3620-poor girl during [her]3620-poor girl illness ; and with a blush which shewed [me]123-emma how it was all connected , desired [me]123-emma , whenever [I]123-emma had an opportunity , to thank [you]3321-my love -- [I]123-emma could not thank [you]3321-my love too much -- for every wish and every endeavour to do [her]3620-poor girl good . [She]3620-poor girl was sensible that [you]3321-my love had never received any proper acknowledgment from [herself]3620-poor girl . ”[123-emma]

“ If [I]123-emma did not know [her]3620-poor girl to be happy now , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , seriously , “ which , in spite of every little drawback from [her]3620-poor girl scrupulous conscience , [she]3620-poor girl must be , [I]123-emma could not bear these thanks;--for , oh ! [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , if there were an account drawn up of the evil and the good [I]123-emma have done [Miss Fairfax!--Well]5312-miss fairfax!--well ( checking [herself]3620-poor girl , and trying to be more lively ) , this is all to be forgotten . [You]88-mrs. weston are very kind to bring [me]123-emma these interesting particulars . [They]5313-they shew [her]3620-poor girl to the greatest advantage . [I]123-emma am sure [she]3620-poor girl is very good -- [I]123-emma hope [she]3620-poor girl will be very happy . It is fit that the fortune should be on [his]102-frank churchill side , for [I]123-emma think the merit will be all on [hers]3620-poor girl . ”[123-emma]

Such a conclusion could not pass unanswered by [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . [She]88-mrs. weston thought well of [Frank]102-frank churchill in almost every respect ; and , what was more , [she]88-mrs. weston loved [him]102-frank churchill very much , and [her]88-mrs. weston defence was , therefore , earnest . [She]88-mrs. weston talked with a great deal of reason , and at least equal affection -- but [she]88-mrs. weston had too much to urge for [Emma]123-emma 's attention ; it was soon gone to [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square or to [Donwell]24-donwell ; [she]88-mrs. weston forgot to attempt to listen ; and when [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston ended with , “ [We]2455-we have not yet had the letter [we]2455-we are so anxious for , [you]123-emma know , but [I]88-mrs. weston hope it will soon come , ”[88-mrs. weston] [she]88-mrs. weston was obliged to pause before [she]88-mrs. weston answered , and at last obliged to answer at random , before [she]88-mrs. weston could at all recollect what letter it was which [they]2455-we were so anxious for .

“ Are [you]123-emma well , [[my]88-mrs. weston [Emma]123-emma]3544-my emma ? ”[88-mrs. weston] was [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's parting question .

“ Oh ! perfectly . [I]88-mrs. weston am always well , [you]123-emma know . Be sure to give [me]88-mrs. weston intelligence of the letter as soon as possible . ”[88-mrs. weston]

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's communications furnished [Emma]123-emma with more food for unpleasant reflection , by increasing [her]123-emma esteem and compassion , and [her]123-emma sense of past injustice towards [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax . [She]123-emma bitterly regretted not having sought a closer acquaintance with [her]88-mrs. weston , and blushed for the envious feelings which had certainly been , in some measure , the cause . Had [she]123-emma followed [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's known wishes , in paying that attention to [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , which was every way [her]123-emma due ; had [she]123-emma tried to know [her]152-miss fairfax better ; had [she]123-emma done [her]123-emma part towards intimacy ; had [she]123-emma endeavoured to find [a friend there]2456-a friend there instead of in [Harriet Smith]111-harriet ; [she]123-emma must , in all probability , have been spared from every pain which pressed on [her]123-emma now.--Birth , abilities , and education , had been equally marking one as an associate for [her]123-emma , to be received with gratitude ; and the other -- what was she?--Supposing even that [they]2457-they had never become [intimate friends]2458-intimate friends ; that [she]123-emma had never been admitted into [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's confidence on this important matter -- which was most probable -- still , in knowing [her]123-emma as [she]123-emma ought , and as [she]123-emma might , [she]123-emma must have been preserved from the abominable suspicions of an improper attachment to [Mr. Dixon]192-mr. dixon , which [she]123-emma had not only so foolishly fashioned and harboured [herself]123-emma , but had so unpardonably imparted ; an idea which [she]123-emma greatly feared had been made a subject of material distress to the delicacy of [Jane]152-miss fairfax 's feelings , by the levity or carelessness of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's . Of all the sources of evil surrounding the former , since [her]123-emma coming to [Highbury]3-highbury , [she]123-emma was persuaded that [she]123-emma must [herself]123-emma have been the worst . [She]123-emma must have been [a perpetual enemy]2459-a perpetual enemy . [They]2460-they never could have been all three together , without [her]123-emma having stabbed [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's peace in a thousand instances ; and on [Box Hill]64-box hill , perhaps , it had been the agony of a mind that would bear no more .

The evening of this day was very long , and melancholy , at [Hartfield]2-hartfield . The weather added what it could of gloom . A cold stormy rain set in , and nothing of July appeared but in the trees and shrubs , which the wind was despoiling , and the length of the day , which only made such cruel sights the longer visible .

The weather affected [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , and [he]85-mr. woodhouse could only be kept tolerably comfortable by almost ceaseless attention on [[his]85-mr. woodhouse daughter]2723-his daughter 's side , and by exertions which had never cost [her]2723-his daughter half so much before . It reminded [her]123-emma of [their]2460-they first forlorn tete - a - tete , on the evening of [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's wedding - day ; but [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley had walked in then , soon after tea , and dissipated every melancholy fancy . Alas ! such delightful proofs of [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse 's attraction , as those sort of visits conveyed , might shortly be over . The picture which [she]123-emma had then drawn of the privations of the approaching winter , had proved erroneous ; [no friends]2462-no friends had deserted [them]2460-they , no pleasures had been lost.--But [her]123-emma present forebodings [she]123-emma feared would experience no similar contradiction . The prospect before [her]123-emma now , was threatening to a degree that could not be entirely dispelled -- that might not be even partially brightened . If all took place that might take place among [the circle of [[her]123-emma friends]3093-her friends]2463-the circle of her friends , [Hartfield]2-hartfield must be comparatively deserted ; and [she]123-emma left to cheer [[her]123-emma father]425-her father with the spirits only of ruined happiness .

[The child]498-the child to be born at [Randalls]101-randalls must be a tie [there]448-there even dearer than [herself]123-emma ; and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's heart and time would be occupied by it . [They]2468-them should lose [her]123-emma ; and , probably , in great measure , [[her]123-emma husband]441-her husband also.--Frank [Churchill]102-frank churchill would return among [them]2468-them no more ; and [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , it was reasonable to suppose , would soon cease to belong to [Highbury]3-highbury . [They]2470-they would be married , and settled either at or near [Enscombe]7-enscombe . All that were good would be withdrawn ; and if to these losses , the loss of [Donwell]24-donwell were to be added , what would remain of cheerful or of rational society within [their]2470-they reach ? [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley to be no longer coming [there]448-there for [his]92-mr. knightley evening comfort!--No longer walking in at all hours , as if ever willing to change [[his]92-mr. knightley own [home]562-home]2472-his own home for their's!--How was it to be endured ? And if [he]92-mr. knightley were to be lost to [them]2468-them for [Harriet]111-harriet 's sake ; if [he]92-mr. knightley were to be thought of hereafter , as finding in [[Harriet]111-harriet 's society]2474-harriet 's society all that [he]92-mr. knightley wanted ; if [Harriet]111-harriet were to be the chosen , the first , the dearest , [the friend]3151-the friend , [the wife to whom [he]92-mr. knightley looked for all the best blessings of existence]2476-the wife to whom he looked for all the best blessings of existence ; what could be increasing [Emma]123-emma 's wretchedness but the reflection never far distant from [her]123-emma mind , that it had been all [her]123-emma own work ?

When it came to such a pitch as this , [she]123-emma was not able to refrain from a start , or a heavy sigh , or even from walking about [the room]701-the room for a few seconds -- and the only source whence any thing like consolation or composure could be drawn , was in the resolution of [her]123-emma own better conduct , and the hope that , however inferior in spirit and gaiety might be the following and every future winter of [her]123-emma life to the past , it would yet find [her]123-emma more rational , more acquainted with [herself]123-emma , and leave [her]123-emma less to regret when it were gone .

CHAPTER XIII

The weather continued much the same all the following morning ; and the same loneliness , and the same melancholy , seemed to reign at [Hartfield]2-hartfield -- but in the afternoon it cleared ; the wind changed into a softer quarter ; the clouds were carried off ; the sun appeared ; it was summer again . With all the eagerness which such a transition gives , [Emma]123-emma resolved to be out of doors as soon as possible . Never had the exquisite sight , smell , sensation of nature , tranquil , warm , and brilliant after a storm , been more attractive to [her]123-emma . [She]123-emma longed for the serenity [they]2478-they might gradually introduce ; and on [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry 's coming in soon after dinner , with a disengaged hour to give [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , [she]123-emma lost no time in hurrying into [the shrubbery.--There]2480-the shrubbery.--there , with spirits freshened , and thoughts a little relieved , [she]123-emma had taken a few turns , when [she]123-emma saw [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley passing through [the garden]5008-the garden door , and coming towards her.--It was the first intimation of [his]92-mr. knightley being returned from [London]1-london . [She]123-emma had been thinking of [him]92-mr. knightley the moment before , as unquestionably sixteen miles distant.--There was time only for the quickest arrangement of mind . [She]123-emma must be collected and calm . In half a minute [they]2478-they were together . The “ How d'ye do 's ”[123-emma] were quiet and constrained on each side . [She]123-emma asked after [[their]2478-they mutual friends]2482-their mutual friends ; [they]2482-their mutual friends were all well.--When had [he]92-mr. knightley left them?--Only that morning . [He]92-mr. knightley must have had a wet ride.--Yes.--He meant to walk with [her]123-emma , [she]123-emma found . “ [He]92-mr. knightley had just looked into [the dining - room]1589-the dining - room , and as [he]92-mr. knightley was not wanted [there]448-there , preferred being out of doors . ”--She[92-mr. knightley] thought [he]92-mr. knightley neither looked nor spoke cheerfully ; and the first possible cause for it , suggested by [her]123-emma fears , was , that [he]92-mr. knightley had perhaps been communicating [his]92-mr. knightley plans to [[his]92-mr. knightley brother]824-his brother , and was pained by the manner in which [they]2478-they had been received .

[They]2478-they walked together . [He]92-mr. knightley was silent . [She]123-emma thought [he]92-mr. knightley was often looking at [her]123-emma , and trying for a fuller view of [her]123-emma face than it suited [her]123-emma to give . And this belief produced another dread . Perhaps [he]92-mr. knightley wanted to speak to [her]123-emma , of [his]92-mr. knightley attachment to [Harriet]111-harriet ; [he]92-mr. knightley might be watching for encouragement to [begin.--She]2484-begin.--she did not , could not , feel equal to lead the way to any such subject . [He]92-mr. knightley must do it all [himself]92-mr. knightley . Yet [she]123-emma could not bear this silence . With [him]92-mr. knightley it was most unnatural . [She]123-emma considered -- resolved -- and , trying to smile , began--

“ [You]92-mr. knightley have some news to hear , now [you]92-mr. knightley are come back , that will rather surprize [you]92-mr. knightley . ”[123-emma]

“ Have [I]92-mr. knightley ? ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley quietly , and looking at [her]123-emma ; “ of what nature ? ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Oh ! the best nature in [the world]403-the world -- a wedding . ”[92-mr. knightley]

After waiting a moment , as if to be sure [she]123-emma intended to say no more , [he]92-mr. knightley replied ,

“ If [you]123-emma mean [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax and [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , [I]92-mr. knightley have heard that already . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ How is it possible ? ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma , turning [her]123-emma glowing cheeks towards [him]92-mr. knightley ; for , while [she]123-emma spoke , it occurred to [her]123-emma that [he]92-mr. knightley might have called at [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's in [his]92-mr. knightley way .

“ [I]92-mr. knightley had a few lines on parish business from [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston this morning , and at the end of [them]5318-them [he]86-mr. weston gave [me]92-mr. knightley a brief account of what had happened . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma was quite relieved , and could presently say , with a little more composure ,

“ _ [You]92-mr. knightley _ probably have been less surprized than any of [us]5319-us , for [you]92-mr. knightley have had [your]92-mr. knightley suspicions.--I have not forgotten that [you]92-mr. knightley once tried to give [me]123-emma a caution.--I wish [I]123-emma had attended to it -- but--(with a sinking voice and a heavy sigh ) [I]123-emma seem to have been doomed to blindness . ”[123-emma]

For a moment or two nothing was said , and [she]123-emma was unsuspicious of having excited any particular interest , till [she]123-emma found [her]123-emma arm drawn within [his]92-mr. knightley , and pressed against [his]92-mr. knightley heart , and heard [him]92-mr. knightley thus saying , in a tone of great sensibility , speaking low ,

“ Time , [[my]92-mr. knightley dearest]2979-my dearest [Emma]123-emma , time will heal the wound.--Your own excellent sense -- [your]123-emma exertions for [[your]123-emma father]3597-your father 's sake -- [I]92-mr. knightley know [you]123-emma will not allow [yourself--]5322-yourself-- . ”[92-mr. knightley] [Her]123-emma arm was pressed again , as [he]92-mr. knightley added , in a more broken and subdued accent , “ The feelings of the warmest friendship -- Indignation -- Abominable scoundrel!”--And[92-mr. knightley] in a louder , steadier tone , [he]92-mr. knightley concluded with , “ [He]92-mr. knightley will soon be gone . [They]5323-they will soon be in [Yorkshire]47-yorkshire . [I]92-mr. knightley am sorry for _ [her]123-emma _ . [She]123-emma deserves a better fate . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma understood [him]92-mr. knightley ; and as soon as [she]123-emma could recover from the flutter of pleasure , excited by such tender consideration , replied ,

“ [You]92-mr. knightley are very kind -- but [you]92-mr. knightley are mistaken -- and [I]123-emma must set [you]92-mr. knightley right.-- [I]123-emma am not in want of that sort of compassion . [My]123-emma blindness to what was going on , led [me]123-emma to act by [them]5323-they in a way that [I]123-emma must always be ashamed of , and [I]123-emma was very foolishly tempted to say and do many things which may well lay [me]123-emma open to unpleasant conjectures , but [I]123-emma have no other reason to regret that [I]123-emma was not in the secret earlier . ”[123-emma]

“ [Emma]123-emma ! ”[92-mr. knightley] cried [he]92-mr. knightley , looking eagerly at [her]123-emma , “ are [you]123-emma , indeed?”--but[92-mr. knightley] checking himself--“No , no , [I]123-emma understand [you]123-emma -- forgive [me]123-emma -- [I]123-emma am pleased that [you]123-emma can say even so much.--He is no object of regret , indeed ! and it will not be very long , [I]123-emma hope , before that becomes the acknowledgment of more than [your]123-emma reason.--Fortunate that [your]123-emma affections were not farther entangled!--I could never , [I]123-emma confess , from [your]123-emma manners , assure [myself]123-emma as to the degree of what [you]123-emma felt -- [I]123-emma could only be certain that there was a preference -- and a preference which [I]123-emma never believed [him]92-mr. knightley to deserve.--He is a disgrace to the name of man.--And is [he]92-mr. knightley to be rewarded with [that sweet young woman?--Jane]5324-that sweet young woman?--jane , [Jane]152-miss fairfax , [you]123-emma will be a miserable creature . ”[123-emma]

“ [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , trying to be lively , but really [confused--“I]123-emma am in a very extraordinary situation . [I]123-emma can not let [you]2485-he continue in [your]2485-he error ; and yet , perhaps , since [my]123-emma manners gave such an impression , [I]123-emma have as much reason to be ashamed of confessing that [I]123-emma never have been at all attached to [the person [we]5326-we are speaking of]5325-the person we are speaking of , as it might be natural for [a woman]2864-a woman to feel in confessing exactly the reverse.--But [I]123-emma never have . ”[123-emma]

[He]2485-he listened in perfect silence . [She]123-emma wished [him]2485-he to speak , but [he]2485-he would not . [She]123-emma supposed [she]123-emma must say more before [she]123-emma were entitled to [his]2485-he clemency ; but it was a hard case to be obliged still to lower [herself]123-emma in [his]2485-he opinion . [She]123-emma went on , however .

“ [I]123-emma have very little to say for [my]123-emma own conduct.--I was tempted by [his]2485-he attentions , and allowed [myself]123-emma to appear pleased.--An old story , probably -- a common case -- and no more than has happened to hundreds of [my]123-emma sex before ; and yet it may not be the more excusable in one who sets up as [I]123-emma do for Understanding . Many circumstances assisted the temptation . [He]2485-he was [the son of [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston]5328-the son of mr. weston -- [he]2485-he was continually [here]2707-here -- [I]123-emma always found [him]2485-he very pleasant -- and , in short , for ( with a sigh ) let [me]123-emma swell out the causes ever so ingeniously , they all centre in this at last -- [my]123-emma vanity was flattered , and [I]123-emma allowed [his]2485-he attentions . Latterly , however -- for some time , indeed -- [I]123-emma have had no idea of [their]5330-their meaning any thing.--I thought [them]5330-their a habit , a trick , nothing that called for seriousness on [my]123-emma side . [He]2485-he has imposed on [me]123-emma , but [he]2485-he has not injured [me]123-emma . [I]123-emma have never been attached to [him]2485-he . And now [I]123-emma can tolerably comprehend [his]2485-he behaviour . [He]2485-he never wished to attach [me]123-emma . It was merely a blind to conceal [his]2485-he real situation with another.--It was [his]2485-he object to blind all about [him]2485-he ; and [no one]3090-no one , [I]123-emma am sure , could be more effectually blinded than [myself]123-emma -- except that [I]123-emma was _ not _ blinded -- that it was [my]123-emma good fortune -- that , in short , [I]123-emma was somehow or other safe from [him]2485-he . ”[123-emma]

[She]2486-she had hoped for an answer here -- for a few words to say that [her]2486-she conduct was at least intelligible ; but [he]2487-i was silent ; and , as far as [she]2486-she could judge , deep in thought . At last , and tolerably in [his]2487-i usual tone , [he]2487-i said ,

“ [I]2487-i have never had a high opinion of [Frank Churchill.--I]357-frank churchill.--i can suppose , however , that [I]2487-i may have underrated [him]2485-he . [My]2487-i acquaintance with [him]2485-he has been but trifling.--And even if [I]2487-i have not underrated [him]2485-he hitherto , [he]2485-he may yet turn out well.--With such a woman [he]2485-he has a chance.--I have no motive for wishing [him]2485-he ill -- and for [her]5332-her sake , whose happiness will be involved in [his]2485-he good character and conduct , [I]2487-i shall certainly wish [him]2485-he well . ”[2487-i]

“ [I]123-emma have no doubt of [their]5333-their being happy together , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma ; “ [I]123-emma believe [them]5333-their to be very mutually and very sincerely attached . ”[123-emma]

“ [He]2485-he is [a most fortunate man]5334-a most fortunate man ! ”[92-mr. knightley] returned [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , with energy . “ So early in life -- at three - and - twenty -- a period when , if [a man]2840-a man chuses [a wife]2759-a wife , [he]2840-a man generally chuses ill . At three - and - twenty to have drawn such a prize ! What years of felicity [that man]5337-that man , in all human calculation , has before him!--Assured of the love of [such a woman]1835-such a woman -- the disinterested love , for [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's character vouches for [her]152-miss fairfax disinterestedness ; every thing in [his]5337-that man favour,--equality of situation -- [I]92-mr. knightley mean , as far as regards society , and all the habits and manners that are important ; equality in every point but one -- and that one , since the purity of [her]1835-such a woman heart is not to be doubted , such as must increase [his]5337-that man felicity , for it will be [his]5337-that man to bestow the only advantages [she]1835-such a woman wants.--A [man]774-man would always wish to give [a woman]2864-a woman a better home than [the one [he]774-man takes [her]2864-a woman from]5341-the one he takes her from ; and [he]774-man who can do it , where there is no doubt of _ [her]2864-a woman _ regard , must , [I]92-mr. knightley think , be the happiest of [mortals.--Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill is , indeed , [the favourite of fortune]5342-the favourite of fortune . Every thing turns out for [his]5337-that man good.--He meets with [a young woman at a watering - place]5343-a young woman at a watering - place , gains [her]5343-a young woman at a watering - place affection , can not even weary [her]5343-a young woman at a watering - place by negligent treatment -- and had [he]5337-that man and all [[his]5337-that man family]3014-his family sought round [the world]403-the world for [a perfect wife for [him]5337-that man]5346-a perfect wife for him , [they]3014-his family could not have found [her]5343-a young woman at a watering - place superior.--His aunt is in the way.--His aunt dies.--He has only to speak.--His [friends]579-friends are eager to promote [his]5337-that man happiness.--He had used every body ill -- and [they]579-friends are all delighted to forgive him.--He is [a fortunate man]5348-a fortunate man indeed ! ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [You]123-emma speak as if [you]123-emma envied [him]5337-that man . ”[123-emma]

“ And [I]92-mr. knightley do envy [him]5337-that man , [Emma]123-emma . In one respect [he]5337-that man is the object of [my]92-mr. knightley envy . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma could say no more . [They]2488-they seemed to be within half a sentence of [Harriet]111-harriet , and [her]123-emma immediate feeling was to avert the subject , if possible . [She]123-emma made [her]123-emma plan ; [she]123-emma would speak of something totally different -- [the children in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square]2489-the children in brunswick square ; and [she]123-emma only waited for breath to begin , when [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley startled [her]123-emma , by saying ,

“ [You]123-emma will not ask [me]92-mr. knightley what is the point of envy.--You are determined , [I]92-mr. knightley see , to have no curiosity.--You are wise -- but _ [I]92-mr. knightley _ can not be wise . [Emma]123-emma , [I]92-mr. knightley must tell [you]123-emma what [you]123-emma will not ask , though [I]92-mr. knightley may wish it unsaid the next moment . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Oh ! then , do n't speak it , do n't speak it , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma eagerly cried . “ Take a little time , consider , do not commit [yourself]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

“ Thank [you]123-emma , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley , in an accent of deep mortification , and not another syllable followed .

[Emma]123-emma could not bear to give [him]92-mr. knightley pain . [He]92-mr. knightley was wishing to confide in [her]123-emma -- perhaps to consult her;--cost [her]123-emma what it would , [she]123-emma would listen . [She]123-emma might assist [his]92-mr. knightley resolution , or reconcile [him]92-mr. knightley to it ; [she]123-emma might give just praise to [Harriet]111-harriet , or , by representing to [him]92-mr. knightley [his]92-mr. knightley own independence , relieve [him]92-mr. knightley from that state of indecision , which must be more intolerable than any alternative to such a mind as his.--They had reached [the house]435-the house .

“ [You]123-emma are going in , [I]92-mr. knightley suppose ? ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley .

“ No,”--replied[123-emma] [Emma]123-emma -- quite confirmed by the depressed manner in which [he]92-mr. knightley still spoke--“I should like to take another turn . [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry is not gone . ”[92-mr. knightley] And , after proceeding a few steps , [she]123-emma added--“I stopped [you]92-mr. knightley ungraciously , just now , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , and , [I]123-emma am afraid , gave [you]92-mr. knightley pain.--But if [you]92-mr. knightley have any wish to speak openly to [me]123-emma as [a friend]416-a friend , or to ask [my]123-emma opinion of any thing that [you]92-mr. knightley may have in contemplation -- as [a friend]416-a friend , indeed , [you]92-mr. knightley may command me.--I will hear whatever [you]92-mr. knightley like . [I]123-emma will tell [you]92-mr. knightley exactly what [I]123-emma think . ”[123-emma]

“ As a friend!”--repeated[358-mr. knightley.--“emma] [Mr. Knightley.--“Emma]358-mr. knightley.--“emma , that [I]2491-i fear is a word -- No , [I]2491-i have no wish -- Stay , yes , why should [I]2491-i hesitate?--I have gone too far already for concealment.--Emma , [I]2491-i accept [your]2491-i offer -- Extraordinary as it may seem , [I]2491-i accept it , and refer [myself]2491-i to [you]2491-i as a friend.--Tell [me]2491-i , then , have [I]2491-i no chance of ever succeeding ? ”[2491-i]

[He]2491-i stopped in [his]2491-i earnestness to look the question , and the expression of [his]2491-i eyes overpowered [her]2492-her .

“ [[My]2491-i dearest]2979-my dearest [Emma]123-emma , ”[2491-i] said [he]2491-i , “ for dearest [you]123-emma will always be , whatever the event of this hour 's conversation , [[my]2491-i dearest]2979-my dearest , most beloved [Emma]123-emma -- tell [me]2491-i at once . Say ' No , ' if it is to be said . ”--She[2491-i] could really say nothing.--“You are silent , ”[2491-i] [he]2491-i cried , with great animation ; “ absolutely silent ! at present [I]2491-i ask no more . ”[2491-i]

[Emma]123-emma was almost ready to sink under the agitation of this moment . The dread of being awakened from the happiest dream , was perhaps the most prominent feeling .

“ [I]2491-i can not make speeches , [Emma]123-emma : ”[2491-i] [he]2491-i soon resumed ; and in a tone of such sincere , decided , intelligible tenderness as was tolerably convincing.--“If [I]2491-i loved [you]123-emma less , [I]2491-i might be able to talk about it more . But [you]123-emma know what [I]2491-i am.--You hear nothing but truth from me.--I have blamed [you]123-emma , and lectured [you]123-emma , and [you]123-emma have borne it as [no other woman in [England]36-england]5353-no other woman in england would have borne it.--Bear with the truths [I]2491-i would tell [you]123-emma now , dearest [Emma]123-emma , as well as [you]123-emma have borne with [them]5354-them . The manner , perhaps , may have as little to recommend [them]5354-them . God knows , [I]2491-i have been a very indifferent lover.--But [you]123-emma understand me.--Yes , [you]123-emma see , [you]123-emma understand [my]2491-i feelings -- and will return them if [you]123-emma can . At present , [I]2491-i ask only to hear , once to hear [your]123-emma voice . ”[2491-i]

While [he]2493-he spoke , [Emma]123-emma 's mind was most busy , and , with all the wonderful velocity of thought , had been able -- and yet without losing a word -- to catch and comprehend the exact truth of the whole ; to see that [Harriet]111-harriet 's hopes had been entirely groundless , a mistake , a delusion , as complete a delusion as any of [her]123-emma own -- that [Harriet]111-harriet was nothing ; that [she]111-harriet was every thing [herself]111-harriet ; that what [she]111-harriet had been saying relative to [Harriet]111-harriet had been all taken as the language of [her]111-harriet own feelings ; and that [her]111-harriet agitation , [her]111-harriet doubts , [her]111-harriet reluctance , [her]111-harriet discouragement , had been all received as discouragement from herself.--And not only was there time for these convictions , with all [their]2494-their glow of attendant happiness ; there was time also to rejoice that [Harriet]111-harriet 's secret had not escaped [her]123-emma , and to resolve that it need not , and should not.--It was all the service [she]123-emma could now render [[her]123-emma poor friend]2495-her poor friend ; for as to any of that heroism of sentiment which might have prompted [her]123-emma to entreat [him]2495-her poor friend to transfer [his]2495-her poor friend affection from [herself]123-emma to [Harriet]111-harriet , as infinitely the most worthy of the two -- or even the more simple sublimity of resolving to refuse [him]2495-her poor friend at once and for ever , without vouchsafing any motive , because [he]2495-her poor friend could not marry [them]2496-them both , [Emma]123-emma had it not . [She]123-emma felt for [Harriet]111-harriet , with pain and with contrition ; but no flight of generosity run mad , opposing all that could be probable or reasonable , entered [her]123-emma brain . [She]123-emma had led [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend astray , and it would be a reproach to [her]123-emma for ever ; but [her]123-emma judgment was as strong as [her]123-emma feelings , and as strong as it had ever been before , in reprobating any such alliance for [him]2495-her poor friend , as most unequal and degrading . [Her]123-emma way was clear , though not quite smooth.--She spoke then , on being so entreated.--What did [she]123-emma say?--Just what [she]123-emma ought , of course . [A lady]2918-a lady always does.--She said enough to [shew]2499-shew there need not be despair -- and to invite [him]2495-her poor friend to say more [himself]2495-her poor friend . [He]2495-her poor friend _ had _ despaired at one period ; [he]2495-her poor friend had received such an injunction to caution and silence , as for the time crushed every hope;--she had begun by refusing to hear him.--The change had perhaps been somewhat sudden;--her proposal of taking another turn , [her]123-emma renewing the conversation which [she]123-emma had just put an end to , might be a little extraordinary!--She felt its inconsistency ; but [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley was so obliging as to put up with it , and seek no farther explanation .

Seldom , very seldom , does complete truth belong to any human disclosure ; seldom can it happen that something is not a little disguised , or a little mistaken ; but where , as in this case , though the conduct is mistaken , the feelings are not , it may not be very material.--Mr . [Knightley]92-mr. knightley could not impute to [Emma]123-emma a more relenting heart than [she]123-emma possessed , or a heart more disposed to accept of [his]92-mr. knightley .

[He]92-mr. knightley had , in fact , been wholly unsuspicious of [his]92-mr. knightley own influence . [He]92-mr. knightley had followed [her]123-emma into the shrubbery with no idea of trying it . [He]92-mr. knightley had come , in [his]92-mr. knightley anxiety to see how [she]123-emma bore [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's engagement , with no selfish view , no view at all , but of endeavouring , if [she]123-emma allowed [him]92-mr. knightley an opening , to soothe or to counsel her.--The rest had been the work of the moment , the immediate effect of what [he]92-mr. knightley heard , on [his]92-mr. knightley feelings . The delightful assurance of [her]123-emma total indifference towards [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , of [her]123-emma having a heart completely disengaged from [him]92-mr. knightley , had given birth to the hope , that , in time , [he]92-mr. knightley might gain [her]123-emma affection himself;--but it had been no present hope -- [he]92-mr. knightley had only , in the momentary conquest of eagerness over judgment , aspired to be told that [she]123-emma did not forbid [his]92-mr. knightley attempt to attach her.--The superior hopes which gradually opened were so much the more enchanting.--The affection , which [he]92-mr. knightley had been asking to be allowed to create , if [he]92-mr. knightley could , was already his!--Within half an hour , [he]92-mr. knightley had passed from a thoroughly distressed state of mind , to something so like perfect happiness , that it could bear no other name .

_ [Her]123-emma _ change was equal.--This one half - hour had given to each the same precious certainty of being beloved , had cleared from each the same degree of ignorance , jealousy , or distrust.--On [his]92-mr. knightley side , there had been a long - standing jealousy , old as the arrival , or even the expectation , of [Frank Churchill.--He]359-frank churchill.--he had been in love with [Emma]123-emma , and jealous of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill , from about the same period , one sentiment having probably enlightened [him]92-mr. knightley as to the other . It was [his]92-mr. knightley jealousy of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill that had taken [him]92-mr. knightley from [the country.--The Box Hill party]2500-the country.--the box hill party had decided [him]92-mr. knightley on going away . [He]92-mr. knightley would save [himself]92-mr. knightley from witnessing again such permitted , encouraged attentions.--He had gone to learn to be indifferent.--But [he]92-mr. knightley had gone to [a wrong place]2501-a wrong place . There was too much domestic happiness in [[[his]92-mr. knightley brother]824-his brother 's house]2503-his brother 's house ; [woman]749-woman wore too amiable a form in it ; [Isabella]87-isabella was too much like [Emma]123-emma -- differing only in those striking inferiorities , which always brought [the other]739-the other in brilliancy before [him]92-mr. knightley , for much to have been done , even had [his]92-mr. knightley time been longer.--He had stayed on , however , vigorously , day after day -- till this very morning 's post had conveyed the history of [Jane Fairfax.--Then]360-jane fairfax.--then , with the gladness which must be felt , nay , which [he]92-mr. knightley did not scruple to feel , having never believed [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill to be at all deserving [Emma]123-emma , was there so much fond solicitude , so much keen anxiety for [her]123-emma , that [he]92-mr. knightley could stay no longer . [He]92-mr. knightley had ridden [home]562-home through the rain ; and had walked up directly after dinner , to see how [this sweetest and best of all creatures]2507-this sweetest and best of all creatures , faultless in spite of all [her]123-emma faults , bore the discovery .

[He]92-mr. knightley had found [her]123-emma agitated and [low.--Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill was a villain.-- [He]92-mr. knightley heard [her]123-emma declare that [she]123-emma had never loved [him]102-frank churchill . [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's character was not desperate.--She was [his]102-frank churchill own [Emma]123-emma , by hand and word , when [they]2508-they returned into [the house]435-the house ; and if [he]92-mr. knightley could have thought of [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill then , [he]92-mr. knightley might have deemed [him]102-frank churchill [a very good sort of fellow]2510-a very good sort of fellow .

CHAPTER XIV

What totally different feelings did [Emma]123-emma take back into [the house]435-the house from what [she]123-emma had brought [out!--she]361-out!--she had then been only daring to hope for a little respite of suffering;--she was now in an exquisite flutter of happiness , and such happiness moreover as [she]123-emma believed must still be greater when the flutter should have passed away .

[They]2508-they sat down to tea -- the same party round the same table -- how often it had been collected!--and how often had [her]123-emma eyes fallen on the same shrubs in [the lawn]4430-the lawn , and observed the same beautiful effect of the western sun!--But never in such a state of spirits , never in any thing like it ; and it was with difficulty that [she]123-emma could summon enough of [her]123-emma usual self to be [the attentive lady of [the house]435-the house]2513-the attentive lady of the house , or even [the attentive daughter]2515-the attentive daughter .

[Poor Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse little suspected what was plotting against [him]85-mr. woodhouse in the breast of [that man whom [he]85-mr. woodhouse was so cordially welcoming]2516-that man whom he was so cordially welcoming , and so anxiously hoping might not have taken cold from [his]85-mr. woodhouse ride.--Could [he]85-mr. woodhouse have seen the heart , [he]85-mr. woodhouse would have cared very little for the lungs ; but without the most distant imagination of the impending evil , without the slightest perception of any thing extraordinary in the looks or ways of either , [he]85-mr. woodhouse repeated to [them]2508-they very comfortably all the articles of news [he]85-mr. woodhouse had received from [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry , and talked on with much self - contentment , totally unsuspicious of what [they]2508-they could have told [him]85-mr. woodhouse in return .

As long as [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley remained with [them]2508-they , [Emma]123-emma 's fever continued ; but when [he]92-mr. knightley was gone , [she]123-emma began to be a little tranquillised and subdued -- and in the course of the sleepless night , which was the tax for such an evening , [she]123-emma found one or two such very serious points to consider , as made [her]123-emma feel , that even [her]123-emma happiness must have some alloy . [[Her]123-emma father]425-her father -- and [Harriet]111-harriet . [She]123-emma could not be alone without feeling the full weight of [their]2508-they separate claims ; and how to guard the comfort of both to the utmost , was the question . With respect to [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , it was a question soon answered . [She]123-emma hardly knew yet what [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley would ask ; but a very short parley with [her]123-emma own heart produced the most solemn resolution of never quitting [her]123-emma father.--She even wept over the idea of it , as a sin of thought . While [he]92-mr. knightley lived , it must be only an engagement ; but [she]123-emma flattered [herself]123-emma , that if divested of the danger of drawing [her]123-emma away , it might become an increase of comfort to him.--How to do [her]123-emma best by [Harriet]111-harriet , was of more difficult decision;--how to spare [her]111-harriet from any unnecessary pain ; how to make [her]111-harriet any possible atonement ; how to appear least [her]111-harriet enemy?--On these subjects , [her]111-harriet perplexity and distress were very great -- and [her]123-emma mind had to pass again and again through every bitter reproach and sorrowful regret that had ever surrounded it.--She could only resolve at last , that [she]123-emma would still avoid a meeting with [her]111-harriet , and communicate all that need be told by letter ; that it would be inexpressibly desirable to have [her]111-harriet removed just now for a time from [Highbury]3-highbury , and -- indulging in one scheme more -- nearly resolve , that it might be practicable to get an invitation for [her]111-harriet to [Brunswick Square.--Isabella]76-brunswick square.--isabella had been pleased with [Harriet]111-harriet ; and a few weeks spent in [London]1-london must give [her]111-harriet some amusement.--She did not think it in [Harriet]111-harriet 's nature to escape being benefited by novelty and variety , by [the streets]2519-the streets , [the shops]2520-the shops , and the children.--At any rate , it would be a proof of attention and kindness in [herself]111-harriet , from whom every thing was due ; a separation for the present ; an averting of the evil day , when [they]2521-they must all be together again .

[She]111-harriet rose early , and wrote [her]111-harriet letter to [Harriet]111-harriet ; an employment which left [her]111-harriet so very serious , so nearly sad , that [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , in walking up to [Hartfield]2-hartfield to breakfast , did not arrive at all too soon ; and half an hour stolen afterwards to go over the same ground again with [him]92-mr. knightley , literally and figuratively , was quite necessary to reinstate [her]111-harriet in a proper share of the happiness of the evening before .

[He]92-mr. knightley had not left [her]111-harriet long , by no means long enough for [her]111-harriet to have the slightest inclination for thinking of any body else , when a letter was brought [her]111-harriet from [Randalls]101-randalls -- a very thick letter;--she guessed what it must contain , and deprecated the necessity of reading it.--She was now in perfect charity with [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill ; [she]111-harriet wanted no explanations , [she]111-harriet wanted only to have [her]111-harriet thoughts to [herself]111-harriet -- and as for understanding any thing [he]92-mr. knightley wrote , [she]111-harriet was sure [she]111-harriet was incapable of it.--It must be waded through , however . [She]111-harriet opened the packet ; it was too surely so;--a note from [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston to [herself]111-harriet , ushered in the letter from [Frank]102-frank churchill to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston .

“ [I]3345-my dear madam have the greatest pleasure , [[my]3345-my dear madam dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , in forwarding to [you]123-emma the enclosed . [I]3345-my dear madam know what thorough justice [you]123-emma will do it , and have scarcely a doubt of its happy effect.--I think [we]5356-we shall never materially disagree about [the writer]727-the writer again ; but [I]3345-my dear madam will not delay [you]123-emma by a long preface.--We are quite well.--This letter has been the cure of all the little nervousness [I]3345-my dear madam have been feeling lately.--I did not quite like [your]123-emma looks on Tuesday , but it was an ungenial morning ; and though [you]123-emma will never own being affected by weather , [I]3345-my dear madam think every body feels a north - east wind.--I felt for [[your]123-emma dear father]5358-your dear father very much in the storm of Tuesday afternoon and yesterday morning , but had the comfort of hearing last night , by [Mr. Perry]106-mr. perry , that it had not made [him]5358-your dear father ill .[3345-my dear madam]

“ [Yours]123-emma ever , “[3345-my dear madam] A. W. ”[3345-my dear madam]

[ To [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston . ]

[WINDSOR]75-windsor - JULY . [[MY]0-my DEAR MADAM]3345-my dear madam ,

“ If [I]3345-my dear madam made [myself]3345-my dear madam intelligible yesterday , this letter will be expected ; but expected or not , [I]3345-my dear madam know it will be read with candour and indulgence.--You are all goodness , and [I]3345-my dear madam believe there will be need of even all [your]123-emma goodness to allow for some parts of [my]3345-my dear madam past conduct.--But [I]3345-my dear madam have been forgiven by [one who had still more to resent]5359-one who had still more to resent . [My]3345-my dear madam courage rises while [I]3345-my dear madam write . It is very difficult for [the prosperous]5360-the prosperous to be humble . [I]3345-my dear madam have already met with such success in two applications for pardon , that [I]3345-my dear madam may be in danger of thinking [myself]3345-my dear madam too sure of [yours]123-emma , and of those among [[your]123-emma friends who have had any ground of offence.--You]5361-your friends who have had any ground of offence.--you must all endeavour to comprehend the exact nature of [my]3345-my dear madam situation when [I]3345-my dear madam first arrived at [Randalls]101-randalls ; [you]123-emma must consider [me]3345-my dear madam as having a secret which was to be kept at all hazards . This was the fact . [My]3345-my dear madam right to place [myself]3345-my dear madam in a situation requiring such concealment , is another question . [I]3345-my dear madam shall not discuss it here . For [my]3345-my dear madam temptation to _ think _ it a right , [I]3345-my dear madam refer every caviller to [a brick house]5362-a brick house , sashed windows below , and casements above , in [Highbury]3-highbury . [I]3345-my dear madam dared not address [her]5363-her openly ; [my]3345-my dear madam difficulties in the then state of [Enscombe]7-enscombe must be too well known to require definition ; and [I]3345-my dear madam was fortunate enough to prevail , before [we]5364-we parted at [Weymouth]23-weymouth , and to induce [the most upright female mind in the creation]5365-the most upright female mind in the creation to stoop in charity to a secret engagement.--Had [she]5363-her refused , [I]3345-my dear madam should have gone mad.--But [you]123-emma will be ready to say , what was [your]123-emma hope in doing this?--What did [you]123-emma look forward to?--To any thing , every thing -- to time , chance , circumstance , slow effects , sudden bursts , perseverance and weariness , health and sickness . Every possibility of good was before [me]3345-my dear madam , and the first of blessings secured , in obtaining [her]5363-her promises of faith and correspondence . If [you]123-emma need farther explanation , [I]3345-my dear madam have the honour , [[my]3345-my dear madam dear madam]3345-my dear madam , of being [[[your]123-emma husband]5367-your husband 's son]5368-your husband 's son , and the advantage of inheriting a disposition to hope for good , which no inheritance of [houses]5369-houses or lands can ever equal the value of.--See [me]3345-my dear madam , then , under these circumstances , arriving on [my]3345-my dear madam first visit to [Randalls;--and]77-randalls;--and here [I]3345-my dear madam am conscious of wrong , for that visit might have been sooner paid . [You]123-emma will look back and see that [I]3345-my dear madam did not come till [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax was in [Highbury]3-highbury ; and as _ [you]123-emma _ were [the person slighted]5370-the person slighted , [you]123-emma will forgive [me]3345-my dear madam instantly ; but [I]3345-my dear madam must work on [[my]3345-my dear madam father]2740-my father 's compassion , by reminding [him]2740-my father , that so long as [I]3345-my dear madam absented [myself]3345-my dear madam from [[his]2740-my father house]409-his house , so long [I]3345-my dear madam lost the blessing of knowing [you]123-emma . [My]3345-my dear madam behaviour , during the very happy fortnight which [I]3345-my dear madam spent with [you]123-emma , did not , [I]3345-my dear madam hope , lay [me]3345-my dear madam open to reprehension , excepting on one point . And now [I]3345-my dear madam come to [the principal]5373-the principal , the only important part of [my]3345-my dear madam conduct while belonging to [you]123-emma , which excites [my]3345-my dear madam own anxiety , or requires very solicitous explanation . With the greatest respect , and the warmest friendship , do [I]3345-my dear madam mention [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse ; [[my]3345-my dear madam father]2740-my father perhaps will think [I]3345-my dear madam ought to add , with the deepest humiliation.--A few words which dropped from [him]2740-my father yesterday spoke [his]2740-my father opinion , and some censure [I]3345-my dear madam acknowledge [myself]3345-my dear madam liable to.--My behaviour to [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse indicated , [I]3345-my dear madam believe , more than it ought.--In order to assist a concealment so essential to [me]3345-my dear madam , [I]3345-my dear madam was led on to make more than an allowable use of the sort of intimacy into which [we]5375-we were immediately thrown.--I can not deny that [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse was [my]3345-my dear madam ostensible object -- but [I]3345-my dear madam am sure [you]123-emma will believe the declaration , that had [I]3345-my dear madam not been convinced of [her]93-miss woodhouse indifference , [I]3345-my dear madam would not have been induced by any selfish views to go on.--Amiable and delightful as [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse is , [she]93-miss woodhouse never gave [me]3345-my dear madam the idea of [a young woman]3868-a young woman likely to be attached ; and that [she]93-miss woodhouse was perfectly free from any tendency to being attached to [me]3345-my dear madam , was as much [my]3345-my dear madam conviction as [my]3345-my dear madam wish.--She received [my]3345-my dear madam attentions with an easy , friendly , goodhumoured playfulness , which exactly suited [me]3345-my dear madam . [We]5375-we seemed to understand [each other]430-each other . From [our]5375-we relative situation , those attentions were [her]93-miss woodhouse due , and were felt to be so.--Whether [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse began really to understand [me]3345-my dear madam before the expiration of that fortnight , [I]3345-my dear madam can not say;--when [I]3345-my dear madam called to take leave of [her]93-miss woodhouse , [I]3345-my dear madam remember that [I]3345-my dear madam was within a moment of confessing the truth , and [I]3345-my dear madam then fancied [she]93-miss woodhouse was not without suspicion ; but [I]3345-my dear madam have no doubt of [her]93-miss woodhouse having since detected [me]3345-my dear madam , at least in some degree.--She may not have surmised the whole , but [her]93-miss woodhouse quickness must have penetrated a part . [I]3345-my dear madam can not doubt it . [You]5378-you will find , whenever the subject becomes freed from its present restraints , that it did not take [her]93-miss woodhouse wholly by surprize . [She]93-miss woodhouse frequently gave [me]3345-my dear madam hints of it . [I]3345-my dear madam remember [her]93-miss woodhouse telling [me]3345-my dear madam at the ball , that [I]3345-my dear madam owed [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton gratitude for [her]93-miss woodhouse attentions to [Miss Fairfax.--I]362-miss fairfax.--i hope this history of [my]3345-my dear madam conduct towards [her]93-miss woodhouse will be admitted by [you]5378-you and [[my]3345-my dear madam father]2740-my father as great extenuation of what [you]5378-you saw amiss . While [you]5378-you considered [me]3345-my dear madam as having sinned against [Emma Woodhouse]123-emma , [I]3345-my dear madam could deserve nothing from either . Acquit [me]3345-my dear madam here , and procure for [me]3345-my dear madam , when it is allowable , the acquittal and good wishes of that said [Emma Woodhouse]123-emma , whom [I]3345-my dear madam regard with so much brotherly affection , as to long to have [her]93-miss woodhouse as deeply and as happily in love as myself.--Whatever strange things [I]3345-my dear madam said or did during that fortnight , [you]5378-you have now a key to . [My]3345-my dear madam heart was in [Highbury]3-highbury , and [my]3345-my dear madam business was to get [my]3345-my dear madam body thither as often as might be , and with the least suspicion . If [you]5378-you remember any queernesses , set them all to the right account.--Of the pianoforte so much talked of , [I]3345-my dear madam feel it only necessary to say , that its being ordered was absolutely unknown to [Miss F--]363-miss f-- , who would never have allowed [me]3345-my dear madam to send it , had any choice been given her.--The delicacy of [her]93-miss woodhouse mind throughout the whole engagement , [[my]3345-my dear madam dear madam]3345-my dear madam , is much beyond [my]3345-my dear madam power of doing justice to . [You]5378-you will soon , [I]3345-my dear madam earnestly hope , know [her]93-miss woodhouse thoroughly yourself.--No description can describe [her]93-miss woodhouse . [She]93-miss woodhouse must tell [you]5378-you [herself]93-miss woodhouse what [she]93-miss woodhouse is -- yet not by word , for never was there [a human creature who would so designedly suppress [her]93-miss woodhouse own merit.--Since [I]3345-my dear madam began this letter , which will be longer than [I]3345-my dear madam foresaw , [I]3345-my dear madam have heard from her.--She gives a good account of [her]93-miss woodhouse own health]5381-a human creature who would so designedly suppress her own merit.--since i began this letter , which will be longer than i foresaw , i have heard from her.--she gives a good account of her own health ; but as [she]93-miss woodhouse never complains , [I]3345-my dear madam dare not depend . [I]3345-my dear madam want to have [your]5378-you opinion of [her]93-miss woodhouse looks . [I]3345-my dear madam know [you]5378-you will soon call on [her]93-miss woodhouse ; [she]93-miss woodhouse is living in dread of the visit . Perhaps it is paid already . Let [me]3345-my dear madam hear from [you]5378-you without delay ; [I]3345-my dear madam am impatient for a thousand particulars . Remember how few minutes [I]3345-my dear madam was at [Randalls]101-randalls , and in how bewildered , how mad a state : and [I]3345-my dear madam am not much better yet ; still insane either from happiness or misery . When [I]3345-my dear madam think of the kindness and favour [I]3345-my dear madam have met with , of [her]93-miss woodhouse excellence and patience , and [[my]3345-my dear madam uncle]4367-my uncle 's generosity , [I]3345-my dear madam am mad with joy : but when [I]3345-my dear madam recollect all the uneasiness [I]3345-my dear madam occasioned [her]93-miss woodhouse , and how little [I]3345-my dear madam deserve to be forgiven , [I]3345-my dear madam am mad with anger . If [I]3345-my dear madam could but see [her]93-miss woodhouse again!--But [I]3345-my dear madam must not propose it yet . [[My]3345-my dear madam uncle]4367-my uncle has been too good for [me]3345-my dear madam to encroach.--I must still add to this long letter . [You]5384-you have not heard all that [you]5384-you ought to hear . [I]3345-my dear madam could not give any connected detail yesterday ; but the suddenness , and , in one light , the unseasonableness with which the affair burst out , needs explanation ; for though the event of the 26th ult . , as [you]5384-you will conclude , immediately opened to [me]3345-my dear madam the happiest prospects , [I]3345-my dear madam should not have presumed on such early measures , but from the very particular circumstances , which left [me]3345-my dear madam not an hour to lose . [I]3345-my dear madam should [myself]3345-my dear madam have shrunk from any thing so hasty , and [she]93-miss woodhouse would have felt every scruple of [mine]3345-my dear madam with multiplied strength and refinement.--But [I]3345-my dear madam had no choice . The hasty engagement [she]93-miss woodhouse had entered into with [that woman]4574-that woman -- Here , [[my]3345-my dear madam dear madam]3345-my dear madam , [I]3345-my dear madam was obliged to leave off abruptly , to recollect and compose myself.--I have been walking over [the country]611-the country , and am now , [I]3345-my dear madam hope , rational enough to make the rest of [my]3345-my dear madam letter what it ought to be.--It is , in fact , a most mortifying retrospect for [me]3345-my dear madam . [I]3345-my dear madam behaved shamefully . And here [I]3345-my dear madam can admit , that [my]3345-my dear madam manners to [Miss W.]364-miss w. , in being unpleasant to [Miss F.]365-miss f. , were highly blameable . _ [She]93-miss woodhouse _ disapproved [them]5388-them , which ought to have been enough.--My plea of concealing the truth [she]93-miss woodhouse did not think sufficient.--She was displeased ; [I]3345-my dear madam thought unreasonably so : [I]3345-my dear madam thought [her]93-miss woodhouse , on a thousand occasions , unnecessarily scrupulous and cautious : [I]3345-my dear madam thought [her]93-miss woodhouse even cold . But [she]93-miss woodhouse was always right . If [I]3345-my dear madam had followed [her]93-miss woodhouse judgment , and subdued [my]3345-my dear madam spirits to the level of what [she]93-miss woodhouse deemed proper , [I]3345-my dear madam should have escaped the greatest unhappiness [I]3345-my dear madam have ever known.--We quarrelled.-- Do [you]5389-you remember the morning spent at [Donwell?--_There]78-donwell?--_there _ every little dissatisfaction that had occurred before came to a crisis . [I]3345-my dear madam was late ; [I]3345-my dear madam met [her]93-miss woodhouse walking [home]562-home by [herself]93-miss woodhouse , and wanted to walk with [her]93-miss woodhouse , but [she]93-miss woodhouse would not suffer it . [She]93-miss woodhouse absolutely refused to allow [me]3345-my dear madam , which [I]3345-my dear madam then thought most unreasonable . Now , however , [I]3345-my dear madam see nothing in it but a very natural and consistent degree of discretion . While [I]3345-my dear madam , to blind [the world]403-the world to [our]5392-our engagement , was behaving one hour with objectionable particularity to [another woman]3977-another woman , was [she]93-miss woodhouse to be consenting the next to a proposal which might have made every previous caution useless?--Had [we]5392-our been met walking together between [Donwell]24-donwell and [Highbury]3-highbury , the truth must have been suspected.--I was mad enough , however , to resent.--I doubted [her]93-miss woodhouse affection . [I]3345-my dear madam doubted it more the next day on [Box Hill]64-box hill ; when , provoked by such conduct on [my]3345-my dear madam side , such shameful , insolent neglect of [her]93-miss woodhouse , and such apparent devotion to [Miss W.]364-miss w. , as it would have been impossible for [any woman of sense]5394-any woman of sense to endure , [she]93-miss woodhouse spoke [her]93-miss woodhouse resentment in a form of words perfectly intelligible to me.--In short , [[my]3345-my dear madam dear madam]3345-my dear madam , it was a quarrel blameless on [her]93-miss woodhouse side , abominable on [mine]3345-my dear madam ; and [I]3345-my dear madam returned the same evening to [Richmond]61-richmond , though [I]3345-my dear madam might have staid with [you]3345-my dear madam till the next morning , merely because [I]3345-my dear madam would be as angry with [her]93-miss woodhouse as possible . Even then , [I]3345-my dear madam was not such [a fool as not to mean to be reconciled]5396-a fool as not to mean to be reconciled in time ; but [I]3345-my dear madam was [the injured person]5397-the injured person , injured by [her]93-miss woodhouse coldness , and [I]3345-my dear madam went away determined that [she]93-miss woodhouse should make the first advances.--I shall always congratulate [myself]3345-my dear madam that [you]3345-my dear madam were not of [the Box Hill party]5398-the box hill party . Had [you]3345-my dear madam witnessed [my]3345-my dear madam behaviour there , [I]3345-my dear madam can hardly suppose [you]3345-my dear madam would ever have thought well of [me]3345-my dear madam again . Its effect upon [her]93-miss woodhouse appears in the immediate resolution it produced : as soon as [she]93-miss woodhouse found [I]3345-my dear madam was really gone from [Randalls]101-randalls , [she]93-miss woodhouse closed with the offer of that officious [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton ; the whole system of whose treatment of [her]93-miss woodhouse , by the bye , has ever filled [me]3345-my dear madam with indignation and hatred . [I]3345-my dear madam must not quarrel with a spirit of forbearance which has been so richly extended towards [myself]3345-my dear madam ; but , otherwise , [I]3345-my dear madam should loudly protest against the share of it which [that woman]4574-that woman has known.--'Jane , ' indeed!--You will observe that [I]3345-my dear madam have not yet indulged [myself]3345-my dear madam in calling [her]93-miss woodhouse by that name , even to [you]3345-my dear madam . Think , then , what [I]3345-my dear madam must have endured in hearing it bandied between [the Eltons]339-the mrs. eltons with all the vulgarity of needless repetition , and all the insolence of imaginary superiority . Have patience with [me]3345-my dear madam , [I]3345-my dear madam shall soon have [done.--She]5400-done.--she closed with this offer , resolving to break with [me]3345-my dear madam entirely , and wrote the next day to tell [me]3345-my dear madam that [we]5401-we never were to meet again.--_She _ _ felt _ _ the _ _ engagement _ _ to _ _ be _ _ a _ _ source _ _ of _ _ repentance _ _ and _ _ misery _ _ to _ _ each _ : _ [she]93-miss woodhouse _ _ dissolved _ _ it_.--This letter reached [me]3345-my dear madam on the very morning of [[my]3345-my dear madam poor aunt]5402-my poor aunt 's death . [I]3345-my dear madam answered it within an hour ; but from the confusion of [my]3345-my dear madam mind , and the multiplicity of business falling on [me]3345-my dear madam at once , [my]3345-my dear madam answer , instead of being sent with all the many other letters of that day , was locked up in [my]3345-my dear madam writing - desk ; and [I]3345-my dear madam , trusting that [I]3345-my dear madam had written enough , though but a few lines , to satisfy [her]93-miss woodhouse , remained without any uneasiness.--I was rather disappointed that [I]3345-my dear madam did not hear from [her]93-miss woodhouse again speedily ; but [I]3345-my dear madam made excuses for [her]93-miss woodhouse , and was too busy , and -- may [I]3345-my dear madam add?--too cheerful in [my]3345-my dear madam views to be captious.--We removed to [Windsor]75-windsor ; and two days afterwards [I]3345-my dear madam received a parcel from [her]93-miss woodhouse , [my]3345-my dear madam own letters all returned!--and a few lines at the same time by the post , stating [her]93-miss woodhouse extreme surprize at not having had the smallest reply to [her]93-miss woodhouse last ; and adding , that as silence on such a point could not be misconstrued , and as it must be equally desirable to both to have every subordinate arrangement concluded as soon as possible , [she]93-miss woodhouse now sent [me]3345-my dear madam , by a safe conveyance , all [my]3345-my dear madam letters , and requested , that if [I]3345-my dear madam could not directly command [hers]93-miss woodhouse , so as to send them to [Highbury]3-highbury within a week , [I]3345-my dear madam would forward them after that period to [her]93-miss woodhouse at-- : in short , the full direction to [Mr. Smallridge]366-mr. smallridge 's , near [Bristol]40-bristol , stared [me]3345-my dear madam in the face . [I]3345-my dear madam knew the name , the place , [I]3345-my dear madam knew all about it , and instantly saw what [she]93-miss woodhouse had been doing . It was perfectly accordant with that resolution of character which [I]3345-my dear madam knew [her]93-miss woodhouse to possess ; and the secrecy [she]93-miss woodhouse had maintained , as to any such design in [her]93-miss woodhouse former letter , was equally descriptive of its anxious delicacy . For [the world]403-the world would not [she]93-miss woodhouse have seemed to threaten [me.--Imagine]3345-my dear madam the shock ; imagine how , till [I]3345-my dear madam had actually detected [my]3345-my dear madam own blunder , [I]3345-my dear madam raved at the blunders of the post.--What was to be done?--One thing only.--I must speak to [[my]3345-my dear madam uncle]4367-my uncle . Without [his]4367-my uncle sanction [I]3345-my dear madam could not hope to be listened to again.--I spoke ; circumstances were in [my]3345-my dear madam favour ; the late event had softened away [his]4367-my uncle pride , and [he]4367-my uncle was , earlier than [I]3345-my dear madam could have anticipated , wholly reconciled and complying ; and could say at last , [poor man]5405-poor man ! with a deep sigh , that [he]4367-my uncle wished [I]3345-my dear madam might find as much happiness in the marriage state as [he]4367-my uncle had done.--I felt that it would be of a different sort.--Are [you]5406-you disposed to pity [me]3345-my dear madam for what [I]3345-my dear madam must have suffered in opening the cause to [him]4367-my uncle , for [my]3345-my dear madam suspense while all was at stake?--No ; do not pity [me]3345-my dear madam till [I]3345-my dear madam reached [Highbury]3-highbury , and saw how ill [I]3345-my dear madam had made [her]3-highbury . Do not pity [me]3345-my dear madam till [I]3345-my dear madam saw [her]3-highbury wan , sick looks.--I reached [Highbury]3-highbury at the time of day when , from [my]3345-my dear madam knowledge of [their]5407-their late breakfast hour , [I]3345-my dear madam was certain of a good chance of finding [her]3-highbury alone.--I was not disappointed ; and at last [I]3345-my dear madam was not disappointed either in the object of [my]3345-my dear madam journey . A great deal of very reasonable , very just displeasure [I]3345-my dear madam had to persuade away . But it is done ; [we]5408-we are reconciled , dearer , much dearer , than ever , and no moment 's uneasiness can ever occur between [us]5408-we again . Now , [[my]3345-my dear madam dear madam]3345-my dear madam , [I]3345-my dear madam will release [you]3345-my dear madam ; but [I]3345-my dear madam could not conclude before . A thousand and a thousand thanks for all the kindness [you]3345-my dear madam have ever shewn [me]3345-my dear madam , and ten thousand for the attentions [your]3345-my dear madam heart will dictate towards her.--If [you]3345-my dear madam think [me]3345-my dear madam in a way to be happier than [I]3345-my dear madam deserve , [I]3345-my dear madam am quite of [your]3345-my dear madam opinion.--Miss W. calls [me]3345-my dear madam [the child of good fortune]5410-the child of good fortune . [I]3345-my dear madam hope [she]123-emma is right.--In one respect , [my]3345-my dear madam good fortune is undoubted , that of being able to subscribe [myself]3345-my dear madam ,[3345-my dear madam]

[Your]2523-your obliged and affectionate Son ,

[F. C. WESTON CHURCHILL]156-weston churchill .

CHAPTER XV

This letter must make its way to [Emma]123-emma 's feelings . [She]123-emma was obliged , in spite of [her]123-emma previous determination to the contrary , to do it all the justice that [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston foretold . As soon as [she]123-emma came to [her]123-emma own name , it was irresistible ; every line relating to [herself]123-emma was interesting , and almost every line agreeable ; and when this charm ceased , the subject could still maintain itself , by the natural return of [her]123-emma former regard for [the writer]727-the writer , and the very strong attraction which any picture of love must have for [her]123-emma at that moment . [She]123-emma never stopt till [she]123-emma had gone through the whole ; and though it was impossible not to feel that [he]727-the writer had been wrong , yet [he]727-the writer had been less wrong than [she]123-emma had supposed -- and [he]727-the writer had suffered , and was very sorry -- and [he]727-the writer was so grateful to [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , and so much in love with [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , and [she]123-emma was so happy [herself]123-emma , that there was no being severe ; and could [he]727-the writer have entered [the room]701-the room , [she]123-emma must have shaken hands with [him]727-the writer as heartily as ever .

[She]123-emma thought so well of the letter , that when [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley came again , [she]123-emma desired [him]92-mr. knightley to read it . [She]123-emma was sure of [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's wishing it to be communicated ; especially to one , who , like [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , had seen so much to blame in [his]727-the writer conduct .

“ [I]92-mr. knightley shall be very glad to look it over , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley ; “ but it seems long . [I]92-mr. knightley will take it [home]562-home with [me]92-mr. knightley at night . ”[92-mr. knightley]

But that would not do . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston was to call in the evening , and [she]123-emma must return it by [him]92-mr. knightley .

“ [I]92-mr. knightley would rather be talking to [you]123-emma , ”[92-mr. knightley] [he]92-mr. knightley replied ; “ but as it seems a matter of justice , it shall be done . ”[92-mr. knightley]
