[He]92-mr. knightley began -- stopping , however , almost directly to say , “ Had [I]92-mr. knightley been offered the sight of one of [this gentleman]5412-this gentleman 's letters to [[his]5412-this gentleman mother - in - law]1397-his mother - in - law a few months ago , [Emma]123-emma , it would not have been taken with such indifference . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[He]92-mr. knightley proceeded a little farther , reading to [himself]92-mr. knightley ; and then , with a smile , observed , “ Humph ! a fine complimentary opening : But it is [his]5412-this gentleman way . [One man]5414-one man 's style must not be the rule of another 's . [We]5415-we will not be severe . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ It will be natural for [me]92-mr. knightley , ”[92-mr. knightley] [he]92-mr. knightley added shortly afterwards , “ to speak [my]92-mr. knightley opinion aloud as [I]92-mr. knightley read . By doing it , [I]92-mr. knightley shall feel that [I]92-mr. knightley am near [you]123-emma . It will not be so great a loss of time : but if [you]123-emma dislike it-- ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Not at all . [I]92-mr. knightley should wish it . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley returned to [his]92-mr. knightley reading with greater alacrity .

“ [He]5412-this gentleman trifles here , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley , “ as to the temptation . [He]5412-this gentleman knows [he]5412-this gentleman is wrong , and has nothing rational to urge.--Bad.--He ought not to have formed [the engagement.--'His father]5416-the engagement.--'his father 's disposition:'--he is unjust , however , to [[his]5412-this gentleman father]518-his father . [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston 's sanguine temper was a blessing on all [his]86-mr. weston upright and honourable exertions ; but [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston earned every present comfort before [he]86-mr. weston endeavoured to gain it.--Very true ; [he]86-mr. weston did not come till [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax was [here]2707-here . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ And [I]123-emma have not forgotten , ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma , “ how sure [you]123-emma were that [he]86-mr. weston might have come sooner if [he]86-mr. weston would . [You]123-emma pass it over very handsomely -- but [you]123-emma were perfectly right . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]2526-he was not quite impartial in [my]2526-he judgment , [Emma:--but]367-emma:--but yet , [I]2526-he think -- had _ [you]123-emma _ not been in the case -- [I]2526-he should still have distrusted [him]86-mr. weston . ”[2526-he]

When [he]2526-he came to [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [he]2526-he was obliged to read the whole of it aloud -- all that related to [her]93-miss woodhouse , with a smile ; a look ; a shake of the head ; a word or two of assent , or disapprobation ; or merely of love , as the subject required ; concluding , however , seriously , and , after steady reflection , thus--

“ Very bad -- though it might have been worse.--Playing a most dangerous game . Too much indebted to the event for [his]86-mr. weston acquittal.--No judge of [his]86-mr. weston own manners by you.--Always deceived in fact by [his]86-mr. weston own wishes , and regardless of little besides [his]86-mr. weston own convenience.--Fancying [you]123-emma to have fathomed [his]86-mr. weston secret . Natural enough!--his own mind full of intrigue , that [he]2526-he should suspect it in others.--Mystery ; Finesse -- how [they]5419-they pervert the understanding ! [[My]123-emma [Emma]123-emma]3544-my emma , does not every thing serve to prove more and more the beauty of truth and sincerity in all [our]5421-our dealings with [each other]430-each other ? ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma agreed to it , and with a blush of sensibility on [Harriet]111-harriet 's account , which [she]123-emma could not give any sincere explanation of .

“ [You]2526-he had better go on , ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma .

[He]2526-he did so , but very soon stopt again to say , “ the pianoforte ! Ah ! That was the act of [a very , very young man]5423-a very , very young man , one too young to consider whether the inconvenience of it might not very much exceed the pleasure . A boyish scheme , indeed!--I can not comprehend [a man]2840-a man 's wishing to give [a woman]2864-a woman any proof of affection which [he]2526-he knows [she]2864-a woman would rather dispense with ; and [he]2526-he did know that [she]2864-a woman would have prevented the instrument 's coming if [she]2864-a woman could . ”[2526-he]

After this , [he]2526-he made some progress without any pause . [Frank Churchill]102-frank churchill 's confession of having behaved shamefully was the first thing to call for more than a word in passing .

“ [I]102-frank churchill perfectly agree with [you]2526-he , sir,”--was[102-frank churchill] then [his]102-frank churchill remark . “ [You]2526-he did behave very shamefully . [You]2526-he never wrote a truer line . ”[102-frank churchill] And having gone through what immediately followed of the basis of [their]2527-their disagreement , and [his]2526-he persisting to act in direct opposition to [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's sense of right , [he]2526-he made a fuller pause to say , “ This is very bad.--He had induced [her]2864-a woman to place [herself]2864-a woman , for [his]2526-he sake , in a situation of extreme difficulty and uneasiness , and it should have been [his]2526-he first object to prevent [her]2864-a woman from suffering unnecessarily.--She must have had much more to contend with , in carrying on the correspondence , than [he]2526-he could . [He]2526-he should have respected even unreasonable scruples , had there been such ; but [hers]5426-hers were all reasonable . [Emma]123-emma knew that [he]2526-he was now getting to the Box Hill party , and grew uncomfortable . [Her]123-emma own behaviour had been so very improper ! [She]123-emma was deeply ashamed , and a little afraid of [his]2526-he next look . It was all read , however , steadily , attentively , and without the smallest remark ; and , excepting one momentary glance at [her]123-emma , instantly withdrawn , in the fear of giving pain -- no remembrance of [Box Hill]64-box hill seemed to exist .

“ There is no saying much for the delicacy of [[our]2527-their good friends]5427-our good friends , [the Eltons]5428-the eltons , ”[2526-he] was [his]2526-he next observation.--“His feelings are natural.--What ! actually resolve to break with [him]2526-he entirely!--She felt the engagement to be a source of repentance and misery to each -- [she]2864-a woman dissolved it.--What a view this gives of [her]2864-a woman sense of [his]2526-he behaviour!--Well , [he]2526-he must be a most extraordinary-- ”[2526-he]

“ Nay , nay , read on.--You will find how very much [he]2526-he suffers . ”[2526-he]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley hope [he]2526-he does , ”[92-mr. knightley] replied [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley coolly , and resuming the letter . “ ' [Smallridge!'--What]369-smallridge!'--what does this mean ? What is all this ? ”[92-mr. knightley]

[I]92-mr. knightley shall soon have done . What a letter [the man]3033-the man writes ! ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]2526-he wish [you]123-emma would read it with a kinder spirit towards [him]3033-the man . ”[2526-he]

“ [You]123-emma do not appear so well satisfied with [his]3033-the man letter as [I]2526-he am ; but still [you]123-emma must , at least [I]2526-he hope [you]123-emma must , think the better of [him]3033-the man for it . “ Yes , certainly it does . [He]3033-the man has had great faults , faults of inconsideration and thoughtlessness ; and [I]92-mr. knightley am very much of [his]3033-the man opinion in thinking [him]3033-the man likely to be happier than [he]3033-the man deserves : but still as [he]3033-the man is , beyond a doubt , really attached to [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , and will soon , it may be hoped , have the advantage of being constantly with [her]152-miss fairfax , [I]92-mr. knightley am very ready to believe [his]3033-the man character will improve , and acquire from [hers]152-miss fairfax the steadiness and delicacy of principle that it wants . The subject followed ; it was in plain , unaffected , gentlemanlike English , such as [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley used even to [the woman [he]92-mr. knightley was in love with]2528-the woman he was in love with , how to be able to ask [her]2528-the woman he was in love with to marry [him]92-mr. knightley , without attacking the happiness of [[her]2528-the woman he was in love with father]425-her father . [Emma]123-emma 's answer was ready at the first word . “ While [[her]123-emma dear father]5439-her dear father lived , any change of condition must be impossible for [her]123-emma . [She]123-emma could never quit [him]425-her father . ”[123-emma] Part only of this answer , however , was admitted . The impossibility of [her]123-emma quitting [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley felt as strongly as [herself]123-emma ; but the inadmissibility of any other change , [he]92-mr. knightley could not agree to . [He]92-mr. knightley had been thinking it over most deeply , most intently ; [he]92-mr. knightley had at first hoped to induce [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse to remove with [her]123-emma to [Donwell]24-donwell ; [he]92-mr. knightley had wanted to believe it feasible , but [his]92-mr. knightley knowledge of [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse would not suffer [him]92-mr. knightley to deceive [himself]92-mr. knightley long ; and now [he]92-mr. knightley confessed [his]92-mr. knightley persuasion , that such a transplantation would be a risk of [[her]123-emma father]425-her father 's comfort , perhaps even of [his]92-mr. knightley life , which must not be hazarded . [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse taken from [Hartfield!--No]79-hartfield!--no , [he]85-mr. woodhouse felt that it ought not to be attempted . But the plan which had arisen on the sacrifice of this , [he]85-mr. woodhouse trusted [[his]85-mr. woodhouse dearest]2532-his dearest [Emma]123-emma would not find in any respect objectionable ; it was , that [he]85-mr. woodhouse should be received at [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; that so long as [[her]123-emma father]425-her father 's happiness -- in other words , [his]92-mr. knightley life -- required [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse to continue [[her]93-miss woodhouse [home]562-home]638-her home , it should be [his]92-mr. knightley likewise .

Of [their]2536-their all removing to [Donwell]24-donwell , [Emma]123-emma had already had [her]123-emma own passing thoughts . Like [him]85-mr. woodhouse , [she]123-emma had tried the scheme and rejected it ; but such an alternative as this had not occurred to [her]123-emma . [She]123-emma was sensible of all the affection it evinced . [She]123-emma felt that , in quitting [Donwell]24-donwell , [he]85-mr. woodhouse must be sacrificing a great deal of independence of hours and habits ; that in living constantly with [[her]123-emma father]425-her father , and in [no house of [his]85-mr. woodhouse own]2538-no house of his own , there would be much , very much , to be borne with . [She]123-emma promised to think of it , and advised [him]85-mr. woodhouse to think of it more ; but [he]85-mr. woodhouse was fully convinced , that no reflection could alter [his]85-mr. woodhouse wishes or [his]85-mr. woodhouse opinion on the subject . [He]85-mr. woodhouse had given it , [he]85-mr. woodhouse could assure [her]123-emma , very long and calm consideration ; [he]85-mr. woodhouse had been walking away from [William Larkins]234-william larkins the whole morning , to have [his]85-mr. woodhouse thoughts to [himself]85-mr. woodhouse .

“ Ah ! there is one difficulty unprovided for , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma . “ [I]123-emma am sure [William Larkins]234-william larkins will not like it . [You]85-mr. woodhouse must get [his]234-william larkins consent before [you]85-mr. woodhouse ask [mine]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

[She]123-emma promised , however , to think of it ; and pretty nearly promised , moreover , to think of it , with the intention of finding it a very good scheme .

It is remarkable , that [Emma]123-emma , in the many , very many , points of view in which [she]123-emma was now beginning to consider [Donwell Abbey]24-donwell , was never struck with any sense of injury to [[her]123-emma nephew]3651-her nephew [Henry]125-henry , whose rights as [heir - expectant]2540-heir - expectant had formerly been so tenaciously regarded . Think [she]123-emma must of the possible difference to [the poor little boy]2541-the poor little boy ; and yet [she]123-emma only gave [herself]123-emma a saucy conscious smile about it , and found amusement in detecting the real cause of that violent dislike of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's marrying [Jane Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , or any body else , which at the time [she]123-emma had wholly imputed to the amiable solicitude of [the sister]2542-the sister and [the aunt]520-the aunt .

This proposal of [his]92-mr. knightley , this plan of marrying and continuing at [Hartfield]2-hartfield -- the more [she]123-emma contemplated it , the more pleasing it became . [His]92-mr. knightley evils seemed to lessen , [her]123-emma own advantages to increase , [their]2544-their mutual good to outweigh every drawback . Such a companion for [herself]123-emma in the periods of anxiety and cheerlessness before her!--Such [a partner in all those duties and cares to which time]2545-a partner in all those duties and cares to which time must be giving increase of melancholy !

[She]123-emma would have been too happy but for [poor Harriet]111-harriet ; but every blessing of [her]123-emma own seemed to involve and advance the sufferings of [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend , who must now be even excluded from [Hartfield]2-hartfield . The delightful family party which [Emma]123-emma was securing for [herself]123-emma , poor [Harriet]111-harriet must , in mere charitable caution , be kept at a distance from . [She]111-harriet would be [a loser]2547-a loser in every way . [Emma]123-emma could not deplore [her]123-emma future absence as any deduction from [her]123-emma own enjoyment . In such a party , [Harriet]111-harriet would be rather a dead weight than otherwise ; but for [the poor girl]2548-the poor girl [herself]2548-the poor girl , it seemed a peculiarly cruel necessity that was to be placing [her]111-harriet in such a state of unmerited punishment .

In time , of course , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley would be forgotten , that is , supplanted ; but this could not be expected to happen very early . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley [himself]92-mr. knightley would be doing nothing to assist the cure;--not like [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , always so kind , so feeling , so truly considerate for every body , would never deserve to be less worshipped than now ; and it really was too much to hope even of [Harriet]111-harriet , that [she]111-harriet could be in love with more than [_ three _ men]2549-_ three _ men in one year .

CHAPTER XVI

It was a very great relief to [Emma]123-emma to find [Harriet]111-harriet as desirous as [herself]111-harriet to avoid a meeting . [Their]2550-their intercourse was painful enough by letter . How much worse , had [they]2550-their been obliged to meet !

[Harriet]111-harriet expressed [herself]111-harriet very much as might be supposed , without reproaches , or apparent sense of ill - usage ; and yet [Emma]123-emma fancied there was a something of resentment , a something bordering on it in [her]123-emma style , which increased the desirableness of [their]2550-their being separate.--It might be only [her]123-emma own consciousness ; but it seemed as if [an angel only could have been quite without resentment under such a stroke]2551-an angel only could have been quite without resentment under such a stroke .

[She]123-emma had no difficulty in procuring [Isabella]87-isabella 's invitation ; and [she]123-emma was fortunate in having a sufficient reason for asking it , without resorting to invention.--There was a tooth amiss . [Harriet]111-harriet really wished , and had wished some time , to consult [a dentist]2552-a dentist . [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley was delighted to be of use ; any thing of ill health was a recommendation to [her]122-mrs. john knightley -- and though not so fond of [a dentist]2552-a dentist as of [a Mr. Wingfield]159-mr. wingfield , [she]122-mrs. john knightley was quite eager to have [Harriet]111-harriet under [her]122-mrs. john knightley care.--When it was thus settled on [[her]123-emma sister]407-her sister 's side , [Emma]123-emma proposed it to [[her]123-emma friend]427-her friend , and found [her]123-emma very persuadable.--Harriet was to go ; [she]123-emma was invited for at least a fortnight ; [she]123-emma was to be conveyed in [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's carriage.--It was all arranged , it was all completed , and [Harriet]111-harriet was safe in [Brunswick Square]5-brunswick square .

Now [Emma]123-emma could , indeed , enjoy [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's visits ; now [she]123-emma could talk , and [she]123-emma could listen with true happiness , unchecked by that sense of injustice , of guilt , of something most painful , which had haunted [her]123-emma when remembering how disappointed a heart was near [her]123-emma , how much might at that moment , and at a little distance , be enduring by the feelings which [she]123-emma had led astray [herself]123-emma .

The difference of [Harriet]111-harriet at [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard 's , or in [London]1-london , made perhaps an unreasonable difference in [Emma]123-emma 's sensations ; but [she]123-emma could not think of [her]111-harriet in [London]1-london without objects of curiosity and employment , which must be averting the past , and carrying [her]111-harriet out of [herself]123-emma .

[She]123-emma would not allow any other anxiety to succeed directly to the place in [her]123-emma mind which [Harriet]111-harriet had occupied . There was a communication before [her]123-emma , one which _ [she]123-emma _ only could be competent to make -- the confession of [her]123-emma engagement to [[her]123-emma father]425-her father ; but [she]123-emma would have nothing to do with it at present.--She had resolved to defer the disclosure till [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston were safe and well . No additional agitation should be thrown at this period among those [she]123-emma loved -- and the evil should not act on [herself]123-emma by anticipation before the appointed time.--A fortnight , at least , of leisure and peace of mind , to crown every warmer , but more agitating , delight , should be [hers]123-emma .

[She]123-emma soon resolved , equally as a duty and a pleasure , to employ half an hour of this holiday of spirits in calling on [Miss Fairfax.--She]2557-miss fairfax.--she ought to go -- and [she]123-emma was longing to see [her]111-harriet ; the resemblance of [their]2558-their present situations increasing every other motive of goodwill . It would be a _ secret _ satisfaction ; but the consciousness of a similarity of prospect would certainly add to the interest with which [she]123-emma should attend to any thing [Jane]152-miss fairfax might communicate .

[She]123-emma went -- [she]123-emma had driven once unsuccessfully to the door , but had not been into [the house]435-the house since the morning after [Box Hill]64-box hill , when poor [Jane]152-miss fairfax had been in such distress as had filled [her]152-miss fairfax with compassion , though all the worst of [her]152-miss fairfax sufferings had been unsuspected.--The fear of being still unwelcome , determined [her]152-miss fairfax , though assured of [their]2558-their being at [home]562-home , to wait in [the passage]3811-the passage , and send up [her]152-miss fairfax name.--She heard [Patty]196-patty announcing it ; but no such bustle succeeded as [poor Miss Bates]105-miss bates had before made so happily intelligible.--No ; [she]123-emma heard nothing but the instant reply of , “ Beg [her]105-miss bates to walk up;”--and[196-patty] a moment afterwards [she]123-emma was met on the stairs by [Jane]105-miss bates [herself]105-miss bates , coming eagerly forward , as if no other reception of [her]105-miss bates were felt sufficient.--Emma had never seen [her]105-miss bates look so well , so lovely , so engaging . There was consciousness , animation , and warmth ; there was every thing which [her]105-miss bates countenance or manner could ever have wanted.-- [She]105-miss bates came forward with an offered hand ; and said , in a low , but very feeling tone ,

“ This is most kind , indeed!--Miss [Woodhouse]123-emma , it is impossible for [me]105-miss bates to express -- [I]105-miss bates hope [you]123-emma will believe -- Excuse [me]105-miss bates for being so entirely without words . ”[105-miss bates]

[Emma]123-emma was gratified , and would soon have shewn no want of words , if the sound of [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton 's voice from the sitting - room had not checked [her]123-emma , and made it expedient to compress all [her]123-emma friendly and all [her]123-emma congratulatory sensations into a very , very earnest shake of the hand .

[Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates and [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton were together . [Miss Bates]105-miss bates was out , which accounted for the previous tranquillity . [Emma]123-emma could have wished [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton elsewhere ; but [she]123-emma was in a humour to have patience with every body ; and as [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton met [her]123-emma with unusual graciousness , [she]123-emma hoped [the rencontre]2562-the rencontre would do [them]2563-our no harm .

[She]123-emma soon believed [herself]123-emma to penetrate [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton 's thoughts , and understand why [she]123-emma was , like [herself]123-emma , in happy spirits ; it was being in [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax 's confidence , and fancying [herself]123-emma acquainted with what was still a secret to [other people]456-other people . [Emma]123-emma saw symptoms of it immediately in the expression of [her]123-emma face ; and while paying [her]123-emma own compliments to [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates , and appearing to attend to [the good old lady]1206-the good old lady 's replies , [she]123-emma saw [her]110-mrs. bates with a sort of anxious parade of mystery fold up a letter which [she]110-mrs. bates had apparently been reading aloud to [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax , and return it into the purple and gold reticule by [her]110-mrs. bates side , saying , with significant nods ,

“ [We]2563-our can finish this some other time , [you]110-mrs. bates know . [You]110-mrs. bates and [I]110-mrs. bates shall not want opportunities . And , in fact , [you]110-mrs. bates have heard all the essential already . [I]110-mrs. bates only wanted to prove to [you]110-mrs. bates that [Mrs. S.]370-mrs. s. admits [our]2563-our apology , and is not offended . [You]110-mrs. bates see how delightfully [she]370-mrs. s. writes . Oh ! [she]370-mrs. s. is [a sweet creature]5440-a sweet creature ! [You]110-mrs. bates would have doated on [her]370-mrs. s. , had [you]110-mrs. bates gone.--But not a word more . Let [us]2563-our be discreet -- quite on [our]2563-our good behaviour.--Hush!--You remember those lines -- [I]110-mrs. bates forget the poem at this moment :[110-mrs. bates]

“ For when [a lady]2918-a lady 's in the case , “[2566-you] [You]2566-you know all other things give place . ”[2566-you]

Now [I]0-my say , [[my]0-my dear]2714-my dear , in _ [our]2568-our _ case , for _ [lady]4976-lady _ , read----mum ! a word to the wise.--I am in a fine flow of spirits , an't [I]0-my ? But [I]0-my want to set [your]2714-my dear heart at ease as to [Mrs.]2570-mrs. S.--_My _ representation , [you]2714-my dear see , has quite appeased [her]2570-mrs. . ”[123-emma]

And again , on [Emma]123-emma 's merely turning [her]123-emma head to look at [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates 's knitting , [she]123-emma added , in a half whisper ,

“ [I]123-emma mentioned no _ names _ , [you]2714-my dear will observe.--Oh ! no ; cautious as [a minister of state]5442-a minister of state . [I]123-emma managed it extremely well . ”[123-emma]

[Emma]123-emma could not doubt . It was a palpable display , repeated on every possible occasion . When [they]2571-they had all talked a little while in harmony of the weather and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , [she]123-emma found [herself]123-emma abruptly addressed with ,

“ Do not [you]2714-my dear think , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [[our]2571-they saucy little friend]5443-our saucy little friend here is charmingly recovered?--Do not [you]2714-my dear think [her]2570-mrs. cure does [Perry]106-mr. perry the highest credit?--(here was a side - glance of great meaning at [Jane]152-miss fairfax . ) Upon [my]123-emma word , [Perry]106-mr. perry has restored [her]2570-mrs. in a wonderful short time!--Oh ! if [you]2714-my dear had seen [her]2570-mrs. , as [I]123-emma did , when [she]2570-mrs. was at the worst!”--And[123-emma] when [Mrs. Bates]110-mrs. bates was saying something to [Emma]123-emma , whispered farther , “ [We]2571-they do not say a word of any _ assistance _ that [Perry]106-mr. perry might have ; not a word of [a certain young physician from [Windsor.--Oh]80-windsor.--oh]5444-a certain young physician from windsor.--oh ! no ; [Perry]106-mr. perry shall have all the credit . ”[110-mrs. bates]

“ [I]110-mrs. bates have scarce had the pleasure of seeing [you]2714-my dear , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , ”[110-mrs. bates] [she]110-mrs. bates shortly afterwards began , “ since the party to [Box Hill]64-box hill . Very pleasant party . But yet [I]110-mrs. bates think there was something wanting . [Things]371-things did not seem -- that is , there seemed a little cloud upon the spirits of some.--So it appeared to [me]110-mrs. bates at least , but [I]110-mrs. bates might be mistaken . However , [I]110-mrs. bates think it answered so far as to tempt one to go again . Soon after this [Miss Bates]105-miss bates came in , and [Emma]123-emma could not help being diverted by the perplexity of [her]123-emma first answer to [herself]123-emma , resulting , [she]123-emma supposed , from doubt of what might be said , and impatience to say every thing .

“ Thank [you]2714-my dear , [dear Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , [you]2714-my dear are all kindness.--It is impossible to say -- Yes , indeed , [I]123-emma quite understand -- dearest [Jane]105-miss bates 's prospects -- that is , [I]123-emma do not mean.--But [she]105-miss bates is charmingly recovered.--How is [Mr. Woodhouse?--I]231-mr. woodhouse?--i am so glad.--Quite out of [my]123-emma power.--Such a happy little circle as [you]2714-my dear find [us]5446-us here.--Yes , [indeed.--Charming young man!--that]5447-indeed.--charming young man!--that is -- so very friendly ; [I]123-emma mean good [Mr. Perry!--such]372-mr. perry!--such attention to [Jane!”--And]373-jane!”--and[123-emma] from [her]123-emma great , [her]123-emma more than commonly thankful delight towards [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton for being [there]448-there , [Emma]123-emma guessed that there had been a little show of resentment towards [Jane]105-miss bates , from [the vicarage quarter]2573-the vicarage quarter , which was now graciously overcome.--After a few whispers , indeed , which placed it beyond a guess , [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , speaking louder , said ,

“ Yes , here [I]207-mrs. elton am , [[my]207-mrs. elton good friend]3942-my good friend ; and here [I]207-mrs. elton have been so long , that anywhere else [I]207-mrs. elton should think it necessary to apologise ; but , the truth is , that [I]207-mrs. elton am waiting for [[my]207-mrs. elton lord]4647-my lord and [master]4648-master . “ What ! are [we]5451-we to have the pleasure of a call from [Mr. Elton?--That]374-mr. elton?--that will be a favour indeed ! for [I]207-mrs. elton know [gentlemen]675-gentlemen do not like morning visits , and [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton 's time is so engaged . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ Upon [my]2574-i word it is , [Miss Bates.--He]375-miss bates.--he really is engaged from morning to night.--There is no end of [people]2986-people 's coming to [him]95-mr. elton , on some pretence or other.--The [magistrates]5454-magistrates , and [overseers]5455-overseers , and [churchwardens]5456-churchwardens , are always wanting [his]95-mr. elton opinion . [Miss Bates]105-miss bates looked about [her]105-miss bates , so happily-- !

“ [He]95-mr. elton promised to come to [me]105-miss bates as soon as [he]95-mr. elton could disengage [himself]95-mr. elton from [Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; but [he]95-mr. elton and [Knightley]92-mr. knightley are shut up together in deep consultation.--Mr . [Emma]123-emma would not have smiled for [the world]403-the world , and only said , “ Is [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton gone on foot to [Donwell?--He]81-donwell?--he will have a hot walk . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! no , it is a meeting at [the Crown]43-the crown , a regular meeting . “ Have not [you]95-mr. elton mistaken the day ? ”[123-emma] said [Emma]123-emma . “ [I]123-emma am almost certain that the meeting at [the Crown]43-the crown is not till to - morrow.--Mr . [Knightley]92-mr. knightley was at [Hartfield]2-hartfield yesterday , and spoke of it as for Saturday . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! no , the meeting is certainly to - day , ”[105-miss bates] was the abrupt answer , which denoted the impossibility of any blunder on [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton 's side.--“I do believe , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma continued , “ this is [the most troublesome parish that ever was]5461-the most troublesome parish that ever was . [We]5462-we never heard of such things at [Maple Grove]51-maple grove . ”[123-emma]

“ [[Your]95-mr. elton parish]5463-your parish there was small , ”[105-miss bates] said [Jane]105-miss bates .

“ Ah ! [you]95-mr. elton clever creature , that 's very true . What a thinking brain [you]95-mr. elton have ! It seemed an unnecessary caution ; [Jane]105-miss bates was wanting to give [her]105-miss bates words , not to [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , but to [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , as [the latter]1655-the latter plainly saw . The wish of distinguishing [her]105-miss bates , as far as civility permitted , was very evident , though it could not often proceed beyond a look .

[Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton made [his]95-mr. elton appearance . [[His]95-mr. elton lady]1858-his lady greeted [him]95-mr. elton with some of [her]1858-his lady sparkling vivacity .

“ Very pretty , [sir]2734-sir , upon [my]1858-his lady word ; to send [me]1858-his lady on [here]2707-here , to be an encumbrance to [[my]1858-his lady friends]2921-my friends , so long before [you]2734-sir vouchsafe to come!--But [you]2734-sir knew what a dutiful creature [you]2734-sir had to deal with . [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton was so hot and tired , that all this wit seemed thrown away . [His]95-mr. elton civilities to [the other ladies]1573-the other ladies must be paid ; but [his]95-mr. elton subsequent object was to lament over [himself]95-mr. elton for the heat [he]95-mr. elton was suffering , and the walk [he]95-mr. elton had had for nothing .

“ When [I]95-mr. elton got to [Donwell]24-donwell , ”[95-mr. elton] said [he]95-mr. elton , “ [Knightley]92-mr. knightley could not be found . Very odd ! very unaccountable ! after the note [I]95-mr. elton sent [him]92-mr. knightley this morning , and the message [he]92-mr. knightley returned , that [he]92-mr. knightley should certainly be at [home]562-home till one . ”[95-mr. elton]

“ [Donwell]24-donwell ! ”[95-mr. elton] cried [his]95-mr. elton wife.--“My dear [Mr. E.]255-mr. e. , [you]255-mr. e. have not been to [Donwell!--You]377-donwell!--you mean [the Crown]5478-the crown ; [you]255-mr. e. come from the meeting at [the Crown]43-the crown . ”[95-mr. elton]

“ No , no , that 's to - morrow ; and [I]95-mr. elton particularly wanted to see [Knightley]92-mr. knightley to - day on that very account.--Such a dreadful broiling morning!--I went over [the fields]5479-the fields too--(speaking in a tone of great ill - usage , ) which made it so much the worse . And then not to find [him]92-mr. knightley at [home]562-home ! [I]95-mr. elton assure [you]255-mr. e. [I]95-mr. elton am not at all pleased . And no apology left , no message for [me]95-mr. elton . [The housekeeper]883-the housekeeper declared [she]883-the housekeeper knew nothing of [my]95-mr. elton being expected.--Very extraordinary!--And [nobody]2718-nobody knew at all which way [he]92-mr. knightley was gone . Perhaps to [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse , perhaps to [the Abbey Mill]1347-the abbey mill , perhaps into [[his]92-mr. knightley woods.--Miss Woodhouse]5484-his woods.--miss woodhouse , this is not like [[our]5485-our friend]5486-our friend Knightley!--Can [you]95-mr. elton explain it ? ”[95-mr. elton]

[Emma]123-emma amused [herself]123-emma by protesting that it was very extraordinary , indeed , and that [she]123-emma had not a syllable to say for [him]2579-him .

“ [I]207-mrs. elton can not imagine , ”[207-mrs. elton] said [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , ( feeling the indignity as [a wife]2759-a wife ought to do , ) “ [I]207-mrs. elton can not imagine how [he]92-mr. knightley could do such a thing by [you]123-emma , of all people in [the world]403-the world ! [The very last person whom one]5488-the very last person whom one should expect to be forgotten!--My dear [Mr. E.]255-mr. e. , [he]92-mr. knightley must have left a message for [you]123-emma , [I]207-mrs. elton am sure [he]92-mr. knightley must.--Not even [Knightley]92-mr. knightley could be so very eccentric;--and [[his]92-mr. knightley servants]5489-his servants forgot it . Depend upon it , that was the case : and very likely to happen with [the Donwell servants]5490-the donwell servants , who are all , [I]207-mrs. elton have often observed , extremely awkward and remiss.--I am sure [I]207-mrs. elton would not have such a creature as [[his]92-mr. knightley Harry]5491-his harry stand at [our]5492-our sideboard for any consideration . And as for [Mrs. Hodges]235-mrs. hodges , [Wright]266-wright holds [her]235-mrs. hodges very cheap indeed.--She promised [Wright]266-wright a receipt , and never sent it . ”[207-mrs. elton]

“ [I]95-mr. elton met [William Larkins]234-william larkins , ”[95-mr. elton] continued [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , “ as [I]95-mr. elton got near [the house]435-the house , and [he]234-william larkins told [me]95-mr. elton [I]95-mr. elton should not find [[his]234-william larkins master]4212-his master at [home]562-home , but [I]95-mr. elton did not believe him.--William seemed rather out of humour . [He]234-william larkins did not know what was come to [[his]234-william larkins master]4212-his master lately , [he]234-william larkins said , but [he]234-william larkins could hardly ever get the speech of [him]234-william larkins . [I]95-mr. elton have nothing to do with [William]234-william larkins 's wants , but it really is of very great importance that _ [I]95-mr. elton _ should see [Knightley]92-mr. knightley to - day ; and it becomes a matter , therefore , of very serious inconvenience that [I]95-mr. elton should have had this hot walk to no purpose . ”[95-mr. elton]

[Emma]123-emma felt that [she]123-emma could not do better than go [home]562-home directly . In all probability [she]123-emma was at this very time waited for there ; and [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley might be preserved from sinking deeper in aggression towards [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton , if not towards [William Larkins]234-william larkins .

[She]123-emma was pleased , on taking leave , to find [Miss Fairfax]152-miss fairfax determined to attend [her]123-emma out of [the room]701-the room , to go with [her]123-emma even [downstairs]1377-downstairs ; it gave [her]123-emma an opportunity which [she]123-emma immediately made use of , to say ,

“ It is as well , perhaps , that [I]123-emma have not had the possibility . Had [you]152-miss fairfax not been surrounded by [other friends]5497-other friends , [I]123-emma might have been tempted to introduce a subject , to ask questions , to speak more openly than might have been strictly [correct.--I]123-emma feel that [I]123-emma should certainly have been impertinent . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! ”[152-miss fairfax] cried [Jane]152-miss fairfax , with a blush and an hesitation which [Emma]123-emma thought infinitely more becoming to [her]152-miss fairfax than all the elegance of all [her]152-miss fairfax usual composure--“there would have been no danger . The danger would have been of [my]152-miss fairfax wearying [you]152-miss fairfax . [You]152-miss fairfax could not have gratified [me]152-miss fairfax more than by expressing an interest-- . Indeed , [Miss Woodhouse]93-miss woodhouse , ( speaking more collectedly , ) with the consciousness which [I]152-miss fairfax have of misconduct , very great misconduct , it is particularly consoling to [me]152-miss fairfax to know that [those of [[my]152-miss fairfax friends]2921-my friends , whose good opinion is most worth preserving]5498-those of my friends , whose good opinion is most worth preserving , are not disgusted to such a degree as to -- [I]152-miss fairfax have not time for half that [I]152-miss fairfax could wish to say . [I]152-miss fairfax long to make apologies , excuses , to urge something for [myself]152-miss fairfax . [I]152-miss fairfax feel it so very due . But , unfortunately -- in short , if [your]152-miss fairfax compassion does not stand [my]152-miss fairfax friend-- ”[152-miss fairfax]

“ Oh ! [you]152-miss fairfax are too scrupulous , indeed [you]152-miss fairfax are , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma warmly , and taking [her]2584-her hand . “ [You]152-miss fairfax owe [me]123-emma no apologies ; and every body to whom [you]152-miss fairfax might be supposed to owe [them]5500-them , is so perfectly satisfied , so delighted even-- ”[123-emma]

“ [You]152-miss fairfax are very kind , but [I]152-miss fairfax know what [my]152-miss fairfax manners were to you.--So cold and artificial!--I had always a part to act.--It was a life of deceit!--I know that [I]152-miss fairfax must have disgusted [you]152-miss fairfax . ”[152-miss fairfax]

“ Pray say no more . [I]123-emma feel that all the apologies should be on [my]123-emma side . Let [us]5501-we forgive [each other]430-each other at once . [We]5501-we must do whatever is to be done quickest , and [I]123-emma think [our]5501-we feelings will lose no time there . [I]123-emma hope [you]152-miss fairfax have pleasant accounts from [Windsor]75-windsor ? ”[123-emma]

“ Very . ”[152-miss fairfax]

“ And the next news , [I]123-emma suppose , will be , that [we]5501-we are to lose [you]152-miss fairfax -- just as [I]123-emma begin to know [you]152-miss fairfax . ”[123-emma]

“ Oh ! as to all that , of course nothing can be thought of yet . [I]152-miss fairfax am here till claimed by [Colonel]164-colonel campbell and [Mrs. Campbell]164-colonel campbell . ”[152-miss fairfax]

“ Nothing can be actually settled yet , perhaps , ”[123-emma] replied [Emma]123-emma , smiling--“but , excuse [me]123-emma , it must be thought of . ”[123-emma]

The smile was returned as [Jane]152-miss fairfax answered ,

“ [You]152-miss fairfax are very right ; it has been thought of . And [I]152-miss fairfax will own to [you]152-miss fairfax , ( [I]152-miss fairfax am sure it will be safe ) , that so far as [our]5501-we living with [Mr. Churchill]102-frank churchill at [Enscombe]7-enscombe , it is settled . There must be three months , at least , of deep mourning ; but when they are over , [I]152-miss fairfax imagine there will be nothing more to wait for . ”[152-miss fairfax]

“ Thank [you]152-miss fairfax , thank you.--This is just what [I]123-emma wanted to be assured of.--Oh ! if [you]152-miss fairfax knew how much [I]123-emma love every thing that is decided and open!--Good - bye , good - bye . ”[123-emma]

CHAPTER XVII

[[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston 's friends]2585-mrs. weston 's friends were all made happy by [her]88-mrs. weston safety ; and if the satisfaction of [her]88-mrs. weston well - doing could be increased to [Emma]123-emma , it was by knowing [her]88-mrs. weston to be [the mother of [a little girl]2587-a little girl]2586-the mother of a little girl . [She]123-emma had been decided in wishing for [a Miss Weston]379-a miss weston . [She]123-emma would not acknowledge that it was with any view of making a match for [her]123-emma , hereafter , with [either of [[Isabella]87-isabella 's sons]2589-isabella 's sons]2588-either of isabella 's sons ; but [she]123-emma was convinced that [a daughter]2306-a daughter would suit both [father]3777-father and [mother]3738-mother best . It would be a great comfort to [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston , as [he]86-mr. weston grew older -- and even [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston might be growing older ten years hence -- to have [his]86-mr. weston fireside enlivened by the sports and the nonsense , the freaks and the fancies of [a child]497-a child never banished from [home]562-home ; and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston -- [no one]3090-no one could doubt that [a daughter]2306-a daughter would be most to [her]88-mrs. weston ; and it would be quite a pity that any one who so well knew how to teach , should not have [their]2597-their powers in exercise again .

“ [She]88-mrs. weston has had the advantage , [you]92-mr. knightley know , of practising on [me]123-emma , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma continued--“like [La Baronne]380-la baronne d'Almane on [La Comtesse]381-la comtesse d'Ostalis , in [Madame de Genlis]382-madame de genlis ' Adelaide and [Theodore]383-theodore , and [we]5503-we shall now see [her]88-mrs. weston own little [Adelaide]384-adelaide educated on a more perfect plan . ”[123-emma]

“ That is , ”[92-mr. knightley] replied [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , “ [she]88-mrs. weston will indulge [her]88-mrs. weston even more than [she]88-mrs. weston did [you]92-mr. knightley , and believe that [she]88-mrs. weston does not indulge [her]88-mrs. weston at all . It will be the only difference . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [Poor child]5504-poor child ! ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma ; “ at that rate , what will become of [her]88-mrs. weston ? ”[123-emma]

“ Nothing very bad.--The fate of [thousands]5505-thousands . [She]88-mrs. weston will be disagreeable in infancy , and correct [herself]88-mrs. weston as [she]88-mrs. weston grows older . [I]123-emma am losing all [my]123-emma bitterness against [spoilt children]5506-spoilt children , [[my]123-emma dearest]2979-my dearest [Emma]123-emma . [Emma]123-emma laughed , and replied : “ But [I]123-emma had the assistance of all [your]92-mr. knightley endeavours to counteract the indulgence of [other people]456-other people . [I]123-emma doubt whether [my]123-emma own sense would have corrected [me]123-emma without it . ”[123-emma]

“ Do you?--I have no doubt . [Nature]385-nature gave [you]92-mr. knightley understanding:--Miss [Taylor]84-miss woodhouse gave [you]92-mr. knightley principles . [You]92-mr. knightley must have done well . [My]123-emma interference was quite as likely to do harm as good . It was very natural for [you]92-mr. knightley to say , what right has [he]5509-he to lecture me?--and [I]123-emma am afraid very natural for [you]92-mr. knightley to feel that it was done in a disagreeable manner . [I]123-emma do not believe [I]123-emma did [you]92-mr. knightley any good . The good was all to [myself]123-emma , by making [you]92-mr. knightley an object of the tenderest affection to [me]123-emma . [I]123-emma could not think about [you]92-mr. knightley so much without doating on [you]92-mr. knightley , faults and all ; and by dint of fancying so many errors , have been in love with [you]92-mr. knightley ever since [you]92-mr. knightley were thirteen at least . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]123-emma am sure [you]92-mr. knightley were of use to [me]123-emma , ”[123-emma] cried [Emma]123-emma . “ [I]123-emma was very often influenced rightly by [you]92-mr. knightley -- oftener than [I]123-emma would own at the time . [I]123-emma am very sure [you]92-mr. knightley did [me]123-emma good . And if poor little [Anna Weston]386-anna weston is to be spoiled , it will be the greatest humanity in [you]92-mr. knightley to do as much for [her]386-anna weston as [you]92-mr. knightley have done for [me]123-emma , except falling in love with [her]386-anna weston when [she]386-anna weston is thirteen . ”[123-emma]

“ How often , when [you]92-mr. knightley were [a girl]2892-a girl , have [you]92-mr. knightley said to [me]123-emma , with one of [your]92-mr. knightley saucy looks--'Mr . “ What [an amiable creature]5512-an amiable creature [I]123-emma was!--No wonder [you]92-mr. knightley should hold [my]123-emma speeches in such affectionate remembrance . ”[123-emma]

“ ' [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . '--You always called [me]123-emma , ' [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; ' and , from habit , it has not so very formal a sound.--And yet it is formal . “ [I]123-emma remember once calling [you]92-mr. knightley ' [George]126-george , ' in one of [my]123-emma amiable fits , about ten years ago . “ [Impossible!--I]387-impossible!--i never can call [you]92-mr. knightley any thing but ' [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . [Emma]123-emma grieved that [she]123-emma could not be more openly just to one important service which [his]2599-his better sense would have rendered [her]123-emma , to the advice which would have saved [her]123-emma from the worst of all [her]123-emma womanly follies -- [her]123-emma wilful intimacy with [Harriet Smith]111-harriet ; but it was too tender a subject.--She could not enter on it.--Harriet was very seldom mentioned between [them]2600-them . This , on [his]2599-his side , might merely proceed from [her]123-emma not being thought of ; but [Emma]123-emma was rather inclined to attribute it to delicacy , and a suspicion , from some appearances , that [their]2600-them friendship were declining . [She]123-emma was aware [herself]123-emma , that , parting under any other circumstances , [they]2600-them certainly should have corresponded more , and that [her]123-emma intelligence would not have rested , as it now almost wholly did , on [Isabella]87-isabella 's letters . [He]2599-his might observe that it was so . The pain of being obliged to practise concealment towards [him]2599-his , was very little inferior to the pain of having made [Harriet]111-harriet unhappy .

[Isabella]87-isabella sent quite as good an account of [[her]87-isabella visitor]1760-her visitor as could be expected ; on [her]87-isabella first arrival [she]87-isabella had thought [her]87-isabella out of spirits , which appeared perfectly natural , as there was [a dentist to be consulted]2602-a dentist to be consulted ; but , since that business had been over , [she]87-isabella did not appear to find [Harriet]111-harriet different from what [she]87-isabella had known [[her]87-isabella before.--Isabella]2603-her before.--isabella , to be sure , was [no very quick observer]2604-no very quick observer ; yet if [Harriet]111-harriet had not been equal to playing with [the children]591-the children , it would not have escaped [her]111-harriet . [Emma]123-emma 's comforts and hopes were most agreeably carried on , by [Harriet]111-harriet 's being to stay longer ; [her]111-harriet fortnight was likely to be a month at least . [Mr.]2606-mr. and [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley were to come down in August , and [she]123-emma was invited to remain till [they]2607-they could bring [her]123-emma back .

“ [John]122-mrs. john knightley does not even mention [[your]123-emma friend]2922-your friend , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . “ Here is [his]92-mr. knightley answer , if [you]123-emma like to see it . ”[92-mr. knightley]

It was the answer to the communication of [his]92-mr. knightley intended marriage . “ [John]92-mr. knightley enters like [a brother]5515-a brother into [my]92-mr. knightley happiness , ”[92-mr. knightley] continued [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , “ but [he]92-mr. knightley is [no complimenter]5516-no complimenter ; and though [I]92-mr. knightley well know [him]92-mr. knightley to have , likewise , a most brotherly affection for [you]123-emma , [he]92-mr. knightley is so far from making flourishes , that [any other young woman]5517-any other young woman might think [him]92-mr. knightley rather cool in [her]5517-any other young woman praise . “ [He]92-mr. knightley writes like [a sensible man]2966-a sensible man , ”[123-emma] replied [Emma]123-emma , when [she]123-emma had read the letter . “ [I]123-emma honour [his]92-mr. knightley sincerity . “ [[My]92-mr. knightley Emma]3544-my emma , [he]92-mr. knightley means no such thing . [He]92-mr. knightley only means-- ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [He]92-mr. knightley and [I]2609-i should differ very little in [our]5520-our estimation of [the two]3078-the two , ”[2609-i] interrupted [she]2609-i , with a sort of serious smile--“much less , perhaps , than [he]92-mr. knightley is aware of , if [we]5520-our could enter without ceremony or reserve on the subject . ”[2609-i]

“ [Emma]123-emma , [[my]92-mr. knightley dear]2714-my dear [Emma--]389-emma-- ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Ah ! ”[2609-i] [he]2609-i cried , “ [I]2609-i wish [[your]123-emma father]3597-your father might be half as easily convinced as [John]92-mr. knightley will be , of [our]5526-our having every right that equal worth can give , to be happy together . “ If [I]2609-i understand [[your]123-emma brother]3332-your brother , [he]92-mr. knightley only means so far as [your]123-emma having some thoughts of marrying . [He]92-mr. knightley had no idea of [me]2609-i . [He]92-mr. knightley seems perfectly unprepared for that . ”[2609-i]

“ Yes , yes -- but [I]2609-i am amused that [he]92-mr. knightley should have seen so far into [my]2609-i feelings . What has [he]92-mr. knightley been judging by?--I am not conscious of any difference in [my]2609-i spirits or conversation that could prepare [him]92-mr. knightley at this time for [my]2609-i marrying any more than at another.--But it was so , [I]2609-i suppose . The time was coming when the news must spread farther , and [other persons]2610-other persons ' reception of it tried . As soon as [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was sufficiently recovered to admit [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's visits , [Emma]123-emma having it in view that [her]123-emma gentle reasonings should be employed in the cause , resolved first to announce it at [home]562-home , and then at [Randalls.--But]390-randalls.--but how to break it to [[her]123-emma father]425-her father at last!--She had bound [herself]123-emma to do it , in such an hour of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's absence , or when it came to the point [her]123-emma heart would have failed [her]123-emma , and [she]123-emma must have put it off ; but [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley was to come at such a time , and follow up the beginning [she]123-emma was to make.--She was forced to speak , and to speak cheerfully too . [She]123-emma must not make it a more decided subject of misery to [him]92-mr. knightley , by a melancholy tone [herself]123-emma . [She]123-emma must not appear to think it a misfortune.--With all the spirits [she]123-emma could command , [she]123-emma prepared [him]92-mr. knightley first for something strange , and then , in a few words , said , that if [his]92-mr. knightley consent and approbation could be obtained -- which , [she]123-emma trusted , would be attended with no difficulty , since it was a plan to promote the happiness of all -- [she]123-emma and [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley meant to marry ; by which means [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse would receive the constant addition of [[that person]2613-that person 's company whom [she]123-emma knew [he]92-mr. knightley loved]2614-that person 's company whom she knew he loved , next to [[his]92-mr. knightley daughters]977-his daughters and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , best in [the world]403-the world .

[Poor man!--it]85-mr. woodhouse was at first a considerable shock to [him]92-mr. knightley , and [he]92-mr. knightley tried earnestly to dissuade [her]123-emma from it . [She]123-emma was reminded , more than once , of having always said [she]123-emma would never marry , and assured that it would be a great deal better for [her]123-emma to remain single ; and told of [poor Isabella]87-isabella , and [poor Miss Taylor.--But]391-poor miss taylor.--but it would not do . [Emma]123-emma hung about [him]92-mr. knightley affectionately , and smiled , and said it must be so ; and that [he]92-mr. knightley must not class [her]123-emma with [Isabella]87-isabella and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , whose marriages taking [them]2617-they from [Hartfield]2-hartfield , had , indeed , made a melancholy change : but [she]123-emma was not going from [Hartfield]2-hartfield ; [she]123-emma should be always [there]448-there ; [she]123-emma was introducing no change in [their]2617-they numbers or [their]2617-they comforts but for the better ; and [she]123-emma was very sure that [he]92-mr. knightley would be a great deal the happier for having [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley always at hand , when [he]92-mr. knightley were once got used to the idea.--Did [he]92-mr. knightley not love [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley very much?--He would not deny that [he]92-mr. knightley did , [she]123-emma was sure.--Whom did [he]92-mr. knightley ever want to consult on business but [Mr. Knightley?--Who]392-mr. knightley?--who was so useful to [him]92-mr. knightley , who so ready to write [his]92-mr. knightley letters , who so glad to assist [him?--Who]92-mr. knightley so cheerful , so attentive , so attached to him?--Would not [he]92-mr. knightley like to have [him]92-mr. knightley always on the spot?--Yes . That was all very true . [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley could not be there too often ; [he]92-mr. knightley should be glad to see [him]92-mr. knightley every day;--but [they]2617-they did see [him]92-mr. knightley every day as it was.--Why could not [they]2617-they go on as [they]2617-they had done ?

[Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse could not be soon reconciled ; but the worst was overcome , the idea was given ; time and continual repetition must do the rest.--To [Emma]123-emma 's entreaties and assurances succeeded [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley 's , whose fond praise of [her]123-emma gave the subject even a kind of welcome ; and [he]92-mr. knightley was soon used to be talked to by each , on every fair occasion.--They had all the assistance which [Isabella]87-isabella could give , by letters of the strongest approbation ; and [Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was ready , on the first meeting , to consider the subject in the most serviceable light -- first , as a settled , and , secondly , as a good one -- well aware of the nearly equal importance of the two recommendations to [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse 's mind.--It was agreed upon , as what was to be ; and every body by whom [he]92-mr. knightley was used to be guided assuring [him]92-mr. knightley that it would be for [his]92-mr. knightley happiness ; and having some feelings [himself]92-mr. knightley which almost admitted it , [he]92-mr. knightley began to think that some time or other -- in another year or two , perhaps -- it might not be so very bad if the marriage did take place .

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston was acting no part , feigning no feelings in all that [she]88-mrs. weston said to [him]92-mr. knightley in favour of the event.--She had been extremely surprized , never more so , than when [Emma]123-emma first opened the affair to [her]88-mrs. weston ; but [she]88-mrs. weston saw in it only increase of happiness to all , and had no scruple in urging [him]92-mr. knightley to the utmost.--She had such a regard for [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , as to think [he]92-mr. knightley deserved even [her]88-mrs. weston dearest Emma ; and it was in every respect so proper , suitable , and unexceptionable a connexion , and in one respect , one point of the highest importance , so peculiarly eligible , so singularly fortunate , that now it seemed as if [Emma]123-emma could not safely have attached [herself]123-emma to [any other creature]2619-any other creature , and that [she]123-emma had [herself]123-emma been the stupidest of [beings in not having thought of it]2620-beings in not having thought of it , and wished it long ago.--How [very few of [those men in a rank of life]2622-those men in a rank of life]2621-very few of those men in a rank of life to address [Emma]123-emma would have renounced [[their]2621-very few of those men in a rank of life own home for [Hartfield]93-miss woodhouse]2623-their own home for hartfield ! And who but [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley could know and bear with [Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse , so as to make such an arrangement desirable!--The difficulty of disposing of [poor Mr. Woodhouse]85-mr. woodhouse had been always felt in [[her]88-mrs. weston husband]441-her husband 's plans and [her]88-mrs. weston own , for a marriage between [Frank]102-frank churchill and [Emma]123-emma . How to settle the claims of [Enscombe]7-enscombe and [Hartfield]2-hartfield had been a continual impediment -- less acknowledged by [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston than by [herself]88-mrs. weston -- but even [he]441-her husband had never been able to finish the subject better than by saying--“Those matters will take care of [themselves]5532-themselves ; [the young people]1723-the young people will find a way . ”[441-her husband] But here there was nothing to be shifted off in a wild speculation on the future . It was all right , all open , all equal . No sacrifice on any side worth the name . It was a union of the highest promise of felicity in itself , and without one real , rational difficulty to oppose or delay it .

[Mrs. Weston]88-mrs. weston , with [[her]88-mrs. weston baby]2625-her baby on [her]88-mrs. weston knee , indulging in such reflections as these , was one of [the happiest women in [the world]403-the world]2626-the happiest women in the world . If any thing could increase [her]88-mrs. weston delight , it was perceiving that [the baby]946-the baby would soon have outgrown its first set of caps .

The news was universally a surprize wherever it spread ; and [Mr. Weston]86-mr. weston had [his]86-mr. weston five minutes share of it ; but five minutes were enough to familiarise the idea to [his]86-mr. weston quickness of mind.--He saw the advantages of the match , and rejoiced in them with all the constancy of [[his]86-mr. weston wife]2763-his wife ; but the wonder of it was very soon nothing ; and by the end of an hour [he]86-mr. weston was not far from believing that [he]86-mr. weston had always foreseen it .

“ It is to be a secret , [I]86-mr. weston conclude , ”[86-mr. weston] said [he]86-mr. weston . “ These matters are always a secret , till it is found out that [every body]2749-every body knows them . Only let [me]86-mr. weston be told when [I]86-mr. weston may speak out.--I wonder whether [Jane]152-miss fairfax has any suspicion . ”[86-mr. weston]

[He]86-mr. weston went to [Highbury]3-highbury the next morning , and satisfied [himself]86-mr. weston on that point . [He]86-mr. weston told [her]2763-his wife the news . Was not [she]2763-his wife like [a daughter]2306-a daughter , [[his]86-mr. weston eldest]2631-his eldest daughter?--he must tell [her]2763-his wife ; and [Miss Bates]105-miss bates being present , it passed , of course , to [Mrs. Cole]185-mrs. cole , [Mrs. Perry]104-mrs. perry , and [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton , immediately afterwards . It was no more than [the principals]2632-the principals were prepared for ; [they]2632-the principals had calculated from the time of its being known at [Randalls]101-randalls , how soon it would be over [Highbury]3-highbury ; and were thinking of [themselves]2632-the principals , as the evening wonder in many a family circle , with great sagacity .

In general , it was a very well approved match . [Some]4385-some might think [him]86-mr. weston , and [others]2773-others might think [her]2763-his wife , the most in luck . [One set]2635-one set might recommend [their]2632-the principals all removing to [Donwell]24-donwell , and leaving [Hartfield]2-hartfield for [the John Knightleys]393-the john knightleys ; and another might predict disagreements among [[their]2632-the principals servants]5007-their servants ; but yet , upon the whole , there was no serious objection raised , except in one habitation , [the Vicarage.--There]2637-the vicarage.--there , the surprize was not softened by any satisfaction . [Mr. Elton]95-mr. elton cared little about it , compared with [[his]95-mr. elton wife]2763-his wife ; [he]95-mr. elton only hoped “ [the young lady]3152-the young lady 's pride would now be contented ; ”[95-mr. elton] and supposed “ [she]3152-the young lady had always meant to catch [Knightley]92-mr. knightley if [she]3152-the young lady could ; ”[95-mr. elton] and , on the point of living at [Hartfield]2-hartfield , could daringly exclaim , “ Rather [he]92-mr. knightley than I!”--But[95-mr. elton] [Mrs. Elton]207-mrs. elton was very much discomposed indeed.--“Poor [Knightley]92-mr. knightley ! poor fellow!--sad business for [him]95-mr. elton . ”--She[95-mr. elton] was extremely concerned ; for , though very eccentric , [he]95-mr. elton had a thousand good qualities.--How could [he]95-mr. elton be so taken in?--Did not think [him]95-mr. elton at all in love -- not in the least.--Poor [Knightley!--There]394-knightley!--there would be an end of all pleasant intercourse with [him.--How]2639-him.--how happy [he]95-mr. elton had been to come and dine with [them]2639-him.--how whenever [they]2639-him.--how asked [him]95-mr. elton ! But that would be all over now.--Poor fellow!--No more exploring parties to [Donwell]24-donwell made for _ [her]207-mrs. elton _ . Oh ! no ; there would be a [Mrs. Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley to throw cold water on every thing.--Extremely disagreeable ! But [she]207-mrs. elton was not at all sorry that [she]207-mrs. elton had abused [the housekeeper]883-the housekeeper the other day.--Shocking plan , living together . It would never do . [She]207-mrs. elton knew [a family near [Maple Grove]51-maple grove]2641-a family near maple grove who had [tried it , and been obliged to separate before the end of the first quarter]2642-tried it , and been obliged to separate before the end of the first quarter .

CHAPTER XVIII

Time passed on . A few more to - morrows , and [the party from [London]1-london]2643-the party from london would be arriving . It was an alarming change ; and [Emma]123-emma was thinking of it one morning , as what must bring a great deal to agitate and grieve [her]123-emma , when [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley came in , and distressing thoughts were put by . After the first chat of pleasure [he]92-mr. knightley was silent ; and then , in a graver tone , began with ,

“ [I]92-mr. knightley have something to tell [you]123-emma , [Emma]123-emma ; some news . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Good or bad ? ”[123-emma] said [she]123-emma , quickly , looking up in [his]92-mr. knightley face .

“ [I]92-mr. knightley do not know which it ought to be called . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Oh ! good [I]92-mr. knightley am sure.--I see it in [your]92-mr. knightley countenance . [You]92-mr. knightley are trying not to smile . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley am afraid , ”[92-mr. knightley] said [he]92-mr. knightley , composing [his]92-mr. knightley features , “ [I]92-mr. knightley am very much afraid , [[my]92-mr. knightley dear]2714-my dear [Emma]123-emma , that [you]123-emma will not smile when [you]123-emma hear it . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Indeed ! but why [so?--I]92-mr. knightley can hardly imagine that any thing which pleases or amuses [you]123-emma , should not please and amuse [me]92-mr. knightley too . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ There is one subject , ”[92-mr. knightley] [he]92-mr. knightley replied , “ [I]92-mr. knightley hope but one , on which [we]5537-we do not think alike . ”[92-mr. knightley] [He]92-mr. knightley paused a moment , again smiling , with [his]92-mr. knightley eyes fixed on [her]2644-her face . “ Does nothing occur to you?--Do not [you]123-emma recollect?--Harriet [Smith]111-harriet . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Her]2644-her cheeks flushed at the name , and [she]2644-her felt afraid of something , though [she]2644-her knew not what .

“ Have [you]123-emma heard from [her]2644-her [yourself]123-emma this morning ? ”[92-mr. knightley] cried [he]92-mr. knightley . “ [You]123-emma have , [I]92-mr. knightley believe , and know the whole . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ No , [I]123-emma have not ; [I]123-emma know nothing ; pray tell [me]123-emma . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]123-emma are prepared for the worst , [I]92-mr. knightley see -- and very bad it is . [Harriet Smith]111-harriet marries [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma gave a start , which did not seem like being prepared -- and [her]123-emma eyes , in eager gaze , said , “ No , this is impossible ! ”[123-emma] but [her]123-emma lips were closed .

“ It is so , indeed , ”[92-mr. knightley] continued [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; “ [I]92-mr. knightley have it from [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin [himself]116-mr. martin . [He]116-mr. martin left [me]92-mr. knightley not half an hour ago . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[She]123-emma was still looking at [him]92-mr. knightley with the most speaking amazement .

“ [You]92-mr. knightley like it , [[my]123-emma Emma]3544-my emma , as little as [I]123-emma feared.--I wish [our]5539-our opinions were the same . But in time they will . Time , [you]92-mr. knightley may be sure , will make one or the other of [us]5539-our think differently ; and , in the meanwhile , [we]5539-our need not talk much on the subject . ”[123-emma]

“ [You]92-mr. knightley mistake [me]123-emma , [you]92-mr. knightley quite mistake [me]123-emma , ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma replied , exerting [herself]123-emma . “ It is not that such a circumstance would now make [me]123-emma unhappy , but [I]123-emma can not believe it . It seems [an impossibility!--You]5540-an impossibility!--you can not mean to say , that [Harriet Smith]111-harriet has accepted [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin . [You]92-mr. knightley can not mean that [he]116-mr. martin has even proposed to [her]111-harriet again -- yet . [You]92-mr. knightley only mean , that [he]116-mr. martin intends it . ”[123-emma]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley mean that [he]116-mr. martin has done it , ”[92-mr. knightley] answered [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , with smiling but determined decision , “ and been accepted . ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Good God ! ”[123-emma] [she]123-emma cried.--“Well!”--Then having recourse to [her]123-emma workbasket , in excuse for leaning down [her]123-emma face , and concealing all the exquisite feelings of delight and entertainment which [she]123-emma knew [she]123-emma must be expressing , [she]123-emma added , “[92-mr. knightley] Well , now tell [me]0-my every thing ; make this intelligible to [me]0-my . How , where , when?--Let [me]0-my know it all . [I]0-my never was more surprized -- but it does not make [me]0-my unhappy , [I]0-my assure you.--How -- how has it been possible ? ”[123-emma]

“ It is a very simple story . [He]116-mr. martin went to [town]2760-town on business three days ago , and [I]2645-i got [him]116-mr. martin to take charge of some papers which [I]2645-i was wanting to send to [John.--He]395-john.--he delivered these papers to [John]92-mr. knightley , at [[his]92-mr. knightley chambers]5542-his chambers , and was asked by [him]92-mr. knightley to join [their]5543-their party the same evening to [Astley]396-astley 's . [They]5543-their were going to take [the two eldest boys]5544-the two eldest boys to [[Astley]396-astley 's]5545-astley 's . [[My]2645-i friend]3149-my friend [Robert]116-mr. martin could not resist . [They]5543-their called for [him]116-mr. martin in [their]5543-their way ; were all extremely amused ; and [[my]2645-i brother]2939-my brother asked [him]116-mr. martin to dine with [them]5543-their the next day -- which [he]116-mr. martin did -- and in the course of that visit ( as [I]2645-i understand ) [he]116-mr. martin found an opportunity of speaking to [Harriet]111-harriet ; and certainly did not speak in vain.--She made [him]116-mr. martin , by [her]111-harriet acceptance , as happy even as [he]116-mr. martin is deserving . [He]116-mr. martin came down by [yesterday 's coach]5550-yesterday 's coach , and was with [me]2645-i this morning immediately after breakfast , to report [his]116-mr. martin proceedings , first on [my]2645-i affairs , and then on [his]116-mr. martin own . This is all that [I]2645-i can relate of the how , where , and when . [[Your]2645-i friend]2922-your friend [Harriet]111-harriet will make a much longer history when [you]2645-i see her.--She will give [you]2645-i all the minute particulars , which [only woman]5552-only woman 's language can make interesting.--In [our]5553-our communications [we]5553-our deal only in the great.--However , [I]2645-i must say , that [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin 's heart seemed for _ [him]116-mr. martin _ , and to _ [me]2645-i _ , very overflowing ; and that [he]116-mr. martin did mention , without its being much to the purpose , that on quitting [[their]5554-their box at [Astley 's]396-astley]5555-their box at astley 's , [[my]2645-i brother]2939-my brother took charge of [Mrs. John Knightley]122-mrs. john knightley and [little John]122-mrs. john knightley , and [he]2939-my brother followed with [Miss Smith]111-harriet and [Henry]125-henry ; and that at one time [they]5554-their were in such a crowd , as to make [Miss Smith]111-harriet rather uneasy . ”[2645-i]

[He]2645-i stopped.--Emma dared not attempt any immediate reply . To speak , [she]2646-you was sure would be to betray a most unreasonable degree of happiness . [She]2646-you must wait a moment , or [he]2645-i would think [her]2646-you mad . [Her]2646-you silence disturbed [him]2645-i ; and after observing [her]2646-you a little while , [he]2645-i added ,

“ [Emma]123-emma , [[my]2645-i love]3321-my love , [you]2646-you said that this circumstance would not now make [you]2646-you unhappy ; but [I]2645-i am afraid it gives [you]2646-you more pain than [you]2646-you expected . [His]2645-i situation is an evil -- but [you]2646-you must consider it as what satisfies [[your]2646-you friend]2922-your friend ; and [I]2645-i will answer for [your]2646-you thinking better and better of [him]2645-i as [you]2646-you know [him]2645-i more . [His]2645-i good sense and good principles would delight you.--As far as [the man]3033-the man is concerned , [you]2646-you could not wish [[your]2646-you friend]2922-your friend in better hands . [His]2645-i rank in [society]4763-society [I]2645-i would alter if [I]2645-i could , which is saying a great deal [I]2645-i assure [you]2646-you , [Emma.--You]397-emma.--you laugh at [me]2645-i about [William Larkins]234-william larkins ; but [I]2645-i could quite as ill spare [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin . ”[2645-i]

[He]2647-i wanted [her]2648-her to look up and smile ; and having now brought [herself]2648-her not to smile too broadly -- [she]2648-her did -- cheerfully answering ,

“ [You]2647-i need not be at any pains to reconcile [me]2647-i to the match . [I]2647-i think [Harriet]111-harriet is doing extremely well . _ [Her]111-harriet _ connexions may be worse than _ [his]2645-i _ . In respectability of character , there can be no doubt that they are . [I]2647-i have been silent from surprize merely , excessive surprize . [You]2646-you can not imagine how suddenly it has come on [me]2647-i ! how peculiarly unprepared [I]2647-i was!--for [I]2647-i had reason to believe [her]111-harriet very lately more determined against [him]2645-i , much more , than [she]111-harriet was before . ”[2647-i]

“ [You]2646-you ought to know [[your]2646-you friend]2922-your friend best , ”[92-mr. knightley] replied [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley ; “ but [I]92-mr. knightley should say [she]111-harriet was [a good - tempered , soft - hearted girl]5563-a good - tempered , soft - hearted girl , not likely to be very , very determined against [any young man who told [her]111-harriet [he]2645-i loved [her]111-harriet]5564-any young man who told her he loved her . ”[92-mr. knightley]

[Emma]123-emma could not help laughing as [she]123-emma answered , “ Upon [my]123-emma word , [I]123-emma believe [you]92-mr. knightley know [her]111-harriet quite as well as [I]123-emma do.--But , [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley , are [you]92-mr. knightley perfectly sure that [she]111-harriet has absolutely and downright _ accepted _ [him]2645-i . [I]123-emma could suppose [she]111-harriet might in time -- but can [she]111-harriet already?--Did not [you]92-mr. knightley misunderstand him?--You were both talking of other things ; of business , shows of cattle , or new drills -- and might not [you]92-mr. knightley , in the confusion of so many subjects , mistake him?--It was not [Harriet]111-harriet 's hand that [he]2645-i was certain of -- it was the dimensions of some famous ox . ”[123-emma]

The contrast between the countenance and air of [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley and [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin was , at this moment , so strong to [Emma]123-emma 's feelings , and so strong was the recollection of all that had so recently passed on [Harriet]111-harriet 's side , so fresh the sound of those words , spoken with such emphasis , “ No , [I]123-emma hope [I]123-emma know better than to think of [Robert Martin]116-mr. martin , ”[123-emma] that [she]123-emma was really expecting the intelligence to prove , in some measure , premature . It could not be otherwise .

“ Do [you]92-mr. knightley dare say this ? ”[92-mr. knightley] cried [Mr. Knightley]92-mr. knightley . “ Do [you]92-mr. knightley dare to suppose [me]92-mr. knightley so great [a blockhead]5565-a blockhead , as not to know what [a man]2840-a man is talking of?--What do [you]92-mr. knightley deserve ? ”[92-mr. knightley]

“ Oh ! [I]123-emma always deserve the best treatment , because [I]123-emma never put up with any other ; and , therefore , [you]92-mr. knightley must give [me]123-emma a plain , direct answer . Are [you]92-mr. knightley quite sure that [you]92-mr. knightley understand the terms on which [Mr. Martin]116-mr. martin and [Harriet]111-harriet now are ? ”[123-emma]

“ [I]92-mr. knightley am quite sure , ”[92-mr. knightley] [he]92-mr. knightley replied , speaking very distinctly , “ that [he]116-mr. martin told [me]92-mr. knightley [she]111-harriet had accepted [him]116-mr. martin ; and that there was no obscurity , nothing doubtful , in the words [he]116-mr. martin used ; and [I]92-mr. knightley think [I]92-mr. knightley can give [you]92-mr. knightley a proof that it must be so . [He]116-mr. martin asked [my]92-mr. knightley opinion as to what [he]116-mr. martin was now to do . [He]116-mr. martin knew of [no one]3090-no one but [Mrs. Goddard]109-mrs. goddard to whom [he]116-mr. martin could apply for information of [[her]109-mrs. goddard relations]5568-her relations or [friends]579-friends .
